abstract: I fear that M. DE LA GUARRONIERE is about to be superseded in his post of pamphlet-writer in ordinary, for he seems to have a dangerous rival to dispute the laurels with him. This rival is the well-known M. ABOUT, who has just brought out a pamphlet with the ominous title of "L'Empereur Napoleon III et la Prusse." Opinions vary as to its merit.

abstract: The progress of arrangements for the reception of visitors to the Great Eastern, the time when she will be thrown open to inspection, and the price to be exacted for admission, are the principal topics which interest the public. As soon as the ship was fairly secured to her dock, and the passengers were out of the way, gangs or workmen were organized to clean, paint, varnish, and otherwise put the ship in order.
lead_paragraph: The progress of arrangements for the reception of visitors to the Great Eastern, the time when she will be thrown open to inspection, and the price to be exacted for admission, are the principal topics which interest the public. As soon as the ship was fairly secured to her dock, and the passengers were out of the way, gangs or workmen were organized to clean, paint, varnish, and otherwise put the ship in order. The five smoke-pipes, which were so unsightly upon her arrival, have been painted with a coat of cream color, and the topmasts are undergoing the scraping process, which greatly improves the appearance of the spars and top-hamper; the houses on deck are to be smoothed by sandpaper and varnished, which will give freshness to the mahogany in striking contrast with their blistered and sun-dried appearance when she arrived. The outside of the ship will be painted, the brass work scouted up, the engines polished off, the saloons swept and garnished, and everything put in the most inviting condition. The great extant of surface to be gone over, makes this renovating process necessarily a laborious one, one, it is feared, will not be finished at so early a day as has been announced -- Tuesday, the 3d of July. At a meeting of the directors, which took place on Saturday at the counting-room of Messrs. GRINNEIL, MINTURN & Co., that day was fixed upon for admission of visitors, and the price for tickets established at one dollar for adults, and "children under twelve years half price." An impression having gained ground that fifty cents would be the maximum charge, very general disappointment was expressed. The plan adopted in England, of setting apart particular days of the week for the sale of tickets at reduced rates, it is hoped may be adopted, and particularly that the Fourth of July may be thus set apart, when so many from the country will make the journey to New-York for the sole purpose of viewing the steamer. The announcement that a dollar will be charged, will deter thousands from coming, to whom fifty cents would be no objection. All these matters, however, were thoroughly discussed at the meeting. All persons are rigidly excluded, and necessarily so, until the paint is dry. It is stated that the approaches to the ship will be covered with coarse gravel, to prevent the dust from flying, clouds of which obscure the sight and damage the dilicate wardrobes of ladies who go upon the ground in a windy day.

abstract: Shortly before 12 o'clock on Saturday night two murders, as deliberately committed as the most shocking that have ever marked the criminal annals of the City, were perpetrated in Eighteenth-street near Third-avenue. The victims are Mr. JOHN WALTON, a well-known distiller, doing business in this City, and Mr. JOHN WARTS MATHEWS, a railroad contractor, who resided with his brother at No. 31 Union-place.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 12 o'clock on Saturday night two murders, as deliberately committed as the most shocking that have ever marked the criminal annals of the City, were perpetrated in Eighteenth-street near Third-avenue. The victims are Mr. JOHN WALTON, a well-known distiller, doing business in this City, and Mr. JOHN WARTS MATHEWS, a railroad contractor, who resided with his brother at No. 31 Union-place. Both of these gentlemen were strangers to each other, and Mr. MATHEWS was shot dead while attempting to secure the man who, a few moments before, had given the death-wound to Mr.WALTON. The following narrative of the affair, and the cir[???]stances which probably [???]ed to the double crime, was obtained from authentic sources. Mr, WALTON was a member of the firm of LONG & WALTON, distillers, having a store at Nos. 93 and 05 West Twenty-fifth-street, and a distillery in Eighteen-street, a short distance east of First-avenue. On account of unhappiness in his relations with his wife for some months past Mr. WILTON had lived in an upper apartment of the premises in which his store was located, and usually visited the distillery on Thursday and Saturday Rights. On the evening of his death, in company with his cousin, RICHARD H. PASCALL, who acted as his clerk, he-had been in the distillery and collected the day's receipts, and was returning up Eighteenth street on his way home. Near the corner of Third avenue, the attention of Mr. PASCALL and himself was attracted fey a man, dressed in light clothes and wearing a straw-hat,who leaned against a tree, but as no attack was anticipated, they passed close to him. Scarcely however, had they gone three steps beyond when the stranger stepped quickly up to Mr. WALTON and discharged a pistol at his head. The ball entered behind his left ear, and he sank to the pavement without uttering a word. PASCALL, whom the report of the pistol had somewhat stunned, upon recovering from his fright, called "Murder," and started in pursuit of the assassin, who had crossed the street, and was running in the direction of Irving place. A number of persons, among whom were two policemen, responded to the call for assistance, and joined in the chase of the murderer. Among them was Mr. MATTHEWS , who, with another man, had so far gained upon the fugitive as to have almost overtaken him by the time he had reached the corner of Sixteenth-street and Irving-place. At that point the man turned upon his pursuers and fired. Mr. MATTHEWS immediately fell, excialming, "I'm a dead man" having received the bail in his chest. The confusion occasioned by the occurrence diverted the attention of the crowd from the murderer for an instant, and afterwards do trace of his course was obtained. Mr. MATTHEWS was immediately removed to a drag-store at the corner of Sixteenth-street and Third avenue, but died in the arms of the men who were carrying him thither. Meantime Mr. WALTON had been taken to the druggist's at the corner of Eighteenth-street, where measures were adopted to restore him to consciousness. He never revived sufficiently to speak, however, and was taken thence to Be[???]rve Hospital. There lie lingered for several hours, perfectly insensible, and died early morning.

abstract: BOOLE seems to have carried into effect a modification of his roving Sanitary Commission. Not being able to secure a trip to Europe in the beginning of the season in company with "a savant," he has contented himself with a less exciting visit to Boston; but what he has lost in the length of the tour, he has gained in the number of the tourists.
lead_paragraph: BOOLE seems to have carried into effect a modification of his roving Sanitary Commission. Not being able to secure a trip to Europe in the beginning of the season in company with "a savant," he has contented himself with a less exciting visit to Boston; but what he has lost in the length of the tour, he has gained in the number of the tourists. The original Commission of Inquiry into the sanitary condition of all the most agreeable and interesting cities of the Old World was to consist of only one member from each Board of the Common Council -- the "savant" making the third. This arrangement was, however, not carried out, partly, we believe, because everybody else was just as anxious to investigate sanitary matters in Europe as were BOOLE and VAN TINE; partly because some difficulty was anticipated in finding a savant impecunous enough to consent to traveling in such company; partly because Mayor WOOD showed his teeth in advance; but mainly because the Japanese and the $30,000 just then began to loom up on the horizon. The idea was, however, not wholly abandoned. The health of the City could not be entirely neglected, and failing an inspection of European sinks, sewers and slums, it was determined that a monster deputation of more than twenty philosophers, seven from each branch of the Common Council, and seven from the Board of Health, should proceed to Boston to attend the meetings of the Sanitary Convention recently sitting in that city. We are not able at this moment to furnish the names of these devoted and learned persons, but we cannot be far wrong in presuming that BOOLE, BAGLEY, VAN TINK, FARLEY, or BARRY must have been among them -- names that would lend lustre to the meetings of any scientific body in the world. The Royal Academy of Sciences or the British Association itself, would be only too glad to hear BOOLE on numismatics and balls, BAGLEY on dynamics, and the resisting power of the nasal cartilage, VAN TINX on ethnology, BARRY on jurisprudence, the mixing of liquors and juvenile education, or TERENO[???] FARLEY on drainage and cesspools.

abstract: The lightning last night struck the house of JONATHAN B. GOODENOUGH, in Brighton, killing Mr. G. and his son, and seriously injuring Mrs. G. The force of the gale was terrific, uprooting large trees, demolishing chimneys, awnings, and doing other damage. Many sailing boats in the harbor were upset, and there are reports that several lives are lost, but those reports are not confirmed, though there were many narrow escapes.

abstract: A dispatch dated at Cagliari, June 12, says: "Two steamers, bearing the American flag, have entered the harbor this morning, having on board volunteers for Sicily.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch dated at Cagliari, June 12, says: "Two steamers, bearing the American flag, have entered the harbor this morning, having on board volunteers for Sicily. The Washington has 1,400 men, and the. Oregon between 300 and 460. With the exception of the American captain and an American artist, the vessels have had no communication with the shore. According to the statement of the Captain of the Oregon, these steamers are only awaiting the arrival of another, which has a large sailing vessel in tow, and have together 3,000 more volunteers. "GARIBALDI's Englishman" is on board the Washington. The ardor and zeal with which these men have taken up the cause of Sicily may be estimated by the privations to which they subject themselves."

abstract: The large marble store, for a year pass in process of erection, on the corner of Broadway and Prince-sheet, and designed for the occupation of the well-known firm of BALL, BLACK & Co., jewellers, is at length completed, and will be open to the public to-morrow. In elegance of design, thoroughness of construction, and architectural beauty, this building surpasses anything yet elected in this City, and as a structure for commercial purposes, it is doubtful whether it has its equal in the world. If "a thing of beauty is a joy forever," then the public of New-York are indebted to the munificence of Messrs. BALL, BLACK & Co., and the architectural ekill of Messrs. KELLUM & Son, for having furnished them with a perpetual enjoyment, and added another and a crowding glory to the many beautiful structures which combine to make Broadway the most splendid thoroughfare in the world.

abstract: We have called attention again and again to the shocking inadequacy of the means provided at our theatres for the easy egress of audiences in moments of peril or of panic, and to the obstinate disregard of decency and the laws which managers show in making these inadequate means more inadequate still by blocking up their aisles and passage-ways with seats, and admitting crowds of people to choke their lobbies, long after every legitimate place in the building has been filled.

abstract: Officers interested in learning the result of "the gun-boat experiment" in the United States Navy, have collected the different reports forwarded by Captains of that class of vessels now doing duty on foreign stations. The Narragansett and Wyoming in the Pacific, the Mohican on the African station, the Iroquo[???]s in the Mediterranean, and the Saginaw in China are described as baring pro red perfectly satisfactory, surpassing, in many cases, ships of a larger size in speed and usefulness. The Pawnee and Dacotah are also favorably reported of, so far as they can be judged at present; and, indeed, of all the gun-boats built for the navy, the Seminole, about to sail for Brazil, is the only one which does not seem to have answered the Department's expectations.

abstract: POLICE ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY.  The Police Captains have been instructed by a general order from Superintendent KENNEDY, to have every men of their respective commands on duty on the Fourth. The officers are cautioned to exercise forbearance, but to use prompt measures to prevent breaches of the peace. A reserve force is to be kept in each station-house to act as circumstances may require, either in its own or other precincts.
lead_paragraph: POLICE ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY. -- The Police Captains have been instructed by a general order from Superintendent KENNEDY, to have every men of their respective commands on duty on the Fourth. The officers are cautioned to exercise forbearance, but to use prompt measures to prevent breaches of the peace. A reserve force is to be kept in each station-house to act as circumstances may require, either in its own or other precincts. Dangerous fireworks, such as double-headers and snakes, are are proscribec, and the police are directed to arrest any person who may use them. At every point where there will be a public display of fireworks, a strong force will be stationed to preserve order, and for the same object a body of officers will accompany the procession. Anything of interest that may transpire during the day must be promgtly telegraphed to headquarters.

abstract: An aritcle from Sir JOHN BURGOYNE, who commanded the English engineers at Sebastopol, until he was snubbed and sent home for maintaining that the Malakoff was the key of the position, published in the Cornhill Magazine, upon the defence of London, has thrown the British public into a state of great excitement.
lead_paragraph: An aritcle from Sir JOHN BURGOYNE, who commanded the English engineers at Sebastopol, until he was snubbed and sent home for maintaining that the Malakoff was the key of the position, published in the Cornhill Magazine, upon the defence of London, has thrown the British public into a state of great excitement. He proposes to surround the city with a chain of earthworks of great strength, arm them heavily with rifled guns, and rely on the volunteers to man them. He asserts, and with truth, that this is the only way in which -- in the present state of military science -- a small and imperfectly disciplined force can reasonably expect to be able to stand their ground against a large and efficient one; that recent experience has proved that all that is needed to make well-constructed earthworks tenable for any reasonable length of time, is plenty of ammunition and plenty of pluck, requisites which the rifle volunteers can readily supply. The Arab Tabia, the redoubt at Salistria, which a small garrison held for two months in the last war against a Russian force of sixty thousand men, proves, even more conclusive than Sebastopol itself, that if the rear of such a work can be kept open, so that supplies and reinforcements can be regularly forwarded to the garrison, it is all but impregnable, as long as the defenders are determined to fight. The old rules, by which an engineer could deduce from the number of the garrison and extent of the works almost the exact number of days, of "open trenches," that would insure the fate of the place, entirely fail when applied to earthworks, for the simple reason that the opening of a breach is all but an impossibility, and without this an assault can be made with just as much chance of success, barring the demoralization of the garrison, on the first day as on the fortieth. No breach was ever effected in any work at Sebastopol, and the only reason why the Redan and Malakoff were not assaulted at the outset was, the desire to run the cover for the assaulting columns as close up to the works as possible. London fortified in the same manner, with Woolwich Arsenal to draw on for guns and ammunition, would furnish a r[???]llying point for the whole of the v[???]r force, and a retreat for the regular army, in case they were worsted in an encounter with the invader on the coast, against which two hundred thousand of the best troops in the world would have to make at least a long halt.

abstract: An inquest was held on Saturday afternoon by Coroner GAMBLE, at No. 21 lrving-place, upon the body of EUGRNE H. KELLY, a lad the years of age, son of JAMES KELLY, Esq., Receiver of Takes, who was run over by a Third-avenue Railroad Car, hear Fifteenth-street. On Saturday Morning. It appeared from the te[???]mony that c[???]ea[???]ed was playing with another boy, who offen[???]d him in some manner, and he went to a dirt heap along side the track and obtained a stone to throw at his companion. Just at that moment a car came along the lad attempted to get out of its way by passing before the horses. In doing so he fell, and the car passed over him, killing h[???] almost instantly. The car was going very slowly at the time, and the accident would seem to have been unavoidable. The jury rendered a verdict in acc[???]rcance with the facts, but not withstanding that no want of care was shown on the part of the driver, attached to it following advice; "while they find no disposition to attribute neglect to the company, they cannot forbear the suggestion, that prudent and careful drivers should hereafter in all cases be selcected.

abstract: The steam saw-mill of Mr. GEORGE TURGOT, in Eighteenth street, near Avenue A, was totally des[???]yed on Saturday evening. The fire is supposed to Lave been caused by friction of the machinery, and it extended to BURROUGHS & BANE's staircase factory, on the year of the adjoining lot, and thence to the carriage house and stables in front, owned by J.J. VAN PELT. Mr. TURGOT's loss about $12,000; insured for $8,000. Mr. VAN PELT's loss on building and stock is estimated at $13,000 -- About 8 o'clock on the same evening, the times upper stories of The building No, 49 Broadway were bu[???]t through. The top floor was occupied by Mr. GORGE, dealer in four; loss $2,000. The two next below by FRANK & SON, cap manufacturers; loss $8,000. C. WATSON, dealers in hats and hatters goods, kept the first floor and basement. His stock was damaged by water to the extent of $10,00. The building can scarcely be repaired short of $6,000. It, as well as the stock it contained, are said to have been insured.  MARTIN BATES & SON, dealers goods, at No. 51 adjoining, suffered some damage to their stock by water. In returning from the fire the members of NOS. 14 and 20 engine companies engaged in a riot at the corner of Liberty-street. Bricks were thrown and pistols discharged, but the disgraceful scene was stooped by the police before mate[???] injury had been inflicted by the combatants -- Soon alter the occurrence of the Broadway fire, another happened at No. 67 Liberty street, in the second floor on the premises of CHARLES R. DUXBURY, whose loss will reach $2,000: insured. T.M. T[???]us & Co., dealers in Yankee notions, in the same building, had his stock damaged about 9000: insured. BERNARD MARTIN, occupant of the upper part of the building, sustained a loss of $1,500; insured. MACY & JENEIOS, libuor and winedealers, en the first floor and basement, suffered about $500 damage; insured. G. LEWIS, [???]., owns the building. It was not materially damaged, and is insured.

abstract: What might have been expected has come to pass. M. MOCQUARD has set all inspired quills into motion, in order to persuade the Foreign Powers and the Germans that LOUIS NAPOLEON had succeeded in duping the Prince Regent of Prussia, and causing him, against the interest of his country, to enter into an alliance with Russia and the "Second December."
lead_paragraph: What might have been expected has come to pass. M. MOCQUARD has set all inspired quills into motion, in order to persuade the Foreign Powers and the Germans that LOUIS NAPOLEON had succeeded in duping the Prince Regent of Prussia, and causing him, against the interest of his country, to enter into an alliance with Russia and the "Second December." Happily this calumny is too fross, and this miserable intrigue too apparent, as to warrant a fear that it might lead the Foreign Powers to believe the Prince had already forgotten the words spoken by him on the 23d May, before the assembled representatives of his country. The Prince has no more desire ef forming an alliance with LOUIS NAPOLEON than to aggrandize Prussia at the expense of the other German States. We doubt not but the German Princesin Baden-Baden will receive numerous solemn assurances, which -- although not so solemn as the promise LOUIS NAPOLEON made to LOUIS PHILIPPE after his farce of Strasbourg, or the oath which he swore to 1he French people, or the Treaties of Viliafranca and Zurich -- will still fee solemn enough to lead Germans astray, if they should forget how the well-known, phrase, "L' Empire c'est la paix," has been put into practice during the last eight years. Did not LOUIS NAPOLEON solemnly declare France was fighting in Italy for an idea? This idea, as everyone knows, was Savoy and Nice. Did he not solemnly declare, nothing but Austria's invasion of Piedmont had forced him to declare in favor of Piedmont? and is it not a fact, that even at Plombieres a contract had already been made with VICTOR ENANUEL, in regard to the annexations om Italy, since which Count CAYOUR systematically continued to provoke Austria until shelo[???]t her petience?

abstract: The Catholic Archbishop of New-York, having recently distinguished himself by an offer to die on the scaffold rather than register the names of the couples he married, has now come forward to explain to his faithful people how divine a thing is the right of Popes to govern wrong and to beg the money of American citizens for the support of a Government which has filled its prisons with political captives, makes the sale of the Scriptures a felony, and hires foreign mercenaries to compel with the bayonet the love, and fidelity of the subjects committed to its care, as the Archbishop would have us believe, by the same God who moved the Christians in the early times of our faith to make each other partners in their worldly goods.

abstract: At 1 1/2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon the huge propeller of the United States steamship Niagara began to revolve, and, amid salutes from all quarters, the noble vessel started on her mission, conveying the Japanese Embassy to their native country. abstract: Prof. JAMES RENWICK'S idea of a Park for New-York, as developed before the Senatorial Committee on Friday, is a number of roads, thirty feet wide fifteen feet in the centre macadamized with borders of native mud and dust running through a vast extent of swamp and wood, such as the ground now covered by the Central Park was before the year 1857.
lead_paragraph: Prof. JAMES RENWICK's idea of a Park for New-York, as developed before the Senatorial Committee on Friday, is a number of roads, thirty feet wide -- fifteen feet in the centre macadamized -- with borders of native mud and dust -- running through a vast extent of swamp and wood, such as the ground now covered by the Central Park was before the year 1857. The Professor would neither have drained it planted it, no[???] made a lake in it. He would have resorted to no artificial ornamention, and it is not even quite clear that he would have demanded the removal of the pigstyes and shanties. Here is a report of his own statement:

abstract: The steamship Adriatic, from Havre and Southampton, with European advices to the 20th of June, arrived at this port on Saturday, and the Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 20th and Londonderry on the 21st, has arrived at Quebec, with telegraphic advices to the latter date. No movement of special importance had taken place in Sicily.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Adriatic, from Havre and Southampton, with European advices to the 20th of June, arrived at this port on Saturday, and the Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 20th and Londonderry on the 21st, has arrived at Quebec, with telegraphic advices to the latter date. No movement of special importance had taken place in Sicily. "The Washington of Sicily," as the English Press are pleased to term GARIBALDI, was said to be organizing his forces for an effort on the main land; but this is probably a mistake, unless his resources of men and means are greater than [???] present appear. The conscription to swell his forces had been ordered by decree for the 18th of June, and on the 20th the conscripts were to take their departure for Catania and Palermo. The rumor, which reached us by a provious arrival that a number of GARIBALDI'S troops had dismbarked in calabria is pronounced to be untruc. The capture of the two steamers, with 800 passengers, by the Neapolitan frigate Fullminantc, is likely to cause the Government of FRANCIS II. Some trouble, as the Sardinian Minister had demanded their restitution and the release of the passengers, who had passports for Malta. In this demand the Sardinian Minister was supported by the English Ambassador. One of the captured steamers is stated to have displayed American colors. The conference of Sovereilgnsat Baden-Baden closed on the 17th and its results aare said to be eninently satisfactory. Both the French and the Prussian journals declaare that the pleaace of Europe is now consolidated and insured. The civil war in Turky up to last accounts still continued. Thirty-six villaages at Mount Lebanon are stated to have been burnt by the Druses, who have been the victors. The Turkish authorilties have not interfered, and the soldicrs who had been sent to protect the chrilstians had joined the Druses and partilcilplatedi ln the massacre. There is nothing of interest from other points. No change of importance had occurredd in money affairs. Consols were quoted at 93 1/2 @ 93$ fo;r account, ex divildend. Cotton had improved in demand.

abstract: Hartt ct al. vs. White et al. -- This was a motion in this case for an order compelling the defendants to put in a more specific return to the mandamus, or to show cause why the return should not be quashed and a peremptory mandamus issue. The motion was argued before Justice INGRAHAM at Chambers. The position was taken by defendants' counsel, that there was no such motion known to the practice. Counsel for plaintiffs cited authorities showing that there were instances of such motions, and that they were common. Decision reserved.

abstract: The Committee of the Common Council, to whom is intrusted an appropriation of $7,000 for duly celebrating "the Fourth," held a meeting on Saturday, at which Jackson square was added to the places designated for the exhibition of the municipal fireworks, and $75 were set apart to furnish a pyrotechnic display on Randall's Island.

abstract: The attention of Serjeant Jourdan, of the Sixth Precinct was attracted between 6 and 7 o'clock on Saturday evening to the movements of three young men, whom he saw enter the building No. 368 Broadway, occupied by various importers and dealers in dry goods. In a short time one of the individuals left the premises are entered a stage, having "with him piece of velvet which had been en stolen from the premises of Mr, Sulzbacher, one of the occupants, Jourdan immediately dragged the man out of the venire, and while so engaged, observed his two accomplices come out of the building -- one having a bundle, which on examination proved to contain thirty mantillas, and the other a small black black trunk. At [???]i[???]ht of their confederate in custody, both ran away, he of the mantillas leaving his bundle to facilitate his flight. The prisoner strunggled hard with Jourdan to escape, but finding his efforts useless, offered a bribe of $200 to obtain his liberty.  The officer, however, took him to the Station-house, where he was searched, and four lock picks, be side a valuable gold watch and chain, were found in his possession. He was afterwards examined before Justice WELSSH, to whom he gave the name of George Leonard, and said that he boarded at the Brandreth House. An examination of the premises in Broadway showed that Sulzbacher's place had been entered by picking the lock, and that the adjoining store of Myer Rosenthal, from which the mantillas and trunk had been taken, was opened by blearing a pane of glass in the door, which admitted the drawing of the belt which secured it. The magistrate held Leonard, in spite of his protestations of innocence, to answer for both burglaries in tae sum of $200 in each complaint. All the property, excepting the trunk, which contained some cheap clothing, was recovered

abstract: Observatory, the well-Known mathematician, communicates to the Boston Advertiser the following parabolic elements of the comet. It appears from them that its future course through the evening sky will be very much the same as that of the celebrated comet of DONATI. The new visitor is somewhat remarkable for its near approach to the sun, when in perihelion, on the 15th inst, being less than twenty-seven millions of miles. As the elements have no resemblance to those of any recorded comet, it may be concluded that it has never before been observed :

abstract: The refusal of Commodore VANDERBILT to carry the California mails for the postages, and the failure of Congrees to provide for the termination of Mr. VANDERBILT'S provisional contract, has occasioned considerable inconvenience to our merchants in the California trade, and others desiring to maintain cor- respondence with the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: The refusal of Commodore VANDERBILT to carry the California mails for the postages, and the failure of Congrees to provide for the termination of Mr. VANDERBILT'S provisional contract, has occasioned considerable inconvenience to our merchants in the California trade, and others desiring to maintain cor- respondence with the Golden State. It is true that the establishment of the Overland mail has enabled the merchants and other citizens of the West to be entirely independent of the Atlantic mails; but, the distance between the seaboard and the termini of the Overland Mall at Memphis and St. Louts, precludes the possibility of making so quick time between California and the Eastern States as can be made by sea. The contract time of the Overland Mall is twenty-five days, and letters are often thirty days in reaching New-York by the Overland route, while the average trips of the steamers are made in about twenty-two days. Eastern merchants, therefore, how-ever much they may dislike steamship monopolies, prefer to send their letters in 22 days rather than in 30, The stoppage of the steamship mall is a matter of great importance to them, and accounts for the consternation created by the announcement that the Arul which sailed yesterday could not carry a mall. The purser and other officers of the ship were overrun with applications to take "just this one letter" through for a friend, but they were inexorable and all applicants were referred to the office of the agent. At the office, scenes like the following were of momentary occurrence: Gent rushes in with a huge envelope in his hand, and in breathless haste asks

abstract: CITY MARSHAL'S MONTHLY REPORT There were committed to the City Prison, during the month of June, 174 prisoners, for the following offences: Drunkennees 101, threatening life 1, stealing 15, assault and battery 28, insane 2, violating city ordinance 2, grand larceny 1, incendiary 2, vagrancy 3, burglary 2, rioting 2, malicious mischief 1. Nativity: Ireland 114, United States 28, England 8, Scotland 11, Hungary 1, Germany 9, Wales 1, France 1, Colored 3 total 174.
lead_paragraph: CITY MARSHAL'S MONTHLY REPORT. -- There were committed to the City Prison, during the month of June, 174 prisoners, for the following offences: Drunkennees 101, threatening life 1, stealing 15, assault and battery 28, insane 2, violating city ordinance 2, grand larceny 1, incendiary 2, vagrancy 3, burglary 2, rioting 2, malicious mischief 1. abstract: To-day will witness the first regular attempt to throw open the Great Eastern to the inspection of the public. The anxiety to hare her in readiness for the Fourth of July, in order to secure the visits of the masses on the great American holiday, has left too little time for putting the ship in that perfect condition which was desirable; but considering the great amount of labor bestowed on the ship, occupying day and night since she arrived, and the expedition with which it has been accomplished, little will be left to find fault with. The public will be more occupied with the ship -- her vast proportions, her model, engines, paddle-wheels and screw; her length, breadth and depth, her colossal from masts, chains and anchors, and her splendid saloons, than with the color or quantity of the paint and varnish which cover them. The moorings of the ship were completed yesterday, one of her seven-ton anchors being carried two hundred feet into the stream and dropped. Attached to this is one of the largest chain cables, which will be hove ta[???]t at the bow. Another anchor and chain, of the same dimensions, will constitute the after moorings on the offshore side. There being no spiles of adequate strength on the dock to hold the giant ship in the event of a sudden squall, two stream anchors, of one third, the size of the others, have been planted firmly in the earth, to which chains have been attached from the bow and stern. These precautions were deemed necessary on account of the great surface which the ship presents to the wind. The entrance for visitors will be through a large open port in the after half of the ship, equidistant from the paddle box and the stern. A firm stage, with railings, has been constructed at this place, and similar platforms for the egress of the multitude. Each visitor will be registered by a patent apparatus used at the exhibition in England. The ticket-offices have been put up, and by strenuous exertions, the shin will he ready to day, the hours of admission being from 9 o'clock A.M. to 6 o'clock P.M. A refreshment saloon has been opened near the after part of the ship, on the upper deck, for the accommodation of the hungry and thirsty multitude.

abstract: INCENDIARY AND OTHER FIRES. -- Seven or eight barns have been set on fight and destroyed with their contents, at Hudson City and vicinity, within the last few days. The loss is considerable. A boy named CROSSMAN has been arrested at Catskill on suspicion of having set them on fire. On Thursday a fire broke out in the drug-store of Mr. FOWLEK at Newburgh, caused by the igniting of a kettle of boiling oil. Loss $500. The store and Post-office at Stormville, Dutchess County, were also destroyed a few days since. The origin of the fire is unknown. The building was occupied by Mr. W. KELLY. Another fire also occurred at New-Paltz, Ulster County, and $800 worth of damage was done. No insurance.

abstract: The Louisville Democrat of the 27th, groups together a murder, a shooting affray, and a fatal acci- dent, which occurred in that City on the preceding day.
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Democrat of the 27th, groups together a murder, a shooting affray, and a fatal acci- dent, which occurred in that City on the preceding day. The murder was perpetrated at Randolph Station on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. One GOSSETT, was so offended by the request of an inoffensive old man, DAVIS by name, to lend him his pipe, that he seized an axe, and with one stroke sank it to the helve in the forehead of DAVIS. Another blow fell on the back of his bead, and the brains oozed out. Another blow cut off one of DAVIS' ears, and still another laid his eye open. Perhaps the diabolical ruffian would have continued his fiendish work, but Mr. FRANCE, a wood contractor, arrested him, took from him his weapons and secured him. Mr. FRANCE left him in charge of some of the men while he went to see his wife, and during his absence the men foolishly set GOSSETT at liberty. The villain then became so dangerous that the men were compelled to hide from him, fearing lest he should attack them. Matters remained in this condition until Mr. FRANCE came to Louisville late Saturday night to lodge the proper information with the Sheriff for GOSSETT'S arrest. DAVIS was alive when he left, but was evidently rapidly dying. GOSSETT during the evening was about the house where his victim lay dying, fierce to get to him, swearing that he would cut off his head. On Mr. FRANCE making application to the Sheriff for assistance to make the arrest, that official declined, on the ground that his Deputy had charge of that district.

abstract: Mayor Wood has not withdrawn his objections to the work of laying a new four-foot iron main across High Bridge, but the Croton Board have awarded the contract for the boiler plate and flange iron to Horace Abbott, of Baltimore, Md., who was the lowest bidder for that portion of the job, the bids for which, it will be recollected, were opened on the 2d of June. They were then laid over for consideration. The Board have since concluded to receive bids on and make awards of the contracts necessary to be entered into, and without awaiting further action of the Mayor, send the awards to the Common Council. If the Aldermen and Councilmen confirm the awards, work will be at once begun under the contracts.

They were then laid over for consideration. The Board have since concluded to receive bids on and make awards of the contracts necessary to be entered into, and without awaiting further action of the Mayor, send the awards to the Common Council. If the Aldermen and Councilmen confirm the awards, work will be at once begun under the contracts.

abstract: ORDINATION AT TRINITY CHURCH. -- The interesting ceremony of ordaining twelve young men to the Diaconate was performed on Sunday morning at Trinity Church, in the presence of a large congregation. The Right Rev. Bishops of New-Hampshire, Western New-York and New-Jersey were present. The usual order of morning prayer was read by Rev. Drs.VINTON and OGILBY. The Venite, Gregorian tone 8, the fifth section of the Psalter, the Te Deum and B[???]edictus (CUTLER in E) and the Anthem (HANDEL) taken from the fifty-seventh chapter of Isaiah, " How beautiful are the feet of them that preach to us the Gospel of peace," were chanted by the Choristers, Mr. CUTLER presiding at the organ. After the reading of the prayers, the venerable Bishop (CHASE,) of N. H., ascended the pulpit and preached an excellent discourse, appropriate to the occasion, from the text, 2d Cor., 5th chap., 8th v.: "And had given unto us the ministry of reconciliation." At the close of the sermon, the candidates for ordination, who are all recent graduates of the General Theological Seminary,were presented to the Bishops in form by Rev. Dr. JOHNSON, Dean of the Seminary. After the usual questions and answers set forth in the Book of Common Prayer had been asked by the Bishop (ODENBEIMER.) of New-Jersey, and answered by the candidates, Bishop CHASE laid his hands on the heads of six of them, and gave them authority to minister in the Church in the name of the Trinity. He was followed by the Bishop (DE LANCEY) of W. New-York, who ordained three of the candidates in like manner, and the Bishop of New-Jersey laid his hands upon three. A copy of the New Testament was then given into the hands of each of them by the Bishop who ordained them, with authority to preach the Gospel. The administration of the Holy Communion, singing of the 102d Hymn, and the Benediction closed the solemn and impressive services.
lead_paragraph: ORDINATION AT TRINITY CHURCH. -- The interesting ceremony of ordaining twelve young men to the Diaconate was performed on Sunday morning at Trinity Church, in the presence of a large congregation. The Right Rev. Bishops of New-Hampshire, Western New-York and New-Jersey were present. The usual order of morning prayer was read by Rev. Drs.VINTON and OGILBY. The Venite, Gregorian tone 8, the fifth section of the Psalter, the Te Deum and B[???]edictus (CUTLER in E) and the Anthem (HANDEL) taken from the fifty-seventh chapter of Isaiah, " How beautiful are the feet of them that preach to us the Gospel of peace," were chanted by the Choristers, Mr. CUTLER presiding at the organ. After the reading of the prayers, the venerable Bishop (CHASE,) of N. H., ascended the pulpit and preached an excellent discourse, appropriate to the occasion, from the text, 2d Cor., 5th chap., 8th v.: "And had given unto us the ministry of reconciliation." At the close of the sermon, the candidates for ordination, who are all recent graduates of the General Theological Seminary,were presented to the Bishops in form by Rev. Dr. JOHNSON, Dean of the Seminary. After the usual questions and answers set forth in the Book of Common Prayer had been asked by the Bishop (ODENBEIMER.) of New-Jersey, and answered by the candidates, Bishop CHASE laid his hands on the heads of six of them, and gave them authority to minister in the Church in the name of the Trinity. He was followed by the Bishop (DE LANCEY) of W. New-York, who ordained three of the candidates in like manner, and the Bishop of New-Jersey laid his hands upon three. abstract: The Seventeenth Annual Exhibition of the Mount Washington Collegiate Institute took place in Hope Chapel on Thursday evening, In presence of a large number of relatives of the students and friends of the Institution. The programme, which was of the usual kind, was performed in a manner to elicit well-merited applause and reflect credit upon the Institute. The following is a list of the graduates for 1860: James H. Benson, Charles J. Bhven, Nehemiah Brown, Jr,, George H. Hillyer, Ira A. Kip, J. H. Mahony, Jr., J. Parmly, Jr., Henry W. Poor, Henry B. Starr. Jas. H. Stopford, Henry L. Townsend, Seymour Van Nostrand.

abstract: The community was profoundly shocked, yesterday, by the information of the deliberate mur- der of Mr. JOHN WALTON, in Eighteenth-street, on Saturday night, coupled as it was with the death of Mr. JOHN W. MATHEWS, as estimable citizen, whose life was taken by the hand of the same assassin, to whom he was unknown, and who, consequently, could have borne him no-malice.
lead_paragraph: The community was profoundly shocked, yesterday, by the information of the deliberate mur- der of Mr. JOHN WALTON, in Eighteenth-street, on Saturday night, coupled as it was with the death of Mr. JOHN W. MATHEWS, as estimable citizen, whose life was taken by the hand of the same assassin, to whom he was unknown, and who, consequently, could have borne him no-malice. From an early hour of the morning, until darkness concealed the bloodstains on the sidewalks, which told of the fearful tragedy, the points when the victims fell were visited by a vast number of persons, among whoa were a class which, under circumstances of less peculliar interest, would hare felt no curiosity to look upon the scene of the crime.

abstract: On Friday evening the Board of Police Magistrates met in the room of the Clerk of Special Sessions, at the Tombs, and consulted upon various matters connected with the business of the Police Courts. The Committee on Correspondence to whom had been referred a communication from the District Attorney, requesting that the complaints in all criminal cases should be sent to his office once a week instead of once a month as has been the custom, made a report. They stated that the law made it incumbent upon the magistrates to send the papers in criminal cases to the proper Court at the term following the finding of the complaints, and as the terms commence on the first Monday of each month, it was the duty of the magistrates to make their returns on that day. They recommended, however, that the Justices facilitate the business of the District Attorney by every means in their power, and advised application to the Legislature to so modify the law that the magistrates may comply with the District Attorney's request. The report was adopted, and a copy of it was ordered to be sent to the District Attorney. The Superintendent of the Work-house sent a communication expressive of the good results of the recently adopted rule of sending drunkards to the Workhouse instead of confining them in the Tombs. They now, instead of passing the term of their confinement in idleness, were made to work, and their services were of value at the Island. He recommended the magistrates to commit habitual drunkards for a longer time than ten days, if they had the power, as, by such a course, the community at large, as well as the prisoners, would be benefited. Under the present system, a large proportion of the number imprisoned for drunkenness are released, to return to their evil ways, and in a few days are brought back again. The communication was referred. A resolution was adopted, calling upon the City Inspector to substantiate a charge made in his recent report, to the effect that the magistrates invariably discharged all persons brought before them for throwing garbage in the streets. They deny the impeachment, and state that in the course of a year scarcely a dozen persons are complained of for the offence, but in every case where the charge is substantiated, the prescribed fine has been imposed. It was decided hereafter to open the Police Courts on Sunday morning at 8 A.M., and close at 12 M. The Clerk was directed to inform the Police Commissioners of the new arrangement.

abstract: The usual exercises of Class-day were celebrated yesterday before a large audience. NATHANIEL MIGHILL, of Rowley, gave an oration, and J.W. WARD, jr., of Madison, Wisconsin, a poem. The theme of the oration was the "Individualism of Man." It was gracefully, eloquently and thoroughly handled, as was testified to by an appreciative audience.

abstract: This monarch of the ocean is to be opened to-day to the public. Naturally enough there is a very wide and laudable curiosity to see her, and thousands will eagerly embrace the opportunity now afforded. The Directors, doubtless after due consideration, have decided to charge a dollar for admission. We have neither the right nor the inclination to volunteer any advice on the subject. The enterprise has our best wishes for its success, and we only hope that the experiment by which the managers of the great steamer have resolved to test the curiosity and liberality of the American public, may have a satisfactory result.

abstract: The Washington Constitution, the mouthpiece of the expiring Administration, is, it is said, about to pass into the hands of the Breckinridge and Lane section of the Democracy, as their "organ," and the managers are now searching for somebody to edit it, during the campaign at least, if not longer.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Constitution, the mouthpiece of the expiring Administration, is, it is said, about to pass into the hands of the Breckinridge and Lane section of the Democracy, as their "organ," and the managers are now searching for somebody to edit it, during the campaign at least, if not longer. With every disposition to avoid everything which may wear the appearance of impertinent meddling, we cannot help earnestly advising all whom it may concern not to invest much money in the enterprise -- as we are firmly persuaded that there is no way, short of flinging it into the Potomac, in which money can be laid out with less advantage to the party.

abstract: The clouds that have hovered over us like Fall, Pouring out rain almost incessantly for nearly two months, have at last cleared away, and the sun, so long shut out from view so that we had almost forgotten how it looked, is shining to-day in all its glory, and all nature seems gladdened as the genial rays fall upon tree and flower, opening bud and bursting germ.

abstract: The July term of this Court commenced yesterday. The Grand Jury were ordered to attend on Thursday, the Grand Inquest of the Oyer and Terminer being still impanneled. Judge RUSSELL, who occupies the bench this term, will only try prison cases, and will close the session probably at the end of the week. Three weeks is the regular period for work in this Court, and considering the crowded state of the City Prison during this hot weather, it would not be unsatisfactory if the City Judge would fully attend to his duties.

abstract: SAMUEL COHEN,on boy 2 years of age, was run over on Sunday afternoon in Chatham street by hack No. 268, causing a fracture of the skull, from the effects of which he soon died. The occurrence appeared to be accidental, but the driver of the vehicle, who has not been arrested, was censured by the Coroner's Jury for driving recklessly on without stopping to ascertain how badly the child had been injured ...... On Saturday night a fluid lamp explodedat No. 210 West Thirty-ninth-street, and caused the death of CATHARINE PETRE, a child about 2 years of age..... THOMAS CLINE, a lad 10 years of age, whose parent reside at No. 215 East Thirty-fifth street on Sunday evening, and was drowned... ALBERT CARR, a boy about 8 years of ago, who had been missing since Saturday from his father's house, No. 489 Canal-street, was found drowned yesterday at the foot of Spring-street, N.R.

abstract: The public may have seen with some surprise, notices of a recent meeting of the Stockholders of the American Telegraph Company, called to act upon a threatened quarrel with the Newspaper Press.
lead_paragraph: The public may have seen with some surprise, notices of a recent meeting of the Stockholders of the American Telegraph Company, called to act upon a threatened quarrel with the Newspaper Press. The session ended in the appointment for a Committee to consult representatives of the Press on the subject of a scale of prices of Telegraphic Dispatches, and to make such an arrangement as may seem essentially just and mutually advantageous. It would be a great mistake, however, to suppose that the differences in question relate merely to the prices charged for Telegraphic service. They go much farther than this, and are the natural result of permitting the Telegraph to become a close monopoly, under the control of men who neither understand nor respect the age in which they live.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS THE PRICE OF PRO- VISIONS COUNTY BONDS. An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, but contrary to general expectation, no decisive action was taken on the report to locate the new County Court-house. After the disposal of some routine business, the Penitentiary Committee submitted a report in favor of giving the contracts for supplying the Penitentiary with the different articles required to James Carman, E.B.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS -- THE PRICE OF PROVISIONS -- COUNTY BONDS. -- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, but contrary to general expectation, no decisive action was taken on the report to locate the new County Court-house. After the disposal of some routine business, the Penitentiary Committee submitted a report in favor of giving the contracts for supplying the Penitentiary with the different articles required to James Carman, E.B. Morell, Wm. Lynch and Kelsey & McLaughlin. The following are the rates: Fresh beef, 39-10c. per pound; white Indian Meal, 1 6-10c. do.; yellow meal, 1 4-10c. do.; ship stuff, 1 Cent: best quality family Wheat flour, 6 cents; straw, 6-10c.; salt beef, 3c ; salt pork, 5 1/2 c.; Cuba molasses, 20 cents per gallon; fine Liverpool salt, 40 cents per bushel; rice, 2 1/2 cents per pound; white beans, 90 cents per bushel; pure coffee, 8 cents per pound; ground pepper, 10 do.; mustard, 16 do.; saturates, 5 1/2 do.; codfish, 2 1/2 do.; potatoes, 40 cents per bushel; hard soap, 4 cents per pound; soft soap, 55 cents par barrel; vinegar, $2 25 per barrel; camphens, 45 cents per gallons burning fluid. 45 cents do.; Le high coal $4 59 per ton; pine wood, $7 36 per cord ; eak wood, $5 03 per cord, and other articles at equally low prices. The report was adopted. A communication was received from the County Treasurer, transmitting an account of the county bonds outstanding, as follows:

abstract: Important advices reach us from Mexico, through the arrival of the steamer Arizona at New-Orleans, from Brazos. Private letters from Monterey, authenticated by statements of a similar tenor from Matamoras, state that Gen. ZARAGOZA, commanding the Liberal forces, had defeated Miramon and taken, him prisoner, near Salamanca. A division of MIRAMON's troops, under Gen. RAMIRE[???], had also been defeated by ORTEGA. The locality of the latter engagement is not given. In the States of Nueva Leon, Coahuila, and elsewhere, efforts were being made to further the return of COMONFORT to power.

abstract: Tammany Hall was very well filled, last evening, by those who desired to respond favorably to the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS for the Presidency, and Mr. JOHNSON for the Vice-Presidency.
lead_paragraph: Tammany Hall was very well filled, last evening, by those who desired to respond favorably to the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS for the Presidency, and Mr. JOHNSON for the Vice-Presidency. There was also quite a large meeting outside, in front of the TIMES Building. But neither in the Hall nor in the Square was there an old-fashioned Democratic jam. The management accounted for it by saying that a large number of those who had intended to be present had gone up to the Fifth-avenue Hotel, where Mr. Douglas was to be serenaded, in order to obtain a good position for hearing his speech. Nevertheless, the meetings were large, and the enthusiasm great. During the meeting considerable excitement "was occasioned by the entrance of the Empire Club, headed by JAMES lRVING, and accompanied by a brass band. From the commencement of the proceedings to their close there was no opposition feeling shown worthy of note -- nor were the speakers interrupted as often as used to be the custom of Democratic audiences when gathered in Tammany Hall. Inside the Hail, when the hour for organizing had arrived,

abstract: This institution is situated near the village of Nyack, on the west bank of the Hudson, about 30 miles above New-York. The closing exercises of the Spring term took place on Thursday evening last.
lead_paragraph: This institution is situated near the village of Nyack, on the west bank of the Hudson, about 30 miles above New-York. The closing exercises of the Spring term took place on Thursday evening last. To those who have been present on former similar occasions, it was exceedingly gratifying to notice the very marked and evident progress which the scholars of the institution are making. It indicated unmistakably that the course of the mental discipline pursued by their teachers is peculiarly adapted to develop thoroughly and systematically all the faculties of the mind, and not merely to fasten upon the memory a series of facts, or to cultivate a showy display of superficial "accomplishments;" while the bloom of health which appeared on every cheek told us that there had been no over-taxing of the mind.

abstract: --A wild child is roaming through the forests of Iowa, and exciting much discussion among the primitive naturalists of that section of the country. The nearest approach that has been made to its capture was to find the place where it had slept, and the remains of a frog, whereon it had supped. This latter fact seems very clearly to indicate a French parentage for the young Orson. He probably resembles a canard.

abstract: Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, vulgarly known as the "Commodore," having slapped the faces of the citizens of New-York for years with impunity, if not with positive applause, having amassed a colossal fortune by the ruin of innumerable competitors, and achieved a wide-spread reputation by a constant affectation of sympathy with the class from which and upon which he has risen to his present position, has at last made up his mind that he may safely undertake to deal with States as he has long dealt with individuals, and that he may soar from the monopoly of inland ferries and coasting routes to an open despotism over the highway of nations. We are a little curious to see in what way the patient community of New-York and the submissive Government of the United States will receive this latest and loftiest flight of the great commercial vampire which they have fostered and fed so long. Yesterday morning a number of packages containing newspapers and letters were sent down by various parties in this City, to be carried on board a steamship belonging to him, and advertised to sail for Panama. By the orders of the owner, the officers in charge of this vessel refused positively to receive those packages on any terms and under any pretext, and they were accordingly sent back. The immediate object of this proceeding was not so much, perhaps, to inflict loss and injury upon the individuals directly concerned -- though it is but fair to say that from the past history of the chief actor, it is quite reasonable to conclude that no opportunity of disturbing or damaging any man's business ever finds him indifferent -- as to put a constraint upon the American Government, which should crush that body into accepting Mr. VANDERBILT, at his own terms, as the sole mail-carrier between the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of our empire. The immediate effect, however, of the step, is, unhappily, not a matter of speculation. It cuts off at one blow every nerve of commerce, and of intercourse between the American people of the Atlantic and their brethren of the Pacific. It interrupts the natural course of mercantile exchanges for a period which, in this day of swift and impatient negotiations, may, indeed, must prove, long enough to embarrass hundreds of firms and to ruin many bright hopes. Men do not deliberate over commercial transactions in this age and country as they did in the Holland of our ancestors. The success or failure of great enterprises has now become, in myriads of instances, a mere question of time; and there exists no Government so despotic that it is not bestirring itself to recognize and act upon the vital importance to the welfare of the State of speed and certainty in the transmission of the public mails. Even in moments of anarchy disturbers of the public peace who spare nothing else spare the mails which hold society together. The first act of the French Republicans of 1848 was to secure the regular departure of all the mail coaches from Paris, even before the provisional authorities had fairly learned who they were and what had happened. Other considerations than those of commerce, too, have made all civilized nations agree in punishing the mail-robber with the like exceptional severity that was meted out in the times before MACADAM to the horse-thief. The man who wilfully arrests the tarnsmission of a single public mail deliberately risks inflicting upon an indefinite number of his fellow-creatures all the keenest mental tortures and the most perilous moral suffering which human nature can endure. He puts himself between the dying and their friends, between the mother and her children, between the sinner and his repentance, between the prodigal and his pardon, between the home which deems itself ruined, and the word of hope which might restore it to itself and to the world. Whenever such a deed as this is done on any scale large enough to challenge the attention of society at large, every man's own experience flashes upon him a sudden and appalling sense of the unmeasured miseries which must follow it. A few years ago, when TUCKERMAN, for the sake of providing himself with the means of carrying on his own business systematically, intercepted the mails between Boston and New-York, was discovered, arrested and sentenced to an imprisonment of twenty years, everybody felt that the punishment could bear no assignable proportion to the enormity of the mischief which the criminal had done.

abstract: Will of James Lally. -- The will of James Lally, which has been before the Surrogate on an application for probate, has been rejected. The peculiarity of this case is that the will was duly signed and published the testator in the presence of two witnesses who were requested to witness it, but did not subscribe their names until a few moments after the testator's death. Although every requirement of the statute was complied with by the testator, it was held that the instrument was incomplete at the time of his death, and could not be admitted to probate.
lead_paragraph: Will of James Lally. -- The will of James Lally, which has been before the Surrogate on an application for probate, has been rejected. The peculiarity of this case is that the will was duly signed and published the testator in the presence of two witnesses who were requested to witness it, but did not subscribe their names until a few moments after the testator's death. Although every requirement of the statute was complied with by the testator, it was held that the instrument was incomplete at the time of his death, and could not be admitted to probate.

abstract: The special committee of the Board of Education on the dismissal of the school teachers of the Fourth Ward met again on Saturday afternoon. No additional, witnesses appeared for examination. The Committee examined the pay-rolls for several months, to test the accuracy of Mr.SHINE's testimony, that Mr.SMITH, the principal of the Wiliiam-street School, was in the habit of making false returns of the absence of teachers. The pay-rolls abundantly disprove the charge, and show that Mr.SMITH was exceedingly accurate in his returns, making note of even one minute's absence. The clerk was directed to make an of the pay-roll for 18[???]9, to be embodied in the report of the Committee. The committee then adjourned to Friday, July 6 Of the 12 school officers of the Fourth Ward summoned to testify before the Committee, only two, Messrs. SHINE and RYAN, appeared.

abstract: The Democrats do not open the campaign with much vigor. The Douglas meeting of Monday night, though not a dead failure, showed a dismal falling-off from the spirit and life which marked Democratic gatherings in the better days of the party. It was not very ...
lead_paragraph: The Democrats do not open the campaign with much vigor. The Douglas meeting of Monday night, though not a dead failure, showed a dismal falling-off from the spirit and life which marked Democratic gatherings in the better days of the party. It was not very large, and not at all enthusiastic, in spite of the presence of Mr. DOUGLAS himself. The speakers were not men of mark. None of the local magnates of the party took any conspicuous part in the proceedings: -- there was nothing bold, open and resolute in the action or the temper of the meeting; and it melted away, at an early hour, as quietly and as soberly as an evening gathering for religious service. It was altogether too solemn and subdued to be effective. Nothing but the indifference of blank despair, could make a mass meeting of the Democracy so thoroughly respectable.

abstract: "the right of property in a slave is distinctly and expressly affirmed in the Constitution" -- and Southern men generally, with their allies in the North, insist that the Constitution of the United States, proprio vigore, carries Slavery wherever it reaches; and that, as property, they have a right to take their slaves into the Territories of the United States -- there to be protected by a slave code, to be enacted by Congress. We believe we thus state the assumptions of the slave holders and their party as fully and distinctly as they are asserted; and we now intend to prove to the satisfaction of every enlightened and disinterested reader that the declaration of the Chief Justice, and these assumptions founded thereon, are wholly groundless.

abstract: Agreeably to announcement, the great steamship was yesterday opened, for the first time, to the inspection of the public. With commendable industry, the arrangements for the exhibition were completed on the day designated, though the after part of the ship, on the upper deck only, has been cleaned and painted. The ship, however, has undergone a most favorable change in appearance, and when the varnishing of the bulwarks and forward houses is complete, she will look still better. The American and English ensigns are displayed at her mast-heads, but the colossal size of the latter, which files at the after peak, leaves no one in doubt as to the nationality of the ship. Convenient bridges, with high enclosures, and wide enough for persons to easily pass each other, are constructed midway of each end of the ship, visitors being admitted at the after gangway, an[???] passing out from the forward one. The ticket-office is in the brick building on the dock directly fronting the after gangway, and on the wheel-house is a notice where it may be found.

abstract: The Government seems to be in a fair way of recovering no part of the little sum of $155,000, or thereabouts, "conveyed" by ISAAC V. FOWLER, late Postmaster of this City, as will be seen by a decision rendered yesterday by Judge BETTS, in the United States District Court, and published in another column. It appears that when FOWLER was first appointed, ...
lead_paragraph: The Government seems to be in a fair way of recovering no part of the little sum of $155,000, or thereabouts, "conveyed" by ISAAC V. FOWLER, late Postmaster of this City, as will be seen by a decision rendered yesterday by Judge BETTS, in the United States District Court, and published in another column. It appears that when FOWLER was first appointed, he furnished an official bond in the sum of $50,000, signed by himself, with GEORGE LAW, GUSTAVUS A. CONOVER and OLIVER CHARLICK as sureties. On his reappointment it became necessary for him to file a new bond, which he did, in the sum of $75,000. This bond had four seals affixed to it, but was signed only by FOWLER, LAW, and CONOVER, CHARLICK's name nowhere appearing in it. On his defalcation being brought to light, the Government took steps to collect the amount of the bond from the sureties, who thereupon applied to the Court for an injunction to stop such proceedings, informing the Court that they only gave the bond to FOWLER upon the express agreement that CHARLICK also should sign it, and claiming that, as he did not, they were not liable for anything. And Judge BETTS holds it as well settled law that, if they can establish before a jury that they never consented to the delivery of the bond to the United States in its present shape, but only gave it to FOWLER to get CHARLICK's signature, they are not liable on the bond, and he grants an injunction to stay the Government's proceedings until that question is determined.

abstract: Robert Bruce Kenney, alias Stone, was tried yesterday on a charge of forgery in the third degree. He presented a forged check, purporting to be signed by Dr. Reese, to the amount of $375, to the Chemical Bank, when the amount was paid. Defendant had been previously engaged as driver in the Doctor's service. The jury found him guilty, and he was sentenced to three years in the State Prison.
lead_paragraph: Robert Bruce Kenney, alias Stone, was tried yesterday on a charge of forgery in the third degree. abstract: While thousands of dollars have been expended upon a far away heathen nation, and champagne, and flowers, and fruits, have run up a bill for the City to pay, which tax payers do not, it seems, grumble at; while thousands have been whiling away their time with no better occupation than to assist in these expensive follies, the under-currents of life, the misery and degradation which surrounds so many thousands of our Citypoor, but particularly their offspring, have engaged the attention of those few -- too few, unfortunately -- whose lives seem devoted to rescuing the children of the wretched from a life of vice and crime. While the City Fathers have been expending the City's funds, the friends of the Children's Aid Society have been saving the City many dollars. Who can tell what future horrors were in store for a large number of the bright little ones who yesterday took their departure for the Wide West, to be removed forever from the evil influences of parents whose example could not Jail in lime to corrupt them?

abstract: We publish this morning a paper from one of the surviving sons of ALEXANDER HAMILTON, upon the leading political topic of the day, which merits and will repay a careful perusal. It discusses the provisions of the Federal Constitution on the subject of Slavery, in a spirit of candor and with the temper and ability of a statesman. We remember no document of any kind in which this whole subject is presented with more convincing force and clearness than in this.

abstract: The correspondent of the Boston Traveller writing from Beirut, Syria, on May 18, says: The traveling season is now over, and woe betide any luckless voyager who has loitered upon the road. Relentless fevers which unseat the mind, will be almost sure to catch the hindmost. For the last few weeks the Americans have been scampering to the seacoast as rapidly as their Arab steeds can carry them, [???]to make sure their escape to Constantinople or Greece. A greater number of our countrymen have visited Syria this year than at any previous time -- and now there remains but one party in the interior, and, these gentlemen will avail themselves of the next French steamer.

abstract: A feud which has existed for a long time between the members of Engine Company No. 21, lying in Worth-street, near Church, and Engine Company No. 13, whose house is in Duane-street, culminated last evening in a very serious riot. The alarm was given at about 10 1/2 o'clock for a fire which occurred in the wine-cellar of MAT. GOOD-ERSON'S saloon, No. 9 Chatham-street, which was quickly answered by a numerous body of firemen and engine runners. Among the earliest at the fire was 13's Company, and in a short time thereafter, 21's men came at full speed up Centre-street. When near FRENCH'S Hotel, the two companies came into collision, but which were the aggressing party it is very difficult to say, each of course claiming that they only acted on the defensive. The light continued for at least ten minutes, and was marked by even greater ferocity than is usually exhibited by such a class of combatants. The weapons used were clubs, stones, wrenches, trumpets, fire-caps, pieces of iron and pistols, as many as a dozen shots having been fired in the course of the melee. Sheer exhaustion on the part of the belligerents caused a termination of the fight, platoons of Policemen from the Second Third and Fourth Precincts having reached the scene in season to witness the close of the fray. Officer FULLERSON, of the Fourth Precinct, who was the only officer present while the fight was at its height, exerted himself to the utmost to quell the disturbance, and took one of the rioters into custody. The friends of the prisoner rushed to the rescue, and released him, but the officer retained his fire-cap with the initials "J.O.C." upon it and the number "21," which trophy is now at the Station-house. The combatants fled in every direction, when the police came down upon them, and not one arrest was made. While the fight was in progress No. 13's engine was turned over and badly smashed, making the second time during the night that it had received such treatment, it having been overturned by the rival company in Broad-street, between 6 and 7 o'clock in the evening, where it had gone in response to an alarm which proved to be false.

abstract: At the present moment, when the sweltering heats of July are driving everybody out of town, there are persons lying in the Tombs who are simply accused of crime, and have been waiting months for a chance to establish their innocence. One person, PATRICK ...
lead_paragraph: At the present moment, when the sweltering heats of July are driving everybody out of town, there are persons lying in the Tombs who are simply accused of crime, and have been waiting months for a chance to establish their innocence. One person, PATRICK HENNESSY, has been in confinement a quarter of a year, on the mere suspicion of having fired his own house, no indictment, so far as he or his counsel can learn, having yet been found against him. In the same cell with him a young man has been confined the same length of time, awaiting his trial on an indictment for passing counterfeit money, -- the circumstances of the case being such as to render his acquittal very probable, should a trial, which has been delayed three months by the failure of the complaining witness to appear -- ever be reached. In the former case, the fact that an influential Insurance Company is pecuniarily interested in the issue of the trial, while the prisoner is a laboring man, adds a coloring to the case which reflects very little credit either on the prosecuting parties or the legal authorities who have the case in hand.
headline: {'main': 'Imprisonment before Conviction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Imprisonment before Conviction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Montgomery (Ala.) Mail details the career of MARONEY, who has just been sentenced in that city to ten years' imprisonment in the Alabama Penitentiary for robbing Adams' Express Company of $53,000: "MARONEY stole the money from the private pouch of the Express Company -- $10,000 at one time, $40,000 at another, and $3,000 at another. The $10,000 were employed in the purchase of cotton in South Carolina; the $40,000 package was put in a box, and sent by express to Galveston, Texas, under a fictitious name. It remained there till April, when it was ordered to Natchez. He went to Natchez for it, recovered it, and secreted it in Montgomery. MARONEY had a wife, or rather lived with a woman whom he made his wife during these affairs, who was his confederate. She went North, and took up her residence at Jenkintown, in Pennsylvania, with a brother-in-law, and afterwards returned to the South, got the money, and had it buried in her brother-in-law's cellar. ALLEN PINKERTON, the Chicago detective, who was intrusted with the task of unraveling the mystery connected with the disappearance of the money, traced the movements of the woman wherever she went. Women with whom she became acquainted were engaged to watch and to direct her movements as the police agent desired. When the evidence was strong enough, MARONEY was arrested and put in the Eldridge-street jail. A fictitious arrest was made, and one of PINK[???]RTON'S agents was placed in prison with him. MARONEY was made to confide in this Mr. -- , to confess the robbery and where the money was, and finally engaged his aid to get up a defence and to dispose of the money. Everything he did was under the advice of his prison friend, until on the arrival at Montgomery, whither he was sent under an Executive requisition, to be tried on the indictment, he was confronted in Court by his counsellor as a police detective. He immediately save the uselessness of all equivocation and pleaded guilty of the charge of robbery. The Mail states that the number of persons employed by Mr. PINKERTON averaged about eight for ten months, and that the distance traveled by them during that time was not less than 50,000 miles."

abstract: In the death of Rev. BADEN POWELL, Savilian Professor of Geometry in the University of Oxford, announced by the last mail, English science and literature lose a foremost spirit. He belongd to a group of thinkers who have done much to free modern English thought from sectarian narrownesses and vindicate the rights of mental and spiritual freedom. Prof. POWELL was born towards 1792, and was consequently about 68 years of age at the time of his death, which occurred on the 11th of June.

abstract: -- The Charleston Mercury gives the following description of a design for a monument to be erected to the memory of Hon. JOHN C. CALHOUN, under the auspices of the Ladies' Calhoun Monument Association. It is to be about ninety feet in height, and consists of a double flight of six stairs each, rising from the ground to a platform. On the ground, the area occupied is a fifty feet rectangle. Midway the steps is a fence, on the corner posts of which are placed statues emblematic of Liberty, Justice, Eloquence, and the Constitution. On the platform is erected a cenotaphic or mausoleum chamber, twelve feet square inwardly, and surrounded outwardly by a colonnade of twelve Corinthian columns fifteen feet in height. This chamber presents glass doors on each side, over which is an inscription panel. A parapet crowns this little house, from the centre of which the column proper rises. A rectangular die block, ten feet wide, first attracts attention from the beauty of its ornamentation. One face presents an elegant carved representation of the coat-of-arms of South Carolina; a second, those of the United States; a third, the emblems of power; and the fourth, the emblems of Odd Fellowship. The cylindrical column, forty feet in height, springs from the top. The lower half is plain, save the funeral wreaths which tastefully enrap it; the upper half is fluted. It terminates in a Co[???]inthian capital of exceeding richness, which is surmounted by a parapet, from which rises a colossal statue of CALHOUN, on a plain pedestal. The statue is an original conception, twelve feet in height, and represents Mr. CALHOUN, in classic robes, with his right arm extended upwards, and the right hand pointing aloft. The whole struc ture would be about ninety-five feet in height.

abstract: Lina Norwald vs. Aarons & Cobella. -- The plaintiff in this action was a sewing girl, as will be remembered, and obtained a judgment against the defendant Aarons for an assault upon her while a tenant in his house in Oliver-street. The case was stated fully in the Times of June 21, at which time the action was tried before Justice MONCRIEF, in the Superior Court .Upon the trial the plaintiff obtained a judgment for $2,000. Subsequently the defendant, Aarons, obtained a stay of proceedings upon showing that he intended to move for a new trial, the judgment upon the verdict being allowed to stand for security.

Subsequently the defendant, Aarons, obtained a stay of proceedings upon showing that he intended to move for a new trial, the judgment upon the verdict being allowed to stand for security.
