abstract: Mary Hamilton, alias Fanny Calleen alias Margaret Curran, a young Irishwoman of three names, who within the past twelve months has been employed as a domestic in at least trie same number of families, was apprehended yesterday by Officer Secor, of the Seventh Precinct, on various charges of stealing, preferred by persons with whom she had been at service. It was her practice, as she herself admits, to procure an engagement and decamp when opportunity offered, with everything valuable that she could carry away. In most instances she did not remain in her situation longer than one or two days. The complaints preferred against her so far, are by Wright Putney, of this City, from whom the accused stole $45 worth of jewelry; James II. P. Dawson, No. 774 Pacific street, Brooklyn, who lost silver plate and ladies clothing valued at $70; Frederika Gutmann, of No. 28 Orchard-street, from whom she took a quantity of bed-clothing; Sophia Lynch, of Front street, near Fulton Market, who had watches, bedclothes and other articles, valued in the aggregate at $80, stolen; Wm. W. Fowler, of No. 9 Morton-street, who lost a sword, bed-clothes, and his wife's wearing apparel, the whole of which was valued at $40. The prisoner was taken before Justice BRENNAN, to whom she confessed that she had disposed of most of the property by pledging it at various pawn offices in this City. An officer is engaged in searching for it, and the woman was sent to prison pending the appearance of several other victims who will lodge complaints against her.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL -- THE ALBANY CORRUPTION FUND AGAIN. -- A meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held on Monday evening. The Council Chamber was draped in mourning out of respect to the memory of Alderman STANSBURY, recently deceased. A resolution was presented directing the City Railroad Company to issue transfer tickets on the Fulton and Flushing-avenue lines. It was stated that unless passengers took particular cars over these routes, who wished to go to the end thereof, they were required to pay ten cents each, instead of five cents -- the price agreed upon with the city. The subject was referred to the Law Committee. A resolution was adopted appointing a Special Committee of three to consult with the New-York authorities, with a view to the reduction of ferriage over the East River to one cent for foot passengers. Alderman SCHOLES presented a preamble and resolution relative to the $10,000 appropriated for the use of the Special Committee on Ferries. The preamble fully sets forth all the action heretofore taken by the Common Council, embracing reports, speeches, &c; and the resolution calls upon the Committee for a detailed statement of expenditures. After a lengthy discussion, the resolution was adopted, only three Aldermen voting in the negative. At a late hour the Board adjourned to Thursday evening next.

abstract: Yesterday the Comptroller pronounced the sureties of Mr. ANDREW J. HACKLEY satisfactory, which were given with his bid for the job of putting down a new three and four foot main between the receiving reservoir on 80th street and the distributing reservoir on 42d-street, and as his bid proved to be the lowest of those offered, the Croton Board have awarded him the contract. The award will be sent forthwith to the Common Council for confirmation.

abstract: The Atlanta Examiner gives a pleasing incident in the life of Gen. J.G. BYNUM, who created such a sensation here a few weeks ago by eloping with a young lady, a student in Spingler Institute.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Examiner gives a pleasing incident in the life of Gen. J.G. BYNUM, who created such a sensation here a few weeks ago by eloping with a young lady, a student in Spingler Institute. Mr. LEALS, Editor of the Temperance Crusader, was amusing the crowd by improvising verses, in one of which he was so unfortunate as to mention Gen. BYNUM in connection with a young lady to whom he seemed to be particularly attentive. No sooner had he committed the blunder than a brother of the young lady managed to inform Mr. LEALS that he had given great offence by his allusions. Ample apology was at once made, but Gen. BYNUM was not satisfied with this. After dinner, while Mr. LEALS was sitting on the piazza, the General made his appearance, with a cane in one hand and a pistol in the other, and at once proceeded to administer to Mr. LEALS a flagellation with the hickory. He struck him only three blows, but these were severe enough to confine Mr. LEALS to his bed for two or three days. In a newspaper controversy which Mr. LEALS, who is connected with the Atlanta Intelligencer, subsequently had with Mr. HANLEITER, of the Crusader, the latter taunted him with having received a cowhiding at a public watering-place. A peremptory challenge was the result. The affair terminated with the following note, which Mr. LEALS justifies him, he thinks, in terming Mr. HANLEITER "an impudent and cowardly scoundrel." ATLANTA, June 25, 1860.

abstract: To-day, the eighty-fourth anniversary of our national independence, will be celebrated throughout the country, but nowhere, probably, with more enthusiasm than in the Metropolis. The almost con- ...
lead_paragraph: To-day, the eighty-fourth anniversary of our national independence, will be celebrated throughout the country, but nowhere, probably, with more enthusiasm than in the Metropolis. The almost continued noise of exploding fireworks during the past few days, the flaming handbills of the pyrotechnists, the multifarious excursions advertised, and the extensive transportation of fireworks by overloaded fond parents, having an eye to young America, have already given us a foretaste of the celebration that is to take place to-day. It is true that the City Fathers have only been pleased to appropriate less than one-fourth the sum set apart for the entertainment of the Japanese, but even at that, it is fair to presume that the people will be better pleased with the expenditure. The music, the fireworks, the regatta are tangible returns which even the overburdened tax-payers may recognize, however seriously they may think they "pay too much for the whistle." They may be gratified with the reflection that they often pay too much and don't get any whistle at all.

abstract: All the Theatres are exalting themselves in expectation of the crowds which will to-day be let loose to glorify the fathers and to amuse themselves in the great Metropolis. As these crowds are every year ...
lead_paragraph: All the Theatres are exalting themselves in expectation of the crowds which will to-day be let loose to glorify the fathers and to amuse themselves in the great Metropolis. As these crowds are every year more and more exclusively made up of strangers within our gates, our managers find their reaping easier and their sowing less expensive than ever, and they have accordingly learned to deal with the Fourth less as an "opening day" and more as a "clearing day" than ever. The advertisements and the play-bills remind one more forcibly with every year, on this auspicious in the shop-windows: "Alarming sacrifice! Selling off at cost! This stock to be disposed of in consequence of new arrangements!" New-Yorkers run out of the City into the country, to avoid the, celebration for which they pay, and the country rushes in to enjoy it. Played-out plays instantly revive, with the rush of fresh audiences, and lift up their wilted heads, like dry seaweeds on the beaches when the tide comes swooping in.

abstract: Friday next is the day appointed for the execution of JACOB S. HARDEN, and the New-Jersey papers are filled with reports, more or less authentic, of the manner in which that wretched man spends the few remaining days of his probation. It is not easy to ...
lead_paragraph: Friday next is the day appointed for the execution of JACOB S. HARDEN, and the New-Jersey papers are filled with reports, more or less authentic, of the manner in which that wretched man spends the few remaining days of his probation. It is not easy to surround a story of cold-blooded and deliberate murder with much sentimentality, not would it seem possible to excite much sympathy for a man who could cloak the soul of an assassin under the cover of religion, and feed poison for days and weeks in succession to the wife of his bosom, while bestowing upon her the caresses of pretended affection. But nothing is impossible in this direction, and we are not in the least surprised to read of saintly serenades being given to this monster of cruelty, -- of fair and lovely hands ministering to his physical comfort in his dell of attentive ears listening to the gracious words that flow from his lips as fluently as when he made them the panders to his vices, and of tender hears rejoicing in the indications which his daily walk and conversation afford of a mind at peace with Heaven, and resigned to the sad fate which human justice awards to crime. We have nothing to say against all this; -- we hope this wretched murderer is a sincere penitent; -- but we prefer to leave that question, which is interesting mainly to himself to the tribunal which he cannot deceive and before which he must soon appear. But we find it difficult to imagine a form of crime more utterly unredeemed, more thoroughly marked by every circumstance of aggravation and enormity, -- more perfectly indicative of a black and malignant soul, than that for which HARDEN is about to suffer death.

abstract: The mystery attendant on the double murder in the Eighteenth Ward, of Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS, continues to increase in interest. On Monday night, after his brother EDWIN had been arrested, CHARLES JEFFERD, by the advice of a friend, proceeded to the house of Justice OSBORN for the purpose of giving himself into the hands of the law for-examination, but that magistrate, very singularly, told him to go away, and call at the Police Court in the Tombs on the following morning. Accordingly, yesterday, at the opening of the Court, JEFFRED appeared, and was committed to prison, to await the result of the Coroner's inquest. He asserts his entire innocence, and denies all knowledge whatever of the murders, protesting that he can prove an alibi. On the other hand, the Police, it is understood, have received information, which may render the alleged alibi ineffective. To-morrow the Coroner's inquest will be resumed, when it is expected that some interesting testimony will be produced.
lead_paragraph: The mystery attendant on the double murder in the Eighteenth Ward, of Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS, continues to increase in interest. Accordingly, yesterday, at the opening of the Court, JEFFRED appeared, and was committed to prison, to await the result of the Coroner's inquest. He asserts his entire innocence, and denies all knowledge whatever of the murders, protesting that he can prove an alibi. On the other hand, the Police, it is understood, have received information, which may render the alleged alibi ineffective. To-morrow the Coroner's inquest will be resumed, when it is expected that some interesting testimony will be produced.

abstract: -- The Rocky Mountain News tells of the following tragedy recently enacted in Jefferson Territory: MARCUS GRIDLER, a native of the Tyrolese, in company with JACOB MILLWE, his wife, and other emigrants, left Leavenworth for Denver City on the 26th of April. GRIDLER and MILLER quarreled frequently on the road, and particularly; about their camping places. When about six miles from Denver, the quarrel was renewed, MILLER struck GRIDLER with a whip, and the latter seized an axe, knocked the former down, and shot him while lying on the ground. GRIDLER, having arranged with those who witnessed the tragedy to testify that the deed was done in Self-defence, proceeded to Denver City, and on the 14th of June surrendered himself to the authorities. A meeting of the citizens was called the following day; a jury formally impanneled, judges appointed, an attorney selected to prosecute and another to defend; witnesses were called, sworn, examined and cross-examined; pleas were made and a formal charge to the jury delivered by the Judge; and after decent deliberation; a verdict of murder in the first degree rendered. The Judges, after consultation, sentenced the prisoner to be executed the following day (Friday) between the hours of 10 and 5 P. M., and the sentence was ratified by a vote of the people. A scaffold was erected near Cherry Creek ; two reverend gentlemen administered to the spiritual concerns of the culprit; the Jefferson Rangers escorted him to the place of execution, where, in the presence of a concourse of over four thousand people, the sentence of the "Court" was carried into effect -- the prisoner having first confessed his crime from the scaffold.
lead_paragraph: -- The Rocky Mountain News tells of the following tragedy recently enacted in Jefferson Territory: MARCUS GRIDLER, a native of the Tyrolese, in company with JACOB MILLWE, his wife, and other emigrants, left Leavenworth for Denver City on the 26th of April. GRIDLER and MILLER quarreled frequently on the road, and particularly; about their camping places. When about six miles from Denver, the quarrel was renewed, MILLER struck GRIDLER with a whip, and the latter seized an axe, knocked the former down, and shot him while lying on the ground. GRIDLER, having arranged with those who witnessed the tragedy to testify that the deed was done in Self-defence, proceeded to Denver City, and on the 14th of June surrendered himself to the authorities. A meeting of the citizens was called the following day; a jury formally impanneled, judges appointed, an attorney selected to prosecute and another to defend; witnesses were called, sworn, examined and cross-examined; pleas were made and a formal charge to the jury delivered by the Judge; and after decent deliberation; a verdict of murder in the first degree rendered. The Judges, after consultation, sentenced the prisoner to be executed the following day (Friday) between the hours of 10 and 5 P. M., and the sentence was ratified by a vote of the people. A scaffold was erected near Cherry Creek ; two reverend gentlemen administered to the spiritual concerns of the culprit; the Jefferson Rangers escorted him to the place of execution, where, in the presence of a concourse of over four thousand people, the sentence of the "Court" was carried into effect -- the prisoner having first confessed his crime from the scaffold.

abstract: -- The will of the late THEODORE PARKER was presented for probate a day or two since. From it we learn that he gives to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts "the two firearms formerly the property of my honored grandfather, Captain JOHN PARKER, late of Lexington, to wit.: the large musket or king's arm, which was by him captured from the British on the morning of the 19th of April, 1775, in the battle of Lexington, and which is the first firearm taken from the enemy in the war of Independence; and also the smaller musket, which was used by him in that battle while fighting in 'the sacreo cause of God and his country;' and I desire that these relics of the Revolution may be placed in the Senate Chamber of this Commonwealth, and there sacredly kept in perpetuam rei memoriam." To his "much valued friend, WENDELL PHILLIPS," he gives his "folio copy of the English State Trials, in eleven volumes, with many portraits interleaved." To his "much valued friend, CHARLES SUMNER," he gives his "copy of the Parliamentary History of England, in thirty-six volumes." To other friends he makes bequests of particular works from his library as mementoes and of special significance, and then the remainder of his very, extensive and valuable collection he gives to the City of Boston, "to put into the Public Library of the city, for the use and benefit of such as have access thereto, and be read on such terms as the Directors of the said Library shall think just; and I desire that so far as consistent with public utility, the said books be kept in alcoves, or on shelves by themselves; and I desire that the said books shall in no case be sold, or given away, or exchanged for other books." In case the city declines to accept them, then they are to be offered to the library of Harvard College; and Mrs. PARKER'S consent is necessary to any disposal of them in any event, and she may entirely change their direction if she choose. All the remainder of his property is left to his wife; certain provisions being made for its disposal in case Mrs. PARKER should not survive him; these, of course, are now of no force.

abstract: The brothers CHARLES and EDWIN JEFFERD, who are suspected of having murdered Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS on Saturday night, or at least of being implicated in the crime, are both in the hands of the criminal authorities. EDWIN, the younger, it ...
lead_paragraph: The brothers CHARLES and EDWIN JEFFERD, who are suspected of having murdered Messrs. WALTON and MATHEWS on Saturday night, or at least of being implicated in the crime, are both in the hands of the criminal authorities. EDWIN, the younger, it will be remembered, yielded himself into custody on Monday morning, and CHARLES attempted to follow his example on the evening of the same day, but Justice OSBORN, the magistrate to whom he made an offer of surrender, would not accept it, and it was not until yesterday morning that he could obtain a legal custodian.

abstract: YOUNG MEN'S REPUBLICAN UNION. A regular meeting of this association was to have been held at their head-quarters last evening, but owing to the small number in attendance, the President recommended an adjournment, which was carried. It was stated by the President that no meeting of the Union would be held on Tuesday next. It was expected that Mr. SUMNER would speak in the City on Monday.

abstract: ACCIDENTALLY DROWNED. -- On Saturday last Miss MANEY, 16 years of age, residing in West Thirteenth-street, New-York, accompanied an excursion party on the steamboat Only Son and a barge. When about half a mile from the Bay House, situated on the east side of Newark Bay, she attempted to step from the steamer to the barge, and falling between them was drowned before assistance could be rendered. The boats at the time were aground, and the body was not recovered until yesterday. Last evening Coroner GAFNEY, of Jersey City, held an inquest on the body, aid the jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts.

abstract: That Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT has under  taken to make himself the master of Ocean communication between the Atlantic and the Pacific coasts of the United States, our readers already know. They know, too, that as a ...
lead_paragraph: That Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT has under taken to make himself the master of Ocean communication between the Atlantic and the Pacific coasts of the United States, our readers already know. They know, too, that as a means to this end, the same individual has not shrunk from striking down, as far as his power extends, every private interest and private right of thousands of his fellow-citizens, which the interruption of the national mails can reach and put in peril. But the systematic and deliberate selfishness with which this speculator on the necessities of his kind has followed up his schemes, demands and deserves a more full and minute exposition than it has yet received. The act by which public attention was drawn on Monday last to the matter was but the culmination of a series of steps, each and all tending to the subjugation of the public.

abstract: George Law and Gustavus A. Conover vs. The United States. -- This matter came up in the U.S. District Court yesterday, before Judge BETTS, on a motion for an injunction, made on behalf of complainants who were the sureties upon the official bond of Isaac V. Fowler, late Postmaster in this City, to restrain the proceedings initiated to collect from them by a distress warrant, the amount of Fowler's defalcation. The bill was served on the 2d of June, 1860, on the United States District Attorney. It alleged that on the 20th of September 1858, Fowler was by and with the advice of the Senate appointed to the office of Deputy Postmaster of New-York; that he had been previously appointed and then held the same office, and had on such previous appointment executed an official bond in the sum of $50,000, with the complainants and OLIVER CHARLICK as sureties; that on this reappointment he applied to the complainants to execute a new bond with him, which they did on the 22d of September, 1858, in the penalty of $75,000, and which they delivered to him, but with the express agreement that before it was delivered to the Government it should be executed by CHARLICK also; but that CHARLICK never did execute the bond at all, of which fact, however, they were entirely ignorant until they were called upon on May 12, 1860, by the Deputy Marshal with the warrant of distress to collect the amount of the defalcation.
lead_paragraph: George Law and Gustavus A. Conover vs. The United States. -- This matter came up in the U.S. District Court yesterday, before Judge BETTS, on a motion for an injunction, made on behalf of complainants who were the sureties upon the official bond of Isaac V. Fowler, late Postmaster in this City, to restrain the proceedings initiated to collect from them by a distress warrant, the amount of Fowler's defalcation. The bill was served on the 2d of June, 1860, on the United States District Attorney. It alleged that on the 20th of September 1858, Fowler was by and with the advice of the Senate appointed to the office of Deputy Postmaster of New-York; that he had been previously appointed and then held the same office, and had on such previous appointment executed an official bond in the sum of $50,000, with the complainants and OLIVER CHARLICK as sureties; that on this reappointment he applied to the complainants to execute a new bond with him, which they did on the 22d of September, 1858, in the penalty of $75,000, and which they delivered to him, but with the express agreement that before it was delivered to the Government it should be executed by CHARLICK also; but that CHARLICK never did execute the bond at all, of which fact, however, they were entirely ignorant until they were called upon on May 12, 1860, by the Deputy Marshal with the warrant of distress to collect the amount of the defalcation.

abstract: -- Senator SEWARD is in receipt of a letter from J. AUGUSTUS JOHNSON, United States Consul at Berut, announcing that the horses which had been presented him by the Effendi Ayoub Beg Trouboulski will be shipped from that place by the American vessel due there on the 10th. There are five horses in all. Three of them were presented to Gov. SEWARD, and two were purchased -- one for Hon. SIMON CAMERON, and the other for Mr. WALSH, of Harrisburgh, Pa. Those for Gov. SEWARD will, after their arrival, be left to recruit for some weeks upon the farm of Hon.: GARY V. SACKETT, an eminent agricultural friend of the Governor, residing at Seneca Falls. Mr. JOHNSON states in his letter that Syria is in a state of civil war, and that the Maronites and Druses are killing each other as rapidly as possible.

abstract: The Santa Fe mails, with dates to June 18, arrived to-day, making the regular schedule time. No rain had fallen in New-Mexico this year, and the crops are almost entirely destroyed. There has never been such a scarcity of provisions and forage in that country as at present. Corn is selling at almost any price asked.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE, Tuesday, July 3.

abstract: The United States steam revenue-cutter Harriet Lane, Capt. FAUNCE, seized yesterday afternoon, outside of Sandy Hook, the bark Kate, Capt. OTTO, on suspicion that she was about to engage in the Slavetrade. The Kate, was cleared at the Custom-house by Capt. WATTS, bound to Cape Palmas, West Coast of Africa, and sailed yesterday. She was brought to the City and anchored off the Battery. Her crew are composed principally of Portuguese and Spaniards, from whom no information could be gained Her cargo is such as slavers generally carry. At the the time she was seized, Capt. FAUNCE observed some curious movements on the part of a steam tug, then some distance off and ran for her, when she proved to be the Magnolia, having on board a number of men of whom no reliable account was given. Capt. F., having no doubt that they were to have been put on board the Kate, as appearances indicated such an intention, immediately seized the tug and brought her to The City, and detained her passengers for examination.

abstract: -- One evening last week the wife of a sea-captain, residing at Saybrook, was returning from a visit to a neighbor, when she was followed by two men. She overheard them say, "the captain is gone," and "there must be considerable money in the house." The lady, upon reaching home, concluded to await the arrival of the parties who, she had no doubt, intended to rob the house during the night. She had not long to wait, for at 11 o'clock a summons came to open the door. Instead of complying she raised a chamber window and inquired who was there? No response came to this or further inquiries, and she told them to leave or she would shoot them. They then tried to effect an entrance by clambering upon a shed, but one of them fell and both returned to the front door which they attempted to force. The lady, taking a revolver in one hand and a candle in the other, stood by the door to await the issue. In a few minutes the burglars had broken it in, when she told them that if they moved a step towards coming into the house, they were dead men. They looked at her, consulted together a few minutes and then went away, declining to take the risk. After the peril was over she returned to her two children, exhausted with the tension to which her nerves and courage had been subjected. Such a woman as that is worth having in the house, and we regret being unable to give her name. -- Hartford Courant.

abstract: The decision of the Supreme Court of this State establishing the validity of the Farm Mortgage Bonds seems to give, as was expected, very great satisfaction at the East. As an evidence of the conservative disposition of the Court, this is undoubtedly justified. But the holders of that class of Securities must not infer from that decision that the contest is over, and the Bonds will now be paid or recognized by the mortgagors.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: Of Gen. CASS, and the insult lately offered him by the Michigan State Convention, the Cleveland Plaindealer says: "We happen to know that he left Washington with a secret determination never to return. He has come to the conclusion, and so tells ...
lead_paragraph: Of Gen. CASS, and the insult lately offered him by the Michigan State Convention, the Cleveland Plaindealer says: "We happen to know that he left Washington with a secret determination never to return. He has come to the conclusion, and so tells his confidential friends, that 'the Union is about at its end, and he has gone home to put his house in order preparatory for dissolution.' He says the only contingency that can save the Union is the adoption by the Douglas Democrats of the North, of the slave code policy proposed by the Davis Democracy of the South." He has been waiting, during the two Conventions at Charleston and Baltimore, to see the Douglas men cave in to this proposition as a Union-saving measure, but he waited in vain. He is satisfied now that the Douglas men can never be driven from their Popular Sovereignty position, 'though the heavens fall,' and therefore the old Michigander is without hope and without God in the world. We know his ambition was to die in Washington on some Fourth of July, the same as JEFFERSON, MADISON and ADAMS did, and be buried at the foot of the Washing ton Monument. But now he dies in Michigan." (!)

abstract: -- In the Superior Criminal Court for Middlesex County, now in session at Concord, Mass., the Grand Jury came in on Saturday morning, and returned bills of indictment against SILAS CARLETON. GEO. J. COOLEDGE, Wm. B. CARLETON and WATSON FREEMAN, Jr., of Boston, for attempting to kidnap FRANK B. SANBORN, of Concord, on the 3d of April last. There are four counts in the indictiments -- charging first that they inveigled and seized Mr. SANBORN without any lawful warrant or authority, with intent to send him out of the Commonwealth; second, an assault; third, a forcible seizure, with intent to confine him in the Commonwealth; and fourth, that they seized, confined and hand-cuffed him; with the design of transporting him out of the Commonwealth. The case will not be called until after jail cases ate disposed of. There was no bill returned against Mr. SANBORN for assaulting the officers. The parties were not arraigned, -- Boston Courier, July 2.

abstract: Coroner O'KEEFE was summoned to the New-York Hospital yesterday morning to inquire into the facts In relation to the death of HENRY J. S.LEAR, an English youth, 20 years of age, who was admitted to that institution on Monday afternoon in a dying condition, produced by a dose of strychnine, which he had intentionally taken. Deceased resided with his mother at No. 119 Leonard-street, and was employed as clerk in a down-town store. Some months ago he suddenly left home without informing his friends of his intention, and was absent nearly eight weeks, when he returned, but could not be induced, upon any consideration, to reveal where he had been spending his time. On several occasions a[???]erward no went from home, remaining away for many weeks. He has lately appeared greatly depressed in spirits, but utterly refused to make a confidant of his mother otherwise than to say that he was a married man. Recently it was ascertained that he had been a frequent visitor at Newburgh, but beyond this fact nothing to show in want manner he had passed the time of his absence from the City is known. A post-mortem examination of the body revealed the presence of strychnine in the stomach, and a verdict of death from the effects of that poison was returned. In his pocket was found the following letter:

abstract: The City authorities of Brooklyn have appropriated $1,000 with which to celebrate this day. This will be used for fireworks and music. National sa- ...
lead_paragraph: The City authorities of Brooklyn have appropriated $1,000 with which to celebrate this day. This will be used for fireworks and music. National salutes will be fired in the Eastern and Western Districts at sunrise, and there will be a display of national flags from all the public buildings, and the fire bells throughout the city will be rung. At noon the bells will be again rung, and another national salute will be fired; and the same will be repeated again at sunset. In the evening there will be a display of fire-works in front of the City Hall, and also on the open lots bounded by Graham-avenue, Ewen, Ainslie and Devoe streets.

abstract: A pubic meeting to ratify the nomination of DOUGLAS and JOHNSON took place to-night in front of the City Hall. The stand was beautifully illuminated with numerous transparencies,  Resolutions indorsing the Cincinnati Platform and non-inter  vention were passed. G.W. CREUT, of Virginia, and others delivered speeches in earnest advocacy of the nominees, and predicting the triumph of the principles which they declared. The proceedings were continued till a late hour.

abstract: -- The execution of NATHANIEL HARTEN for the murder of Miss MELISSA MORRIS, took place at Moundsville, Marshall County, Va., on Thursday. As usual at all public executions, the crowd of people was immense. The Wheeling Intelligencer says; "HARTEN ascended the scaffold slowly, but firmly, accompanied by Rev. Mr. RICHMOND and other clergymen. When the condemned man beheld the scaffold, the little blood in his face disappeared, his eyes seemed to sink suddenly deeper into his head, and he seemed almost instantly to lose one-third of his flesh. This lasted but a short time, and becoming seated upon the scaffold , assumed the old dull, morose appearance, which has characterized him ever since the first day of his arrest. Rev. Mr. RICHMOND then offered up a prayer in behalf of the condemned man, in which he intimated that he (HARTEN) had experienced a change of heart, and hoped for Divine forgiveness. The rope was then adjusted about his neck, the cap drawn over his eyes, Sheriff REED pulled the trigger, and the next moment HARTEN was swinging in the air. He drew himself up twice or three times in violent struggles, but was soon motionless and lifeless. Among the many persons who pressed prominently upon the line of soldiers surrounding the scaffold, before the drop fell, was the father of the murdered girl, MORRIS, who was very much intoxicated, and so clamorously eager for the awful scene that it was with difficulty he was restrained by his neighbors.

abstract: A considerable number of the friends of Mr. Geo. WILKES, and of those who admired the course pursued by him in England, in relation to the fight for the Championship, between John C. HEENAN and THOMAS SAYERS, met at the dining table of the Astor House last evening, for the purpose of presenting to him a token of their regard. The chair was occupied by Ex-Judge PHILLIPS, who, as soon at the fruits appeared, made a few remarks introductory to the presentation, and closed by calling upon Capt. JAMES M, TURNLR to present the testimonial. In coming for ward to perform the duty assigned him, Capt. TURNER opened a handsome case, containing a Swiss chronometer stop-watch, valued at $500; and, presenting it to Mr. WILKES, who occupied a seat on the right of the Chairman, said he regretted that some more capable person had not been selected to perform the pleasurable task that had been assigned to him. The testimonial, he said, was from those who had looked with admiration upon the course of Mr. WILKES, while managing the American side of the controversy created by the peculiar termination of the contest between John C. HEENAN and THOMAS SAYERS -- and also by those who admired his integrity and independence as a journalist, and the example he had afforded, both at home and abroad, of a true American gentleman.

abstract: THE LAST SLAVER. -- The bark Kate, which was captured on Tuesday by Capt. FAUNCE, of the revenue cutter Harriet Lane, while she was in the act of leaving this port, and while about receiving her crew of Spaniards and Portugese on board from the steamtug Magnolia, remains at anchor "under the guns" of the cutter. The Kate is a very sharp clipper, with raking masts, and is heavily sparred. She looks as if it would take a fast steamer to catch her, when she had all her canvas spread to a "spanking breeze." She is 267 tons register, was built in Baltimore seven years ago, and was newly metalled last year. She has a trunk cabin. While getting ready for her present trading voyage to the coast she lay near the foot of Delancey-street, East River, and attracted much attention by her rakish appearance.

abstract: THE SUPPOSED KIDNAPPING CASE THE MISSING MAN AT HOME A SINGULAR STORY. Yesterday morning Recorder TILDEN, of Jersey City, received a letter from Mr. BUNN, whose sudden disappearance a short time since caused considerable apprehension as to his safety. He is now at home in Rathboneville,...
lead_paragraph: THE SUPPOSED KIDNAPPING CASE -- THE MISSING MAN AT HOME -- A SINGULAR STORY. -- Yesterday morning Recorder TILDEN, of Jersey City, received a letter from Mr. BUNN, whose sudden disappearance a short time since caused considerable apprehension as to his safety. He is now at home in Rathboneville, quite ill from rough usage and exposure. He states in substance that he left home on the 11th of June last with about $1,500 on his person, intending to transact business on the line of the Erie Railroad, also at New-York and Newark, and that immediately after taking dinner at Turner's Hotel, Oswego, he felt very unwell, and was conscious of nothing more until he recollects being struck on the head because he would not get into a small boat. How long he remained unconscious at that time he does not know, but when he recovered he found himself out at sea in a small coasting schooner, robbed of everything except his watch, which he carried in such a manner that easily escaped detection. The vessel was an old foretopsail schooner, painted black. Mr. BUNN thinks that there was a large patch on the foretopsail. The captain was a man of middle size. He thinks he would know him. When Mr. BUNN would ask any question in relation to his whereabouts the only answer he would receive was: "Your fare is paid, Sir." The crew consisted of six or seven men, with whom he was allowed no conversation whatever. After being at sea six days they neared land, and he ascertained that they were on the Coast of Florida. He was put ashore in a small boat, after solemnly promising not to speak to one of the hands in the boat. Fortunately, he reached a planter's house before night, where he was kindly cared for, and after he had sufficiently recovered, was furnished funds with which he returned home. From the state of his system Mr. BUNN thinks that he was a drugged at the hotel where he took supper, at Owego. He does not think the hands on board the schooner knew anything about the transactions on shore, or in fact anything regarding him, except that he was a passenger. He will visit Jersey City as soon as his health is sufficiently recovered to bear the journey.

abstract: The National Anniversary was duty observed in Brooklyn by all classes in a becoming manner. The day was ushered in by the ringing of bells and firing of cannon and a general explosion of small arms. Bells were rung and national salutes were fired again at noon and sunset. In the morning the Fifth Brigade, Gen. CROCKE, paraded and marched through some of the principal streets, and in the evening there were two displays of fireworks -- one in the Eastern and the other in the Western District -- got up at an expense of $1,000. During the day was as usual a continual turmoil caused by the discharge of small fireworks and firearms. Fortunately no total accidents occurred.

abstract: There is nothing new under the political sun. In the conduct of party warfare, the thing that hath been is the thing that shall be. Events sometimes throw new issues into the field, but the mode of contesting them remains the same. Party tactics know little variety and undergo no substantial change. We may take it for granted, therefore, that we shall hear in...
lead_paragraph: There is nothing new under the political sun. In the conduct of party warfare, the thing that hath been is the thing that shall be. Events sometimes throw new issues into the field, but the mode of contesting them remains the same. Party tactics know little variety and undergo no substantial change. We may take it for granted, therefore, that we shall hear in the year 1863 precisely the same threats and reproaches and prognostications by which our ears were assailed in the year 1859. All the timid people will be made to undergo precisely the same agonies, and all the credulous people be imposed upon by precisely the same braggadocio. We live so fast and forget so rapidly that they never seem old or familiar.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN was summoned to the Eleventh Ward Station-house, on Wednesday afternoon, to investigate the circumstances attending the death of a woman, probably 23 years of age, who had been confined in one of the cells under the supposition that she was intoxicated. From the testimony that was obtained it was shown that deceased had been found between 5 and 6 o'clock in the morning in the area-way of the house No. 351 East Tenth-street by a servant girl engaged at that place. She seemed to be partially insensible, but as it was thought that she was intoxicated an officers was called, who conveyed her to the Station-house. On the way thither she stated that on the evening previous she had come to the City from Staten Island, and taken a stage to ride up town. She felt so sick, however, that she left the stage before it had gone very far, and went into a drag-store, where she drank a glass of soda water, after which she had no recollection of what transpired, but she was sure she had taken no intoxicating beverage. Her story, in this respect, was not believed, and she was locked up. Half an hour later, when the doorman visited the cell, he found her dead. Dr. JOHN BEACH made a post-mortem examination of the body, and discovered abundant evidence that her death had been produced by the action of some corrosive poison, and further investigation of the case was postponed until Sunday morning next, in order that a chemical analysis of the stomach and intestines might be made. Deceased had every appearance of being a lady. She was dressed nearly in a black silk, trimmed with velvet, and her undergarments were of a corresponding description. In her pocket the likeness of a young man, a small amount of money, and some trinkets, were found. The body was removed to Bellevue Hospital, that the friends may have an opportunity to identify it.

abstract: It is stated that a Circular Note, demanding the recognition of the cession of Savoy and Nice to France, was transmitted on the 21st ultimo, from Paris to the French Ambassadors at the various European Courts, for communication to the Governments to which they are respectfully accredited. In...
lead_paragraph: It is stated that a Circular Note, demanding the recognition of the cession of Savoy and Nice to France, was transmitted on the 21st ultimo, from Paris to the French Ambassadors at the various European Courts, for communication to the Governments to which they are respectfully accredited. In this note. M. THOUVENEL reviews the circumstances of the case, and expresses his confidence in the recognition of the act which has been accomplished in conformity with the principles of public rights and international law -- and because France is ready to renew the assurance that she intends to assume the obligation resulting from the final act of Vienna, referring to the neutralized districts of Faucigny and Chablais. M. THOUVENEL, in conclusion, distinctly hints that France will not consent to any lessening of Savoyard territory in favor of Switzerland, although she accepts the European Conference on the question.

abstract: Unless as the philosophic WIGFALL declares  "poverty is a crime," we see no valid reason why measures for the preservation of the public health should not be as promptly adopted, and as thoroughly executed, in those quarters of this great town which are occupied by the laboring poor as in the more aristocratic precincts of wealth and leisure. Yet no contrast can be more striking than that which ex-...
lead_paragraph: Unless -- as the philosophic WIGFALL declares -- "poverty is a crime," we see no valid reason why measures for the preservation of the public health should not be as promptly adopted, and as thoroughly executed, in those quarters of this great town which are occupied by the laboring poor as in the more aristocratic precincts of wealth and leisure. Yet no contrast can be more striking than that which exists between the cleanly pavement and pure atmosphere of Fifth-avenue and the regions of Union-square, and the noisome stench that rises from the filthy gutters and assails the nostrils of any chance pedestrian through not only the thoroughfares in the vicinity of the docks, but many of the cross streets in the upper part of the City, between the most frequently traveled avenues. The difference in the habits of neatness which characterize the rich and the poor does not afford sufficient explanation for this different condition of the quarters they respectively inhabit. If the poorer classes use the street gutters as cesspools, it is not to be inferred that they would not appreciate marble basins and bathing-tubs, with plenty of Croton in their chambers, quite as well as the more wealthy who can afford such luxuries. If the absence of these conveniences forces them to turn the streets into receptacles of filth, it is only a stronger reason why the proper authorities should pay especial attention to the purification of those streets. A person who could pass from Seventh to Eighth avenues, on any of the first dozen streets above Twenty-fifth, and not wonder how human beings can breathe such a fetid atmosphere and live, would do well to put himself on exhibition as a phenomenon, destitute of either the organ of wonder, the sense of smell, or both. On any of the hot days of last week, when the street gutters, almost boiling beneath the burning heat of the noontide sun, sent up fumes of poisonous stench, could the twenty-one Sanitarians who went to the Boston Convention, have passed through the thoroughfares mentioned above, they would have gained more information concerning the needs of the City, and certainly have better earned the money which they pilfered from the City funds, than they did in the expensive pleasure-trip to the modern Athens.

abstract: During a portion of the years from 1849 to 1853 inclusive, the mails between certain  ports on Lake Erie were carried on steamboats belonging to ARTHUR EDWARDS and his associates. There were two classes of mails  the through mail and the local; and ac-...
lead_paragraph: During a portion of the years from 1849 to 1853 inclusive, the mails between certain ports on Lake Erie were carried on steamboats belonging to ARTHUR EDWARDS and his associates. There were two classes of mails -- the through mail and the local; and according to the practice of the Post-office Department, the compensation for the whole service was adjusted according to the number of letters and papers destined for the port of delivery constituting the local mails. It is distinctly stated by Postmaster-General CAMPBELL, in reference to this very case, that it was always understood that the amount paid on the local mails was to be in full for the whole service.

abstract: A general fue de joie among our Metropolitan population, and the thousands of our country cousins who visited on Wednesday, testified to the national appreciation of the importance of our country's birthday. The general suspension of business, and the absolute abandon with which all classes participated in the sports of the day -- the strong turnout of the military, the carnival scene in the streets, the brilliant scene on the bay among the fleet of pleasure craft -- all combined to add zest to the festive scene, and enhance the universal enjoyment. The day was not without its customary list of accidents and incidents, all of which will be found detailed below:

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, proceeded to Staten Island for ten days' encampment. The turn out was not as showy...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, proceeded to Staten Island for ten days' encampment. The turn out was not as showy as was anticipated, for many excellent reasons. Among these were the demands upon the time of the men in the recent regimental parades; the interruption of business occasioned by the celebration of the Fourth; and the exceedingly unpropitious state of the weather. This last, indeed, occasioned a report that the encampment was postponed, and prevented the attendance of many who would otherwise have been present.

abstract: The Coroner's inquest into the facts connected with the recent murder of GEORGE W. WALTON and  JOHN W. MATHEWS, was resumed yesterday at the Bellevue Hospital. There was a large attendance of spectators.
lead_paragraph: The Coroner's inquest into the facts connected with the recent murder of GEORGE W. WALTON and JOHN W. MATHEWS, was resumed yesterday at the Bellevue Hospital. There was a large attendance of spectators. Among the parties present were the mother and daughter of Mr. WALTON, both, of whom gave testimony. The brothers JEFFERD, were also present, and twice appeared before the inquest for the purpose of identification by witnesses, but none were able to identity either of them with the man who was seen running down Irving-place. Messrs. CHAUNCEY SCHAFFEE in behalf of the friends of the deceased, and C.H. SMITH from the District-Attorney's office, appeared as counsel and assisted in the examination of witnesses.

abstract: The members of Hook and Ladder Company No. 16 observed the day on their own account. The truck-house, located at the corner of Fiftieth-street and Lexington-avenue, was cleared of their apparatus in the morning. An excellent and abundant collation was spread in the building, and at precisely 12 o'clock the foreman of the Company, Coroner ROBT. GAMBLE, called those present to order. The Declaration of Independence was then read by Mr. GEORGE DALLINGER, and addresses followed by DANIEL B. TAYLOR and HENRY ARCULARIUS. After these exercises the collation was served. Sentiments appropriate to the day were the adjuncts of the repast. Mr. GEERY, foreman of Bose Company No. 56; the Chairman, and Messrs. SWARTZ and BENNETT and others, enlivened the occasion with songs. At night, when the display of fireworks at Hamilton-square was over, the public in the neighborhood of the truck-house were treated to fire works, music by a brass band, &c.

abstract: The display of fireworks in the evening was on a more extensive scale than has characterized this part of the programme of any previous Fourth.
lead_paragraph: The display of fireworks in the evening was on a more extensive scale than has characterized this part of the programme of any previous Fourth. Instead of being confined to three or four public squares as hitherto, there was an exhibition in more than a dozen different places, scattered over all parts of the City from the City Hall Park to Harlem. All ages, sexes, classes and conditions of Young America were accommodated, and the $7,000 appropriated by the Common Council for this part of the celebration received, for once, the approbation of the people. The pyrotechnics were under the superintendence of the Messrs. EDGE, of Jersey City, who performed their part of the contract with entire satisfaction, and gave the public the worth of their money. Exhibitions took place in the following places:

lead_paragraph: The tendency of the funds would probably have been towards improvement to-day, the weather being more promising, but that the delivery of the large amount of Government Stock recently sold caused considerable pressure for money in the Stock Ex change. As much as 4 1/2 cent. was paid readily for short loans.

abstract: The fourth was also extensively celebrated by our German citizens, their various places of amusement being crowded from morning till night, where they enjoyed their favorite lager and theatrical performances. A very large number had also left the City during the day and enjoyed a stroll through the country. Among these were the Turners, who left the City early in the morning to proceed to Strattonport, where they participated in the Sixth Anniversary of the Turnverein of that place.

abstract: For some time past the boating community of this vicinity have been endeavoring to have the aquatic-sports, which are an essential part of the Fourth of July festivities, placed on the same liberal footing, as regards appropriations, as fireworks and the other sources of amusements. Their efforts have at length been successful, and something over a week ago, the Common Council appropriated for this sport a sum of money that was perfectly munificent, compared with those of former years.
lead_paragraph: For some time past the boating community of this vicinity have been endeavoring to have the aquatic-sports, which are an essential part of the Fourth of July festivities, placed on the same liberal footing, as regards appropriations, as fireworks and the other sources of amusements. abstract: The European advices published in the TIMES this morning are one week later than before received, and are quite interesting. The Persia, which arrived at this port on Wednesday evening, brought news to the 23d ult., three days later; and the Parana, from Galway, which arrived at St. Johns, N.F., and Etna, from Liverpool via Queenstown, which arrived off Cape Race yesterday morning, extend our advices to the 27th. No further hostilities are reported from Sicily, but an attack upon Messina by GARIBALDI was expected to take place very soon. Large reinforcements for the insurrectionary army had arrived. The Neapolitan Government, probably despairing of success against GARIBALDI by legitimate means, were striving to compass their ends by treachery. It is positively asserted that a number of brigands had been dispatched to attempt his assassination. The Government troops were being concentrated at Messina, and a desperate effort would probably be made to retain that city as a new base of operations. It was reported that a proposition had been made to restore the two American steamers captured by the Neapolitans, but that the American Minister had demanded reparation for the insult to the American flag. A rumor prevailed that the Neapolitan Council proposed to grant a Constitution, a general amnesty, a change of Ministry, and a free Press, and to enter into an Italian confederation with Piedmont, but the proposition lacked the coasent of the king, who was reported to be ill. With reference to the conference of sovereigns at Baden-Baden, various rumors were afloat, but nothing definite seemed to be known as to what had been done. The most significant fact announced in this connection is the withdrawal of the French troops which, previous to the Conference had been concentrated on the Eastern borders of France. Our Italian correspondence represents Austria to be making vast military preparations in Venitia, and it is believed in some quarters that FRANCIS JOSEPH intends soon to make an effort to redeem what he has lost in Italy. The fortifications are being put in complete repair, and provisioned as for a loeg siege. Turkey is still reported in an unsettled condition. Sanguinary disturbances had taken place at various points. Advices from China are to the 6th of May. The answer from the authorities to the last communition of the Allies was to the effect that the Chinese were preparing to resist. The Prince of Wales was to embark on the 11th of July for Canada, on board the frigate St. George. The death of Prince JEROME BONAPARTE is announced.

abstract: The expectation that the Fourth of July would witness an immense crush of visitors to the Great Eastern, was realized on Wednesday -- partially. The numbers which went to see the ship are variously estimated at from thirty to forty thousand -- in steamboats, yachts and all manner of sailing craft, to look at her from the river. Multitudes also thronged the piers for the same purpose. The actual visitors, however, who paid for tickets was not over fifteen hundred, according to the best information which could be obtained on board of the ship. Acting under the instructions of the managers, the person who has charge of the registering apparatus refuses to give the number who pass in, while the person who sells the tickets shows a disposition to sell all who ask questions on that subject, leaving the reporters to count or to guess how many or how few go on board. The throngs of outside spectators continue to testify to the public interest in the great ship, and their admiration of her vast and beautiful proportions, while not one in ten thousand who wish to inspect her interior will pay a dollar for that purpose. Had the price of admission been fifty cents, ten thousand would probably have embraced the opportunity, and twice that number if it had been seasonably announced that twenty-five cents only would be charged.

abstract: All along the Hudson the glorious Fourth was celebrated in a becoming manner and so various were the amusements in the different cities and villages that all who had money to spend could take their choice as to whether they should witness a firemen's or military parade, balloon ascension, regatta, or join in an excursion or ball. In almost every town a splendid exhibition of fireworks closed the day.
lead_paragraph: All along the Hudson the glorious Fourth was celebrated in a becoming manner and so various were the amusements in the different cities and villages that all who had money to spend could take their choice as to whether they should witness a firemen's or military parade, balloon ascension, regatta, or join in an excursion or ball. In almost every town a splendid exhibition of fireworks closed the day.

abstract: The Society of St. Tammany celebrated the day by meeting in Tammany Hail, reading the Declaration of Independence, and listening to addresses. At 12...
lead_paragraph: The Society of St. Tammany celebrated the day by meeting in Tammany Hail, reading the Declaration of Independence, and listening to addresses. At 12 o'clock the enter Sacrems and Warriors, and others not belonging to the Society, in all numbering about 70, congregated in the hotel, and soon afterwards the doors of the Council Chamber were thrown open and the chiefs and friends of the Society entered. At 1 o'clock the Grand Sachem, JAMES CONNER, took the Chair, and the exercises were commenced with music by Shelton's Brass Band. The Declaration of Independence was then read by Brother JOHN T. HOFFMAN, and followed by the band playing "Hail Columbia." The address was then delivered by Hon. JOHN COCHRANE. He referred, in commencing, to the peculiar condition of political affairs in the country, and to the duty of the Society -- that duty which it had always fulfilled, of meeting in council and endeavoring to restore harmony, whenever danger threatened, in the ranks of the great Democratic Party, which was the party of the United States. That party was now divided, and it was their duty to take counsel together as to the best means of restoring harmony among the brethren. He then gave a brief sketch of the rise and progress of the party, from the time of JEFFERSON to the present, claiming that it had always been the party of the people, and the great party of freedom of the United States. The fundamental doctrine of the party had always been, that all power came from the people, and that it should remain with them. That party had been found standing in support of all the great movements for the good of the people, and, therefore, its organization must be kept intact, for he claimed that party was necessary to the successful carrying out of any great idea, and that without party organization nothing effective could be done. He had declared before that it had always been democratic doctrine -- that Sovereign power was in the people and of right belonged to the people, and while their party organization was threatened with corruption, he advised them to stand by that doctrine, and by its representative, STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, who, in accordance with the usages of the party had received the regular nomination for the Presidency of the United States. (Great applause.) He (Mr. DOUGLAS) had recognized that popular Sovereignty to which he had referred, and he had staked his fortunes upon the success of the democratic party; and therefore, as the regular nominee of the party, it was their duty there and then, to declare him worthy of their support; and that they would continue to support him until that support should culminate in complete triumph. [Applause.] In conclusion he recommended them to work for one organization, and for one man, until both should again prove successful.

abstract: The youngsters confided to the charge of the various benevolent institutions of the City, both public and private, are usually treated in some extraordinary manner on the national holiday, both out of respect to the day itself and to impress Young America with a patriotic regard for the land of their home. In general, yesterday, the "children of the City" were only treated to extra dinners, which were, no doubt, the pleasantest features of the occasion, and will probably be pleasurably borne in memory for the next twelve months.

abstract: The WEEKLY TIMES, now ready at the counter, in wrappers ready for mailing, contains a complete and accurate Narrative of the First Voyage of the Great Eastern, with scientific details of the performance of the great ship at sea, the working of her engines at sea, &c., from the pen of our Special Correspondent, "Tubal Cain." Also, an Illustrated Description of the Great Eastern, with a very large Sectional View of her Interior, and a Comparative Diagram of her Proportions, Scientific Description of her Machinery and Build, and Engineering Criticisms.
lead_paragraph: The WEEKLY TIMES, now ready at the counter, in wrappers ready for mailing, contains a complete and accurate Narrative of the First Voyage of the Great Eastern, with scientific details of the performance of the great ship at sea, the working of her engines at sea, &c., from the pen of our Special Correspondent, "Tubal Cain." abstract: This somewhat celebrated match was played on the ground of the "St. George's Club of Philadelphia," at Camac's Woods, Philadelphia, on July 3. The New-York Eleven comprised three professional players of cricket -- Hampshire, Sams and Crosley -- with Higham and Sharp as wicket-keeper and point; Wilby, Beach and Gillespie, splendid fielders; and Bray and Spivey, fine batsmen; Balliere, a good one to finish with. All of them being Englishmen, and successful cricketers. Against this strong team Germantown displayed an "Eleven American Cricketers," whose ages only averaged twenty years, and at the conclusion of the day's play the score stood -- New-York, first innings, 113 runs; Germantown, first innings, 60 runs, with a loss of seven wickets -- two of which were thrown away by the batsmen's unnecessary hurry in sending their men to the wickets, in the darkness of the twilight, just before drawing the stumps. The fielding of the young Germantown players was of the highest order. They were agile and active at all points, and but few mistakes occurred, a chance or two being given by SHARP which might have been taken, and an easy catch by SAMS, from BARCLAY, to JONES WISTER at long filed off, was dropped after getting it in his hands; this gave SAMS a new lease for twenty more runs. The bowling of KEPHARDT, F. WISTER, BARCLAY, and LARGE was first-rate, but the ground was altogether too hard and lively for the bowling to tell with great effect. NEWHALL's wicket-keeping, while at it, was very good. That ought to have been his position throughout the match. SHARP's score, comprising two threes, three twos and singles, were well got, and caught NEWHALL at long-stop. SAMS made a splendid score of 35, giving but one chance out of a four, four threes, four twos and singles, finely played for to all parts of the field. CROSLEY played well for 26 -- in which was a four, three, five twos, and singles; and SPIVEY playing steadily for 13, consisting of three twos and singles, WILBY having a bad run out. Germantown was unfortunate in losing NEWHALL by a mistake on the part of JACKSON, (the Umpire,) an American cricketer, from Amsterdam, New-York. An off ball, which he had attempted to play, but let alone, glanced from his elbow into HIGHAM's hands and he was given out; his score of 17 was marked by fine play throughout, in which were 3 3's, 3 2's and 1's; BAYARD's score of 20 numbered in it 2 3's, 5 2's and singles, and was also well played for; CADWALLADER played brilliantly for a 4, 3, 5 2's and 1's; BARCLAY made a spirited couple of 2's and 2 1's; JONES WISTER being bowled out by SAMS in the twilight, after making a fine leg hit for 3. The total at sundown was 80 runs, and on account of the English and American match coming off on the 4th and 5th of July it was agreed to make it a drawn game; and a finer one has never been played on the same ground since the All-England match last September. SAMS' bowling was very fine, and GILLESPIE's long-stopping very creditable.

abstract: The eighty-fourth Anniversary of American Independence was duly celebrated yesterday in Jersey City. At sunrise a national salute was fired by a detachment of the Hudson County Artillery at the head of Warren street. At noon a salute of thirty-three guns was fired from the foot of Morris-street, and at sunset a salute of thirteen guns in Hamilton-aquare. The Continental Guard, under command of Capt. LEIMBACK, made a parade in the forenoon.

abstract: The demand for money was active and no transactions were reported below 4 per cent. The supply was scanty. The weekly Bank statement shows an increase in bullion of  303,932.
lead_paragraph: The demand for money was active and no transactions were reported below 4 per cent. The supply was scanty. The English funds were dull, but on 22d there was a tendency towards improvement, which was checked by the pressure for money. Consols closed at 93 1/2@5/8 for account ex-dividend. The weekly Bank statement shows an increase in bullion of £303,932.

abstract: Sanguinary disturbances had taken place in Albania. The dragoman of the Austrian Consulate had been assassinated at Scutari. The Albanians, in virtue of their privileges had refused to pay the taxes, or to contribute to the conscription, both of which the Christians refused to bear alone. It was rumored that a dispatch had been received announcing the outbreak of an insurrection at Smyrna, and the assassination of public functionaries, but the correctness of this news was doubted.

abstract: Returns from the Oregon election come in slowly. Official and reported returns are received from Jackson, Josephine, Douglas, Umpqua, Lane, Benton, Linn, Marion, Moltmoneli, Clackanas, Washington, and Yarnhill counties. In all these counties the Democratic candidate for Congress received 1,032 votes, and the Republican 1,033.
lead_paragraph: Returns from the Oregon election come in slowly. Official and reported returns are received from Jackson, Josephine, Douglas, Umpqua, Lane, Benton, Linn, Marion, Moltmoneli, Clackanas, Washington, and Yarnhill counties. In all these counties the Democratic candidate for Congress received 1,032 votes, and the Republican 1,033. The counties yet to be heard from are Wasco, Polk, Curry, Coos, Columbia, Clotsop, and Tillamook, which last year cast 752 Democratic and 600 Republican votes. Material changes have taken place this year in the counties heard from, showing Republican gains on last year's vote in some cases and material Republican losses in others. Both parties are hopeful of securing the member of Congress this year. All accounts agree that such a Legislature of Republicans and Anti-Lecompton Democrats has been elected as will insure the defeat of Gen. LANE and DELAZON SMITH for reelection to the United States Senate.

abstract: The London Times was not far wrong when, in commenting on Earl GREY'S recent attack upon the political organization of the United States, it declared a loss of confidence in the institutions which it has itself deliberately adopted to be the greatest misfortune which can befall a nation; and under this affliction it solemnly pronounced America to be writhing.
lead_paragraph: The London Times was not far wrong when, in commenting on Earl GREY'S recent attack upon the political organization of the United States, it declared a loss of confidence in the institutions which it has itself deliberately adopted to be the greatest misfortune which can befall a nation; and under this affliction it solemnly pronounced America to be writhing. We endeavored to show, shortly after this opinion had been enunciated, that, whatever truth there might be in the charges made against our system of government, our material progress during the eighty-three years of our national independence was one long and splendid refutation of the allegation that the faith of the people in their laws had in the smallest degree diminished. Institutions which tempt immigrants to the tune of a million a year for three generations, to place themselves, their fortunes and their children, under their protection, under which commerce had been developed with a rapidity unknown in history, and under which enterprise bordering on rashness had become a national trait, might possibly be a failure, but nothing was more certain than that the people did not think so. Commercial caution is the characteristic of those who fear for the future. The dauntless courage which gives the wildest venture a temporary success is the product of the profoundest faith and the strongest hope. There is no test by which the confidence of a people in the political system under which they live, can be so surely ascertained as their readiness to invest their savings; and, judged by this, there is no people in the world less open to the charge of doubting the stability of their own laws than the American.

abstract: Yesterday was the day appointed by the Governor of New-Jersey for the execution of the sentence imposed upon JACOB S. HALBEN for the murder of HANNAH DORLAND HARDEN, his wife. The facts connected with the death, arrest, trial and conviction, have, in full details, been given to our readers, and it now remains for us to present the last dark picture in the tragedy, and leave the rest to be settled between the murderer and his Maker.

abstract: CARRIED OFF. -- A letter from Clifton, Ill., dated July 2, says: "JAMES, WILLIAM and Mr. KINGMAN's JOHN were taken last evening by the slave hunters. They were all at SELLER's, (a store in Clifton,) enticed there by an Ashkum man, who was bribed by the kidnappers from the South. Mr. KINGMAN's NED and FRANK's WILLIAM succeeded in getting away. My WILLIAM and Mr. KINGMAN's JOHN were taken on the spot and handcuffed. JAMES made a desperate struggle and got as far as the railroad, when one of the men threatened, to shoot if he did not stop, and he was foolish enough to do so, for, had he kept on, he might have got away; but I presume he had been stunned by the repeated blows he had received on his head by a pistol. After getting them into a wagon, the man-hunters drove to Ashkum and took the cars there. A gang of men from Clifton were at the cars when I arrived, and we all went to Ashkum; but these scamps, twenty-five in number, were all armed with pistols, and we had no arms of any kind, so it was useless to resist them. The conductor of the train showed no disposition to aid us in any way, and I hope he did not favor the slave-drivers; but it looked very much like it. The Clifton men were scattered about town, and, as it was all done so quick, they had no chance to do anything. It is hard to submit to such things, I assure you. We suspect two Irishmen of Clifton were concerned in it, and are now quite sure of it: and also, two men from Ashkum. Clifton is wide awake to-day, and these fellows will be looked to."

abstract: Early yesterday morning Officer Senior, of the Thirteenth Precinct, heard an explosion, accompanied with the crashing of glass in the provision store of Simeon Sage & Co., No. 183 Rivington-street. Suspecting burglars were at work, he obtained the assistance of several other policemen who surrounded the premises, while he looked for the place through which the rogues had effected an entrance. Presently he found the rear door had been pried open, and just as he was passing into the store he met a young fellow, named Henry Hawk, coming out. The officer at once secured him and took from him a full set of burglar's tools, consisting of a jimmy, brace and bit, saws, chisels and an assortment of lock-picks. An examination of the place showed that the explosion had been caused by the prisoner's attempt to blow off the lock of an iron safe, instead of succeeding in which he had managed to break off with the powder a corner of the safe, which was projected through the window and served to attract the attention of the Police to his operations. Hawks was taken before Justise BRENNAN yesterday, to whom he confessed his guilt. He also stated that he had been engaged in the commission of many burglaries, but never before had he taken so much pains for so little plunder -- it having cost him three hours' hard labor to force the door, and $2 in pennies being all that he had obtained up to the time of his arrest. He was committed for trial in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: Hon. JOSEPH LANE Sir: I am directed by a vote of the National Democratic Convention to inform you that you have been this day unanimously nominated by it as the candidate of the Democratic party for the office of Vice-President of the United States, and in their behalf to request you accept the same.
lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTION, BALTIMORE, Md., June 23, 1860.

abstract: A long address to the Democracy of Iowa, signed by D.A. MAHONY, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, appears in the Dubuque Herald. It reviews the causes which led to the final rupture at Baltimore, argues that national conventions cannot decide upon the construction of a Territorial doctrine, but that such questions should be left to the adjudication of the Supreme Court, and concludes with the recommendation that the Democracy of Iowa run but one electoral ticket, "in order to present an unbroken front" to the enemy.
lead_paragraph: A long address to the Democracy of Iowa, signed by D.A. MAHONY, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, appears in the Dubuque Herald. It reviews the causes which led to the final rupture at Baltimore, argues that national conventions cannot decide upon the construction of a Territorial doctrine, but that such questions should be left to the adjudication of the Supreme Court, and concludes with the recommendation that the Democracy of Iowa run but one electoral ticket, "in order to present an unbroken front" to the enemy.

abstract: The funeral of the late CHARLES B. CROMWELL, Esq., took place from his residence in this City. The sad and sudden termination of his life has cast a deep gloom over the spirits of his acquaintance. It was only the day before that he was in the full enjoyment of health and happiness, and was preparing to leave home with a party of friends on a pleasure excursion for the Summer. When, without a moment's warning, he was cut off in the midst of a life full of promise, the hope of his parents and the idol of his friends. His sudden death was occasioned by the capsizing of a sail boat on Long Island Sound.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, a resolution was adopted directing the Street Commissioner to inform the Board why the small cars are not run to Forty-second-street on the Fourth-avenue road as often as to Twenty-seventhstreets, as required by the ordinances of the Common Council. A resolution was offered and adopted requesting...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, a resolution was adopted directing the Street Commissioner to inform the Board why the small cars are not run to Forty-second-street on the Fourth-avenue road as often as to Twenty-seventhstreets, as required by the ordinances of the Common Council. A resolution was offered and adopted requesting the Comptroller to report by what authority a ferry slip is made in the Battery extension, near the foot of Whitehall-street; also, if any wharfage is received for the use of the bulkhead thereat; and if the said occupancy is authorized, what measures have been taken by him to protect the Battery from this encroachment.

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the carpenter shop owned by Gen. DAVIS, and occupied by Mr. WM. HARLOE, at the foot of Main-street, Poughkeepsie. The firemen were promptly upon the spot, but in a short time the building was enveloped in flames, and all attempts to extinguish them were abortive, and the building and its contents were entirely destroyed. The latter were very valuable, and consisted of all the furniture of the new Episcopal Church, the finished and unfinished work of three or four other large buildings, and between thirty and forty tool-chests belonging to the workmen, worth from fifty to two hundred dollars each, a house-carver's tools, and a new twelve-horse power planing and sawing machine, with a variety of other articles too numerous to mention, were also included. The damage in this shop alone will probably reach $20,000. The flames also communicated to a pile of lumber in the lumber and coal yard of DUDLEY & THOMPSON, and in a short time the whole Yard was a mass of flame. The city was as light as day. The vessels near the docks were removed and anchored in the river for greater safety. The Exchange Hotel, kept by Capt. DANIEL H. TURNER, was liable at any moment to take fire, as well as the store-house of ROSEKRANS & GAYLORD, and the lumber yard of Mr. FOSTER, but they were saved by the exertions of the firemen. All the lumber, and a large quantity of the coal was consumed, together with the new office. This loss is estimated at from eight to ten thousand dollars, upon which there was an insurance of $4,500. On the other fire the building alone was insured for $1,500, the whole of Mr. HARLOE's property not being insured. Engine No. 6 was not at the fire, as she was in this City undergoing repairs. The fire was no doubt the work of an incendiary. At one time it was thought that all the lumberyards, the hotel, the vessels, and all on the dock, would be destroyed. When the fire was at its height, a steamboat passed Poughkeepsie, and on its arriving at Rondout, the firemen of that village were apprised of the conflagration, and at once chartered the steamer Columbus, and started for Poughkeepsie to assist in extinguishing it, but it was nearly subdued when they arrived there. The names of these companies are Lackawanna Engine Company No. 1 and Protector Engine Company No. 2. The kindness of their noble act was duly felt and appreciated. At 9 o'clock the fire was so far extinguished that three or four companies retired with their engines; but in about an hour the alarm was again given, the fire having broken out afresh; but so exhausted were the firemen, that horses were procured to bring the engines back. The fire then was speedily overcome.

When the fire was at its height, a steamboat passed Poughkeepsie, and on its arriving at Rondout, the firemen of that village were apprised of the conflagration, and at once chartered the steamer Columbus, and started for Poughkeepsie to assist in extinguishing it, but it was nearly subdued when they arrived there. The names of these companies are Lackawanna Engine Company No. 1 and Protector Engine Company No. 2. The kindness of their noble act was duly felt and appreciated. At 9 o'clock the fire was so far extinguished that three or four companies retired with their engines; but in about an hour the alarm was again given, the fire having broken out afresh; but so exhausted were the firemen, that horses were procured to bring the engines back. The fire then was speedily overcome.
