abstract: These two Hoboken Clubs played an exciting game at the Elysian Fields on Friday last, when some very fine play was made, especially by the "Eagles" The "sky-scrapers" of the Mutuals, and the "let-up" in their fielding at the latter part of the game, spoiled what would have been one of the best contested games of the season, and deprived them of all the chance they had of victory. At the end of the sixth innings the runs stood: Eagle 10, Mutual 8; a very pretty game, -- but in the next innings the "Eagles" put their opponents out, and through their own good play and the Mutual's bad fielding, succeeded in scoring eight runs. The three fielders of the "Eagles" showed very finely in comparison with those of the Mutual Club, Sanger making a very difficult catch, and the others seconding his endeavors by steady play. Williams was efficient as pitcher, but the other players did not seem at home in their positions, especially Commerford and Sloat, either of whom would officiate with success as short. Sloat redeemed his otherwise bad play by remarkable catch, for which he was compelled to get over considerable ground and make a very awkward turn. McMahon played finely at left field in behalf of the Mutuals, as did Beard as catcher, which, with the good batting of Wildey, Harris and Burns, were the only favorable points in the Mutual play. Brinkerhoff and Yates batted heavily and safely for four runs each, both being credited with home runs, to one of which articles Harris, of the Mutuals, was also entitled.

abstract: A drunken chap in Louisville attempted to enter a lady's room, but was pushed down stairs by the occupant. After reaching the bottom he picked himself up and apologetically remarked  that he perceived he had made a mistake. His perceptive faculties must have been remarkably acute. It is not every one that can distinguish between a flight of fancy and a flight of stairs.

abstract: At the time of which we write nearly the whole of the Spanish Peninsula, south of the Pyrenees, was under the Moorish rule. Abderahman III, sat upon the throne of Cordova, and the season of his reign is known as the Golden Age of the Moorish Empire.
lead_paragraph: At the time of which we write nearly the whole of the Spanish Peninsula, south of the Pyrenees, was under the Moorish rule. Abderahman III, sat upon the throne of Cordova, and the season of his reign is known as the Golden Age of the Moorish Empire. The Moors were an enlightened and industrious race of people, and during their occupation of the country, agriculture, as well as the arts and sciences, flourished in a remarkable degree. In short, so far were they in advance of other European nations in general knowledge, that great numbers of Christians, of all countries, went to study in the Arabian schools of Cordova. And, furthermore, the Moors had brought with them from the Orient a thousand ideas of luxury and elegance never entertained by the Goths; so that even their social and domestic arrangements were far above those of their predecessors in point of comfort and refinement. The proximity, however, of these devoted followers of Islam to the restless and warlike knights of the Cross led to continual scenes of border strife, and to not a few romantic adventures.

abstract: John Garcia, one of the prisoners on board the bark Kate, seized a day or two since as a slaver, was brought up in the U.S. District Court, before Judge BETTS, yesterday morning, on a bench-warrant issued against him, as being Henrico de Costa, who some years since was arrested on board the brig Braman, which was seized on a similar charge. De Costa was indicted on a charge of fitting out the Braman for the Slave-trade, and while in custody of one of the Marshal's officers, named John Helmes, was allowed to go into another room to change his clothes, and took that opportunity to make his escape.

abstract: We are now informed that the young King of Naples, after vowing that he would abdicate his throne and leave his capital city at the mercy of his lazzaroni, armed and unarmed, rather than recognize the right of revolution, has been brought to terms by the echo from Vesuvius of the thunders of Etna, and that he has offered a liberal Constitution to the people whom he was lately consigning to the scaffold and the dungeon for asking it. This intelligence, brought yesterday by the Fulton, still requires confirmation; and the constitutional promises of Bourbons in despair are too well known in history to inspire any particular interest.

abstract: BUSHWICK-AVENUE IMPROVEMENT. -- The Common Council Committee on the Opening of Streets held a session in the Odeon, on Thursday evening, to hear arguments for and against the proposed improvement, under acts passed by the last Legislature, in the Eastern District. There were not more than twenty persons present. A circular was laid before the Committee estimating the first cost of the Bushwick-avenue improvement at $1,000 000, and expressing a belief that before finished it would cost twice that amount, and further stating that the taxable property of the district of assessment does not exceed $20,000,000 in value. After some desultory remarks the Committee adjourned for two weeks.
lead_paragraph: BUSHWICK-AVENUE IMPROVEMENT. -- The Common Council Committee on the Opening of Streets held a session in the Odeon, on Thursday evening, to hear arguments for and against the proposed improvement, under acts passed by the last Legislature, in the Eastern District. After some desultory remarks the Committee adjourned for two weeks.

abstract: Eighty-four years ago this day, the Anglo-American Colonies, acting by their delegates to the Congress at Philadelphia, formally renounced their allegiance to the British Crown, and declared their Independence. We are assembled, Fellow-Citizens, to commemorate the Anniversary of that great day, and the utterance of that momentous declaration. The hand that penned its mighty sentences, and the tongue which, with an eloquence that swept all before it, sustained it on the floor of the Congress, ceased from among the living at the end of half a century, on the same day, almost at the same hour, thirty-four years ago. The last survivor of the signers closed his venerable career six years later; and of the generation sufficiently advanced in life to take part in public affairs on the 4th of July, 1776, not one probably survives to hail this eighty-fourth anniversary. They are gone, but their work remains. It has grown in interest with the lapse of years, beginning already to add to its intrinsic importance those titles to respect which time confers on great events and memorable eras, as it hangs its ivy and plants its mosses on the solid structures of the past, and we have come together to bear our testimony to the Day, the Deed and the Men. We have shut up our offices, our warehouses, our workshops, we have escaped from the cares of business, may I not add from the dissensions of party, from all that occupies and all that divides us, to celebrate, to join in celebrating, the Birthday of the Nation, with one heart and with one voice. We have come for this year 1860 to do our part in fulfilling the remarkable prediction of that noble son of Massachusetts, JOHN ADAMS -- who, in the language of Mr. JEFFERSON, was "the Colossus of Independence, the pillar of its support on the floor of Congress."
lead_paragraph: Eighty-four years ago this day, the Anglo-American Colonies, acting by their delegates to the Congress at Philadelphia, formally renounced their allegiance to the British Crown, and declared their Independence. They are gone, but their work remains. abstract: George T. Finnigan and George W. Hill, indicted for an assault and battery, with intent to kill, were called up for trial. The counsel for the defendants pleaded, in abatement, that another cause against the same parties was pending in another Court, -- the Court of Sessions, -- for the same offence. By consent of the District-Attorney, the indictment in the Court of Sessions was quashed, and the case will be tried in the Oyer and Terminer, probably to-day.

abstract: The Board, at their meeting yesterday, resumed the claim of Dr. Thompson, who was examined at length, and gave a statement of the articles of household furniture which were destroyed, together with their value. Only 151 volumes of his medical library were saved, and those damaged to the amount of $100.
lead_paragraph: The Board, at their meeting yesterday, resumed the claim of Dr. Thompson, who was examined at length, and gave a statement of the articles of household furniture which were destroyed, together with their value. Only 151 volumes of his medical library were saved, and those damaged to the amount of $100. The books were of the greatest value to him on account of marginal notes of his own, and he estimated them at $2 50 a volume. The miscellaneous volumes were worth about a dollar each. Twenty-five or thirty parlor books, worth from $3 to $5 each, were also destroyed, being of the best class of books with expensive bindings. Nothing from the kitchen was saved, so far as he knew. The damage to the piano was $100. No provision was made for his residence after the fire, on which account his claim was $1,500 for rent of house in Brooklyn.

abstract: The camp ground presented a brilliant scene on Thursday evening, on the arrival of the Regiment, although the universal dampness that prevailed was a source of some regret. Through the promptness of Quartermaster WINCHESTER'S department, the heavy stores had all been forwarded, and the first thing to be done was the pitching of the tents.
lead_paragraph: The camp ground presented a brilliant scene on Thursday evening, on the arrival of the Regiment, although the universal dampness that prevailed was a source of some regret. Through the promptness of Quartermaster WINCHESTER'S department, the heavy stores had all been forwarded, and the first thing to be done was the pitching of the tents. This operation was decidedly interesting, and was performed with a facility truly surprising, when it is remembered that the drill must have been entirely theoretical. At the tap of the drum nearly two hundred tents were simultaneously raised -- like a small city springing up by magic. The hour until supper was spent in putting the interiors of the tents in order, and at 7 1/2 o'clock the Regiment, after a hard day's work, partook gladly of the evening meal.

abstract: The position of being between the upper and nether millstone has long been proverbially unpleasant. Perhaps new forms of old ideas are all that we can expect in these days. Certainly, that idea remains the same, when put into the shape of being "between a Collector and a District-Attorney," an instance of which our readers will find in our law reports this morning.
lead_paragraph: The position of being between the upper and nether millstone has long been proverbially unpleasant. Perhaps new forms of old ideas are all that we can expect in these days. Certainly, that idea remains the same, when put into the shape of being "between a Collector and a District-Attorney," an instance of which our readers will find in our law reports this morning. It seems that in January last, a him of this City imported a lot of plate-glass, of which they made entry at the Custom-house, valuing it at about $4,400. The Custom-house appraisers raised its value to upwards of $7,000. This appraisement was naturally distasteful to the importers, who appealed from it, and on a new appraisal, by merchant appraisers, it was cut down to about $5,400, and, thereupon, the Collector, in April -- for all these proceedings had taken some time -- instituted a suit to forfeit the glass for undervaluation. This suit, of course, was brought in the United States District Court. The importers, being desirous of having their goods to use in their business, applied to the District-Attorney, stating that they wished to give bonds for the value of the goods and take them, and would fix the value at either of the appraised values, as he should choose. "Oh, no," says the District-Attorney, "I don't know anything about those appraisements. You must have new appraisers appointed by the Court, under the statute, to get at the amount for which you must give bonds. So, after some further delay the new appraisers were appointed by the Court, and they fixed the value at about $4,200, being less than the invoice value. For this amount, then, the importers gave their bonds, and then went to the collector to pay him the duties, and take their goods. "Oh, no," says the collector, "I don't know anything about that Court appraisement, and I won't take your duties, nor let you have your goods, unless you give bonds to the amount of the highest of my appraisements." The importers thereupon apply to the Court to help them, but the Court says, "I have no power to give you your goods unless you furnish a certificate from the Collector that you have paid your duties, and if the Collector won't give you one, I can't make him. Your case seems to be hard, but the act has not given me the power." What is an importer to do in such a case? Certainly such an arbitrary exercise of power does not exactly consist with our republican ideas. The Collector might as well have required bonds in five times the appraised value of the goods as in the amount he did. That officers of the Government who apply to the Courts to aid them in enforcing the laws, should refuse to be governed themselves by the laws, which relate to the proceedings in Courts, and shield themselves behind the lack of power in the Courts over them, cannot but have an injurious effect upon a people too prone to avoid or refuse obedience to authority.

abstract: Ellen M. Walton vs. John Walton. -- The defendant in this case is the individual whose murder within the past few days has so startled the community. The action was commenced against him, some time since, by the plaintiff, his wife, to procure an accounting and payment of moneys alleged to have been lent to him from the proceeds of her separate estate. She claimed to have made such advances to him to an amount of $4,600 and upwards.

abstract: The match between Flora Temple and George M. Patchen, mile heats, best three in five, took place on the Suffolk Park Track, Philadelphia, on July 4, in presence of about four thousand spectators.
lead_paragraph: The match between Flora Temple and George M. Patchen, mile heats, best three in five, took place on the Suffolk Park Track, Philadelphia, on July 4, in presence of about four thousand spectators. About three hundred carriages were on the course, and considerable excitement was perceptible on the part of the great body of the spectators with whom Flora is an especial favorite in Philadelphia. The trot was to have taken place on Tuesday, but in consequence of the rain in the morning, it was postponed till the Fourth of July, although nearly twenty-five hundred people were at the course. On the morning of the trot the sun had baked the track completely hard, which was said to be in favor of Patchen, as the mare is said to be rather tender in her fore feet. The betting stood, previous to the first heat, at 100 to 80 on Patchen. Both horses looked splendidly.

abstract: A number of Democrats favoring the election of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE, met at Music Hall, No. 765 Broadway, last evening, for the purpose of organizing a Breckinridge and Lane Central Club. The meeting was organized by the election of JAMES B. BENSEL, Chairman, and THADDEUS B. GLOVER, Secretary. Committees on organization, by-laws and platform were appointed, and subsequently upon invitation, joined the Breckinridge meeting in Irving Buildings.

abstract: On Thursday night, JOSEPH MCGRAVE, an Irishman, 24 years of age, lately employed as gas-fitter by the Manhattan Gas Company, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital, where he died yesterday morning from the effects of a dose of arsenic. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body, at which it was shown that deceased was of intemperate habits, and on Thursday evening he procured a glass of beer at the porter house of PATRICK MURPHY, corner of Second-avenue and Thirty-second-street, in which he put about a table spoonfull of arsenic. After he had drank the liquor, he turned to leave the place, exclaiming "That's the last of me; I have taken poison." The paper which contained the arsenic was found on the counter by the bar-keeper. He detained MCGRAVE and sent for a Policeman, who conveyed him to the Hospital. On the way thither he gave three letters to the Officer, with the request that they should be presented to his friends if he should die. One was addressed to a young lady, to whom he was betrothed, and the other to his mother, in which he asked their forgiveness for his conduct, and left some directions as to the disposal of his personal effects.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, JOSEPH MCGRAVE, an Irishman, 24 years of age, lately employed as gas-fitter by the Manhattan Gas Company, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital, where he died yesterday morning from the effects of a dose of arsenic. abstract: By the steamship Fulton, which left Southampton on the 27th ult., and passed Cape Race on Thursday evening, we have a somewhat later dispatch than was received by the Parana, on the 27th, from Galway. The propositions of the Council of the Neapolitan Government, mentioned in the dispatch published yesterday, were said to have been accepted by the King, on certain conditions, but what these conditions are is not stated. During GARIBALDI's operations against Messina, the National Guard were to occupy the different positions at Palermo. It is stated positively that LOUIS NAPOLENON had determined not to recognize the annexation of Sicily and the Romagna to Piedmont. The Liverpool cotton market exhibited a declining tendency. Consols were quoted at 93 3/8@93 1/2 for account, ex dividend.

abstract: This action was brought to forfeit the goods for undervaluation, and came before the United States District Court, before Judge BETTS, on a motion on behalf of the claimants, for an order requiring the plaintiffs to show cause why the claimants should not be allowed to pay to the Collector of this Port the duties on the goods seized and bended in this action, in pursuance of the Act of Congress, and why the Collector should not receive payment from the claimants of the duties chargeable on said goods, to the end that the claimants might obtain a delivery of them, and why such other or further order should not be made, in order to carry out the true intent and meaning of the 89th section of the act of March 2, 1799.

abstract: Pursuant to the advice of the Corporation Counsel, Mayor WOOD declines to act under the new unsafe-building law. There are only two or three clauses of this law which relate to service by the Mayor, and those are stated by Mr. BRONSON to be at variance with the fundamental law of the land, because they direct the taking of private property in certain emergencies, in order to accomplish a primary object, without providing for compensation for the same.

abstract: Prince Albert has generally been unfortunate in those of his public appearances in which he has ventured to touch on political questions. He speaks and writes English well, and has managed to identify himself with the country and the people in a great many things, but on matters of Government he has never been able to rid himself of the old leaven of German despotism. He shoots, hunts, and dines lives ...
lead_paragraph: Prince Albert has generally been unfortunate in those of his public appearances in which he has ventured to touch on political questions. He speaks and writes English well, and has managed to identify himself with the country and the people in a great many things, but on matters of Government he has never been able to rid himself of the old leaven of German despotism. He shoots, hunts, and dines -- lives and looks very like an English gentleman -- but when he discusses politics, he talks like an Austrian Prime Minister, or a Count of the Holy Roman Empire. He gave great offence to the British public in 1854, when Crimean disasters were at their height, by informing it at a public dinner that "Constitutional Government was on its trial." As Constitutional Government had existed in England for four hundred years with great success, and had been found during the whole of that period productive of far more strength and prosperity than any other kind, and as the Prince himself owed his wife and his allowance to its triumph, this declaration of his Royal Highness' views was generally considered on the whole a still stronger indication of impudence than of bad taste. More recently HUMBOLDT's publication of the Prince's opinions upon the wrongs of the Irish and the Poles, revealing the fact that he considers neither of them have anything to complain of, have confirmed many people in the opinion that he would feel a little more at home at Vienna than at Windsor. In order, however, to remove all doubt from the public mind of the contempt which he entertains for all the most glorious traditions of English history, as well as for all the most valuable doctrines of the British Constitution, he delivered himself, at a recent dinner of the officers of the Grenadier Guards, of which he is honorary Colonel, of the following trash:

abstract: COMPLIMENTARY DINNER TO THE OFFICERS OF THE GREAT EASTERN. A complimentary dinner was given to the officers of the Great Eastern last evening, at the Lafarge House, by the proprietors of the New-York Illustrated News, at which about thirty invited guests, besides the officers of the steamer, were present.
lead_paragraph: COMPLIMENTARY DINNER TO THE OFFICERS OF THE GREAT EASTERN. -- A complimentary dinner was given to the officers of the Great Eastern last evening, at the Lafarge House, by the proprietors of the New-York Illustrated News, at which about thirty invited guests, besides the officers of the steamer, were present. Mr. GEO. S. PHILLIPS, the editor of the Illustrated, was President, and Col. DURYEA, of the Seventh Regiment, and JAS. T. BRADY, Esq., acted as Vice-Presidents. Capt. JOHN VINE HALL, Commander of the Great Eastern, sat on the right of the President, and PETER COOPER, Esq., on the left. After the removal of the cloth, toasts were drank in honor of the President of the United States, the Queen of Great Britain, the Army and the Navy, the Officers of the great ship, &c.

abstract: DEATH OF CAPT. RODGERS. -- Capt. WM. T. RODGERS, a highly esteemed citizen of Jersey City, died at his residence in Warren-street on Saturday last, in the sixty-fifth year of his age. Capt. RODGERS took part in the last war with England, and was an officer on board the United States sloop-of-war Peacock, when she captured the British brig Epervier, and for his bravery in this action he was presented with a sword from Congress. While residing in Jersey City he has occupied several positions of honor and trust, and at the time of his decease, was President of the New-Jersey Board of Pilot Commissioners. The funeral takes place this afternoon.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, as soon as it became known to the newly-organized National Democratic Volunteers that Gen. JOSEPH LANE, the candidate of the Seceders for the Vice-Presidency, on the ticket with Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, bad arrived in the City and was stopping at the St. Nicholas Hotel, that association waited upon and welcomed him in the name of the National Democrats of the City and County of New-York. When be had returned thanks for the visit, and expressed confidence in the success of the Breckinridge ticket in November next, he was informed that a committee had been appointed to entertain him with a Dinner, and that during the evening the association would be pleased to see him at their rooms, No. 751 Broadway. The General placed himself entirely in the hands of his friends, and the Volunteers retired. Later in the day the Committee on the entertainment at the hotel appeared, and the General joined them at the table. The entertainment, although not, strictly speaking, private, was not of the speech-making sort, and, therefore, nothing more need be said of it than that it was one that seemed to afford, equal pleasure to tee General and his entertainers.

abstract: The People ex rel. George Peckham vs. The Manhattan Gas-Light Company. This was a mandamus sped out to test the right of the detendants to exact a deposit before furnisaing gas to consumers.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. George Peckham vs. The Manhattan Gas-Light Company. -- This was a mandamus sped out to test the right of the detendants to exact a deposit before furnisaing gas to consumers. It appeared by the papers that the relator, George Peckham, lessee of a store in Gibson's Building, corner of Broadway and Thirteenth-street, required from, the Manhattan Gas Light Company a supply of gas for that store: The Company demanded a deposit to be made, as required by the rule adopted by them a year or two since and which has been the cause of frequent complaint. Mr. Peckham refused to make a deposit and the Company refused to supply the gas.

abstract: The inquest upon the body of the young woman who died in a cell at the Eleventh Ward Station-house on the morning of the 4th inst., was concluded yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN, and resulted in a verdict to the effect that her death had been caused by arsenic, but whether administered by herself or some other person was not ascertained. No evidence by which the identity of the deceased could be established was obtained. ELIZABETH CAVEN, a domestic at No. 351 East Tenth-street, testified that early on the morning of the 4th inst., upon opening the basement door of the house in question, she saw deceased standing in the area-way. She appeared to be under the influence of liquor, and asked for a glass of water, which was given her. She then stated that she bad come from Staten Island the evening previous, and had been taken sick while riding up town in a stage. After leaving the stage she took a glass of lemonade, which she thought must have been drugged, as it made her feel worse as soon as she drank it. She said she had friends residing either in Rose or Monroe-street -- the witness was not sure which. Dr. FINNELL testified to having made an analysis of the contents of the stomach and intestines, and finding a quantity of arsenic. The daguerreotype of a young man, which deceased had with her, may eventually lead to her identification.
lead_paragraph: The inquest upon the body of the young woman who died in a cell at the Eleventh Ward Station-house on the morning of the 4th inst., was concluded yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN, and resulted in a verdict to the effect that her death had been caused by arsenic, but whether administered by herself or some other person was not ascertained. abstract: On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building known as the Brooklyn City Mills, belonging to Messrs. SMITH, LEECH  JEWELL, which, before the flames could be extinguished, was entirely destroyed. It was situated on the corner of Fulton and Furman streets, and was 24 feet by 100 in extent. A large amount of business was done in the place, there being two engines and six run of stone.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building known as the Brooklyn City Mills, belonging to Messrs. SMITH, LEECH & JEWELL, which, before the flames could be extinguished, was entirely destroyed. It was situated on the corner of Fulton and Furman streets, and was 24 feet by 100 in extent. A large amount of business was done in the place, there being two engines and six run of stone, and work was going on day and night. On Friday night, however, there being a scarcity of grain, all hands, except HUGH MCLAUGHLIN, the watchman, left at 12 o'clock. How the fire originated is not precisely known. The watchman gave the alarm, and two ferry-boats steamed out and putting their pumps in motion threw heavy streams on the building, until the danger of being set on fire compelled them to retreat, drawing out several barges, and playing on the ferry house which was in danger of being ignited. The labors of the Fire Department were partially ineffectual, owing to the fact that the hose was imperfect and repeatedly burst. Manhattan Steam Engine Company of New-York came over, and it was chiefly through the admirable working of this machine that the new depot of the City Railroad Company on the opposite corner, which cost $30,000, was saved. The City Mills were destroyed with their contents, involving a loss, including steam engines, boilers, machinery, seven hundred barrels of flour, several thou-sand bushels of feed and grain, of about $35,000. Twenty men are thereby thrown out of employment. The insurance is as follows:

abstract: We are delighted with the prompt and man- ly frankness of Archbishop HUGHES in confess- ing his faults and tendering an apology for acts of injustice.
lead_paragraph: We are delighted with the prompt and man- ly frankness of Archbishop HUGHES in confess- ing his faults and tendering an apology for acts of injustice. In a note published a few days since he accused the City Inspector of having suppressed a portion of the correspondence which had taken place between them, concerning a State law which the Archbishop declared his purpose to disregard. He has found out his mistake and makes public amends. "It might be a humiliation to some," the Archbishop says, "but to me it is only an act of justice" to confess that Mr. DELAVAN has been "entirely right and I have been entirely wrong." He offers a candid apology, and the expression of his regret for the injustice he has done him.

abstract: The public will not be surprised at the announcement of the Directors of the Great Eastern that the price of admission to the steamer has been reduced one-half -- that is, to fifty cents for adults, and for children half price. This arrangement goes into effect to-day, and cannot fail to largely increase the number of visitors. The entire management of the exhibition has been placed in the hands of a gentleman who, it is said, possesses peculiar qualifications for the business, and it is expected that arrangements will be made with the various railroad and steamboat lines to run excursion trains at reduced rates for the accommodation of the people in neighboring cities and towns. It is intimated also, that when she has been sufficiently shown as a curiosity, the ship will make a two day's excursion to some point on the coast. This, however, would involve a heavy-expenditure, not the least of which would be the insurance on the ship, and it is doubtful whether a sufficient number of persons -- at a large price -- could be obtained to render the trip remunerative.

abstract: Francis Hoffman, late treasurer of the Pacific Mali Steamship Company, who is alleged to have absconded several months since, after having overissued the Company's stock to a very considerable amount, was brought back to this City on Saturday from Utica, near which place he had been apprehended by Special Railroad Detective Hugh Masterson. Hoffman was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, by whom he was temporarily committed to prison. His examination is fixed for next Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock. The complainants have not as yet prepared their affidavits against the prisoner, but it is said that he was arrested upon a warrant charging him with having committed forgery.
lead_paragraph: Francis Hoffman, late treasurer of the Pacific Mali Steamship Company, who is alleged to have absconded several months since, after having overissued the Company's stock to a very considerable amount, was brought back to this City on Saturday from Utica, near which place he had been apprehended by Special Railroad Detective Hugh Masterson. abstract: GENTLEMEN: I have the honor to acknowledge your note of invitation to address the Democratic meeting on Monday night. I regret my inability, proved on the last occasion when I made the experiment, to speak in the open air; but so it is, and I must content myself with this mode of expressing my earnest sympathy in the cause of the National Democracy, and its Candidate, Mr. BRECKINRIDGE.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 30, 1860.

abstract: It is not astonishing that the recent murder of two citizens of New-York, in the open street, and at a comparatively early hour of the night, accompanied as it threatens now to be by the successful escape of the murderer, should have shocked our community with a fresh sense of the insecurity of life in the Metropolis, or that it should have provoked a great deal of angry comment on the inefficiency of our Police system. Certainly, if any one had asserted, ten days ago, that on a bright Summer's night, in a populous quarter of this great City, a man could lie in wait for his enemy, perhaps for hours, assail him on his approach, shoot him down at the side of a friend, and within sight of the opened windows of a whole block of inhabited houses, take to his heels, and after a hot but brief pursuit escape by the further murder of his most determined and swiftest pursuer, the assertion would have been resented as an absurd slander upon our social organization. The story of Mr. WALTON's murder seems to belong to the woods of the West rather than to the highways of one of the largest cities in the world. It is a repetition, under new and even more alarming conditions, of the "Bond-street tragedy," which so shocked and startled us three years ago. As the one seemed to prove that New-York, with all her wealth and power, was unable to protect a man in his own home against private vengeance or mercenary assassination, so the other appears to show that the vendetta may range our streets and lurk in the corners of our public places, as freely and as victoriously as in the mountain highways of Corsica.

abstract: We publish this morning details of the Mexican news relative to the capture of MIRAMON and the movements of VIDAURRI, in Coahuila- a brief telegraphic report of which reached us from New-Orleans a few days since.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning details of the Mexican news relative to the capture of MIRAMON and the movements of VIDAURRI, in Coahuila -- a brief telegraphic report of which reached us from New-Orleans a few days since. These details need confirmation, yet, in the main, we are inclined to believe they will prove correct The Liberal army in the interior has of late gained many advantages which have added to their determination and prestige, while their opponents have met with a variety of reverses and become greatly demoralized. The capture of MIRAMON and the total rout of his forces at Salamanca by the Liberals, under Gen. ZARAGOZA, are not improbabilities. We anxiously await advices confirming these important events.

abstract: Three young men connected with the Brooklyn Yacht Club yesterday narrowly escaped drowning by the capsizing of a small boat in which they were attempting to effect a landing from the yacht Wild Wave at the camp grounds on the south side of Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Three young men connected with the Brooklyn Yacht Club yesterday narrowly escaped drowning by the capsizing of a small boat in which they were attempting to effect a landing from the yacht Wild Wave at the camp grounds on the south side of Staten Island. The wind and waves were very high at the time, and when within about fifty yards of the beach the boat swamped.

abstract: Some months ago the Chicago Zouaves issued a manifesto declaring themselves the best organized and drilled military company in the country, and challenging any other organization to dispute their claims  to this preeminence.
lead_paragraph: Some months ago the Chicago Zouaves issued a manifesto declaring themselves the best organized and drilled military company in the country, and challenging any other organization to dispute their claims to this preeminence. To establish their reputation be yond the possibility of disparagement they also announced that they would undertake an Eastern tour during the present Summer. They started on this trip on July 2, and have probably by this time reached Rochester.

abstract: It is well-known that for about a week previous to the departure of the last Vanderbilt steamer, Postmaster-General HOLT was in almost constant telegraphic communication with Mr. VANDERBILT on the subject of the Pacific mails--Mr. HOLT making earnest appeals to him to take them and rely on the justice of the Government to make a fair compensation for the service over and above the postages.
lead_paragraph: It is well-known that for about a week previous to the departure of the last Vanderbilt steamer, Postmaster-General HOLT was in almost constant telegraphic communication with Mr. VANDERBILT on the subject of the Pacific mails -- Mr. HOLT making earnest appeals to him to take them and rely on the justice of the Government to make a fair compensation for the service over and above the postages. These appeals were also backed by Mr. BUCHANAN, who, it was repeatedly stated, was very anxious that the mails should go out as usual, and who pledged himself to make the -proper recommendation to Congress for the extra compensation. These missives were regularly sent, it is presumed, by Mr. ALLEN to Mr. VANDERBILT, who steadfastly refused to allow any mail matter whatever to go on board. It is said that Mr. VANDERBILT joined with the Pacific Mail Company in two propositions, viz.: one, to transport the mails for a fixed sum, say, $300,000 for the steamship service; the other, to receive the postages on the letters, and twenty-five cents a pound for the printed and free matter, but, in the absence of any law, the Department could not act. It is said that 98 per cent. of the mail matter last year consisted of papers and free documents, and that for this large proportion of the entire Pacific mail, only $30,000 was received by the Post-office Department. On account of the regulation requiring all letters to be sent by the overland mail which are not specially directed to go by steamer, a large proportion of letters have gone that way, leaving the heaviest and least profitable part to go by the Isthmus. The overland letter mail is also somewhat increased by a dodge which large numbers have adopted of sending their letters to St. Louis to be re-mailed, thus making the postage six instead of ten cents The Post-office Department has now arranged with VANDERBILT, probably on his own terms for the transportation of the Pacific mails tri-monthly, the service to begin on the 11th of July and continue to the 4th of March next, the condensation to be the postages and the said 25 cents a pound for printed and free matter, which he is to receive upon the recommendation of the Post-office Department, provided Congress are then ready to make the appropriation.

abstract: James Carrol, convicted of arson in the first degree, was brought up on Saturday for sentence.  District Attorney moved for judgment in this case. The prisoner was, therefore, sentenced to hard labor in the State Prison at Sing Sing for the term of his natural life.

abstract: Judge CAMPBELL, of the Supreme Court, delivered on the 30th, in Mobile, an elaborate opinion in the case of the United States vs. R.H. Home, under an indictment for a violation of the act against the African Slave-trade, ordering "that process issue to the Marshals of the State of Mississippi, as well as to the Marshal of this (Alabama) district, for the arrest of the accused." The Tribune publishing the opinion in full, says: "Upon the call of the case, A.J. REQUIER, Esq., U.S. Attorney, moved the Court for alias process against the defendant, but, in doing so, called the attention of the Court to the fact that precisely similar indictments against other offenders have been heretofore held unwarranted by the law under which they were preferred, by Hon. WILLIAM E. JOMES, Judge of the U.S. District Court, The United States Attorney requested the presiding Judge to take the matter under advisement, and if he should agree with his associate, Judge JONES, he wished to be understood as not pressing his motion, but, if not, be asked that, the motion might be granted. The opinion, which we publish, was delivered under these circumstances, and those members of the legal profession who heard it, concede it one of the ablest that have been delivered by its distinguished author."

abstract: On Wednesday next a grand entertainment will be given at the Academy of Music in behalf of the heroic struggle which Sicily is now making, under the command of GARIBALDI, for liberty and independence.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday next a grand entertainment will be given at the Academy of Music in behalf of the heroic struggle which Sicily is now making, under the command of GARIBALDI, for liberty and independence. It is a matter of some importance, no doubt, to Sicily and the Sicilians, that the receipts on this occasion should be large, and that the hand as well as the heart of New-York should be opened to the call of freedom in the Old World. But it is a matter of still greater importance to New-York herself that in this brave battle of free principles and popular right with the mo??? cruel and the blindest of despotisms, the American people should not be found indifferent to the sufferings and the struggle of a noble sister nation. As Mr. BUCHANAN very aptly and gracefully acknowledged on Wednesday last, in receiving the new Minister of France at Washington, our Independence Day recalls not only the gallantry of our fathers, but the sympathy also, warm, practical and all-important, which they met with in the hour of their trial, from foreign States. It may seem, perhaps, not a little strange to the future historian of our times, that while the Court of Louis XVI. should have sent its Lafayettes from the gilded circle of the OEil de boeuf, to flesh their swords in defence of the liberties of a knot of revolted English colonies, the opulent American Republic of 1860 should have furnished no volunteers to the toils and the triumphs of Italian independence. Certainly the enthusiasts of Democracy can hardly have looked for so total an abstinence from practical Quixotism among the youth of a nation which rejoices to believe itself the destined apostle of popular progress throughout the world; and it would do us no harm in respect either of our reputation abroad or of our self-respect at home, to see the American theory maintained in the face of Neapolitan bullets and Papal bayonets by a few chivalric scions of the Revolutionary stock.

abstract: The Church of the Puritans was filled last evening to listen to a sermon from Dr. CHEEVER, on the occasion of his taking leave of absence for a visit to Europe. The text was 2d Corinthians, 10th chapter and 4th verse: "For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strongholds." He said: "The phrase �not carnal� comprehends all that a carnal policy might and would resort to, irrespective of God�s word. It comprehends not merely the employment of violent methods -- not merely swords and revolvers, and all the implements and stratagems of war, but political intrigues, parties, combinations of ambition and wealth, Satanic expediencies, bribes, and all the methods of influence and strength that men resort to whose dependence is not on God -- not on divine truth -- but who, on the whole, are under the guidance of the carnal mind, which is enmity against God. The strongholds we are to attack are those of sin and Satan. They are to be assaulted and carried by the word of truth, by the power of God, by the armor of righteousness on the right hand and on the left." He went on to explain the ground which the Church of the Puritans has taken on the Slavery question, and the treatment which they had received at the hands of the Churches, the ministers and religious newspapers. The Church should take high ground in antagonism to all systems of organized iniquity. They should be met with organized opposition. When WASHINGTON drove the British troops out of Boston, he did it by taking and fortifying Dorchester Heights, overlooking the city. He was not strong enough to meet the enemy on their ground, or to undertake any assault from their level. The whole army must take position for an annihilating bombardment, otherwise it would have been useless for each man to have played the hero with his own gun, or even for all of them together to have attacked the enemy on their own level. The Church of the Puritans had taken the position that slaveholding, under all circumstances, was sinful, and that no slaveholder ought to be admitted to the Christian Church. The slaveholder he compared to the murderer, the thief, the drunkard or adulterer, about which character there was no dispute as to their fitness for membership of the Church. He would as soon talk of admitting Christian polygamists or Christian idolators as Christian slaveholders.

abstract: A new programme for the Mormons is indicated in our Washington dispatches. It is now proposed that they shall emigrate to one of the East India Islands, and reliable information is said to have been received that they will do so.
lead_paragraph: A new programme for the Mormons is indicated in our Washington dispatches. It is now proposed that they shall emigrate to one of the East India Islands, and reliable information is said to have been received that they will do so. The enterprise is to be carried out under the supervision of Capt. WALTER M. GIBSON, who will be remembered as having been imprisoned for some years by the Dutch authorities of one of the islands in question, and who has recently identified himself with the Mormon cause -- it being at his suggestion that BRIGHAM YOUNG proposed to the Government to take the Mormons to Oceanica, if an arrangement could be made by which they could be paid by Government for their improvements in Utah.

abstract: If the Pope does not speedily provide better accommodations for his Irish Volunteers, and favor them with some excitement, there is great danger of their going over bodily to GARIBALDI.
lead_paragraph: If the Pope does not speedily provide better accommodations for his Irish Volunteers, and favor them with some excitement, there is great danger of their going over bodily to GARIBALDI. By the last accounts, one of the bands of recruits have had a glorious fight amongst themselves, and when the gendarmes interfered, they turned upon them and gave them a thorough thrashing in the old time-honored fashion. Then the rations served out to them, however acceptable they might be to Catholics of more Southern latitudes, appear to be very much too light for stomachs trained to their work in Tipperary. To cap the climax, the Roman brigands, moved by the instigation of the devil, and not having in their hearts the smallest respect for piety, virtue and devotion to the Holy See, have fallen upon some of the Irish officers and the chaplain of the brigade, and, according to one account, coming from a Saxon source, left them upon the roadside in a state of nature. So that, on the whole, neither Italy nor the Italians, nor the Papal service, appear to be very satisfactory to the "emigrants;" and if the Liberal Party avoid exasperating them, we should not be at all surprised to see the whole Irish force doing good service before the close of the war under the tri-colored flag. They have gone to Italy to fight, and we have no doubt are bent on fighting somebody before they come home; but it must be remembered they belong to a race intensely sympathetic and susceptible, and we doubt very much whether their enthusiasm for His Holiness would long survive contact and intercourse with the masses of his subjects whose trials they will of course witness, and whose sufferings they will soon learn to pity.
headline: {'main': "The Pope's Irish Recruits.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Pope's Irish Recruits.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The fifth annual Cricket match between the above nationalities was played at Camden, near Philadelphia, on the 4th and 5th of July, and after a brilliant contest in presence of the largest number of spectators which has ever assembled on the ground of the Philadelphia Club, victory rewarded the exertions of the American Cricketers for the first time in five years, who beat their opponents, with eight wickets to spare.
lead_paragraph: The fifth annual Cricket match between the above nationalities was played at Camden, near Philadelphia, on the 4th and 5th of July, and after a brilliant contest in presence of the largest number of spectators which has ever assembled on the ground of the Philadelphia Club, victory rewarded the exertions of the American Cricketers for the first time in five years, who beat their opponents, with eight wickets to spare. The majority of the English players are so well known -- several of them having played against the Americans in their annual matches year after year -- that it is needless to comment on their style of play, and we refer to the score for their names and the result of their doings. For the new players who were selected by the English Committee to secure the supremacy of Cricket in their hands: first on the list, and the supposed great gun of the Eleven, was Sadler, who first made his appearance at Montreal last September as an All-England player, but who, for some reason, did not remain at Montreal while the match was being played, nor did he play in the subsequent International Matches, or accompany "The Eleven" on their tour. Second, is Mr. Brett, St. George's newly-imported English cricketer -- a splendid cricketer at all points of the game. Third, is "Sams," renowned as one of the finest cricketers of the United States. Hampshire is fourth, and a first-rate imported English cricketer at that; the last two being professionals of the New-York Club. Mr. Gibbes, who is so well Known as the first gentleman cricketer in the country, as well as Mr. Brett, played contrary to the expressed opinion of the St. George's Club, who refused, at the Cricketers' Convention, to be a party any longer to national matches, where every newly-imported professional cricketer was brought against American amateurs. Hallis is the professional of the Newark Club, and Barlow is the only Philadelphia English cricketer, and one of their best, his long-stopping being perfection. Thus, six of the Eleven -- two of them professionals -- were from the New-York Club, two from St. George, one from Kings County, one from Newark, and one from Philadelphia.

abstract: The Cunard screw steamship AEtna, already telegraphed from St. John's, and the United States Mail steamship Fulton, telegraphed from Cape Race, arrived at this port yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard screw steamship AEtna, already telegraphed from St. John's, and the United States Mail steamship Fulton, telegraphed from Cape Race, arrived at this port yesterday. Our European files and correspondence received by these vessels are of four days' later date; and a telegram from Quebec, announcing the arrival there of the Palestine, with one day's later news, brings our intelligence from London and Liver, pool down to the 28th ult. The Sicilian insurrection is still the predominant subject of exciting interest. It is not believed that it will be confined to Sicily, and the general impression is that the King's promised Constitution has been offered too late to save him from destruction. A well-founded rumor was current that he had sanctioned a design to assassinate Garibaldi; if so, he wouls probably have to forfeit more, in the end, than his throne.

abstract: To-day at 11 o'clock A.M. Mr. SABIN, the auc-tioneer, will dispose at public vendue of all the theatrical wardrobe, stage properties, dramatic music, and manuscript plays of the late WM. E. BURTON. Here is a sale, indeed, over which the melancholy Jacques might moralize by the hour. When Dr. JOHNSON advertised THRALE's brewery he would not call it a brewery, but rather the "possibility of growing indefinitely rich," for in that brewery he sold the whole future of beer-making men in a beer-drinking state. Could Mr. SABIN sell with these "shreds and patches" the past of which they are so eloquent, what prices might they not command: The catalogue of them, as we turn the leaves, seems to ring the knell of so many bright and flashing scenes, so many cheery and pleasant hours slipped now forever into the irrecoverable void. Here is Bottom's dress, his "complete dress, including fine wig of natural hair, ass's head, &c." Ah! that "&c.," there's the rub! Did it but cover all the humor, all the sense, all the rich Shakes-perian wit that once shone on us from these "cheap integuments," what actor would not hasten to buy them to be "transfigured." Turn the leaves again. If you buy in this lot, No. 3, will you buy the "Toodles" that we knew? His "coat, vest, black silk tights, gaiters, his two hats, neck cloth and cane;" these you may buy, indeed -- but alas! will you make as good a bargain of it as poor Mrs. Toodles did of her door-plate? For the future Miss Toodles a possible "Thompson with a p" slept in the decrees of fate! but what magic shall make this "coat and vest," these "two hats," this "cane," the things they were when first they reeled into the warmest corner of your memory ? Bumble, Autolycus, Aminadab Sleek, Sir Oliver Surface, Sir Toby Belch, here they all are, the shells of them, but "where be their gibes now, their gambols, their songs, their flashes of merriment?" Truly, Mr. SABIN, it is not a very merry office you are to fill to-day.

abstract: The accounts of the civil war in Syria, between the Christians and the Druses, which have reached us so far, are somewhat confused as to the origin of the quarrel, but they agree in representing it to be very bloody, and to have resulted thus far in the defeat and massacre of large numbers of the Christians.
lead_paragraph: The accounts of the civil war in Syria, between the Christians and the Druses, which have reached us so far, are somewhat confused as to the origin of the quarrel, but they agree in representing it to be very bloody, and to have resulted thus far in the defeat and massacre of large numbers of the Christians. A row between Syrian mountaineers, even when it involves the cutting of a good many throats, is very much too common an occurrence to make it very serious to anybody but the combatants; but the share the Turkish authorities are represented to have borne in the present outbreak, gives it an aspect of considerable gravity.

abstract: The adjourned sailing match of the 4th July Corporation Regatta, which was under the direction of the New-York Regatta Club, took place on Monday afternoon. Eleven working boats entered, of various lengths, from 19 1/2 feet to 17 feet, with no allowance of time for length. The course was from the Batten' to Bedlow's Island, turning from the southward to northward and back, a distance of five miles. The wind was from the west-southwest, which gave the boats a dead-beat to windward before turning Bedlow's Island, and the regulation, that the race was to be accomplished without oars or rudder, was the more interesting. The modus operandi by which this used to be done in old times, was that the boatman trimmed his boat on an even keel, and laid his course by sitting in the centre of his boat, and if he wished to keep his boat off he shifted his position a little aft; or, if he desired to sail near the wind, he shifted his position a little forward; in going about, head to wind, he, we suppose, gave a rap full and got good headway, and keeping the sheet in hand, jumped forward, by which he brought her head to the wind, letting go the sheet and hauling to windward as much of the foot of the sail as he could get held of by the foot rope, letting her head pay off, and then hauling taut the sheet, lay her course until required to go about again. In sailing with the wind free, trimming the boat by the head brought her to the wind; and trimming her by the stern payed her oft. Thus, wonderful as it appeared at the first blush to tyros in yachting, it was simple enough in practice to those who "knew the ropes" The start was a very pretty sight. The Julia led, but was upset on nearing the Battery on coming home, as was also the Jersey. A stiff breeze was blowing, and there was a rolling sea, which nearly swamped several of the boats. For so small a craft the second boat made an excellent race of it. The whole affair reflected credit on the management. The following is a list of the boats land the winners:

abstract: THE CORNER-STONE OF ST. PAUL'S LUTHERAN CHURCH LAID -- The ceremony of laying the corner stone of St. Paul's Lutheran Church, at the corner of Sixth-avenue and Fifteenth-street, took place yesterday. The Church was originally organized in. 1840, in a small brick building, but the members of its congregation have so largely increased that the handsome and commodious structure now in course of erection was rendered necessary. The ceremonies yesterday were of the usual interesting order, including prayer, singing of hymns, and addresses both in the English and German languages. In the box inclosed in the corner-stone were deposited specimen numbers of on the United States coins now current in the country, a copy of the Augsburg Confession, another of the Lutheran Litany, a condensed history of the Lutheran Church on parchment, and copies of the Bible in German, and the German Hymn Book, together with the newspapers of the day, both German and American. The new building will be fifty feet wide on Sixth-avenue by eighty feet deep on Fifteenth-street. It is designed to accommodate fifteen hundred persons. The total cost, exclusive of the ground on which it is built, will be $25,000.

abstract: Great interest is felt in certain circles of the City as to the upshot of a difficulty which threatens very serious results. On the evening of the 5th inst., two men, prominently connected with the City Government, accompanied by a third man, invited two ladies of good character and repute to take a sail in a small yacht owned by one of the City Government officials. The invitation was accepted without fear, and the party started for a cruise; but it would seem that the two officials entertained designs of an improper character against the ladies; and about 11 o'clock that night -- the yacht being opposite Randall's Island -- loud screams were heard proceeding from on board of her, and finally the two ladies were put ashore on the Island -- the yacht sailing rapidly away.

abstract: projector of the splendid line of steamships, which ran to Liverpool a few years ago, has received his pay in full, and his account with Government is closed. On the last day of the session of Congress, the Post-office Deficiency bill passed, and in it was a Section directing the Secretary of the Navy to pay to Mr. COLLINS the sum of $80,282 72, being the balance, with interest, due to him on account of money withheld. A draft for this sum has been sent to Mr. COL LINS. -- Nat. Int.

abstract: By the steamer Palestine, which arrived yesterday at Quebec, we are informed of the death "of Mr. ROBERT BROUGH, at the early age of 32 years. His name is familiar to readers en this side of the Atlantic, more than are his acknowledged works, although by his contributions to Punch, and comic periodicals of England of lesser note, he has been favorably noticed here on many occasions, and many of his productions have beer, reprinted here. He was a native of London", but at an early age was removed to monmouth, Wales, where his father opened: a brewery While young BROUGH was yet a boy, the Chartist outbreak headed by FROST, JONES and WILLIAMS occurred in which the elder BROUGH became involved, necessarily taking part with the Government a circumstance which nearly ruined him, as the people Monmouthshire would drink no more of his beer ROBERT BRCUOH, the son had then to shift for himself and tried his hand at portrait painting but finding that he had mistaken his vocation, attempted literature. In that he was more successful, though he never evinced the possession of powers which promised great fame and excellence. He first started as the editor of the Liverpool Lion, a comic bantling, which had a very brief existence; thence went to London, where, in conjunction with AIBEET SMITH and ANOGUS B. REACH (both of whom are lately deceased,) he wrote several farces and novelettes: edited the Comic Almanac", translated several of the songs of VICTOR HUGO and BERANGER, and wrote a History pf Sir John Falstaff, which the celebrated artist, GYORGR CEUIKSHANK, profusely illustrated. Since, in connection with his brother, he has writter many farces, interludes and librettos, and same of the most popular of these have had their run in this and ether American cities, as the works "of the brothers BROUGH." Mr. BROUGH was much esteemed in the literary world of London, and his death, following so soon after his friends SMITH, REACH and DOUGLAS JERROLD, will be severely felt by surriving friends.
lead_paragraph: By the steamer Palestine, which arrived yesterday at Quebec, we are informed of the death "of Mr. ROBERT BROUGH, at the early age of 32 years. His name is familiar to readers en this side of the Atlantic, more than are his acknowledged works, although by his contributions to Punch, and comic periodicals of England of lesser note, he has been favorably noticed here on many occasions, and many of his productions have beer, reprinted here. He was a native of London", but at an early age was removed to monmouth, Wales, where his father opened: a brewery While young BROUGH was yet a boy, the Chartist outbreak headed by FROST, JONES and WILLIAMS occurred in which the elder BROUGH became involved, necessarily taking part with the Government a circumstance which nearly ruined him, as the people Monmouthshire would drink no more of his beer ROBERT BRCUOH, the son had then to shift for himself and tried his hand at portrait painting but finding that he had mistaken his vocation, attempted literature. In that he was more successful, though he never evinced the possession of powers which promised great fame and excellence. He first started as the editor of the Liverpool Lion, a comic bantling, which had a very brief existence; thence went to London, where, in conjunction with AIBEET SMITH and ANOGUS B. REACH (both of whom are lately deceased,) he wrote several farces and novelettes: edited the Comic Almanac", translated several of the songs of VICTOR HUGO and BERANGER, and wrote a History pf Sir John Falstaff, which the celebrated artist, GYORGR CEUIKSHANK, profusely illustrated. Since, in connection with his brother, he has writter many farces, interludes and librettos, and same of the most popular of these have had their run in this and ether American cities, as the works "of the brothers BROUGH." Mr. BROUGH was much esteemed in the literary world of London, and his death, following so soon after his friends SMITH, REACH and DOUGLAS JERROLD, will be severely felt by surriving friends.

abstract: Yesterday morning an organization known as the Barry Musketeers, composed of young men from the Fourth and Sixth Wards, and named after the Alderman, of that District, went on a pic-nic to Bidle's Grove. S.I. On the grounds a dispute arose between JOHN PHEELAN, a member of Hose Company No. 10, residing at No. 3 Dover-street, and MICHAEL WELSH, a character well known to the Police of the Fourth Ward, in the progress of which PHEELAN was stabbed by his opponent three times, once in the groin and twice in the chest. The sufferer was immediately sent back to the City by special conveyance and placed under the care of Dr. BELL, at the City Hospital, who has not the least hope of his recovery. The police were informed of the occurrence, and a piatoon of men, under the command of Sergeant WILLIAMS, awaited the arrival of the boat in the evening at Peck-slip, having the excursionists on board. As she approached the dock the officers were observed, and the friends of WELSH, anticipating their object, succeeded in concealing him by creating confusion on board. Subsequently he was traced to a house in Roosevelt-street, where the officers found him; but he a second time escaped by extinguishing the lights in the room. The police, however, have little doubt of eventually effecting his arrest.

abstract: A recent law relating to unsafe buildings calls upon the Mayor to perform a certain ministerial act in order to perfect its provisions. Mayor WOOD having a holy horror of legislative acts not passed for his benefit, and worshiping the Constitution with the zeal of a devotee, when, it meets his views, obtains an opinion from the Corporation Counsel that the law in question is unconstitutional, and thereupon he refuses to obey its provisions. In this he is consistent -- following his old course upon the Liquor and Police laws.
lead_paragraph: A recent law relating to unsafe buildings calls upon the Mayor to perform a certain ministerial act in order to perfect its provisions. Mayor WOOD having a holy horror of legislative acts not passed for his benefit, and worshiping the Constitution with the zeal of a devotee, when, it meets his views, obtains an opinion from the Corporation Counsel that the law in question is unconstitutional, and thereupon he refuses to obey its provisions. In this he is consistent -- following his old course upon the Liquor and Police laws.

abstract: LARGE FIRE IN ULSTER COUNTY. -- One of the largest fires ever witnessed in Ulster County, occurred a few nights since, in the town of Rosendale, in that county, when the whole of the Lawrenceville Cement Works were entirely destroyed. The fire was first discovered in a small shed adjoining the main building. The flames spread rapidly, and in a short time all efforts to extinguish them were of no avail. The main building was utterly consumed, together with its contents, and several smaller buildings adjoining were destroyed A canal boat, loaded with 600 barrels of cement, was removed just in time to escape destruction. The machinery, tools, a large quantity of cement, and other articles, were also lost. The damage is estimated at $40,000, of which there was an insurance of only $5,000 upon the buildings. The other property was an entire loss, there being no insurance upon it. A large number of men have been thrown out of employment. The fire is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary.
lead_paragraph: LARGE FIRE IN ULSTER COUNTY. -- One of the largest fires ever witnessed in Ulster County, occurred a few nights since, in the town of Rosendale, in that county, when the whole of the Lawrenceville Cement Works were entirely destroyed. abstract: SUPPOSED DEATH FROM VIOLENCE IN ATTEMPTING TO COMMIT AN OUTRAGE. -- Coroner GAFFNEY, of Jersey City, was called upon yesterday morning to hold an inquest upon the body of a woman named ALICE MCGEE, residing in Railroad-avenue near Cole street, who died suddenly on Sunday evening, under circumstances which lead to the supposition that her death was the result of violence On Saturday last Officer MCLOUGHLIN, of the Third Ward, met deceased in front of her house, and observing contusions on one side of her face, asked what the matter was. Mrs. MCGEE said that on Thursday evening last, while lying asleep on her bed; she was suddenly awakened, and discovered that a man named JAMES GRAY had entered her room, and was attempting to violate her person. Being an athletic woman, she threw him off, when a violent struggle followed, and she finally succeeded in ejecting GRAY from the room.

abstract: FREDERICK HOFFMAN, whose arrest at Utica by detectives from this City, has already been noticed, is to have his preliminary examination this morning at the Police Court at Jefferson Market His case is curious and excites a good deal of interest. HOFFMAN is a native of this City, and about 30 years of age. He is a son of one of our oldest and most worthy citizens, Mr. ANTHONY HOFFMAN, who died some years since, leaving an honorable name and reputation to his family of six sons and two daughters. Mr. HOFFMAN was for many years of the well-known firm of HOFFMAN & VAN BUREN, and few steamboat men will be unable to recall his portly form and genial smile. Of the six sons whom he left, all have filled positions of influence and respectability. Two are lawyers; one is a teller at the Mechanics' Bank; AUGUSTUS was until the first of this month "transfer clerk" with the Panama Railroad Company; and FREDERICK was, until his sudden flight, occupying a similar position with the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

abstract: most painful occurrences it has been our duty to chronicle in many a day took place. Mr. EDMOND ARMAND, a gentleman of the first social circle of our Creole families, came to his death by suicide. It appears that Mr. ARMAND had been suffering from an opthalmia complaint for some time, which recently had been aggravated by temporary derangement of the nervous system. This morning, at the hour above named, as he was sitting on the front balcony of his house, on the corner of St. Ann and Bourbon streets, he called his valet, VICTOR, and ordered him to bring a cup of tea. The servant proceeded to obtain the tea, leaving his master alone on the balcony. At this hour Corporal FAGOT and two watchmen were passing, and their attention was attracted to the balcony by cries in the French language of "Help! help! I am lost! My God, what have I done! VICTOR, run for a doctor!" The policemen then heard the noise of a fall on the balcony. They immediately entered the house, and found the unfortunate gentleman prostrate, with Ms throat cut from ear to ear. They then sent for Dr. VIONET, and by the directions of the valet removed the body to a room, and when the Doctor came, he saw there was but a moment longer for the struggles of the unhappy gentleman to close his sad death; and the Doctor was true in his statements, for Mr. ARMAND died but a minute after. At 2 1/2 o'clock this morning the Coroner was called up to hold the inquest, and did so, the Jury rendering a verdict of "Death by suicide." The body was then conveyed to deceased's plantation, in St. James' Parish, whence it will be buried -- New-Orleans Delta. July 4.

abstract: The opinion avowed by THEODORE PARKER, in the letter which we published yesterday, preferring a constitutional monarchy like that of Great Britain to a republic like ours, does not, after all, indicate nearly as much as it seems to indicate, as he evidently, in company with Earl GREY and others, overlooked a fact of considerable importance in the controversy now raging as to the comparative merits of the institutions of the two countries.

abstract: The parade in London of some twenty or thirty thousand British Volunteers, who actually contrived to manoeuvre before the Queen without doing any more damage than frightening a Cabinet Minister off his horse, and who solved the Duke of WELLINGTON'S famous military problem of marching themselves in and out of Hyde Park without breaking down the fences, has evidently turned the heads of our respectable cousins over the sea.
lead_paragraph: The parade in London of some twenty or thirty thousand British Volunteers, who actually contrived to manoeuvre before the Queen without doing any more damage than frightening a Cabinet Minister off his horse, and who solved the Duke of WELLINGTON's famous military problem of marching themselves in and out of Hyde Park without breaking down the fences, has evidently turned the heads of our respectable cousins over the sea. On Friday morning, the 22d June, England, if we are to believe the English Press, was by no means sure that she could defend herself on her own soil against the attack of any daring and well disciplined foe. On Saturday evening, the 23d, England felt quite equal not only to the task of protecting her own kitchen-gardens and areas against the Gallic or Sclavonic hordes, but fully competent too to the grander duty of regulating the affairs of all mankind. In the interval between these dates, a force of young Englishmen, in arms equal in numbers to about one-half an ordinary Austrian corps d'armee, and glorious with fancy uniforms of every shape and every hue, had gone through the simplest military evolutions before the admiring eyes of all London on a holiday. Europeans familiar with the tremendous military arrays of the Continental States, and Americans accustomed from their youth up to the parades of the national militia, can hardly be expected to comprehend the extravagant ecstacies of delight into which the gravest organs of British opinion permit themselves to be transported by this very simple phenomenon. The London Times affirms, on the faith of this fine show, that England has suddenly risen from the estate of a "nation of shopkeepers" to the rank of a great military Power. Nay, the jubilations of the "Thunderer" are retroactive as well as prospective.

abstract: A very good match of base ball was played yesterday at South Brooklyn, on the ground of the Charter Oaks, in which the Old Puts came off victorious On the part of the Putnams, Brown, Masten and Da kin played excellently well, especially Brown, who did most of the fielding. The Putnams, on the whole played in first-rate style. At the bat, Wanzier, Masten and Burr were the most successful, Brown Stimsen and Van Valkenburgh batted well, but were very unfortunate. On the part of the Charter Oaks, J. Patchen was the most efficient, while Fuller and Vanderhoff contributed to lessen the score of the Putnams. Ferguson stopped the balls well from the bat, but did not quite succeed in holding on to them. Car oil made one good play on the list base by catching a one-hand ball from Fuller. With his good fielding, however, were mingled some bad plays. S. Patchen was little better than no one at all as short stop, his wild throwing being much condemned. Murphy was not quite so successful at the bat in this match as with the Manhattans, nor did he play so well as catcher; allowing very many balls to drop from his hands. With these bad misses the match resulted decidedly against the Charter Oaks. There were between fifteen hundred and two thousand spectators surrounding the grounds, in some Hustles instances both the ball and the fielders.

abstract: The influx of visitors to Camp Scott continued yesterday, and there must have been during the day three thousand ladies and gentlemen on the grounds. The Staten Island Railroad, in order to meet the requirements of the traveling public, has been obliged to fit up even their baggage-cars with temporary seats, and nearly all the trains are over-crowded. All species of vehicles are called into requisition to convey the visitors from the Railroad station to the camp ground, and their proprietors drive a thriving business at "only ten cents a head" for the humbler class, including bakers' wagons, go-carts, drays, and other vehicles not commonly used for passenger traffic. A large number of carriages likewise command a good business at a shilling a head, so that Camp Scott is a harvest for Jehu. The Railroad Company, however, not content with the increase to its exchequer, occasioned by Camp Scott, has offered inducements to Mons. DE LAVE to make one of his perilous tight-rope ascensions at Patton's Hotel, in the vicinity of the New-Dorp station, and the first of three exhibitions took place yesterday afternoon in the presence of several thousand spectators. The rope was stretched from the top of the hotel for a distance of four hundred feet to a stout apple tree on a neighboring hill -- the distance from the ground to the rope varying at different points from 85 feet to 25. About 4 o'clock Mons. DE LAVE appeared upon the rope, and performed sundry of his customary feats, to the satisfaction of all who saw him. Two or three exhibitions are yet to be given on different days of this week.

abstract: MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. -- Are all the mothers who read the Freeman acquainted with this article, which we hare advertised for the last few months? We would by no means recommend any kind of medicine which we did not know to be good -- particularly for infants. But of this Syrup we can speak from knowledge: in our own family it has proved a blessing indeed, by giving an infant troubled with colic pains quiet sleep, and its parents unbroken rest at night. Most parents can appreciate these blessings. We are entirely opposed to the prevalent practice of drugging infants, and would sooner lose our night's rest than consent to such a course. But here is an article which works to perfection, and which is harmless, for the sleep which it affords the infant is perfectly natural, and the little cherub awakes as "bright as & button." And during the process of teething its value is incalculable. We have frequently heard mothers say they would not be without it from the birth of the child till it had finished with the teething siege on any considerations what ever.

abstract: Yesterday morning, Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest on board the steamship Great Eastern, on the body of JAMES DARRELL, one of the Quartermasters attached to the vessel, who died very suddenly. The evidence showed that deceased was of intemperate habits, and that his death had been produced by exhaustion consequent upon his excessive drinking. A verdict to that effect was rendered. Deceased was 31 years of age, and a native of Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest on board the steamship Great Eastern, on the body of JAMES DARRELL, one of the Quartermasters attached to the vessel, who died very suddenly. abstract: MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL. -- The regular meeting of the Common Council was held last evening. A communication was received from the Chief Engineer, calling attention to the fact that the hose used by the Fire Department is almost useless. At the recent burning of the City Mills the working of the engines was in consequence very inefficient. A resolution providing for the purchase of 10,000 feet of the proper quality was adopted, A number of communications were received from the Counselor of the Board. One of these reported that a judgment had been obtained by E.B. SPOONER, Esq., proprietor of the Star, against the city, for advertising as a Corporation newspaper. The matter was referred to the Law Committee for a report. The Counselor also submitted his opinion on the application of the Trustees of Plymouth Church to be relieved of tax on the property on Hicks and Montague streets. He gave it as his opinion the property was not exempt by law. Alderman TAYLOR submitted a series of resolutions, which were adopted, instructing the Counselor to report whether Dock-street, Fisher-street, and several wharves and slips, reserved for the use of the people of Brooklyn, by the Corporation of New-York, in a grant to JOSHUA SANDS in 1803, are now open and unobstructed, and if not what steps are necessary to secure the rights of the city in the premises.
