abstract: Mr. BRECKINRIDGE accepts the nomination of the Administration-Secessionists "from a sense of public duty," and, as he thinks, "uninfluenced in any degree by the allurements of ambition." We presume the country will give him full credit for disinterestedness. Indeed it would be difficult to conceive how any ambitious politician could hope to achieve place and power, by the course which the Vice-President has resolved to pursue. The Presidential office does not lie in that direction. The day has gone by when a public man could command the support and enlist the favor of the American people, by lending himself to the factious schemes of the extreme sectionalists of the Southern States. That game has been played out. Partly through the overbearing exactions of the Pro-Slavery propagandists themselves, and partly from the rapid growth of the North and West in population and relative political power, the South can no longer dictate terms to the Union, or put a veto upon the will of either of the great political parties into which the country is divided.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, the "Pompier Corps," composed exclusively of Germans, made a second exhibition of their fire escape in this City. The first took place, some weeks since, in Chrystie-street, and its partial success, together with the nature of the apparatus, mode of working, &c., was duly recorded in our columns. Having much improved thereon, the corps applied to Mr. RICHARD FRENCH, of French's Hotel, for leave to exhibit their own capacities and that of their invention, in front of his building, which is from seventy to eighty feet high, and so situated that thousands of people could witness the spectacle from Chatham-street and the Park. Leave was granted by Mr. FRENCH, the exhibition was advertised, and a large crowd was the result, of which one fact was noticeable, that the majority were Germans, the women being as numerous and curious as the men. The apparatus of the Pompier Corps consists of a series of ladders, about ten or twelve feet long, each provided, at the top, with two broad and strong iron hooks, which [???]h the sill of a window with a tenacious [???]. The first ladder rests on the sidewalk, and is hooked on to the second story window sill; a man seconds, and the second ladder is handed to him, which he seives, and hooks to the third story window sill, and so on, to the fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh stories, when the building, as in the case of French's Hotel, is so high. A stream of men follow the first man, in succession, landing of the windows of the [???]s [???], exploring the apartments for human beings who may be therein, unable to make their escape. To either or all of these windows a canvas tube is dragged up by a rope, through which the inmates of the apartments are swiftly let down, alighting on the ground without injury. Yesterday the possibility of this mode of escape was demonstrated by the Pompier Corps in a variety of ways, much to the delight of the witnessing and applauding crowd. They fairly mounted over the huge projecting cornice of the roof, by means of a platform, which was hauled up by a rope, and stayed against the wall immediately below the uppermost window. Then a rope was fastened securely to the roof, and several members of the corps, by means of a "pulley-slide," lowered themselves rapidly through the whole eighty feet of depth to the sidewalk. One of their number, dressed externally in female costume, and moderately crinolined, but with a perfect set of male garments underneath, accompanied by a boy, shot down the rope amid repeated cheers from the spectators. That same male female or female-male adventurer, afterwards, unaided by rope or any retaining influence, made a clear jump from a window on the fifth story, a height of between fifty and sixty feet, to the ground, his or her crinoline expanding to the dimensions of a small balloon in the descent. This feat was a great success with the crowd, though it had nothing to do with the apparatus of the corps.

abstract: The mystery of these terrible murders appears to deepen daily, despite the strenuous efforts of Coroner JACKMAN to ferret out the perpetrator. Every individual who can reveal the slightest incident connected with the affair is being summoned to testify, and yet nothing positive can be stated as to the identity of the murderer. Thus far the circumstantial evidence seems to point to CHARLES JEFFERD, but not with certainty. His partial identification yesterday, however, by the German HASSELL, who witnessed the murder, produced quite a sensation in Court.

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday concluded an investigation of the circumstances attending the deaths of two children, one a colored girl, named ANNA S. WHITE, the other named LEUGENIA CISCO, both of whom were four years of age, and resided with their parents in the tenement house No. 161 West Twenty-eighth street. While playing in the street they found a bottle, which was supposed to have contained blue ink. They filled the bottle with water, and, assisted by two of their playmates, drank the mixture. Shortly they became very ill, and next day the two, whose names are mentioned, died. An analysis of the contents of the stomach and intestines of the deceased, resulted in showing that death had been produced by the substance called "blueing," used for laundery purposes. It is a compound of Prussian blue and oxalic acid, and, of course, is a deadly poison. A verdict of accidental poisoning was rendered.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday concluded an investigation of the circumstances attending the deaths of two children, one a colored girl, named ANNA S. abstract: About 11 o'clock on Monday night, an affray occurred at the house of Mrs. FITZGERALD, in Prospectstreet, near Railroad avenue, which resulted in the stabbing of HUGH CONROY, who is not expected to survive his injuries. It appears that a young man named PETER VIEZARD was in arrears for board, and returning home on Monday night, Mrs. FITZGERALD ordered...
lead_paragraph: About 11 o'clock on Monday night, an affray occurred at the house of Mrs. FITZGERALD, in Prospectstreet, near Railroad avenue, which resulted in the stabbing of HUGH CONROY, who is not expected to survive his injuries. It appears that a young man named PETER VIEZARD was in arrears for board, and returning home on Monday night, Mrs. FITZGERALD ordered him from the premises, and declining to leave, she threw his trunk down stairs and told him to follow it. This led to a noisy disturbance, when CONROY, the injured man, who is agent for the premises, came from a room on the lower floor, and attempted to quiet the uproar. He succeeded in getting VIEZARD from the house, and proceeded with him as far as the corner of Prospect-street and Newark-avenue, when, it is alleged, VIEZARD drew a knife and stabbed CONROY several times. He then fled. The injured man was conveyed to his residence, where he was attended by the City Physician, Dr. QUIDOR. The two most severe wounds he received were in the left breast in the heart, and it is thought they will prove fatal. Information of the occurrence was at once given to the Police, and men were detailed by Chief of Police MARINUS to search the City for VIEZARD.

abstract: A very interesting game of base ball was played between the first nines of these two clubs, on the grounds of the former, at Elysian Fields, Hoboken, on Tuesday last. There were very many fine plays made during the game, and among them was a throw from catcher to short and back home, instead of to the second base, thus putting one cut, which elicited great applause from the spectators. On the Eagle side there is not much to say. They did not play up to their usual standard. SLOATE played bad, as short, and did not improve himself as catcher. There were a great many balls missed on the fly and then caught on the bound -- (clam-shell catch.) As to the batting, BRINCKERHOFF batted well, but was very unfortunate. On the part of the Gothams, SWEET fielded splendidly, catching many balls on the fly and bound. BURTIS also made two beautiful catches from BRINCKERHOFF's bat. COHEN filled the catcher's position as it ought to be, not changing once during the game. VANDERWORKEN was changed to the third, and a decided improvement was made. MIMNE batted well, making a clean home run, but did not field very well. On the ninth inning, the game was a tie, when another inning was commenced, but the darkness prevented it from being finished. The game resulted as follows:

abstract: DEAR SIR: In answer to the request of the President, as communicated to me by your telegraphic dispatch addressed to me at Saratoga Springs, on the 30th ult., I have to say that the California mails shal go by the steamer of the llth inst., upon the terms proposed by you, and that the service shall be maintained thrice-monthly until the 4th day of March, 1861.

abstract: -- The New Orleans Delta of the 2d gives me following particulars of a brutal murder committed in that city. It says: "About 8 1/2 o'clock night before last, at the corner of Tonti and Lapeyrouse streets, in the rear of the Third District, GEORGE SCHWAGGE was stabbed by JOHN RENK, from the effect of which he died at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. SCHWAGGE was sitting before his door, with his wife, when RENK approached, and with the manner that can well be imagined, exclaimed: 'There's one of my wives,' alluding to Mrs. SCHWAGGE. The husband leaps to his feet instantly, of course, utters an angry word, and slaps the ruffian in the face. The fellow was not disabled by the assault; he drew a bowie-knife, and plunged it into the side of the unfortunate man. The wound was fatal. SCHWAGGE lingered until some fifteen hours, and then expired. The Coroner's investigation will take place to-day. The deceased was a member of that efficient company Creole No. 9. He will be interred to-day."

abstract: At no time within recollection has Young America been so visible on the surface and in the highways and by-ways of Paris life as at present. As if there were not always enough of that class here fitting themselves to become the future husbands of American wives, the last few steamers have discharged upon the continent a number hitherto unknown.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Wednesday, June 20, 1860.

abstract: THE WHARVES AND PIERS OF THE CITY. -- Our wharves and piers, which, like the markets, produce a revenue of two per cent., have at length fallen under the observation of the authorities, and steps are likely to be taken which will do away with one abuse. For years past many of the slips on the Hudson and East Rivers have been occupied by hay oyster and other boats, which lie there for months, being used as store-houses for cargoes which come from various ports on either river. An ordinance has been introduced into the Board of Councilmen compelling all such vessels to leave their berths so as to afford accommodation for the constantly increasing tonnage of the mercantile marine. The North River especially is infested with these floating store-houses, and if the Corporation have the power of removal, and it is exercised, it will have a beneficial effect on the business prospects of the upper part of the City. But while the authorities are looking after the piers and slips, it would be as well to inquire by what right or color of law the entire length of West-street, from Spring to Twelfth-street, is converted into a lumber-yard. More than one Mayor has called the attention of the authorities to these non-paying tenants of the City, whose only claim is that of possession. The ground occupied by the lumber dealers in West-street, if rented at a fair rate, would go very far towards paying the expense of keeping the wharves and piers in repair.

abstract: Yesterday morning officer COAKLEY, of the Fourth Precinct, apprehended a young man named John Riordan, who was conducting himself in a disorderly manner down in Cherry-street. The prisoner was taken before Justice WELSH, who ordered him to pay a fine of $10 or be locked up. The money could...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning officer COAKLEY, of the Fourth Precinct, apprehended a young man named John Riordan, who was conducting himself in a disorderly manner down in Cherry-street. The prisoner was taken before Justice WELSH, who ordered him to pay a fine of $10 or be locked up. The money could not be obtained, and as the officer was escorting Riordan into the prison he threatened to commit a violent assault upon him as soon as he should be released. Having heard of this, the magistrate ordered him back to Court and required him to furnish bail in $1,000 to keep the peace. The additional punishment aggravated the prisoner's ill-temper, and while the officer was surrendering him into the custody of the deputy-keeper he turned around and struck his custodian several violent blows in the face. Officer Blauvelt, of the Sixth Precinct, who was standing near, went to his colleague's assistance, and met a similar infliction. Riordan, however, was finally overcome, and having been taken again before the Justice, had his bail increased by $2,000 to answer complaints for assault and battery, which the officers preferred. The probability is that he will be boarded a few months in the Penitentiary.

abstract: It is now officially announced that the Prince of Wales will sail for America on Thursday next, and that he will visit the City of New York on the invitation of the Common Council, as a private gentleman, and not as the heir apparent of the British crown. He comes, in short, as Lord RENFREW, and not as the Prince of Wales.

abstract: The Cunard steamship Arabia, with three days later news from Europe, arrived at Halifax yesterday. It is confirmed that the King of Naples had granted a liberal constitution to his subjects, but the concessions do not appear to give satisfaction. On the contrary, according to the latest advices, the agitation prevailing in Naples was so intense that the city had been declared in a state of siege. The French Ambassador had been grossly assaulted in the streets by a mob in the interest of Government. It is stated that the American and Sardinian vessels captured by the Neapolitan Government had been released. From all other parts of Europe the news is of an unimportant character. In the Liverpool cotton market another decline is announced. Consols are quoted at 93 3/8@93 1/2 for account.

abstract: The sympathetic interest with which every intelligent American is following the strange and splendid career of GARIBALDI in Sicily, and which will be cordially manifested to-night, we trust, at the Academy of Music, is not likely to be diminished by the news which reaches us this morning from Naples. While the Liberator of Sicily is seemingly bent only on consolidating ...
lead_paragraph: The sympathetic interest with which every intelligent American is following the strange and splendid career of GARIBALDI in Sicily, and which will be cordially manifested to-night, we trust, at the Academy of Music, is not likely to be diminished by the news which reaches us this morning from Naples. While the Liberator of Sicily is seemingly bent only on consolidating the power of the island people he has freed, it is plain that his spirit has gone before him across the Straits, and that it is stirring the main land into life. The miserable young King FRANCIS has already been driven into abandoning the white banner and golden lilies of his dynasty, and the tricolor of Italy floats over the palaces of Bomba. A new ministry interpret the strange symbol to the people of Naples, and if there were any faith possible to be reposed in a Bourbon, it might almost be believed that Southern Italy had entered fairly upon the same path which Sardinia has followed to freedom and to fame.

abstract: The Sangrados have come to the rescue of the Archbishop; the doctors of medicine second the doctors of divinity in breaking the law. The American Medical Gazette, usually one of the most conservative of journals in medicine and politics and in social ethics, openly proclaims that Archbishop HUGHES does right to flaunt his opposition in the face of the Municipal authorities. The Gazette...
lead_paragraph: The Sangrados have come to the rescue of the Archbishop; the doctors of medicine second the doctors of divinity in breaking the law. The American Medical Gazette, usually one of the most conservative of journals in medicine and politics and in social ethics, openly proclaims that Archbishop HUGHES does right to flaunt his opposition in the face of the Municipal authorities. The Gazette tells "the flippant editors who pitch into the Archbishop, that the first attempt to enforce the fine will be resisted and defeated by any honest jury," and gratuitously involves its own profession in the undesirable opprobrium of abetting resistance to the Government; it declares that an enactment exists, similar to that compelling clergymen to report marriages, which requires physicians and midwives to report births, and that not a moiety of the physicians of the City make any report at all.

abstract: We are evidently in a period of penitence. Archbishop HUGHES has just condescended most kindly to express his regret at having borne false witness against one at least of his neighbors; and now we have Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, in a letter which we published yesterday and which we reprint to-day, lamenting that by somebody's blunder he should have been led into trampling on anybody's rights. It is an ungracious office...
lead_paragraph: We are evidently in a period of penitence. Archbishop HUGHES has just condescended most kindly to express his regret at having borne false witness against one at least of his neighbors; and now we have Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, in a letter which we published yesterday and which we reprint to-day, lamenting that by somebody's blunder he should have been led into trampling on anybody's rights. It is an ungracious office to riddle the excuses of a repentant offender, and yet we are forced to undertake it. Were we to consult our own inclination only, we should be moved to take Mr. VANDERBILT at his word, and to represent to ourselves this veteran monopolist weeping over the sorrows of which he had been made the unconscious cause. We might, in that case, forbear to dwell on the extraordinary remissness of the Telegraph Company, in sending a Washington dispatch of June 30 to Saratoga so slowly, that an answer to it could not reach New-York before the 2d of July. We might also admire the reticence, or be amazed at the incapacity of Mr. HOLT in conducting a long negotiation with Mr. VANDERBILT on the subject of steam mail carriage, without once hitting on that one proposition which the law had intended him to make, and which it now appears Mr. VANDERBILT was in his heart longing to accept. These things are worth noticing, certainly, but of our own motion we should have been inclined to overlook them, in a perhaps extravagant wish to deal as gently as might be with a brokenhearted offender. But a document has come into our possession which makes it imperative upon us to challenge Mr. VANDERBILT's story of his motives and his actions, and even leads us to question alike the sincerity of his contrition and the good faith of the President's Washington organ in asserting, as it did on Saturday last, that "Mr. VANDERBILT had shown much public spirit and confidence in the Government by his acceptance of its proposal." Increditable as it may seem, we suspect the Constitution of irony.

abstract: The auction sale of the theatrical wardrobe belonging to the late WM.E. BURTON, took place yesterday, according to announcement, at the sales rooms of J. SABIN & CO., on the comer of Fourth-street and Lafayette-place. The attendance was not so large as the unique character of the sale, the reputation of the former owner of the property, and the pleasant memories connected with it, would have led one to anticipate. There were scarcely one hundred persons present at any time during the day, and the purchasers were mostly confined to some half dozen theatrical managers, actors and costumers. A few ladies were in attendance at the opening of the sale, but they soon left, as did a majority of the spectators, after gratifying their curiosity in examining the costumes of a few of the leading characters in which Mr. BURTON was so popular. These costumes presented but a sorry sight as they hung there drooping upon a row of pegs, when contrasted with their appearance upon the jocund form of BURTON, as he personated the characters of "Capt. Cattle," "Mieawber," "Aminadab Sleek" and the "Toddles." The catalogue numbered 236 lots, and comprised the whole private theatrical wardrobe of Mr. BURTON, (82 pieces,) together with the entire wardrobe of the Chambers-street Theatre and all its appurtenances. There were costumes of all ages and nations from South American Indians to Japanese Kamis, and of every variety of character, from English Kings and Roman Emperors to Swiss peasants and American sailors. Besides the human costumes were the supposed habiliments of angels, nymphs, faries, mermaids, witches, imps and devils.

The catalogue numbered 236 lots, and comprised the whole private theatrical wardrobe of Mr. BURTON, (82 pieces,) together with the entire wardrobe of the Chambers-street Theatre and all its appurtenances. There were costumes of all ages and nations from South American Indians to Japanese Kamis, and of every variety of character, from English Kings and Roman Emperors to Swiss peasants and American sailors. Besides the human costumes were the supposed habiliments of angels, nymphs, faries, mermaids, witches, imps and devils.

abstract: At about fifteen minutes before 9 o'clock last evening the city was startled by a sudden jar as if caused by a falling building, or the combined discharge of several cannon. Buildings for the distance of several blocks from the river, and up and down from the vicinity of foot of Bates-street, trembled as if starting from their foundation, and sudden alarm seized upon all. In a few moments the cause was known. The boiler of the steam-tug A.S. Field, lying at the dock between Bates and Randolph streets, had exploded, and the boat was a total wreck. Thither the citizens hurried by hundreds, clambering and climbing as best they might in the darkness over piles of wood, amid huge timbers and around every kind of rubbish. A mass of sticks and planks was all that remained to be discovered of the tug, and her timbers, cabin, portions of her boiler shelf, flues, wood, &c., were lying in heaps upon the dock near by, and strewn about the neighboring premises for the distance of three or four hundred feet. Outside timbers of the dock had been thrown several feet out of place and some lifted high upon piles of wood.

abstract: The visitors to the encampment of the Seventh Regiment at Camp Scott were very numerous yesterday, but they had to undergo, as before, the blinding nuisance of a heavy cloud of dust on the route from the railroad terminus to the camp, a distance of a little over a mile. To obviate this in future, the Richmond Club, on whose grounds the camp is formed, promise to do to-day what ought to have been done before -- sprinkle the road thoroughly for that distance. The dust will thereby be laid, and dresses and temper will be alike spared.

abstract: The day fixed upon for the execution of the notorious pirate HICKS, is Friday, the 13th instant, and the place, Bedloe's Island, in the harbor of New-York. As the time for this execution approaches, something of the excitement which was produced by the first details of the awful crime is renewed in the public mind, and thousands have already applied to the U.S. Marshal for tickets to witness it.
lead_paragraph: The day fixed upon for the execution of the notorious pirate HICKS, is Friday, the 13th instant, and the place, Bedloe's Island, in the harbor of New-York. As the time for this execution approaches, something of the excitement which was produced by the first details of the awful crime is renewed in the public mind, and thousands have already applied to the U.S. Marshal for tickets to witness it. This feeling will be heightened when it is known that HICKS has dictated to one of the U.S. Marshals a full confession of the triple murders on the E.A. Johnson, and in a complete history which he has given of his life, from boyhood, has also confessed his agency in a series of robberies, murders and other high-handed crimes which stamp him as one of the most hardened and desperate men ever known. If his statements are to be believed, -- and they have been made with a particularity of places dates and other circumstances which strongly favor the supposition of their truth, he has been a party to the commission of nearly one hundred murders. The bare statement of such an appalling amount of crime committed by one human being is calculated to stagger belief, and to raise the suspicion that a morbid desire for criminal notoriety may have led him to exaggerate his story in order to give the narrative a wide sale for the benefit of his wife and child. Be this as it may, the murders on the sloop are fully described, with all their horrible and bloody details, and the remainder of the confession, which includes his life from the age of fifteen years, has been given with such particularity of narration -- such as the mention of vessels, places, names of persons, and dates, as to impress the person who took it from his lips with the idea that it is substantially true.
headline: {'main': 'THE PIRATE HICKS.; His Approaching Execution Preparations for the Event Full Confession of the Triple Murders on the Sloop, and of Numerous other Crimes.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE PIRATE HICKS.; His Approaching Execution Preparations for the Event Full Confession of the Triple Murders on the Sloop, and of Numerous other Crimes.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Independent has the following remarkable statement: "It ought to be distinctly understood that the London Tract Society declined to recognize Rev. Dr. Murray as a representative of the American Tract Society located in Nassau-street in this City. He carried out a commission as representative of that dishonored institution; but the Committee of the London Society would not acknowledge him in that capacity. He exhibited to them a narrative of the doings of the Nassau-street Society, but they refused to have it read or referred to at their public meeting. Dr. Murray was courteously invited to speak simply as Dr. Murray, but his commission and his narrative had to be laid aside. We have these facts on the best authority. Will the Observer and the American Messenger copy?"
lead_paragraph: The Independent has the following remarkable statement: "It ought to be distinctly understood that the London Tract Society declined to recognize Rev. abstract: Yesterday Mayor WOOD took the second step towards that revolution of the City Government which he deems essential to the public good and his own advantage. He removed ALERKO W. CRAVEN from his post as Engineer, and Mr. TAPPAN from his position as Commissioner of  the Croten Aqueduct Department. He has been busy for some weeks in making those "little arrangements" with members of the Board of Aldermen, which are essential to the...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Mayor WOOD took the second step towards that revolution of the City Government which he deems essential to the public good and his own advantage. He removed ALERKO W. CRAVEN from his post as Engineer, and Mr. TAPPAN from his position as Commissioner of the Croten Aqueduct Department. He has been busy for some weeks in making those "little arrangements" with members of the Board of Aldermen, which are essential to the smooth and easy working of schemes of this kind. It was supposed yesterday afternoon that the matter had been fixed, -- that the requisite nine had been "seen," and that all were distinctly and definitely engaged to give their prompt assent. From some cause or other, the project failed. One or two of the parties confidently counted on proved "unreliable." They voted for an adjournment, and thus stayed off the confirmation of the Mayor's action. This, however, though a little awkward, is a matter of small importance. It delays the removal a day or two, but will not prevent it. It may possibly cost his Honor, or His Excellency, to use the phrase of Mr. DALLAS, a little more of patience and of other valuable commodities for which he has abundant use, both in his personal and political capacity, than he had expected. But he is used to making private sacrifices for the sake of the public goods, -- and can very well afford to wait until Friday night for the consummation of his plan for "reforming" the Croton Aqueduct Department. By that time it will, beyond all doubt, be made right.

abstract: The interest which every intelligent American takes in an organized militia service, and which has been not a little quickened of late by the energetic attempts which our English cousins are making to introduce our system into their own country, is not likely to be diminished by a visit to a genuine, soldierly volunteer camp. In camp, for at least a few days, our volunteers are soldiers all the time; they are here given up completely to the military side of life, with no intervals of business or lounging, and it is worth while to know how near they come, in such circumstances, to the regular professors of the noble art of national self-defence.

abstract: Several Washington correspondents have referred of late to a recent quarrel between President BUCHANAN and Senator GWIN, of California, but none of them are quite accurate in their statements of the origin of the difficulty.
lead_paragraph: Several Washington correspondents have referred of late to a recent quarrel between President BUCHANAN and Senator GWIN, of California, but none of them are quite accurate in their statements of the origin of the difficulty. As we learn from sources likely to be well-informed, the quarrel did grow out of a misunderstanding in relation to the California mail service, but was not consequent, as alleged, upon the refusal of the Administration to contract to pay Commodore VANDERBILT a larger sum for carrying the mails via Panama, than the postages, as provided by law. The exact facts in the premises are alike discreditable to both parties to the quarrel, convicting each, as they do, of bad faith, as well as of an unworthy prostitution of public interest to selfish partisan and personal ends.

abstract: The Annual Commencement of St. John's College, Fordham, was held on the College grounds yesterday -- it being the fifteenth Commencement since the institution has been under the charge of the Jesuits. About 2,000 ladies and gentlemen were in attendance, a large portion of whom were from New-York. Among the guests present were Archbishop HUGHES, Vicar-General STARRS, Rev. Dr. KANNA, of Longford, Ireland; Bishop QUINLAN, of Mobile; Bishop MCLOUGHLIN, of Brooklyn ORESTES A. BROWNSON, ERASTUS BENEDICT, and others.

abstract: At a meeting of this Board yesterday afternoon, the Secretary was directed to read a response drawn up by the counsel of the Board, respecting the complaint of Dr. JEROME, for non-payment of salary for the past six months, amounting to $2,500, which was entered about a week ago at the Supreme Court. The Commissioners intend to adopt the response, and contend that the claim is illegal, because the Marine Hospital was abolished by the State Legislature, and consequently, the office of a resident physician was abolished at the same time.

abstract: The Garibaldi demonstration which came off last night at the Academy was a financial and political success, and even as such deserves the commendation to which it would otherwise be entitled on strictly musical grounds. The audience was as large as could be looked for when "everybody" is out of town, and though, perhaps, not quite so irreproachably "fashionable" as an Academy audience in the season is supposed invariably to be, was altogether agreeable to the eye, critical and appreciative. Lucia di Lammermoor was sung, and that the whole strength of the Italian. Opera in New-York came forward in behalf of the stera work which Italians are doing in Italy, will be admitted when we name CORTESI, FREZZOLINI, COLSON, MUSIAMI and FRREI among the volunteers of the occasion We trust their patriotism will not be rewarded with Papal excommunication.

abstract: In the TIMES of Tuesday morning we published a report of the improper and insulting treatment of two ladies by two of our City officials, and of the threats of the brother of one of them, a well-known political character, to revenge the outrage. The affair came near a bloody consummation yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: In the TIMES of Tuesday morning we published a report of the improper and insulting treatment of two ladies by two of our City officials, and of the threats of the brother of one of them, a well-known political character, to revenge the outrage. The affair came near a bloody consummation yesterday afternoon. At about 1 o'clock, Ex-Councilman KERRIGAN passed into the Park, from Park row, and had proceeded up the flagged walk, towards the City Hall, for some distance, when, looking back, he saw Alderman Genet with two other persons walking towards the east side of the Park. He turned, and as the Alderman approached, drew a pistol, and taking deliberate aim at him, asked him if he was armed. He also told the Alderman that he was a villain and a sneak; that he had endeavored to ruin his sister, and that he (Mr. KERRIGAN) was determined to punish him. The City Father immediately dodged behind Mr. SHEPPARD KNAPP, to that gentleman's great discomfort, particularly as Mr. KERRIGAN kept the pistol aimed in his direction. A large number of persons ran rapidly to the scene, while the Alderman, keeping his friends between himself and the muzzle of Mr. KERRIGAN's Navy revolver, intimated that he was not armed, and retreated slowly, until he succeeded in exchanging a friendly tree for the body of Mr. KNAPP. Before this, however, a number of Mr. KERRIGAN's friends, who had been standing in front of Messrs. CROOK & DUFF's Dining Saloon, had crossed over, and were using every effort to induce him to desist from his purpose of shooting Alderman GENET for the present. As soon as they had succeeded so far as to get him to lower his pistol, the Alderman retired from the field, and soon afterward Mr. KERRIGAN left with his friends.

abstract: The final arrangements for the execution of HICKS will be completed to-day by the United States Marshal, so that nothing will remain to be done on  the day appointed but to carry into effect the sentence of the law against the criminal. From present appearances this execution will be attended with...
lead_paragraph: The final arrangements for the execution of HICKS will be completed to-day by the United States Marshal, so that nothing will remain to be done on the day appointed but to carry into effect the sentence of the law against the criminal. From present appearances this execution will be attended with more excitement than is usual on such occasions, and the officers of the law will require the firm support, not only of all law-abiding citizens, but of a police or military force to preserve order during the discharge of their unpleasant duties. Throughout yesterday the execution was the general topic of conversation, and the greatest possible eagerness was manifested to procure tickets of admission upon the island where the prisoner is to meet his fate. Every row-boat and sailing craft, which could be secured, has been engaged for a week in advance to be used in conveying parties to the spot; steamers and all manner of sailing craft will also throng about the Island, crowded undoubtedly, with eager spectators.

abstract: Mr. DALLAS has given FERNANDO WOOD another title. He styles him "His Excellency." As "His Honor, the Mayor," is the official designation which FERNANDO bestows on himself, and is the one by which he is best known, Mr. DALLAS' mode of addressing him is likely to cause considerable confusion amongst "His Honor's" many admirers. They will naturally be puzzled to know which is the proper, recognized, legal designation of our "Chief Magistrate." Mr. DALLAS is a precise, punctilious man, a diplomatist, and skilled in the use of titles; but FERNANDO is also a "smart man," and ought to know what are his official attributes. We trust, therefore, he will at once relieve the public anxiety by a message to the Common Council, giving us a history of the title "His Honor," from the days of DONGAN down; his reasons for wearing it, and the reasons why the Mayor receives it, and a statement of its advantages, if any, over "His Excellency;" why it should be preferred to "His Highness," or "His Smartness," or "His Cuteness," or "His Urbanity," or any other of the thousand and one terms of veneration "which His Honor unquestionably merits. Failing this, we shall feel ourselves at liberty not only to follow Mr. DALLAS' example, but to bestow on "His Honor" any of the other forms of reverent address that happens to occur to us.

abstract: Mrs. ANNA SCHUMAKER, who was attacked last Monday morning, by a roober who had entered her house, situated near the corner of Seventy-first-street and Eleventh-avenue, and whose child was murdered outright by the same ruffian, died on Tuesday night in consequence of her injuries.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. ANNA SCHUMAKER, who was attacked last Monday morning, by a roober who had entered her house, situated near the corner of Seventy-first-street and Eleventh-avenue, and whose child was murdered outright by the same ruffian, died on Tuesday night in consequence of her injuries. She had never been perfectly conscious after the time of her discovery, although her actions indicated that she was not entirely insensible, as frequently in her agony she would toss her arms nervously, and sometimes seek relief by sitting upright for a moment in her bed. The postmortem examination developed such terrible fractures in her skull that the bones dropped out on removal of the scalp, while her cheek-bone was found to have been broken, and other marks of the violence to which she had been subjected were presented.

abstract: Shortly before 11 o'clock, last night, the fire-bells gave an alarm for the Eighth District, which proved to have been caused by the burning of one of the sheds composing the quadruple row on the bulkhead extending from Vesev to Dey-street, and known as West Washington Market. A watchman in the service of the New-York and Hamburg line of steamships, which lie at the pier foot of Fulton-street, first saw the flames as they issued from the centre building of the outermost row, on the side toward the river. Some minutes elapsed before information of the fact could be communicated to the firemen, and the light woodwork flashed into a blaze with the greatest rapidity.

abstract: On the Fourth of July a number of little boys were amusing themselves in the yard of a house in Twenty-sixth street, near Tenth-avenue, by discharging a small cannon at a mark against the sine of an out-building in which JOHN DUNLAP, an Irishman, 33 years of age, while intoxicated, had lain down to sleep. The lads were not aware that any person was within the out-house, and the contents of their piece, consisting of a wooden plug and some of the wadding, passed through and entered DUNLAP'S thigh, inflicting a fatal wound. He was subsequently removed to Bellevue Hospital, where he died on Tuesday. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the body, which resulted, in a verdict in accordance with the facts.
lead_paragraph: On the Fourth of July a number of little boys were amusing themselves in the yard of a house in Twenty-sixth street, near Tenth-avenue, by discharging a small cannon at a mark against the sine of an out-building in which JOHN DUNLAP, an Irishman, 33 years of age, while intoxicated, had lain down to sleep. The lads were not aware that any person was within the out-house, and the contents of their piece, consisting of a wooden plug and some of the wadding, passed through and entered DUNLAP'S thigh, inflicting a fatal wound. He was subsequently removed to Bellevue Hospital, where he died on Tuesday. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the body, which resulted, in a verdict in accordance with the facts.

abstract: learns that in the counties of Clark, Choctaw, Washington and Wayne, in that State, a serious excitement exists among the planters, the discovery having lately been made that in one neighborhood a combination of Abolitionists, who boldly defy public opinion, has existed for some time. A party of men appointed by a public meeting undertook to give them a call, but they armed themselves and offered resistance. An old man named GILBERT, and a preacher named MCDONALD, are the ringleaders. They seem to have been in correspondence with the old Harper's Ferry JOHN BROWN, and it is said that a point near there, and a man living in that place, were designated in old JOHN BROWN's confession. The man was an Irishman, and has left. The negroes have been congregating with these persons of nights -- sometimes fifty of them of a night. One of the negroes was taken up, and confessed this under the lash. It was determined to have a large demonstration there soon. Persons were going from Quitman to it.

abstract: COMMITTED TO PRISON FOR SELLING LAGERBEER -- Mr. FREDERICK THOU, keeper of an extensive lager-beer saloon at Greenville, was committed, to the County Jail for four days, on Tuesday afternoon, by Justice RYERSON, of South Bergen, on a charge of selling lager-beer on Sunday. Mr. THOU refused to pay a fine of $5 imposed upon him, offering to enter into bonds for trial before Judge OGDEN, in order to test the legality of the ordinance imposing a fine or imprisonment for selling beer on the Sabbath, The Judge declined to accept bonds, and at once committed Mr. THOU. The prisoner was at once released from jail on a writ of certiorari, and it is understood will commence an action against Justice RYERSON for false imprisonment.

abstract: Hon. STEPHRN A. DOUGLAS will remain in this City until Saturday, when he proceeds to New-Haven, spending the Sabbath. at Sachem's Head. On Monday he goes to Hartford, Conn., and from thence to Boston, on Tuesday, to attend the Commencement exercises at Harvard University where he has a brother in-law at the Law School. His lady will accompany him on the trip.

abstract: When Lord MELBOURNE was sitting for his portrait to LES???E, he asked how it was that BABHAER was championed by the Pope to paint the wails of the Vatican. The artist in his simpllerty replied I, "Because of his great excellence." "But was not his uncle, BEAMANCK," rejoined his lordship, "architect to the Pope" "I believe BZAMANTE was his uncle." "Then it was a job, you may be sure," said MELBOURNE with his hearty laugh. To the experienced politician the fact was palpable and obvious that had entirely escaped the eye of the unsuspecting painter.

abstract: The announcement that Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, of Boston, was to deliver a speech before the Young Men's Republican Union of this City, drew together last evening one of the largest audiences that ever assembled within the walls of the Cooper Institute Long before 8 o'clock, the time designated for the....
lead_paragraph: The announcement that Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, of Boston, was to deliver a speech before the Young Men's Republican Union of this City, drew together last evening one of the largest audiences that ever assembled within the walls of the Cooper Institute Long before 8 o'clock, the time designated for the meeting, every seat and standing place in the vast Hall was occupied, and, what is not usual at political gatherings, a large proportion of the audience were ladies. Mr. SUMNER entered the Hall from the rear of the stage at precisely 8 o'clock, and the moment he appeared in sight he was greeted with the most vociferous cheers, clapping of hands and stamping of feet from all parts of the room.

abstract: On Tuesday evening Bernard McAtee, a laborer, while partially intoxicated, called at the grocery store, corner of Fortieth-street and Eleventh-avenue, and obtained some liquor. He told the clerk, a boy named James Dougherty, that he was going fishing, and would pay for his drink on his return. The arrangement was not satisfactory to the boy, and an altercation ensued. McAtee retreated to the sidewalk followed by Dougherty, who persistently demanded the price of the liquor. McAtee finally became so incensed that he drew a dirk-knife, and thrust it into the lad's abdomen, inflicting a wound which, it is thought, will prove fatal. Officer Brice promptly effected McAtee's arrest, and yesterday Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him, pending the result of the injuries he had caused. Dougherty was removed to Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN has been winding up his public life by an electioneering speech, containing, we are told, "three thousand words," advocating the Breckinridge and Lane ticket. As if conscious of the impropriety of his appearance on the scene, however, he informed his audience, apologetically, that this was probably the last political speech he would ever make, as his position rendered it improper for him to take part in the canvass, "though his heart was in it."

abstract: FOLLOWING A BAD EXAMPLE -- Recently, a man named PEYER DONNELLY was tried and convicted in the Kings County Court of Sessions, of assault and battery and attempting to rob Mr. HAYS, one of the collectors employed by the Union Perry Company. As the jury was about to retire to consider the case one of the jurors announced that he was unable to understand the English language -- being a German -- but with the consent of prisoner's counsel he was not with drawn. A verdict of guilty was rendered and the accused was sentenced to two years imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing, Since the conviction, a new counsel, Mr. WINCHAD BEITTON, comes into the case and demands a new trial on the ground that the German juror did not understand the language, not with standing that the case was submitted to him by consent of counsel for prisoner, the Cangemi case being referred to as a precedent for such a course. The Court felt compelled to grant the motion, but the District-Attorney intends to test the case at every step.

abstract: A NEW RULE AT THE CITY PRISON. -- The Board of Charities and Correction have directed Mr. SUTTON, Warden of the City Prison, to admit no visitors to that Institution in future, unless they have a pass duly signed by a member of the Commission. Heretofore it has been the custom to allow any person who desired the privilege, to visit the prisoners, and several instances have recently occurred where the permission has been abused. It was through such means that STEVENS, the wife poisoner, obtained the revolver, by means of which he proposed to escape, by shooting his keepers, and MACDONALD, the murderer of VIRGINIA STEWART, the poison with which he committed suicide.

abstract: At the special meeting of the Board, last evening, ANDREW H. GREEN, Esq., occupied the chair, in the absence of the President. An effort to elect a President pro tem., to act during the expected six weeks' absence of Mr. CURTIS, was defeated, the rule requiring all elections of officers to take place at a stated meeting. A motion to postpone the order of business so as to admit a resolution providing for the appointment of Mr. DAVENPORT, with authority temporarily to sign warrants for teachers' salaries, was lost. An effort to postpone the consideration of a communication, on the ground that the subject was not mentioned in the call for the special meeting, failed -- the Board having been occupied exactly an hour and a quarter in doing nothing, up to this time.

abstract: We present herewith a correct list of the names of the parties who were burned out on Wednesday night by the destruction of a large part of West Washington Markets. After particular inquiry, we learn that the value of the property destroyed amounts to about $100,000. It consisted mainly of fruits and vegetables, which belonged to the owners of the stands, who estimate their losses at sums varying from $200 to $5,000. Very few of these dealers were insured, as the perishable nature of their stock precluded its remaining for any long time in store. Many of the persons who were engaged in business at these stands are represented to have done a business of over one million dollars a year.

abstract: If anything could make our mercantile community pause to look the curse of competition fully in the face, and measure the mischief which its unrestrained sway has done and is doing to the moral tone of the age in which we live, it ought to be the character and the career of such monopolists as Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT. His conduct in the matter recently at issue between himself and the Government, in regard to the Pacific mails, has been so clearly set forth in our own previous comments, and in the course of the quarrel which has taken place on this subject between the President and the Senators from California, that we need not here recapitulate its details. Its sum and substance is, that after vainly attempting to drive Congress into surrendering the interests and destinies of our whole Pacific commerce to his keeping on his own terms, Mr. VANDERBILT undertook to avenge his failure upon thousands of his countrymen and countrywomen, by cutting off all mail communication between the Atlantic and the Pacific.

abstract: On Wednesday evening the handsome music rooms of WM. HALL & SONS, in Broadway, were agreeably filled with an appreciative company of musical amateurs, performers, and critics, assembled there to welcome back Mr. WM. VINCENT WALLACE to the United States. The home of a gifted composer is as wide as the world, for music is the universal tongue; but Mr. WALLACE has a particular hold on New-York, and he must have learned on Wednesday night that New-York claims a particular hold on him.

abstract: The murder mania has not yet ceased. It becomes our duty to chronicle two more attempts at murder, and under circumstances of an aggravated character. JOHN WILLIAMS, a laborer in a pork-packing establishment, residing at No. 126 Mott-street, has several times been under arrest for abusing his wife and threatening her life; but as she has uniformly declined to make complaint against him he has never yet received the punishment justly his due. Her forbearance has been illy rewarded. At about 8 3/4 o'clock last evening, as she was preparing supper for her husband, he came home drunk and resumed his abuse. Her mother, who was in the room, attempted to interfere, but was met with a slow. On his wife remonstrating, he snatched a carving knife from the table and stabbed her in the abdomen, inflicting a serious and probably fatal wound. Officers WHITE and WOODBURY were promptly on the ground, but the man made his escape before their arrival. As the woman was too seriously injured to be put in a carriage, she was placed on a litter and conveyed to the hospital, where she was placed in charge of Dr. WEIR, by whom her wounds were dressed; but it is his opinion that she will not recover. The woman is young and good-looking, with a good reputation through the neighborhood, while her husband is known as a brawling, drunken rascal. Officers WHITE and WOODBURY have a clue to his whereabouts, and he will probably be soon arrested.

abstract: The People and Taylor & Brennan vs. The Mayor, &c. -- Judge Bronson proceeded with his argument. After alluding to the question of title, be referred of the acts of the Comptroller: That officer was quite willing a fair compromise should be made -- even willing to buy peace to secure to the City some of the rights claimed. As the time it was suggested that the Legislature Should settle the matter, he was willing it should be so settled; out when the law was submitted to him be could not assent to it in justice to the City. Neither the Comptroller or the speaker were in favor of the bill submitted to them, and the charge that they were was false. The Judge again asserted that there had been collusion between Taylor & Brennan, the representatives of the ten anis, the Commissioners of the Land Office, and the late Corporation Counsel. The non-execution of Justice Roosevelt's order to pay the $40,000 in to the City treasury, was and evidence of this fraud and collusion.
lead_paragraph: The People and Taylor & Brennan vs. The Mayor, &c. -- Judge Bronson proceeded with his argument. abstract: -- The celebrated Averill One Bed Claim of JACOB D. KINGSLAND, at the Clinton Prison, against the State of New-York, is now being investigated before three Commissioners appointed by the Governor, in pursuance of an act of the legislature. Hon. THEODORE M. POMEEOY has been engaged by Gov. MORGAN as counsel for the State, and is now in Clinton pursuing the investigation. The nature of this celebrated claim may be briefly stated as follows: KINGSLAND contracted for a certain number of convicts to work the iron ore beds near the Clinton Prison; the State, for some reason, failed to furnish the convicts; KINGSLAND figures up the amount of ore that the convicts contracted for could have excavated within the time of the contract ascertains the value of such amount when excavated, and then, deducting from such amount the price which would have been due the State for the labor of the convicts, claims that he is entitled to the balance!

abstract: The pronunciamiento of Mr. WOOD, on Presidential politics, is attracting wide attention from both wings of the harmonious Democracy; and, judging from the comments on it, it would seem to be one of those happy documents which possess the rare power of displeasing both parties, while still leaving both in ignorance as to the side of the fence on which the writer means finally to land.

abstract: Early yesterday morning Marshal RYNDERS had the gallows on which HICKS is to be hung, with its appendages, sent to Bedloe's Island, with a party of mechanics, to put it in order for the execution to-day. abstract: We heard on Monday of the failure of two houses in Marysville WM. HAWLEY  Co., and SCOTT, VANTINE  Co. They, jointly, were indebted to R.E. BREWSTER  Co., of this city, some $40,000. Yesterday, rumors were around all the morning, that this extensive house had failed. At 2 o'clock it came out that they had confessed judgment for $104,921, and that they acknowledged their liabilities to be $300,000.

abstract: Twenty-two members of the Excelsior Base Ball Club of this city, embracing in the number seven of the "first nine," started on an excursion through the northern and western portions of New-York, one week ago last Saturday, and reached home yesterday morning. Previous to starting, they adopted a series of rules for their government during the trip, the principal ones of which were -- not to use any intoxicating drinks and to pay their own expenses. As the proposed excursion was generally known, of course many invitations for friendly matches were received -- six of which were accepted and played with the following result:

abstract: PRESENTATIONS. -- Several months ago Mr. E.B. SPOONER, Jr., notified the children in the Truant Institution at Flatbush, that he would present each scholar with a book, who by his conduct during the next three months should prove himself worthy of a reward for good conduct. Twenty-one of the inmates came up to the requisite standard, and on Wednesday last Mr. SPOONER fulfilled his promise by presenting each with a book, accompanying each present with a few remarks of advice and encouragement suitable to the occasion. The children were much pleased with the proceedings, and the encouragement to good conduct will doubtless have a healthy influence.
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATIONS. -- Several months ago Mr. E.B. abstract: The Syracuse Journal says that Mr. Morris Beardsley, who disappeared from that place about three months ago, was discovered on Sunday evening last, lying on the grass in the cemetery at Batasia, in a dying state. He was able to tell his residence, but died before medial aid could be summoned. It is not yet known where he has been during his three months absence from home.

abstract: Postmaster FOWLER seems to be ubiquitous. Now at Pike's Peak, anon at Washoe, and again reported at Havana. His locality seems as difficult to fix as that of the Flying Dutchman. At last accounts he is said to be studying Spanish in the interior of Cuba. He was always a man of letters.
lead_paragraph: -- Postmaster FOWLER seems to be ubiquitous. Now at Pike's Peak, anon at Washoe, and again reported at Havana. His locality seems as difficult to fix as that of the Flying Dutchman. At last accounts he is said to be studying Spanish in the interior of Cuba. He was always a man of letters.

abstract: HIGHWAYMEN FRUSTRATED. -- About 11 o'clock on Wednesday night, as Mr. DAVID F. BERNER residing at the corner of Erie and North Third streets, Jersey City, was returning home from Hudson City, he met two men about midway on Bergen Hill, who bid him good night. Mr. B. returned the salutation and was passing on, when he observed one of the men suddenly raise his hand, when he sprang aside, and a large stone was hurled past, his head with great force. At this moment one of the Bergen cars came in sight, when the ruffians fled up the hill, and Mr. BERNER took refuge in the car.

abstract: letter to the editor of the Louisville Courier, from Richmond, Ky., dated July 8, says; "I learn that there was a fight at Mallory Springs, in this county on Saturday evening, in which five men were shot. Three of them are supposed to be fatally injured. Can give no particulars, but am informed that it grew out of the difficulties with the Abolitionists at Berea, and, the Vigilance Committee."

abstract: The Cunard steamship Arabia arrived at Boston yesterday morning, and her mails reached this City in the evening. We obtain from our foreign files and correspondence some interesting details of the news briefly telegraphed from Halifax. The sovereign act, under which FRANCIS II, grants to his Neapolitan subjects "constitutional and representative institutions on National and Italian principles," is generally regarded as a sham. Signor SPINELLI has succeeded in composing a Cabinet, the Minister for Foreign Affairs being Commander MARTINO who was long Neapolitan Envoy at Rome, and who has lately returned from Paris, whither he was sent to implore the French Emperor's support. It is said that the elections of the Deputies under the new Constitution would be commenced on the 7th of July inst. We publish elsewhere a variety of interesting information concerning the movements and plans of GARIBALDI

abstract: Archbishop HUGHES was very jubilant at the Commencement of St. John's College at Fordham, over the tact that the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge, and Paris, and Pavia, were founded by Catholics and not by Protestants, "there being at that time no Protestants in the world;" and he thence draws the conclusion that Protestants have never done anything for education, while Catholics have done everything. Without the slightest wish to be impertinent, we cannot help calling the Archbishop's attention to the fact, that it was the English Catholics also who perverted Oxford and Cambridge to the base uses which they now serve, and made them hotbeds of heresy and schism.

abstract: THE, SEVENTH REGIMENT ENCAMPMENT. -- Yesterday was comparatively a quiet day at Camp Scott; the number of visitors was far less than on Wednesday, although at the Regimental parade and drill in the afternoon, which was one of the finest that has been witnessed during the encampment, there were not less than 2,000 spectators of both sexes present. Inspector-General SHERMAN visited the camp yesterday, and in company with the field officers of the Regiment and Adjutant-General CARRINGTON, of Ohio, made a personal inspection of every tent in the Camp. He expressed himself much pleased with the encampment in whole and in detail. Between the parade and the Regimented drill, the soldiers were reviewed in line by the Inspector-General. To-day is the last day of the encampment, and a large concourse of visitors is untipated. A grand bal champers is to be given in the evening which will be attended by a. large number of the lady friends and relatives of the soldiers from this City. In addition to the bail, there will be a brilliant display of fireworks on the ground. A special train of ears will leave the Camp for New York at a late hour of the night, for the accommodation of those was may desire to witness the close of the festivities.

abstract: This trotting match took place, yesterday, at the Union Course. About a thousand persons were present, one-half of whom went by the 2 o'clock sporting train of the Long Island Railroad. The track was in excellent condition and considerable interest existed amongst sporting men in regard to the time which might be made in comparison with the recent performances of Flora Temple and Patchen.
lead_paragraph: This trotting match took place, yesterday, at the Union Course. About a thousand persons were present, one-half of whom went by the 2 o'clock sporting train of the Long Island Railroad. The track was in excellent condition and considerable interest existed amongst sporting men in regard to the time which might be made in comparison with the recent performances of Flora Temple and Patchen. The result has shown that Ethan, can squally trot in excellent time, and that Princess is not in the right hands to make the most of her line powers, she being very sore and stiff from the effects of over work; it being said that two minutes and twenty-two seconds had been made by her on the day previous to and on the morning of the trot with Ethan. The betting stood at $100 to $70 on Ethan previous to the first heat.

abstract: We publish this morning a full report of a speech made by Cassius M. CLAY, at Louisville, Ky., on Saturday evening last. It is a vindication of the principles and purposes of the Republican Party, made before an audience of several thousand people, and listened to, according to the statement of our Reporter, with marked attention and interest from the beginning to the end. This fact shows that there are portions of the South in which freedom of opinion and of speech are not mere empty names. We cannot but hope that the people of the whole South may gradually come to see that they are far more deeply interested than those of any other section of the Union, in the calm and dispassionate discussion of the great social and political questions connected with the subject of Slavery. Such speeches as that of Mr. CLAY are admirably calculated to allay the irrational and passionate excitement, which has so frequently been invoked for the suppression of all debate, and the extinction of all freedom of speech and of the Press, in various sections of the Southern States.

abstract: The arguments on the application to reopen the judgments in this case, have closed at last, and it only remains for Judge INGRAHAM to give his decision. We have published, from day to day the leading points of the various speeches that have been made on both sides of the question. The charge on the one hand is, that the judgments by which the State was put in possession of these lands, created by filling out beyond the line of the City Charter, were obtained by fraud and collusion, -- the evidence of such fraud consisting in alleged negligence of the Corporation Counsel, in alleged misconduct of the Commissioners of the Land Office, in alleged ignorance or undue bias of the Judge who presided, and the jury of tax-payers who decided the case, upon the trial. It is not for us to estimate the weight to which these allegations are entitled, as evidence, in a case of so much importance. The main fact in the contest seems to be, that the lawyers and others claiming to represent the City, are dissatisfied with the result of the trials, and feel bound, therefore, to do and say anything which may give them the supposed advantage of going all over that ground again.
lead_paragraph: The arguments on the application to reopen the judgments in this case, have closed at last, and it only remains for Judge INGRAHAM to give his decision. abstract: It is stated that Alderman Genet appealed to Judge RUSSELL yesterday afternoon for a warrant against KERRICAN, for the attempt upon his life in the Park in the forenoon, and that "His Honor" the Judge refused to grant it, believing that he can himself arrange the affair amicably. If this be true, it is a singularly appropriate termination to the whole affair. An Alderman attempts a criminal assault upon the relatives of an Ex-Councilman. The Ex-Councilman sets about murdering the Alderman at noon at the door of the Court-house, in the presence of hundreds of people, in the midst of a large Christian city. The Alderman saves himself by dodging behind a tree, and then both parties leave the ground unmolested, and finally the Judge of the highest criminal Court refuses a warrant, because he intends to make a personal application to the offender himself, to forego his bloody purpose. We hope our pastors and churches and fathers of families like their "municipal system," and are proud of their elective judiciary. We wish them joy of them both.

abstract: In the TIMES of Tuesday morning we published a letter signed "Rev. J.A. SIMMS, No.42 Forty-ninth-street," representing- that the family of an educated gentleman named W A. STORIA was in circumstances of extreme destitution, -- that the father was sick and unable to procure work, that one child had just died of starvation, that two others were very ill from the same cause, that the mother had attempted suicide. -- that both parents were of irreproachable character, and that immediate relief was required. We found the letter upon our desk on Monday night, and deeming the case one of great urgency we published the appeal without taking our usual precaution of making preliminary inquiries, -- appending a note promising to hand over whatever sums of money might be entrusted to us for that purpose, if the parties should prove to be deserving.

abstract: The New-York and Erie Railroad Company is now formally announced to be in the "article of death." Under a decree of the Supreme Court, the fifth mortgage on this broad has been foreclosed, and after the sale on the 20th November next, this vast improvement, one of the great arteries of our metropolitan commerce, and for the last two years the sport and victim of the Stock Exchange, will commence a new career under a new organization and a new name.

abstract: William H. Johnson vs. John S. Irick, et al. -- This was an action for damages for an alleged breach of contract, and was tried before Justice McCARTHY, in the Marine Court. The defendants, who are proprietors of an iron foundry in New-Jersey, furnished to the City of Brooklyn a large quantity of pipe, for conveying water through the streets of that city. The plaintiff complained that in July, 1859, he entered into a contract with the defendants, by which, at a stipulated price, he agreed to apply to 1,200 tons of said pipe a certain bituminous coating, known as "Patent Coal Tar Varnish," the object of which was to prevent cohesion and oxidation in the pipes, and that he had been permitted by the defendants to apply said coating to only part of the amount stated, although the work was entirely satisfactory. The defendants denied the contract as to amount, and set up a counter claim. The Judge charged the jury that, if they found for the plaintiff on the issue of fact, he was entitled to the whole amount of the profits which would have accrued to him had he completed his contract. The case, which has been on trial for several days, yesterday resulted in a verdict for plaintiff, the jury assessing the damages at $350.
lead_paragraph: William H. Johnson vs. John S. Irick, et al. -- This was an action for damages for an alleged breach of contract, and was tried before Justice McCARTHY, in the Marine Court. The defendants denied the contract as to amount, and set up a counter claim. The Judge charged the jury that, if they found for the plaintiff on the issue of fact, he was entitled to the whole amount of the profits which would have accrued to him had he completed his contract. abstract: For a year past the combustible condition of Southern Italy has in a special degree attracted the attention of statesmen, and the results now developed in that beautiful and unhappy land have long been expected. The kindling fires of revolution, still slumbering in Umbria and the Marches, have burst into a flame in Sicily, and threaten to involve, as a dry prairie, the Kingdom of Naples in the conflagration.

abstract: There is something affecting in the relations between the reader of History and the writer of History. Faith is necessarily far more exercised than sight: for few can follow a historian through the chaos of documents, state papers, pamphlets, letters, memoires pour servir -- down to very ballads and pasquinades, from which his history is extracted. We are thus forced to fall back on the capacity and veracity of the writer: and the more thoroughly we are cut off from the possibility of external evidence and authority, the more need for interior warranties. These we are to find in the structure of the Historian's mind, which necessarily communicates itself to his pages, and which we apprehend rather through intuition than through the exercise of any very profound mental anatomy.

abstract: Joshua Atkins et al. vs. August Horrman. -- This was an action brought in the U.S. District Court before Judge BETTS, by the owners of the ship Seth Sprague, to recover freight on some pipes of wine brought on the ship from Rotterdam to New-York in May, 1859, consigned to the respondent. The defence was that a pipe of wine worth more than the freight was lost on the passage by carelessness. This pipe, on arrival of the vessel, was found to have one head pressed in so that the wine had leaked out. The libelants proved that the cargo was well stowed and dunnaged, and proved also that the head of the cask had been made thinner in the middle on the inside than at the sides, and argued that by reason of this the cask had been unable to bear the necessary weight of the cargo.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Atkins et al. vs. August Horrman. -- This was an action brought in the U.S. District Court before Judge BETTS, by the owners of the ship Seth Sprague, to recover freight on some pipes of wine brought on the ship from Rotterdam to New-York in May, 1859, consigned to the respondent. The defence was that a pipe of wine worth more than the freight was lost on the passage by carelessness. This pipe, on arrival of the vessel, was found to have one head pressed in so that the wine had leaked out. The libelants proved that the cargo was well stowed and dunnaged, and proved also that the head of the cask had been made thinner in the middle on the inside than at the sides, and argued that by reason of this the cask had been unable to bear the necessary weight of the cargo.

abstract: NEW REPUBLICAN CLUB. The Republicans of the Assembly District, composed of the Fourth and Tenth Wards, held a meeting on Thursday evening, when it was resolved to organize a Lincoln and Hamlin Club for that District. A public meeting will be held next week to elect officers and perfect the organization, at which time also several distinguished advocates of Republican principles will make addresses.
lead_paragraph: NEW REPUBLICAN CLUB. -- The Republicans of the Assembly District, composed of the Fourth and Tenth Wards, held a meeting on Thursday evening, when it was resolved to organize a Lincoln and Hamlin Club for that District. abstract: The perplexitiy of the inexperienced traveler, who sees a high wall of mountain suddenly rise up before him, write no visible gap in its perpendicular face, nor winding pathway over its cloudcapped comb, not inaptly illustrates the bewilderment which timid people feel in view of the great political revolution which confronts them at the present moment. All before them is dark and threatening, and they see no hope of escape from the dilemma.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The United States corvette Macedonian, which has just return to Portsmouth, N.H., from the Mediterranean, was to haul off the Navy-yard yesterday, where, at a general quarters, the authorities were to inspect the crew. The particulars of the Macedonian's cruise have appeared from time to time in the public journals. She sailed from the United States about two years since, to serve under the Commodore of the steam-frigate Wabash, then flag-ship in "the Straits," and has since, as we stated a few days ago, touched at all the ports of Southern Europe to represent our navy. She returns in good condition, her crew being generally healthy and efficient. The Commodore's dispatches were sent by express to Washington, from Portsmouth, on Tuesday evening; and when the accounts of the ship's company return authenticated by the Secretary of the Navy the men will be paid off and discharged, those deserving certificates of good conduct receiving them.

abstract: To HON. CHARLES SUMNER -- Dear Sir: I presume I am indebted to the fact of my name being on a clerical list for the reception of a document, franked "C. SUMNER," which, on opening, I find to be a copy of your late speech on Slavery, in the Senate of the United States. I had previously read that speech in the NEW-YORK TIMES, which, as usual, gave an excellent report. Before reading it, your name was in my memory as an unjust sufferer; now I cannot think of you otherwise than as a man who has nursed wrath four years, and at last taken his revenge. I do not believe you have improved your position, added to your personal comfort, or increased your influence.

abstract: MEETING FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE GARIBALDI FUND. -- A meeting of citizens of most of the European nationalities, took place on Thursday evening, at the Metropolitan Rooms in Hester-street, Dr. GUSTAVUS STRUNE in the Chair. The object of this gathering was to create a fund, which should be transmitted to Gen. GARIBALDI, to aid him in his struggle against the Bourbon Government at Naples. Several gentlemen addressed the meeting in the French, German and Italian languages; resolutions were adopted expressing sympathy with and promising aid for the Italian cause, and measures were taken for the appointment of a Committee to collect contributions and forward them to the proper destination, said Committee to have power to call other meetings.
lead_paragraph: MEETING FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE GARIBALDI FUND. -- A meeting of citizens of most of the European nationalities, took place on Thursday evening, at the Metropolitan Rooms in Hester-street, Dr. GUSTAVUS STRUNE in the Chair. abstract: The military sensation of to-day, next to the return of the Seventh Regiment, will be the reception of the Chicago Zouaves. The Sixth Regiment will entertain them at the Astor House, and probably afford them an opportunity of viewing the return of the Seventh. They will give an exhibition drill in the Park during the afternoon, and in the evening will visit Laura Keene's Theatre, upon invitation of Mr. JEFFERSON, to witness the burlesque of the "Tycoon."

abstract: We observe that correspondents at Washington are telegraphing with great vigor to all parts of the country that the head of every Douglas officeholder in the land is doomed to fall. They assert, with a very suspicious unanimity of fervor, that the President is inexorable, -- that his mind is fixed, and that nothing whatever can turn or divert him from his bloody purpose. All this really indicates that the Douglas men are perfectly safe in their seals. They will not be removed at all. A few of the small fry may, but no potential and important officeholder will lose his place because he supports Mr. DOUGLAS.

abstract: Twenty-nine years ago, the pirates GIBBS (white) and WAMSLEY (colored) were hung at Ellis' Island for crimes similar to that for which HICKS suffered. The next execution in New-York for piracy was that of CORNELIUS WILHELMS, which took place at Ellis' Island on the 21st of June, 1839. The case of GIBBS was remarkable in many respects. He led a life of crime, and showed compunction for but one of the many murders he committed.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine years ago, the pirates GIBBS (white) and WAMSLEY (colored) were hung at Ellis' Island for crimes similar to that for which HICKS suffered. abstract: John E. Enright, the ticket swindler, was yesterday arrested by Officer Dougherty, of the Lower Police Court, charged with robbing John McQualken, a resident of Richmond, Va., of $105. It appears that McQualken arrived in the City on Thursday afternoon, and was met on the pier by a man who inquired if he wanted a boarding-house. On giving a reply, in the affirmative, he was conducted to Enright's place, No. 117 Cedar-street, and gave his baggage in charge of the bartender; but after being at the house a few minutes he became satisfied that it was not a proper place for him, and asked for the return of the baggage. Enright told him that the baggage would not be given up until he had paid his bill, and demanded $1. McQualken having had nothing in the house, refused to pay the demand, whereupon, as alleged, the barkeeper, by order of Enright, seized him and robbed him of $1 05, after which his carpet bag was given to him, and he was hustled info the street. Qualken, subsequently, appeared before Justice Welsh, and preferred a charge of robbery against Entight, and Ryan the barkeeper, and both were arrested and locked up in the Toombs to await trial. The complainant was sent to the House of Detention to answer his presence in Court as a witness when wanted.

abstract: Yesterday our Congress assembled. The President's Message was at once received. Some of the public journals anticipate the inauguration of a new life of policy by the new minister VARAS, who has recently entered, or, more srictly speaking, returned to the Cabinet. However, be his intentions as they may, no hint has transpired about them yet.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The memorable encampment of the Seventh Regiment ended last evening in a grand feu de joie, although the formal striking of tents and leaving for home takes place this morning. The afternoon review, the brilliant and gay assemblage of both female and male friends of the Regiment, the gorgeous illumination, pyrotechnic display, and the grand ball of the evening made the occasion one to be remembered as one of the incidents in the history of the Regiment.
lead_paragraph: The memorable encampment of the Seventh Regiment ended last evening in a grand feu de joie, although the formal striking of tents and leaving for home takes place this morning.
