abstract: This Club held a regular meeting last night at their head-quarters in Union-square, Mr. D.S. CODDINGTON, Vice-President, in the Chair. At the last meeting, (twenty-four members only being present,) after a long and exciting discussion, the Club passed resolutions indorsing DOUGLAS and JOHNSON as their Presidential candidates, by a vote of 15 to 9. This course was exceedingly unsatisfactory to the members of the Club holding positions under the General Government, who were in the minority, and who recognized a Mr. HARRISON as their leader.
lead_paragraph: This Club held a regular meeting last night at their head-quarters in Union-square, Mr. D.S. CODDINGTON, Vice-President, in the Chair. abstract: -- A terrible altair occurred at Proctorville, Lake Borgne, on Saturday afternoon, the main facts only of which have yet reached town, It appears that a Chinaman went into a coffee-house with a party of fifteen to drink; and only put down twenty-five cents. They went our, and another Chinaman went in and claimed a drink, but the bar-keeper, a Spaniard; refused to give it to him. The Chinaman slapped him in the face, and the Spaniard threw a tumbler at him. A countryman of the bar keeper's went in to his assistance, whereupon the Chinaman stabbed him. He then rushed out and stabbed an other Spaniard on the gallery, who attempted to stop him. He then ran for the wharfs, and was pursued by another Spaniard named AUGUSTINE FELLNRD, and he got cut in several places. The Celestial desperado leaped into the Lake to swim to a boat, but before he reached one he was shot dead. The two men stabbed in the coffee-house expired shortly after. FELLERD was brought up to town, but died in the Charity Hospital at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. He was stabbed in several places, and the flesh was literally hewed off from the bone on the right arm, between the elbow and the shoulder. He was a member of the Spanish Benevolent Association. -- New-Orleans Bulletin.
lead_paragraph: -- A terrible altair occurred at Proctorville, Lake Borgne, on Saturday afternoon, the main facts only of which have yet reached town, It appears that a Chinaman went into a coffee-house with a party of fifteen to drink; and only put down twenty-five cents. abstract: -HICKS' Confession is a choice specimen of penny-a-lining, but does not reflect much credit on Marshal RYNDERS' literary employe. The labor expended in working up the raw material furnished from the scoundrel's own lips must have been very great; and on the whole, the public have seldom had a better opportunity of judging of the manner in which the adventures of cut throats are manufactured into the conglomeration of blood and thunder and bad grammar, which adorns the columns of the weekly papers, under the name of "exciting stories."

abstract: A statement was recently made in a telegram from New-Orleans that a revenue cutter had left that city to overhaul the schooner J.B. Taylor, which had sailed for Central America with "emigrants" on board. A Washington dispatch states that for more than five months it has been known to Government that small parties were occasionally leaving Southern ports in like manner for the same destination, but the movements have hitherto been considered too insignificant for notice. Their importance will probably be learned when it becomes necessary for the Government to interfere again to prevent some one of the Central American States from being overrun by filibusters.
lead_paragraph: A statement was recently made in a telegram from New-Orleans that a revenue cutter had left that city to overhaul the schooner J.B. abstract: The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company yesterday telegraphed Mr. HENRY A. JARRETT, the manager of the receptions on board of the steamer Great Eastern, to know whether it was not practicable and desirable for the great steamship to pay her respects to the waters of the Chesapeake bay for the double purpose of exhibition and coaling, of which 8,000 tons is required for a voyage of the Atlantic. The semi-bituminous coal of the Cumberland regions, so peculiarly adapted to steamers, and used by the steamers of the Cunard and Collins lines, could be conveyed from Locust Point in lighters to Annapolis Roads, at a cost of about 25 cents a ton, thus effecting a saving of above $8,000 on the freight of the coal from Baltimore to New-York. Another inducement offered would be her location, which would afford the citizens of the South and Southwest an opportunity to visit and inspect her 300, 400 and 500 miles nearer their homes than New-York. In case the offer should be accepted by the Great Eastern Company, it is well known that there is ample water in the Chesapeake and at Annapolis Roads; while the facilities that would be afforded by the railroads leading into Baltimore, and other transportation agencies, would afford a sight of the marine wonder to the curious of the States of Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania, Virginia, North and South Carolina, Ohio, and further south and southwest. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company have not as yet learned the determination of the directors of the Great Eastern Company, but hope in a few days to be able to announce that the Great Eastern is coming South to give exhibitions. -- Baltimore Sun, July 11.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company yesterday telegraphed Mr. HENRY A. JARRETT, the manager of the receptions on board of the steamer Great Eastern, to know whether it was not practicable and desirable for the great steamship to pay her respects to the waters of the Chesapeake bay for the double purpose of exhibition and coaling, of which 8,000 tons is required for a voyage of the Atlantic. abstract: One very great defect in the various projects that have been broached for dissolving the Union, has been their lack of any practical, tangible, feasible shape. The Montgomery, Alabama, Mail has removed this little difficulty, and sketched a scheme by which the Union can be dissolved without the slightest difficulty.

abstract: Another of the landmarks of the metropolis has been submerged by the upward wave of trade. Bond-street, once the most aristocratic and fashionable street of New-York, has been given up to boarding-houses and shops of various kinds. For some years past the intrusion has been progressing; first one old family mansion and then another succumbed; one after another of the most aristocratic establishments, where thirty years ago the wealth and beauty and distinction of New-York were wont to congregate, was converted into a receptacle for milliner's bonnets, or a hall devoted to dentistic purposes. The beauty and fashion still were seen in the same houses, but they went to buy their bonnets and to set their teeth, -- not to show them.
lead_paragraph: Another of the landmarks of the metropolis has been submerged by the upward wave of trade. For some years past the intrusion has been progressing; first one old family mansion and then another succumbed; one after another of the most aristocratic establishments, where thirty years ago the wealth and beauty and distinction of New-York were wont to congregate, was converted into a receptacle for milliner's bonnets, or a hall devoted to dentistic purposes. The beauty and fashion still were seen in the same houses, but they went to buy their bonnets and to set their teeth, -- not to show them.

abstract: The Atlanta, Ga., Locomotive of the 11th says: "Hon. John H. Lumskin died suddenly at his residence in Rome, yesterday morning, from apoplexy." Ju[???]ge Lumpkin was born in Ogletho[???]pe County, Georgia, on the 13th or June, 1812. He received a thorough education at Franklin and Yale Colleges, and soon after his graduation served for some time as Secretary in the Executive Department of Georgia. Resigning his position there, he devoted himself to the study of the law, and was admitted to the bar in 1834. In 1838 he was Solicitor General of the Cherokee Circuit; from 1843 to 1849 he was a member of the House of Representatives, and was reelected to the Thirty-first Congress. In 1858 he was again appointed Solicitor-General of the Cherokee Circuit. He also held the office, for three years, of Judge of the Cherokee Circuit Court, a ad that of Judge of the Supreme Court of the State.

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN. On Saturday there was a greater number of visitors to this mammoth megamerian, mastedonical, matchless marine marvel than on any other previous day, and it was gratifying to notice that one-half, at least, of these who inspected her, were children from public and private schools, who took advantage of the "holiday" and the reduced fare, to satisfy a natural and laudable curiosity.
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT EASTERN. -- On Saturday there was a greater number of visitors to this mammoth megamerian, mastedonical, matchless marine marvel than on any other previous day, and it was gratifying to notice that one-half, at least, of these who inspected her, were children from public and private schools, who took advantage of the "holiday" and the reduced fare, to satisfy a natural and laudable curiosity. They were of opinion that they never saw such a big ship before, nor one half so big --no, nor scarcely one "half to big as half so big." The acre deck was a wondrous play-ground for them, while the investigation of the saloons dining-rooms, state-rooms, and engine-rooms, kept their astonishment and approbation alive all the time. Of mounting the wheel houses and gazing down that fearful depth into the water, they seemed never to be weary. The number of adults who visited the ship was also larger than on previous occasion. The shareholders are rapidly reaping the advantage of the reduction, of fare. During the week, arrangements have been made by various railroads to bring people from all parts of this and neighboring States to visit her at reduced fares.

abstract: 9 and 10 o' clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the principal workshop at the car-works of Messrs. KIMBALL & GORTON, Twenty-first and Hamilton streets. The building, a stone one, 196 feet by 50 feet in dim ensions, and one and a half stories high, contained a large quantity of worked material, including the frames for fifty coal cars, ready to be put together, and much valuable machinery, some of which was put up recently at a heavy outlay. In consequence of the quantity of combustible material in it, and of the numerous windows being open, creating a draft, the flames spread rapidly, so much so that the workmen escaped with difficulty and were not able to save their clothing. In a few minutes the whole structure was enveloped in flames, creating a most intense heat and setting fire to a large amount of lumber on Twenty firs street, and rendering it impossible for the firemen to work there. From the principal workshop the flames extended to the blacksmith shop and the paint shop, both of which were destroyed with their contents including two cars, a large one for the Catawissa Railroad, valued at $3,000; the other for the Howard Express Company, worth $800. A large stone shop to the west of those; for the finishing of cars, containing a large number, was not retched by the fire. The principal workshop was totally destroyed, as was also all the valuable machinery in it Some of the lumber was saved in a partially damaged condition. The steam engine was in a fire-proof building, and was not damaged, except by water. The fire burned for several hours, during which time the firemen labored very actively. The office was burnt, but the books and papers were saved. The firm had an insurance of $30,000 upon the buildings and stock, which is divided among the Franklin, Commonwealth, Exchange, and Hope Mutual of Philadelphia, and the [???]na of Hartford, Conn. The insurance will probably cover the loss though the exact amount of damage cannot be ascertained for some days. Immediate arrangements will be made for the rebuilding of the factory, so that the fire will not materially interfere with the operations of the firm. There is no doubt as to the origin of the fire. The furnace-room has an opening into it from the chief work shop through which the shavings are conveyed to be burnt this was being done yesterday, and the back draught caused the flames to burst out under the furnace and [???]et fire to the shavings. The flames instantly extended to the shop. To prevent fire, the engine-room had been made fire-proof, and it was thought every precaution had been taken to guard against it. None of the surrounding property was damaged. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 14.

abstract: A NOTED BURGLAR SENTENCED. -- JAMES MURPHY, alias McCarty, was convicted of burglary in the first degree in the Court of Sessions, on Saturday, for robbing the house of Mr. MESKER, corner of Bush-wick-avenue and Linden-street, on the morning of June 23 last, and was immediately sentenced to ten years' imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing. MURPHY is only 25 years of age, but has been known to the Police for several years as a daring burglar, arid though frequently arrested in New-York, he has always managed to escape punishment there. Several years ago he was sentenced to twenty one years' imprisonment in New-Jersey for burglary, but after a short incarceration he was pardoned.

abstract: -- A Parisian physician has been making successful use of the magnet in discovering foreign substances, such as shell-splinters, fragments of needles, etc., in the organs of the body. He hangs the magnet on a string, and on its becoming immobile, he brings one of the poles near the region where he supposes the foreign body may be lodged; the deviation or immobility of the magnet confirms or destroys his suspicion. In this way he was able to point out the precise locality in the left fore-arm of a voltigeur where a shell-splinter had lodged, and which produced a serious edema of the whole member, lasting for over ten months; but in four days after the extraction of the foreign substance by this means, he was quite cured.
lead_paragraph: -- A Parisian physician has been making successful use of the magnet in discovering foreign substances, such as shell-splinters, fragments of needles, etc., in the organs of the body. He hangs the magnet on a string, and on its becoming immobile, he brings one of the poles near the region where he supposes the foreign body may be lodged; the deviation or immobility of the magnet confirms or destroys his suspicion. abstract: The hearing of the charge of forgery preferred by WILLIAM H. DAVIDGE , President of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, against FREDERICK HOFFMAN, late Secretary and Transfer Clerk of the corporation, was to have been resumed on Saturday before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court. On account, however, of the continued illness of Mr. DAVIDGE , the investigation was not proceeded with, but several additional charges were presented against he defendant, and the case was adjourned until Tuesday next.

abstract: We publish in another column a copy of a memorial, which has just been put into circulation among the taxpayers of New-York, urging the Board of Councilmen to arrest the march of Mayor WOOD towards a pure municipal despotism, by refusing their concurrence in the removal of two officers from the Croton Aqueduct Department for "insubordination."
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a copy of a memorial, which has just been put into circulation among the taxpayers of New-York, urging the Board of Councilmen to arrest the march of Mayor WOOD towards a pure municipal despotism, by refusing their concurrence in the removal of two officers from the Croton Aqueduct Department for "insubordination." We may as well frankly say at once, however, that we have little hope of any good to be effected by this very proper and praiseworthy step. Of course every sensible and respectable man in New-York who knows anything of the way in which his money is spent, and his interests looked after, by the Government we are supposed to have chosen for ourselves, knows perfectly well that Mr. CRAVEN, for instance, is now, as he has for many years past been, an officer wholly competent to the charge of the great aqueduct on which the health, the comfort, and, it may almost be said without exaggeration, the life of New-York, have now come to depend. Of course, too, every such person knows, that to transfer the control and management of this vital public work at this sea-son of the year to new and, necessarily, inexperienced hands, is to risk the whole water supply of the metropolis at the moment when it is of supreme importance to the public hygiene. Equally of course, it requires no great exertion of the intellect for any good citizen to understand that a Chief Magistrate who can thus deliberately trifle e with the welfare of the community, on the ground of personal offence taken by himself is, on his own showing, a man utterly unfit either to remove or to appoint any public officer whatever. Were Mr. CRAVEN lawfully held and bound to do homage to "this our Caesar," and had he willfully neglected this great feudal duty, it would be an act of the commonest good citizenship, in our master, to overlook his own personal annoyance in the consideration of the general good. But Mr. CRAVEN, not being Mr. WOOD'S "subordinate," cannot have been guilty of "insubordination," and the Mayor's, pretended "cause" for his removal rests on the same basis with the enlightened determination of Mr. Alderman CORNELL, who, it seems, has resolved to vote against Mr. CRAVEN'S retention in office, whether he is or is not a fit man for his place, simply because he (Mr. CORNELL) does not like "Mr. CRAVEN'S manners, and thinks him wanting in respect to Aldermen when they call on him." What the errands of Aldermen usually are, when they call on the heads of tax-disbursing Departments, we all know, and it is just possible that the people of New-York may find something to commend in the independence of a public servant who fails to show "respect" to Ward politicians who invade his office with droves of pets whom they wish at once provided with posts at the public crib, Mr. CRAVEN'S destined successor, we may depend, will be exquisitely "respectful" alike to Alderman CORNELL and to Mayor WOOD, at least until after his confirmation in office. Once confirmed, he will belong to "His Excellency" alone, and the silly Fathers, who are so greedily bent on giving us a King Stork, will then perhaps find out that there is not room enough in the City Hall for him and them.

abstract: The Times says: In consequence of the close of the half year, the demand for discount at the Bank has been extremely heavy. In the course or the next for[???]ght, however, owing to the steady arrivals of gold, and the face that the rate of discount is at present higher in England than at any part of the Continent, and equal even to the terms current at New-York, a return of comparative ease is expected, which, in the event of fine weather and the absence of foreign loans, may lead before the end of July to a reduction of the Bank charge to 3 1/3 [???] cent.

abstract: The steamship Vanderbilt, from Havre and Southampton on the 4th inst., arrived at this port on Saturday night. Among her passengers were Col. CIPRIANI, Aid-de-Camp to Prince NAPOLEON, Hon. J.L. WHITE, late United States Consul at Lyons, and JOHN C. HEENAN, the Pugilist. The news by the Vanderbilt, which is four days later, is not of an important character; but the particulars given by our correspondent of the progress of the revolution in Southern Italy will be found extremely interesting. In Sicily, the uni versal suffrage of the people and army would be taken on the question of annexation of Sicily to Piedmont. The concessions of the Neapolitan Government, far from checking the enterprises of the Dictator, have determined him to precipitate the annexation, which he had previously been disposed to delay. The most intense excitement prevailed at Naples. There had been several popular outbreaks, in which the police were severely handled; but at latest dates tranquillity had been temporarily restored. Letters from Rome assert that a crisis there was also imminent. GARIBALDI does not care to conceal his belief that the liberation of Rome and Naples, as well as the liberation of Sicily, form part of his mission. From all other parts of Europe the news by ibis arrival is unusually void of interest.

abstract: The steamship Adriatic, Capt. COMSTOCK, left her pier foot of Canal-street Shortly after 2 o'clock P.M., on Saturday, for Southampton and Havre. She had 315 passengers, a large mail, and $1,122,000 in treasure.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Adriatic, Capt. COMSTOCK, left her pier foot of Canal-street Shortly after 2 o'clock P.M., on Saturday, for Southampton and Havre. She had 315 passengers, a large mail, and $1,122,000 in treasure. The reputation for speed which this ship has already achieved; the splendid accommodations afforded; her great comfort as a sea-going steamer, and the wide popularity of her commander, have made the Adriatic a favorite vessel, particularly to tourists, who constituted a large proportion of the passengers on the present trip. Hon, JOHN F. APPLETON, Minister to Russia, Senor ESCALANTE, Spanish Minister to Mexico, Gen. HALSEY, bearer of dispatches to Germany and France; Bishop QUINLAN of Mobile, Rev. GEORGE B. CHEEVER and Rev. A.H. MEAD were of the number. A large party of the friends of the passengers assembled to take leave, and for an hour before she left the dock the Canal-street pier was a scene of considerable excitement. The mails were detained until the latest moment, and some uneasiness began to be felt on this account. When they finally reached the dock, it only remained to pass them on board, which was accomplished with unusual dispatch, and the ship shot out of her berth in splendid style. Guns from the neighboring steamers, including two from the Great Eastern, complimented her departure. A small steamer, having on board a party of the friends of Rev. Mr. MEAD, went down the Bay for the purpose of waving him a last adieu. A large number of Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S admirers also accompanied him down the bay as far as Sandy Hook on boat d of the steamer May Queen, the Doctor first going on board of the boat at the head of the Canal-street Pier, and taking leave of his friends. Wm. GOODELL, OLIVER JOHNSON, Editor of the Anti-Slavery Standard; THEODORE TILTON. Assistant Editor of the Independent Rev. H. H. GARNETT, pastor of Shiloh Presbyterian Church and a considerable number of colored persons were on board. On the way down, an impromptu meeting was organized on the saloon deck of the May Queen, which was addressed by OLIVER JOHNSON, WILLIAM GOODELL, THEODORE TILTON and Rev. Mr. MATTESON, Mr. JOHNSON denounced in severe terms the article in the last Independent written by Rev, Mr, THOMPSON the Tabernacle Church, condemning Dr. Cheever's mission. He eulogized the Doctor as a noble man, a true minister of Jesus Christ, and one of the most steadfast friends of the slave in the United States, and he wished him God-speed in his mission to Old England in behalf of the enslaved in this land.

abstract: JOHN C. HEENAN, known also as the "Benicia Boy," arrived in the steamer Vanderbilt on Saturday night, accompanied by JOHN MACDONALD, who was his trainer for his fight with THOMAS SAYERS. Owing to the lateness of the hour at which the Vanderbilt arrived off Quarantine, comparatively few of his admirers were aware that he was below until yesterday morning, and consequently he was not met by a very large number of men. On Friday last, Messrs. CAMPBELL and McCABE, of the "Malta" saloon -- the headquarters of HEENAN'S friends -- chartered the steamer John A. Lock-wood, and, after witnessing the execution of Hicks, proceeded down the Bay, with a large party on board, to meet the Vanderbilt, and welcome HEENAN home. They remained off Sandy Hook until Saturday evening, when their coal and refreshment ran short, and the Vanderbilt not appearing, they were obliged to return without seeing the Boy. However, they resolved not to be disappointed, and were about to hire another boat, when the arrival of the Vanderbilt was announced as the Malta Saloon. Quite a large party started immediately for the landing, and on arriving there, were again disappointed; for the vessel had not arrived at her dock, and it was thought she would not arrive there until morning. There was nothing left but to wait until morning, which they reluctantly concluded to do. In the meantime HEENAN and MACDONALD had left the ship, and taken quarters in Burns' Hotel, on Staten Island, where it was thought they would remain over Sunday. That impression caused quite a large number of people to visit Staten Island yesterday, who were curious to see him. But, again, there was disappointment, for at 10 o'clock yesterday, he left Bun's Hotels came up to the City and proceeded to the house of a friend, in Fourth-avenue, where he is supposed to have remained during me day. Both HEENAN and his trainer are in excellent health, and it is expected that arrangements for a fight wish JOHN MORRISSEY will soon be made, as the "Buy" has expressed a fervent desire to whip Mr. M. as soon as possible, so as not to delay his return to England to meet the "Staley bridge Infant," and have another fight for the Champion's belt. By the way, the last effort of the English to satisfy HEENAN, and retain the Champion's belt in their own country, has turnsd out as un-handsome as their previous conduct in connection with the same matter. After having formally presented the new bell to him several times, and in the presence of thousands of people. HEENAN has been obliged to return without it. At the time he left it had not been paid for, and the manufacturers seized it and refused to let it go until after the reception of the requisite amount of money. His friends here are arranging to give him a public reception and welcome home. The following notices of his intended departure from England indicate a slight change in the feeling of a portion of the English Press towards him:

abstract: The pastoral letter of his Grace, the Archbishop of Baltimore, and the Suffragans of that great province of the Roman Catholic Church, an extract from which appears in another column, marks an era in the history of the Church militant, over which every American Protestant will probably exult.
lead_paragraph: The pastoral letter of his Grace, the Archbishop of Baltimore, and the Suffragans of that great province of the Roman Catholic Church, an extract from which appears in another column, marks an era in the history of the Church militant, over which every American Protestant will probably exult. No weapon has been more powerful in the hands of Anti-Papal controversialists than the vast sums of money dispatched by the Roman propaganda, aided by an Austrian missionary combination, to extend the area of Catholicism in this country; and the amounts obtained from ardent disciples of LUTHER and CALVIN as a competing capital wherewith to repel the monetary warfare of the seven-headed monster have been of the most satisfactory character. Indeed, every attribute of national and sectarian jealousy has been called into the liveliest activity by this standard old story. The Pastoral indicates that this state of things has come to an end. The tide has turned. American Catholicism is invoked to aid the Papacy struggling for existence in Europe; and the current of sanctified bullion no longer passes from the Old World to the New, but flows backward in the path of Empire. No longer are Roman scudi and Austrian florins to extend the cords and strengthen the stakes of the Church of St. Peter in the wilderness of the Far Wesi. The blood which has so long poured from the heart to the extremities, now seeks the origin of pulsation; and there will not be wanting shrewd observers who will predict death as the inevitable physiological result of this new action.

abstract: hearing was had in the Supreme Court upon a suit brought against the town of Adams by there administrator of the estate of JAMES RAYMOND, to recover $25,000, the alleged value of &1 elephant Columbus, which received injuries from which he died, by the breaking of a bridge at South Adams. The question submitted to the court was, whether the plaintiff could recover, even if the facts were not liable, and that there was no obligation upon them to maintain roads and bridges safe and convenient for the driving of elephants over them for exhibition, but that if the plaintiff chose roads and bridge, for that purpose, he did it at his own risk. The Court have decided for the plaintiff, so far as to exoress the opinion that the care should be submitted to a jury, upon the evidence. It will probably be tried at the Fall term of the Court for this county, -- Boston Journal,[???]13.

abstract: At the firing of the signal gun, on Saturday morning, Camp Scott disappeared "like snow-flakes on the river;" all the tents were struck simultaneously, and in the twinkling of an eye the white village was no more. The troop rode to the boat on...
lead_paragraph: At the firing of the signal gun, on Saturday morning, Camp Scott disappeared "like snow-flakes on the river;" all the tents were struck simultaneously, and in the twinkling of an eye the white village was no more. The troop rode to the boat on their horses, the baggage and regimental property was disposed in huge, express wagons under the charge of Quartermaster WINCHESTER, the three hundred and fifty men marched to the depot, took their seats in a special train, and were whirled away to the bolt at Vanderbilt's landing. The entire regiment, including troop and baggage embarked on the steamboat Josephine, the band playing "The girl I left behind me," and the corps giving cheers for Staten Island. They were received on landing in the City by the Washington Grays, Eighth Regiment, Lieut.-Col. WATERBURY commanding, mustering all told about four hundred men, a salute being fired from the howitzer battery, under command of Capt. J.M. VARIAN, as the Josephine neared the wharf. So rapid was the firing that but four minutes and a half were consumed in discharging one hundred and two guns. After the customary escort ceremonies, the two regiments proceeded up Broadway, Park-place and the Park, in front of the City Hall, where they passed in review before the Major. Gen. SANDFORD, and members of the Common Council. The two regiments then proceeded up to the armory of the Seventh and dismissed. Camp Scott will long be pleasantly remembered by all who participated in its duties and festivities.

abstract: The almost fabulous sums expended by Londoners in facilitating and cheapening city and suburban passenger traffic, have already been referred to by the TIMES in connection with schemes for quickening our own means of getting to and down town.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Friday, June 8, 1860.

abstract: Events of the greatest importance are about to transpire in Germany. It has been remarked, that numerous meetings of all Arch Dukes have been held in Schoenbrunn. Many commentaries have been attached to these gatherings, some of which turn out at present to fee well-founded. I think I may inform you semi-officially that an understanding with Prussia and a union of Germany is progressing rapidly. It is even reported that the preliminary acts were signed by Austria and Prussia two weeks ago. Austria has recognized how her position is daily becoming more dangerous, and what a serious blow the late events in Naples are inflicting upon her policy. In one point Prussia was firm, and in this Austria was compelled to acquiesce. I allude to the guarantees of Austria's possessions in Italy, After a long consultation, the Cabinet of Vienna has become convinced that Prussia never could undertake such a guarantee, but that an agreement would nevertheless be possible. I believe Austria has made a provision for the special case, if Venetia should be attacked. She would then furnish but a smaller supply of troops to the army of the Confederacy. The Austrian Cabinet states that no more than 200,000 men are necessary to defend Venetia.

abstract: ment and marriage recently occurred in Sussex County, N.J. A bard-hearted parent was connected therewith who has distinguished himself in rattier an unusual manner, seeing that he is a reputable church member. The parties were a Miss DUELING and Mr. DALIEY. The elopement took place on Friday, and when Mrs. DUELING informed her husband thereof, he went to the woods near by, and cut two large hickory s[???]ks and came to the house, where he commenced beating his wife in a most unmerciful manner about the face, shoulders and back. His son, with some lab[???]re[???], came to the rescue of Mrs. DUELING, and took the husband away. On a promise of behaving himself they let him go. On Sunday morning he again went to the woods, and was seen by his son, who gave the alarm to his mother. She fled to a neighbor's, and would not go back. She went to Newton on Monday with the intention of making application for a d[???]voice. Mr. DUELING offered to compromise with her, but she would not, considering her life in danger -- Newark Advertiser, July 13.

abstract: On Thursday night, Mr. EDWARD BRADY, residing at the Johnson House, Chambers-street, fell overboard from a yacht, near Weehawken, and was drowned. His body has not yet been recovered ... JAMES YOUNG, an Englishman, 33 years of age, employed on board the steamship Parana, accidentally fell overboard, on Friday night, at pier No. 36, North River, and was drowned. The remains were recovered yesterday, and Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon them.

abstract: Archbishop HUGHES, or somebody whom he inspires, has addressed a letter to the Tribune, in reply to our recent remarks upon his address at the Commencement of St. John's College, Fordham. He flatly denies having charged Protestants, on that occasion, with hostility or indifference to the cause of education. We can only say that every report of his speech which has appeared that of the Tribune amongst the number confirms our statement.
lead_paragraph: Archbishop HUGHES, or somebody whom he inspires, has addressed a letter to the Tribune, in reply to our recent remarks upon his address at the Commencement of St. John's College, Fordham. He flatly denies having charged Protestants, on that occasion, with hostility or indifference to the cause of education. We can only say that every report of his speech which has appeared -- that of the Tribune amongst the number -- confirms our statement. He alleged distinctly that " New-England was the only Protestant community which had done anything to encourage education;" and he sought by a piece of the clumsiest sophistry to impress his audience with the belief that it was a more creditable achievement to have " founded" Oxford and Cambridge in the eighth or thirteenth century, than to have maintained them in brilliancy, in honor, and in efficiency during the last three hundred years. He cited them as instances of Catholic devotion to learning, but he studiously avoided ail allusion to the fact that these two Universities have won almost all their fame in Protestant, hands; that it is as Protestant institutions -- exclusively and intensely Protestant -- that they have trained hundreds of the greatest lights of science and literature which the modern world has seen. We do not assert that they might not have revolutionized philosophy in Lord Bacon, and natural science in Newton, if they had remained Catholic, though when we consider the persecutions to which Galileo was subjected by Italian prelates in his lifetime, and the angry denunciations heaped upon the earth's rotation, in our own days, by an Irish Archbishop, we might well be pardoned some doubts on the subject. But if a Catholic Archbishop must be illogical enough to sneer at Protestants for not establishing Universities before there were any Protestants in existence, he surely ought to be honest enough to mention that they have made an able use of those which Catholics bequeathed them, and that every great seat of Catholic learning which fell into their hands can show a host of illustrious names on its lists of heretical graduates.

abstract: of the engineer in charge, the boiler in the saw and planing mills of W.A. GRAVES, in Norfolk, Va., exploded on the [???]th, as already noticed by telegraph. The boiler, which weighed about 4.000 pounds, was brown a distance of sixty feet, and the engine and building were completely rutted. Most fortunate there were but few persons in the building at the [???]e of the accident. Among these was Mr. GRAVES, who was standing about twenty meet from the engine, and in the ship house. His escape from death was remarkable. He was struck on the head by some bricks, receiving several cuts, but none are considered vary dangerous. He succeeded in getting out of tee back door, but soon fell. Mr. WM. KAY, an elderly man, was very severely cut on the bead;[???] the colored engineer, receiving a heavy blow on the side, and PHIL, another, colored man, who was on the second floor, over the boiler, was blown out through the opening in the ro[???] and fell overboard in the [???]ck. Fortu[???]ely, no one was p[???]ssing the building just at the moment of the explosion, a[???]though many persons were on the street above and below the location. The loss is estimated at about $3,000, and to this may be a[???]ded a loss of perhaps $1,110 more, which will be occasioned by the a[???]ay in making repairs.

abstract: ecation of this way ward young ma[???]. It Bew[???ere, on the 6th inst., his remains were [???] to the home of his parents, about Jour miles west of Blairstown, arriving there at 6 P.M. On Saturday afternoon the body was deposited in its last resting places on the farm of Mr. HARDEN. The general esteem which the Harden family have long and deservedly enjoyed in the neighborhood, and the deep sympathy felt for them in their affliction, called out an unusually large attendance of acquaintances and friends, and a deep solemnity pervaded the entire multitude. The opening prayer was offered by Rev. I.N. VARSANT, of Hope; an appropriate hymn was sung; when an impressive discourse, founded on Hosea vi., 4, was delivered by Rev. J.B. MATHIS of Still water. The solemn services were closed by the Benediction, pronounced by Rev, Mr. REILLY, of Blairstown.

abstract: Mr. ANTHOY WAGNGER, a manufacturer of guttapercha a combs, who conducted his business in the Empire Works building, corner of Twenty fourth-street and Avenue A, was instantly killed about noon on Saturday, by the explosion of a steam- heating table, at which He was at work. Yesterday Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body, and irons the evidence the explosion appeared to have resulted from carelessness on the part of deceased. For the purpose of softening the gutta-percha, preparatory to finishing the, combs, it is placed on the heating tables, several of which were in use by Mr, WAGNEH. One of these tables was out of repair, and he had frequently been warned of its dangerous condition -- the heads of the screws which held the top of the table in its proper position having been filed off by deceased, probably because his garment were caught by them, and he was inconvenienced in his work. The table had thus become much weakened, and was in constant need of repair. When the explosion occupants he was alone in the room, and when the other occupants of the building ran to inquire the cause of it they found him perfectly dead among the debris of the partition wail, which had been thrown down by the concussion. Subsequently the exhaust-cock attached to the table was found closed, which doubtless hastened the catastrophe. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the facts. Deceased was 47 years of age, and resided in Williamsburgh.

abstract: The attempt to organize a Douglas party, nowhere a thrifty business, is especially unfortunate in Delaware. Not only was the State Convention, summoned to approve the action of the Charleston Convention, a failure, but a meeting called at Wilmington, on Saturday, to ratify the nomination of the Squatter Giant, lacked the numbers requisite to raise it to the dignity and bulk of a Committee meeting, and an adjournment was had without other proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The attempt to organize a Douglas party, nowhere a thrifty business, is especially unfortunate in Delaware. Not only was the State Convention, summoned to approve the action of the Charleston Convention, a failure, but a meeting called at Wilmington, on Saturday, to ratify the nomination of the Squatter Giant, lacked the numbers requisite to raise it to the dignity and bulk of a Committee meeting, and an adjournment was had without other proceedings. It is needless to say that there is an important body of the people of Delaware who approve the doctrine of Popular Sovereignty, and a still larger body whose sympathies are with the principles enunciated at Chicago; while not a score perhaps have the most trilling interest in the protection of slave property in the Territories; and less than that number would be able to say why they prefer BRECKINRIDGE to DOUGLAS. Yet so easily controlled is the movement of party machinery in communities so small, that Delaware will i[???] all likelihood cast her insignificant electoral vote for ideas and a candidate to which she is utterly indifferent. It is sufficient that Senator BAYARD, lending himself to the great Southern conspiracy, has sold the State to SLIDELL, YANCEY & Co., to oblige the Democratic majority to make it over bodily.

abstract: The use of the knife in the settlement of disputes among the laboring class of our population has become a circumstance of almost daily occurrence, and the report of a Stabbing affray scarcely excites a passing comment. On the day and night of Saturday last there were four offences of this description complained of in the Police Courts, while two occurred on Thursday last, both of which, it is thought, will re-suit in the death of the wounded parties. The criminal authorities, by the prompt and severe punishment of ruffians who use a knife upon the slightest provocation,would do much to check the habit. The cases which occurred on Saturday night were as follows: Michael Smith, keeper of a liquor-saloon at No. 208 Avenue C, was accused by one Michael Sutton with having sold liquor to his little boy. Smith denied that he knew the lad, and an angry dispute ensued, during me progress of which Michael Tracy, who had accompanied Sutton to Smith's place, stepped up to the latter, and thrust a knife twice into his abdomen, following the outrage by beating him severely. It is not believed, however, that the injuries are of a fatal character. The assailants are in custody, having been committed by Justice BRENNAN, to answer a charge of felonious assault.... Claus Frenken, a storekeeper at No. 468 Broome-street, caused the arrest of a young Irishman named Patrick Gilligan, whom he charges with having stabbed him in both wrists with a pocket-knife. It is alleged that the prisoner came into the complainant's store and conducted himself indecorously. He was requested to leave, but refused, and an attempt having been made to eject him, he produced his knife and inflicted the injuries. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him for trial in default of $1,600 bail, as be had nothing to offer in extenuation.of his conduct but intoxication....... A number of disorderly persons met in the cigar store, No, 196 1/2 Orchard-street, kept by George Dick, and quarreled among themselves. Dick interfered, and was stabbed very severely in the right arm in consequence. He was unable to tell the name of his assailant, but a young man named George Brower was arrested on suspicion of being a participant in the fracas. justices BRENNAN held him for examination.......... John Nagle, a shoemaker, residing at No. 192 Second-street, was committed by the same magistrate to answer a charge of having stabbed one Jacob Mangold in the arm. The offence was committed on very slight provocation.
lead_paragraph: The use of the knife in the settlement of disputes among the laboring class of our population has become a circumstance of almost daily occurrence, and the report of a Stabbing affray scarcely excites a passing comment. On the day and night of Saturday last there were four offences of this description complained of in the Police Courts, while two occurred on Thursday last, both of which, it is thought, will re-suit in the death of the wounded parties. The criminal authorities, by the prompt and severe punishment of ruffians who use a knife upon the slightest provocation,would do much to check the habit. The cases which occurred on Saturday night were as follows: Michael Smith, keeper of a liquor-saloon at No. 208 Avenue C, was accused by one Michael Sutton with having sold liquor to his little boy. Smith denied that he knew the lad, and an angry dispute ensued, during me progress of which Michael Tracy, who had accompanied Sutton to Smith's place, stepped up to the latter, and thrust a knife twice into his abdomen, following the outrage by beating him severely. It is not believed, however, that the injuries are of a fatal character. The assailants are in custody, having been committed by Justice BRENNAN, to answer a charge of felonious assault.... Claus Frenken, a storekeeper at No. 468 Broome-street, caused the arrest of a young Irishman named Patrick Gilligan, whom he charges with having stabbed him in both wrists with a pocket-knife. It is alleged that the prisoner came into the complainant's store and conducted himself indecorously. He was requested to leave, but refused, and an attempt having been made to eject him, he produced his knife and inflicted the injuries. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him for trial in default of $1,600 bail, as be had nothing to offer in extenuation.of his conduct but intoxication....... A number of disorderly persons met in the cigar store, No, 196 1/2 Orchard-street, kept by George Dick, and quarreled among themselves. Dick interfered, and was stabbed very severely in the right arm in consequence. He was unable to tell the name of his assailant, but a young man named George Brower was arrested on suspicion of being a participant in the fracas. justices BRENNAN held him for examination.......... John Nagle, a shoemaker, residing at No. 192 Second-street, was committed by the same magistrate to answer a charge of having stabbed one Jacob Mangold in the arm. The offence was committed on very slight provocation.

abstract: The St. Joseph papers contain details of the dreadful occurrence which took place recently in that place. The buildings which fell were four-story bricks, with iron fronts, and were erected over a year ago. They were uniformly built, constituting the finest block in the city. Fears had been expressed that they were not as substantial as they should have been, as one of the stores fell while building.
lead_paragraph: The St. Joseph papers contain details of the dreadful occurrence which took place recently in that place. The buildings which fell were four-story bricks, with iron fronts, and were erected over a year ago. They were uniformly built, constituting the finest block in the city. Fears had been expressed that they were not as substantial as they should have been, as one of the stores fell while building. They were occupied by the wholesale dry goods houses of POWELL, LEVY & CO., and TOOTLE & FARLEIGH; and the wholesale grocery of NAVE, McCORD & CO. The walls of the building occupied by the latter firm fell from the weight of a stock of flour, completely crushing a frame house near it. The ruins soon took fire, and the flames communicated to the adjoining store of TOOTLE & FARLEIGH, which was soon leveled to the ground. The building of POWELL, LEVY & Co. was also injured, so that that is in a dangerous condition.

abstract: It was stated at the City Hall, yesterday, that the "Committee on the Reception of the Japanese" had resolved to apply to the Common Council for a new appropriation of $105,000, annulling the $30,000 appropriation, which was to have been taken from the account of "City Contingencies." But, as the Japanese visit was a contmgency not provided for in the tax-levy, it is claimed that the proposed appropriation cannot be made, under the present condition of the City finances, and that it must take its chances in the tax-levy of next year. The bills, many of which are said to be interesting, have not yet been laid before the Common Council.

abstract: on Tuesday, a young man named JERRY SWAN was caught by the arm in some machinery, and the limb was so badly broken and mangled that immediate amputation was necessary. This was successfully performed, but according to the Pittfield Eagle, Mr. SWAN's connection with the dissevered limb did not cease with the operation. The Eagle says: "On recovering from the stupor (produced by the use of chloroform) Mr. SWAN still complained sorely of an aching hand. Late in the evening his distress became very great, and he insisted that the hand was cramped by being doubled up. The limb had been placed in a small box and buried. His attendants dug it up and straightened the hand, and he was soon easier. This morning the limb was again buried. But he soon complained of a sensation of cold and great pain in it. It was accordingly taken up again, wrapped up, and deposited in a tomb, since which he is again relieved."

abstract: WM. CHALMERS, the lad whose head was cut by a saw on Wednesday last at the sash and blind factory in Thirtieth-street, near Tenth-avenue, died on Sunday at the New-York Hospital. When the accident happened, deceased was in the act of removing sawdust from beneath a frame upon which a circular saw was revolving. In attempting to assume an upright posture his head struck the saw, and in an instant it whizzed through his skull, making a cut 7 1/2 inches long, and penetrating a depth of 2 1/2 inches into the brain. The little fellow, for some days after the occurrence, seemed to experience little difficulty from his wound. He conversed rationally and his symptoms were not at all unfavorable. On Friday night, however, inflammation commended, and soon his left arm became paralyzed, after which he sank rapidly. The surgeon in attendance speaks of the case as one of the most remarkable instances of vitality under such injuries that ever came within his experience. Deceased was 14 years of age, and lived at No. 280 West Thirty-third-street. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body.
lead_paragraph: WM. CHALMERS, the lad whose head was cut by a saw on Wednesday last at the sash and blind factory in Thirtieth-street, near Tenth-avenue, died on Sunday at the New-York Hospital. The little fellow, for some days after the occurrence, seemed to experience little difficulty from his wound. He conversed rationally and his symptoms were not at all unfavorable. On Friday night, however, inflammation commended, and soon his left arm became paralyzed, after which he sank rapidly. The surgeon in attendance speaks of the case as one of the most remarkable instances of vitality under such injuries that ever came within his experience. abstract: The Chicago Zouaves have done good service in opening the eyes of our military amateurs to the folly and absurdity of copying blindly, in our volunteer drill in this country, that of European armies of the old school. We called attention to this subject several months ago, commenting on the changes which the new fire-arms were likely to effect upon the formation of troops in action, and ventured, at the risk of being considered blasphemous, to hint that the admired solidity and precision of the Seventh Regiment were likely to prove, within the next five or six years, much more showy than serviceable.

abstract: A new and complete series of Guide-books for American travel has appeared from the house of ALEX. HARTHILL & CO., of this City. Differing from the ordinary "Railroad and Steamboat Guides," in many respects, and prepared with evident care and judgment, these little works will commend themselves to the Summer tourist. Five different routes of travel are described in as many books, all appearing simultaneously. One is descriptive of the Mississippi route, from St. Paul to New-Orleans, illustrated by thirty river-charts and forty wood engravings. Another describes the Hudson River, from New-York to Albany, and the route thence to Lakes George and Champlain and Saratoga, and is illustrated with fifty engravings. The third is devoted to descriptions of Niagara Falls, Trenton Falls, the St. Lawrence route, Quebec and Montmorenci. The fourth is a fuller account of the grand route from Niagara to Quebec, via Lake Ontario, the St. Lawrence and the Thousand Islands, illustrated by an excellent panoramic view. The fifth, and last of the series yet published, is a guide to the White Mountains.

abstract: A few minutes after 12 o'clock, yesterday noon, a fire happened in the stable rear of the iron-railing manufactory of VAN TASSEL  McGINTY, situated in Charles-alley, better known as Pig-alley, in the Ninth Ward, running through the middle of the block bounded by Washington, West, Charles and Perry ...
lead_paragraph: A few minutes after 12 o'clock, yesterday noon, a fire happened in the stable rear of the iron-railing manufactory of VAN TASSEL McGINTY, situated in Charles-alley, better known as Pig-alley, in the Ninth Ward, running through the middle of the block bounded by Washington, West, Charles and Perry streets. The structure in which it originated, as well as those adjoining, was built of wood, and the flames spread so rapidly that before the arrival of the firemen several buildings were destroyed. Even after they had brought several streams of water to bear upon the flames, their progress could not be checked, and some 25 buildings, consisting of stables, icehouses, factories and tenements were consumed. The ravaged district covers at least one-half of the block, leaving only the buildings on the West-street side, and the three or four nearest that locality on Charles and Perry streets standing.

abstract: The current week ought to be called "Corban, it is a gift," by the theatrical people. It is a week of benefits, past, present and to come. Last night "Young New-York" was subjected to a fearful trial, and no doubt many a dashing blade, casually dropped down from Saratoga or Newport, sang with Macheath, ...
lead_paragraph: The current week ought to be called "Corban, it is a gift," by the theatrical people. It is a week of benefits, past, present and to come. Last night "Young New-York" was subjected to a fearful trial, and no doubt many a dashing blade, casually dropped down from Saratoga or Newport, sang with Macheath, "How happy could I be with either, were t'other dear charmer away," for last night Mrs. JOHN WOOD, at Laura Keene's, and Mrs. AGNES ROBERTSON BOURCICAULT, at the Winter Garden, contended for applausive kid gloves and appreciative bouquets. The more pathetic appeal of the two was made by Mrs. BOURCICAULT. who is on the point of leaving us to follow the fortunes of her lord over seas, whilst Mrs. WOOD, being her own mistress, has the wit and good taste to stay at home.

abstract: THE WALTON-MATHEWS MURDERS. To-day the investigation of these mysterious murders will be resumed, in the Superiou Court Room, by Coroner JACKMAN. Some twenty-five additional witnesses were subpoenaed yesterday to testify in the matter, but whether their evidence will serve to fix the crime upon anybody is a matter of great doubt.
lead_paragraph: THE WALTON-MATHEWS MURDERS. -- To-day the investigation of these mysterious murders will be resumed, in the Superiou Court Room, by Coroner JACKMAN. Some twenty-five additional witnesses were subpoenaed yesterday to testify in the matter, but whether their evidence will serve to fix the crime upon anybody is a matter of great doubt. We understand that the most important testimony will be given by a young man who spent a portion of the Sunday following the sight the murders were perpetrated with CHARLES JEFFERD, at East New-York. He asserts that the young man asked his opinion as to whether a person who shot the insulter of his mother would be severely punished, and of course, under the circumstances, the interrogatory adds to the suspicion against him. A colored woman has also been found by Detective ROACE who states that she saw Mr. MATHEWS shot, and had a good view of the murderer, whose arrest she could have caused, but she supposed at the time that he had been attacked by rowdies, and her sympathies were on his side. Other witnesses say that they can testify as to the size and general appearance of the murderer. The request of the Coroner that the person by whom the revolver was sold would come forward and give testimony as to the purchaser has not as yet been answered. If it had been, a very important clue to the assassin would have been given to the police.

abstract: A little square volume, purporting to be an Expose of the Science of Gambling, has been published by F.A. BRADY, No. 24 Ann-street. The author voluntarily assumes the unenviable title of "an adept," and announces himself by no other name. The same field has been previously occupied by another master or the "art of cheating," but this writer enters largely into the mysteries of "watch-stuffing" and kindred swindles, which have nothing whatever to do with cards. He avers that the principal importers of brass watches, (articles wherewith unwary countrymen are daily fleeced on Broadway, under the eyes of the Police) are to be found in Maiden-lane in this City, and declares that they transact an amount of business which is estimated at $200,000 annually. This item may be of interest to Superintendent KENNEDY.

abstract: agent of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, who was sent out to take up the Newfoundland end of the cable, has succeeded in raising a portion of it, after some weeks of labor, and has discovered a serious defect in it, caused by its resting and chafing on a ledge of sharp rocks, over which it was laid, a mile or two from Bay of Bull's Arm, Trinity Bay. It is Capt. KELL's intention to take up as much of the cable as possible and land it at New Perlican, making that its future terminus, in case the undertaking to bring it into working order should prove successful. -- Boston Atlas and Bee, July 13.

abstract: Hon. S. SEYMOUR, late State Engineer, and a prominent member of the American party, comes out in support of the DOUGLAS ticket. His leading reason for so doing is a desire to suppress further agitation of the Slavery question in Congress. He thinks the only way of doing this is by giving the practical control of it to the people of the specific localities concerned, whether States or Territories: -- and he, therefore, desires to install the Popular Sovereignty principle by electing its most prominent indorser and advocate. His letter to Col. FORNEY, which we publish elsewhere, states his view of the case clearly and distinctly.

abstract: The fidelity with which the City Inspector accompanies the weekly banking tables with his report of deaths, is, we trust, an indication of an association in the mind of that official of finance and mortality. We are strengthened in this conviction by the fact that never was the financial report more flattering; never were the specie basis sounder or the deposits larger; never were circulation and discounts more cautiously restricted; and at no period has the market for domestic securities been so buoyantly confident. At such moments it is possible a disappointed bear here and there may rashly rush upon suicide; or some luckless speculator, who has failed to avail himself of the unprecedented advance in Cleveland and Toledo, or Erie bonds, may, through chagrin, precipitate his end; but bulls and bears are not reported in these human statistics, and, moreover, no suicides figure in the actual table. There is obviously, therefore, no connection between the ratio of deaths and the bank averages. The streets, and not "the street," have to do with the matter.

abstract: The Board of Fire Commissioners held a special meeting last evening at Fireman's Hall, in Mercer-street, for the purpose of ascertaining the parties who caused a disturbance in Chatham-street, on the night of the 3d of July, Mr. HENRY WILSON, Commissioner, in the Chair. Considerable interest was manifested among the members of the Department, and the large room in which the investigations took place was well filled. The fight, on the night of the 3d, was between Engine Companies Nos. 13 and 21. The foreman of each of those companies, and some of the members were placed upon the stand and examined, but from the evidence submitted, it was impossible to tell how the fight originated, or who was engaged in it. Timothy Sullivan, foreman of Engine Company No. 13, and James McCullen, foreman of engine company No. 21, stated that to the best of their opinions the fight was caused by outsiders. The decision of the case was deferred until Thursday night, as the Commissioners wish to review the testimony. The charges brought against Engine Company No. 18 and Hook and Ladder Company No. 8, by Capt. CURRY, of the Twentieth Precinct, for engaging in a disgraceful fight on the 4th inst., was next examined by the Commissioners. The companies, it appeared, were returning from a fire in Twenty-eighth-street, and when on the corner of Twenty-fourth-street and Sixth-avenue they ran into each other, and a terrible fight ensued, during which several of the members were cut on their heads with iron wrenches, hooks, bricks, &c. Some officers of the Twentieth Precinct, being in the vicinity, interfered between the companies and put an end to the fight by arresting some of the men, or the row would undoubtedly have ended more seriously. Three policemen of the Twentieth Precinct were examined and testified that some of the members were under the influence of liquor, but they could not tell which company commenced the fight. One of the officers said that the members of the companies were not all present. The roll was then called when it was discovered there were a number of members of both Companies absent. The Chairman said that he supposed those who were the instigators of the row had stayed away, and he thought it was best to expel all those who were absent, and then they would be sure to get the light ones. He gave those present notice, that whoever absented himself after being notified to be present at an investigation, should be expelled. The case was laid over until next Monday night. The meeting then adjourned.

abstract: Notwithstanding the remarkable difference of opinion among the morning papers as to where the Zouaves would drill yesterday, about five thousand people, (no doubt having read the correct announcement in the TIMES,) were at Madison-Park to witness the interesting exhibition in the afternoon. General Superintendent KENNEDY had ordered fifteen platoons, or nearly three hundred policemen, on the ground, and theoretically made every requisite arrangement to have the crowd kept back.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the remarkable difference of opinion among the morning papers as to where the Zouaves would drill yesterday, about five thousand people, (no doubt having read the correct announcement in the TIMES,) were at Madison-Park to witness the interesting exhibition in the afternoon. General Superintendent KENNEDY had ordered fifteen platoons, or nearly three hundred policemen, on the ground, and theoretically made every requisite arrangement to have the crowd kept back. The police lines were extended to within twenty feet of the fence, and all the way round the Park, and within the space thus inclosed, the order was to admit none but policemen, members of the Press, and the Zouaves. If these rules had been strictly adhered to there would doubtless have been little cause for complaint; but, first one exception was made, and then another, and then more, until by the time the drill commenced, the privileged characters amounted to a small army, and seriously obstructed the view of those on the line of the police, among whom were many of the highest military officers in the City. Many members of the City Government were kept out, while others, not officials, and policemen present from curiosity only, were allowed inside the square. Even three personal friends of Col. ELLSWORTH, who entered with him, were put out, though they were known to Mr. KENNEDY, while one gentleman at least, personally known to the Superintendent, aad having no other claim but that of being a prominent politician, was allowed to remain. The Superintendent's course in this respect was not consistent, and was generally condemned.

lead_paragraph: Something more than two thousand persons gathered in Union Square, near Washington Statue, last evening, in response to a call upon "citizens, irrespective of party, who believe that the best interests of our country, the stability of the Union, the success of our free institutions, will be best served and promoted by the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency," to meet in Union Square. Added to the call was the statement that Horace Greeley, Thomas Corwin, James O. Putnam, Roger S. Baldwin, Truman Smith, Geo. R. Babcock, Daniel Ullmann, R.F. Andrews, E.L. Snow, Geo. G. Bellows, and Ex-Mayor Hall, had been invited and were expected to address the meeting. At 8 o'clock, Mr. MERWIN R. BREWER called the meeting to order, and the organization was completed by the election of the following officers:

abstract: MY DEAR BROTHER: I see in the TIMES of this morning a communication from you, addressed to Senator SUMNER, in which you take issue with him as to the cause and meaning of the "barbarism" that exists in connection with Slavery.
lead_paragraph: MY DEAR BROTHER: I see in the TIMES of this morning a communication from you, addressed to Senator SUMNER, in which you take issue with him as to the cause and meaning of the "barbarism" that exists in connection with Slavery. If I understand you -- and your language is perfectly explicit -- your position is, that the barbarism which you admit to be found where Slavery is, is not of Slavery, but, from the character of the Africans who originally were brought as slaves, necessarily exists "amid Slavery," without determining at all the character of the institution itself.

abstract: On the 28th of May a resolution was offered in the Board of Councilmen by Councilman VAN TINE, requesting the Mayor to report to this Board the arrangements effected with Mr. N.C. PLATT, the new City Chamberlain, in regard to the payment of interest on the moneys deposited in the Artisans' Bank. That resolution was, on motion of Councilman HALL, laid on the table, where it now remains, and is likely to stay.

abstract: A communication from the Comptroller, relative to the floating debt of the City, was sent to the Board of Aldermen on the 3d of May last, and on motion referred to the Finance Committee, where it still remains. On the 11th ult., the Board met, and transacted a very large amount of business, which was published the next day in the papers employed by the Corporation. In connection with other measures this communication appeared as passed, on a division, by 17 members voting in the affirmative. This action seemed to gladden the hearts of some who were in for a [???]lice of this appropriation. But, alas! on a further inquiry, it was found that the Finance Committed had not yet fully made up their minds to report on this important measure. It appears that the clerks of the Common Council enter all the work to be done on a manifold book before the meeting of the Board, and as each paper is disposed of, mark the action thereon on a place left vacant for that purpose. In some routine cases, they anticipate the vote, and generally nearly correct, even to a division vote; but, in this instance, they (the clerks) committed an error in considering the document as routine, and more so in publishing the same as passed. The only thing about it, is that this notice will bring it before the Board probably sooner than it would have come if otherwise.

abstract: The weekly statement of the City Inspector shows that there were 442 deaths in the City last week, showing an increase of 11 over the mortality of the previous, and 155 less than the corresponding week in 1859. Deaths from acute disease, 277; from chronic disease, 135 external causes, , 30.
lead_paragraph: The weekly statement of the City Inspector shows that there were 442 deaths in the City last week, showing an increase of 11 over the mortality of the previous, and 155 less than the corresponding week in 1859. Deaths from acute disease, 277; from chronic disease, 135 external causes, &, 30. Of the whole number, 259 were children under five years of age. The principal diseases were: cholera infantum, 52; infantile convulsions, 50; diarrhoea, 17; scarlet fever, 19; consumption, 53; dropsy in the head, 17; infantile marasmus, 24; inflammation of the lung, 15. Their nativity was: United States, 298; Ireland, 82; Germany, 36; England, 6; France, 6; Scotland, 2; Switzerland, 2; Wales, 1; West Indies, 2, Austria, 1; and unknown, 6.

abstract: Contrary to general expectation, but much to everybody's satisfaction, the California mail arrived in this city last night, all safe. Some anxiety had been felt here concerning the fate of certain enter  prising traders on the route from this place for California, but it is now understood that they came to no harm, excepting one poor fellow whom the over-ac commodating red-skins relieved of the care of four hundred head of stock, in the daylight.

abstract: We are requested to state that in an article upon this subject, in the TIMES of Saturday, the Postmaster-General was erroneously charged with ordering that the letter-carriers of New-York should "pay into a common fund one cent for each letter delivered -- the aggregate collections so made being afterwards divided equally between all the letter-carriers of the City." This is a mistake. The responsibility of the existing mode of compensating the carriers rests with the Postmaster of this City, who regards the new law as assuming that the earnings of the carriers are to constitute "a carriers' fund," and as authorizing him to divide it among the carriers as he may deem just and proper.

This is a mistake. abstract: SHOCKING FATE OF A LOST CHILD. -- The Newark Mercury, of yesterday, publishes the following: "Several notices have recently been published concerning a child named THOMAS HENRY FINLEY, aged 4 1/2 years, who disappeared on July 5, having followed from home the band of the Turners, who held a picnic that day. His dead body was found on Saturday near the Kossuth Woods on "the Neck," by Mr. WM. STEVENS, who was gunning. The barking of his dog in a marsh having attracted his attention, he went to the spot and found the body almost imbedded in mud. The child had evidently followed the procession to the vicinity, and having started to return to his home on the hill, over the meadows, had become fastened in the mire, and perished from exposure and hunger. During the night of the 5th his cries were heard, but nothing unusual was suspected, and no search was undertaken. The eyes and nose of the unfortunate lad had been eaten away, probably by muskrats, and the body was otherwise mutilated. One thumb was in his mouth, showing that in the agony of starvation the lad had attempted to relieve himself. He had perhaps lingered in this horrible condition for two or three days, under a broiling sun by day, and exposed to cold at night, and finally perishing. The case is one of the most affecting that has occurred for a long time. Coroner CRAVEN announced the sad intelligence to the bereaved parents, and the scene that followed was very touching."
lead_paragraph: SHOCKING FATE OF A LOST CHILD. -- The Newark Mercury, of yesterday, publishes the following: "Several notices have recently been published concerning a child named THOMAS HENRY FINLEY, aged 4 1/2 years, who disappeared on July 5, having followed from home the band of the Turners, who held a picnic that day. The case is one of the most affecting that has occurred for a long time. Coroner CRAVEN announced the sad intelligence to the bereaved parents, and the scene that followed was very touching."

abstract: George Chanman et al vs. John Cochran. This case, which has been two years before the Marine Court, has at length been finally decided by the General Term in favor of the plaintiffs. The case involves questions of considerable importance to merchants, involving the rights and liabilities of a guarantor or surety, as affected by the "Statute of Fraud's."

abstract: All the magazines were issued promptly at the beginning of the month. The Eclectic has a fine portrait of the Earl of ELGIN, and a choice selection of articles from the English Reviews. Among the papers reproduced, are the London Review's notice of "Macaulay and his Writings," the British Quarterly's estimate of DARWIN's "Origin of Species," the North British on the "State of Europe." and two or three tales. These are followed by original articles and a biographical sketch of Lord ELGIN. The readers of the Eclectic are always sure of an agreeable variety in its pages....The North American Review has some excellent papers: among them, a just estimate of the literary career of MARGARET FULLER OSSOLI, an appreciative notice of PERCIVAL, and a second article on THOMAS JEFFERSON -- the latter based on Mr. RANDALL's book, but introduced for the sake of giving two or three letters, hitherto unpublished, which paint the private life of JEFFERSON. These epistles, written by personal friends of the statesman, shed new light upon his private life, and especially upon his religious convictions. Other articles in this number treat of the new edition of the Septuagint, of landscape gardening, of Dr. HAWKS' History of North Carolina, of the Charities of Boston, of Political Economy in Legislation, and of Slavery in ancient Rome.....The July number of the Congregational Quarterly has a portrait and biography of Prof. NATHANIEL W. TAYLOR, and a number of controversial and statistical papers, relating to Congregationalism....The Southern Baptist Review has articles on Associations and Churches, the Duties of Pastors, and others of a denominational character....The Church Review (Episcopalian) publishes the third paper in the series entitled "The Present State and Prospects of Christianity," and a curious chapter upon the subject of "Romish Perverts and where they come from." We quote a single passage from this latter article, written in explanation of the defection of clergymen from the Episcopal Church:

abstract: is at present considerable excitement in Savannah, Geo., because of the refusal of the bread-bakers of the city to comply with a city ordinance, which requires the City Treasurer, at the beginning of every month, to ascertain from the best authority the average price of flour in the city for the month previous, and thereby to regulate the assize of bread for the month ensuing, on such terms, in all instances, as shall secure a profit of $4 50 per barrel to the bakers. The bakers rebel against the enforcement of the law, and continue to make their loaves of a size which will give them the greatest profit.

abstract: The famous Chicago Zouaves visited Brooklyn yesterday, as the guests of the National Greys, Capt. MORGAN. They crossed the Fulton Ferry between 10 and 11 o'clock A.M., and after inspecting the Navyyard, where they were finely received, they proceeded to City Hall-square, and were reviewed by the Mayor...
lead_paragraph: The famous Chicago Zouaves visited Brooklyn yesterday, as the guests of the National Greys, Capt. MORGAN. They crossed the Fulton Ferry between 10 and 11 o'clock A.M., and after inspecting the Navyyard, where they were finely received, they proceeded to City Hall-square, and were reviewed by the Mayor and Aldermen. At 4 o'clock, after having dined, they proceeded to Fort Greene, and, much to the satisfaction of at least 20,000 people, displayed their remarkable skill in drilling. They were loudly applauded, and produced an immense sensation. At 6 1/2 o'clock, after visiting the State Arsenal, they were escorted to their quarters in New-York.

abstract: OUR STREET CHILDREN. A large number of children from the Juvenile Asylum, who had, heretofore, been rovers in the streets, started on Monday for Illinois, under the superintendance of Mr. ALLAN, one of the Officers of that Institution. They will be located on farms in that State, and will, in all probability, become honorable men. The best possible account is received of those who have preceded them. Of the children taken to that State...
lead_paragraph: OUR STREET CHILDREN. -- A large number of children from the Juvenile Asylum, who had, heretofore, been rovers in the streets, started on Monday for Illinois, under the superintendance of Mr. ALLAN, one of the Officers of that Institution. They will be located on farms in that State, and will, in all probability, become honorable men. The best possible account is received of those who have preceded them. Of the children taken to that State n April, the agent of the Institution says: "The system of family government maintained at the Asylum shows nowhere to such advantage as in a company of children who have enjoyed its benefits, when they are a thousand miles away. I have never heard a saucy word from the two hundred children I have accompanied to the West, and very little of profanity and obscenity. Most of them seem to take pleasure in doing right." There are still over five hundred children under training in this Institution, who will shortly be sent to one of the Western States.
