abstract: NAPOLEON III. has said as well as done a good many wise things, but he never said anything wiser than that " in the present age public opinion is sure to win the last victory. The Houses of Hapsburg and Bourbon are just now illustrating the truth of this proposition in a..
lead_paragraph: NAPOLEON III. has said as well as done a good many wise things, but he never said anything wiser than that " in the present age public opinion is sure to win the last victory. The Houses of Hapsburg and Bourbon are just now illustrating the truth of this proposition in a manner more edifying to the rest of the world than agreeable to themselves. In their own eyes the princes of these families are still "hedged round with the divinity" which encompassed their ancestors, and acting on the precedents of the past they have never hesitated to commit any extravagant cruelty, or to utter any flat perjury which the exigency of the moment appeared to make advisable, confiding always that SHAKESPEARE's distinction between the choler of the captain and the mutiny of the soldier was still the law of human feeling. Meanwhile, mankind at large have been gradually coming to look upon Kings as at least no better than other people, and so, when FRANCIS II., of Naples, in the extremity of his terror, calls upon Italy and the world to believe that he will henceforth "deal justly, love mercy," and walk honestly with his subjects, not even official politeness can protect him against the sneering "reminder" that Europe has heard this sort of thing from Bourbons before; and that perjured princes must henceforth take their chance with other convicted felons.

abstract: To-day occurs the most impressive of all celestial phenomena a total Solar Eclipse! Not only is it total, lasting three entire and precious minutes, but the chief planets of our system Venus, Mercury, Jupiter and Saturn, constellated around the sun " assist " at the fete.
lead_paragraph: To-day occurs the most impressive of all celestial phenomena -- a total Solar Eclipse! Not only is it total, lasting three entire and precious minutes, but the chief planets of our system -- Venus, Mercury, Jupiter and Saturn, constellated around the sun -- "assist" at the fete. Many a century will pass before the numbers which rule the stars shall bring about so rare a combination, and permit other eyes in other ages to contemplate a spectacle so magnificent.

abstract: The Revue de Commerce, a Haytian journal, is its issue of the 30th ult., has an article on the Ex-Emperor SOULOUQUE, in which it is stated that the illustrious exile was so excited by the news of the triumphal tour of President GEFFRARD, that he seriously contemplated invading the island over which he formerly reigned.
lead_paragraph: The Revue de Commerce, a Haytian journal, is its issue of the 30th ult., has an article on the Ex-Emperor SOULOUQUE, in which it is stated that the illustrious exile was so excited by the news of the triumphal tour of President GEFFRARD, that he seriously contemplated invading the island over which he formerly reigned. It is further alleged that VIL LUBIN and ADELSON, SOULOUQUE's Prime Ministers, were charged with the execution of the project of invasion; that they had already obtained a schooner as the first installment of a fleet, and that the day of SOULOQUE's departure from Jamaica had been definitively fixed.

abstract: Our citizens, or some among them, demur to paying for their Japanese whistle. They think $120,000 too much money for so little fun. This only shows how innocent and unreasonable they are. It will be a long time before they will have another Japanese caravan even at that price. Besides, they ought to have thought..
lead_paragraph: Our citizens, or some among them, demur to paying for their Japanese whistle. They think $120,000 too much money for so little fun. This only shows how innocent and unreasonable they are. It will be a long time before they will have another Japanese caravan even at that price. Besides, they ought to have thought of all this before they bought the whistle. They were glad enough to invite the Japanese here; they were jubilant when they found their invitation accepted: -- words could not express their delight when they found that these novel guests were to be handsomely entertained, -- and the public joy reached its climax when details of the magnificent Japanese ball, in honor of our illustrious and princely visitors, were spread before the world. Did they expect to get all these nice delights for nothing? Why, the Messrs. LELAND, who had explicit and peremptory orders from the Aldermanic Committee to pay no regard whatever to expense, paid $1,100 for the flowers that bloomed upon the supper tables on the night of the fete. Do our citizens expect such luxuries for nothing? The wine bill for that occasion alone amounted to over $20,000. Can ladies expect to stand ancle-deep in champagne all the evening without expense? How could the waiters, suckers, and miscellaneous hangers-on of that vast and motley crowd, pass champagne bottles out of the windows, and sell them at twenty-five and fifty cents each, unless the City paid cost price for them? The bill for the Japanese Ball alone was over $55,000. We warned the public in advance that the visit of the Japanese would cost over $100,000. But the warning only increased the general eagerness to have them at all hazards and regardless of expense. And now that pay-day comes round, there is a general outcry because hotel-keepers, hackmen, and every body else decline to work for nothing.

We do not, in these latitudes'...
lead_paragraph: By the time this journal reaches this morning's breakfast-table -- at 7 h. 10 m. 21.3 sec., A.M., from the longitude of the TIMES Office, (to be astronomically precise) -- the great solar eclipse long foretold in the prophecy of mathematics, will have begun for us. We do not, in these latitudes' indeed, come under the line of total obscuration -- the great cone of shadow which the moon projects behind her on the whirling earth, sweeps across our upper latitudes, from the mouth of the Columbia River, in Washington Territory, to Cape Chidley, in Labrador, in a black belt seventy miles wide, traveling at the speed of 1,850 miles an hour, or four times the velocity of a cannon-ball! New-York falls under the line of "six digits eclipsed," and under this line, precisely the northern half of the sun will be obscured.

abstract: The annual commencement of the Catholic Young Ladies' Seminary, under the control of the Sisters of  Charity, and known as Mount St. Vincent Academy, formerly located in the Central Park, but now occu-...
lead_paragraph: The annual commencement of the Catholic Young Ladies' Seminary, under the control of the Sisters of Charity, and known as Mount St. Vincent Academy, formerly located in the Central Park, but now occupying the delightful country seat on the banks of the Hudson, known as "Font Hill," the whilom residence of EDWIN FORREST, the tragedian, was held, yesterday. This was the first anniversary of the Institution since its removal to its new quarters, and the large attendance of the Catholic clergy, as well as laity of both sexes, testified to the high favor in which the Institution is held by the Catholic community. Extensive improvements have been made upon the grounds since its purchase by the Sisters of Charity. The castle erected by Mr. FORREST is now occupied as a residence for priests, and is also used as a library for the Institute. A large and imposing brick edifice has been built a few rods to the north of the castle, for the accommodation of the Sisters of Charity and their pupils. This building is four stories in height, and about 150 feet in length, and with its towers and turrets, surmounted by crosses, presents a very scholastic and romantic appearance. The beautiful scenery in the neighborhood, the broad expanse of the Hudson, with the green lawn of Font Hill sloping to its margin, the bold outline of the high bluffs on the opposite side of the river, and the shady groves in the vicinity of the Academy, all combine to make it one of the most delightful locations for a seat of learning to be found in the country; and the Sisters of Charity have the satisfaction of knowing that the beautiful spot selected by them is appreciated by the public, and that their Seminary is daily adding to its numbers, and increasing in prosperity.

abstract: We give further interesting details of Mexican news this morning, brought by the English steamer from Vera Cruz on the 2d, and received by way of Charleston. MIRAMON had retired from before the Liberal forces, and retreated to Guadalajara.
lead_paragraph: We give further interesting details of Mexican news this morning, brought by the English steamer from Vera Cruz on the 2d, and received by way of Charleston. MIRAMON had retired from before the Liberal forces, and retreated to Guadalajara. The papers at the Capital were silent with regard to the motives which induced this step, but no doubt is entertained that he has sustained severe defeats and lost a great portion of his forces. His prestige is believed now to be completely nullified. The Liberals now occupy a better position than ever before, and unless some unforseen accident should occur, its speedy and final triumph is certain.

abstract: The writer commences with his childhood, and goes on to give a description of his life until he began to teach school at or near Blairstown, his manner of life while teaching, his appointment as colporteur, his license to preach, describes the people among whom he was thrown and the influences surrounding him, tells of his success as a preacher, gives a sketch of his first acquaintance with the Dorland family, describes his courtship and marriage, tells how, where and why he poisoned his wife, gives his flight, travels, arrest, &c. A number of essays of his own and letters to friends while he was in prison will be published with the confession, and the whole, will make a work of from fifty to seventy-five pages, HARDEN's father, who will publish the work, has employed a few general agents for its sale. -- Trenton Gazette, July 17.
lead_paragraph: The writer commences with his childhood, and goes on to give a description of his life until he began to teach school at or near Blairstown, his manner of life while teaching, his appointment as colporteur, his license to preach, describes the people among whom he was thrown and the influences surrounding him, tells of his success as a preacher, gives a sketch of his first acquaintance with the Dorland family, describes his courtship and marriage, tells how, where and why he poisoned his wife, gives his flight, travels, arrest, &c. A number of essays of his own and letters to friends while he was in prison will be published with the confession, and the whole, will make a work of from fifty to seventy-five pages, HARDEN's father, who will publish the work, has employed a few general agents for its sale. -- Trenton Gazette, July 17.

abstract: "Independent," writing from Washington on the 14th to the Philadelphia North American, says: "Mr. SCHELL, the Collector of New-York, is here again, to contrive the ways and means for a thorough organization of the Breckinridge move-
lead_paragraph: "Independent," writing from Washington on the 14th to the Philadelphia North American, says: "Mr. SCHELL, the Collector of New-York, is here again, to contrive the ways and means for a thorough organization of the Breckinridge movement in New-York. He and his disinterested confederates fear the Douglas faction will out-number them in votes, and thus claim future ascendancy in the organization, unless they devise immediate steps. The defection of that modern Brutus, FERNANDO WOOD, has grieved them sorely, especially as he was supposed to be 'national' to the back-bone, and stirred the hearts of the chivalry at Charleston with protestations exceeding the devotion of YANCEY. It was my privilege to be within earshot of his 'Excellency,' -- as Lord JOHN RUSSELL, with a charming deference to the Spanish-American custom, styles him -- on several occasions when he 'stood by the rights of the South,' and to have been an eye-witness of the scene when he entered the hall of the Seceders, and was invited to take a back seat. The new alliance with DOUGLAS is quite refreshing, all things considered, and does one good now that the dog-star rages so fiercely. There is reason to suppose that Mr. WOOD did not dine at the White House, on his last visit here. Perhaps he may have had a plate at the other end of the town, where the rival rose blooms outside the sunshine of power. Mr. BUCHANAN has evidently lost much of his affection for the Mayor, at which intelligence the country will, of course, put on sackcloth and ashes."

abstract: The details of Mexican news which we publish this morning are of recent date, and appear to be reliable. Though not captured, MIRAMON is said to have met with serious re  verses, and is, in fact, hemmed in near Largos, in the State of Jalisco. Gen. URAGA, we learn...
lead_paragraph: The details of Mexican news which we publish this morning are of recent date, and appear to be reliable. Though not captured, MIRAMON is said to have met with serious re verses, and is, in fact, hemmed in near Largos, in the State of Jalisco. Gen. URAGA, we learn from a private source, was convalescent at Guadalajara. DEGOLLADO had offered to exchange a large number of captive officers for URAGA, but the offer was refused. Several of the States had contributed quite a large sum, ($12,000,) and dispatched it to URAGA, for his immediate necessities, and as a token of admiration for his patriotism and courage.

abstract: The Coroner's inquest in the case of the WALTON and MATTHEWS murders was continued yesterday, in the Superior Court-room, commencing at a quarter to ten, and ending at a quarter to five, with an intermission of but one hour. An audience of about fifty persons was in attendance, but, owing to the undertone in which the examination was carried on, neither jurors nor reporters heard more than half the testimony. Such as came to the ears of our reporters is given below.

abstract: The Commencement exercises of the Free Academy last evening were witnessed and listened to by a larger number of persons than ever attended a Commencement of the same institution before. The building chosen was the Academy of Music, and it was filled from the parquette to the dome, with an audience composed, as is usual on such occasional principally of ladies. The Chair was occu-...
lead_paragraph: The Commencement exercises of the Free Academy last evening were witnessed and listened to by a larger number of persons than ever attended a Commencement of the same institution before. The building chosen was the Academy of Music, and it was filled from the parquette to the dome, with an audience composed, as is usual on such occasional principally of ladies. The Chair was occupied by ANDREW H. GREEN, Esq., one of the Commissioners of the Board of Education. On his right was Prof. WEBSTER, and on his left PETER COOPER, Esq. The stage was occupied principally by members of the Board of Education, and other friends of the Institution. The speaking, which was good, and which in all cases elicited applause, consisted of orations, dissertations and the recital of poems. The programme was so extensive that it was some time after 12 o'clock before the exercises were concluded.

abstract: DAN RICE is a very clever man in his way. The Tribune used to be very severe in its criticisms of his wit, but even that fastidious journal conceded to him nimbleness of limb and great powers of performing curious end audacious feats. Yet DAN was a fool to BENNETT.
lead_paragraph: DAN RICE is a very clever man in his way. The Tribune used to be very severe in its criticisms of his wit, but even that fastidious journal conceded to him nimbleness of limb and great powers of performing curious end audacious feats. Yet DAN was a fool to BENNETT. Our poor old neighbor, even in his decrepitude, can throw more summersaults, and turn his back upon his face oftener than DAN ever could, -- and the coolness, the gravity, the perfectly placid composure with which he does it, is little short of miraculous.

abstract: The Philadelphia Committee, now waiting upon the directors of the Great Eastern, have succeeded, if we may trust the Philadelphia papers, in impressing those gentlemen with the accessibility of that much-favored port. They assure the courteous Board that there is..
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Committee, now waiting upon the directors of the Great Eastern, have succeeded, if we may trust the Philadelphia papers, in impressing those gentlemen with the accessibility of that much-favored port. They assure the courteous Board that there is not the least danger of the great ship touching bottom in the Delaware, as she does when the tide flags at her Hammond-street moorings, pointing with justifiable pride to the five or six fathoms which confront the Philadelphia water-line; and, that assertion may not fail for lack of circumstance, the fact that a certain Cathedral, drawing 25 1/2 feet of water, was at some unreported time unable to pass the bar into the Bay of New-York, and had to be taken to Philadelphia, where such monsters find so much easier admission, is produced in evidence.

abstract: The inhabitants of St. Johns, Newfoundland, intend presenting to the Prince of WALES a very appropriate specimen of their native production. A fine large Newfoundland dog has been selected for his Royal Highness, and to have this noble animal appear to the best advantage, a silver collar was necessary. So they requested their friends, Messrs. HEWLET  TORRANCE, of this City, to have one made regardless of expense. These gentlemen, with great judgment,...
lead_paragraph: The inhabitants of St. Johns, Newfoundland, intend presenting to the Prince of WALES a very appropriate specimen of their native production. A fine large Newfoundland dog has been selected for his Royal Highness, and to have this noble animal appear to the best advantage, a silver collar was necessary. So they requested their friends, Messrs. HEWLET & TORRANCE, of this City, to have one made regardless of expense. These gentlemen, with great judgment, instructed Messrs. TIFFANY & CO. to do their best, -- and the elaborate and highly-finished article which we had the pleasure of inspecting, yesterday morning, reflects great credit on this house, which has so long had the reputation of producing the most artistic and elegant silverware in the country.

abstract: Wm. N. Langley vs. B.K. Shanetts. This was an action to dissolve a copartnership between the proprietors of the Dey street House, and to set aside a bill of sate made by Langley to B.K. Shanetts, of the hotel, furniture, good will, , , upon the ground that it was freudulent, and that there was a conspiracy between certain parties to defraud the plentiff of his rights.
lead_paragraph: Wm.N. Langley vs. B.K. Shanetts. -- This was an action to dissolve a copartnership between the proprietors of the Dey street House, and to set aside a bill of sate made by Langley to B.K. Shanetts, of the hotel, furniture, good will, &c., &c., upon the ground that it was freudulent, and that there was a conspiracy between certain parties to defraud the plentiff of his rights. It was also claimed that the defendant Shanettes was for a long time proprietor of the hotel, and that recently Shanetts, in consideration of certain advances to the amount of $14,000, proposed to be made by Langley, had agreed to take him (Langley,) into partnership in the business, and give him half of the profits of the business, half the property of the hotel, and half interest in the lease, the lease to still remain in the name of Shanetts, subject to a mortgage of $8,000, held by John T. Shanetts, upon the furniture of the hotel, which Langley agreed to assist, as is alleged, in paying off Thereupon a short agreement of copartnership was entered into between the parties, by which Langley at present should receive only half of the net profits of the house. This agreement was based upon the condition, that when Langley should pay in the amount proposed, (as he had then paid in but $600.) then full articles of copartnership should be entered into, and Langley should become joint owner of the hotel. The defendant claims that immediately after the $600 was paid in by Langley, Messrs. Whitney & Bonner, who claimed to have advanced that sum to Langley, came to him and demanded to be repaid the $600. He avows that he paid it out of his private purse. The papers on both sides make a great many allegations, Those of each being mostly in conflict with the other, and making the facts of the case very obscure at present.

abstract: Sergeant Lord, of the Sanitary Police, a few days since entered a complaint before Justice CONNOLLY, against the Slaughter-house No. 423 First-avenue, as being in so filthy a condition that it was a public nuisance. The owner of the establishment, Councilman Edward Castello, was accordingly summoned to answer the complaint, and a number of witnesses having testified to the unhealthy stench which emanated from the premises, he was required to furnish $500 bail for his appearance at the Court of Special Sessions for trial on the charge of keeping a nuisance.

abstract: SERIOUS FIRE. -- About 10 o'clock on Monday night a fire broke out in a large, two-story frame building, about a mile north of West Hoboken, owned and occupied by Messrs. WURM & STICHNOR as a lagerbier saloon. Several fire companies from Hoboken attempted to reach the spot, but after dragging their apparatus a long distance were under the necessity of returning. The building was entirely destroyed. Loss about $4,000, upon which there was an insurance of $2,500. The fire originated from the stove in the kitchen.

abstract: Our correspondent at Buenos Ayres, writing on the 28th of May, gives an interesting account of the improvements inaugurated by the Government. About $60,000 have already been appropriated for the erection of school houses. Buenos Ayres is, rightly considered, far in advance of all the other Spanish American Republics, except, perhaps, Chili. The United States Exploring Expedition, initiated some eight years ago, under Capt. PAGE, has finished its explorations, and is about to return home. All the principal tributaries of the La Plata have been surveyed.

lead_paragraph: That well-known corps of citizen soldiers, the City Guard, under the direction of its commander, Capt. MANSFIELD LOVEL, has initiated a movement which cannot fail to be of very marked importance to this City, and, indeed, to the country at large. It has undertaken to qualify its members to work the heavy guns in the forts provided for the defence of our harbor, -- and the result of its efforts as shown by the target practice of the Company yesterday at Fort Hamilton, was such as must turn the attention of other companies of our volunteer soldiers to the very great importance of the movement.

abstract: The regular weekly meeting of this Board took place yesterday, President VERPLANCK in the Chair. A communication from the City Chamberlain, Mr. Platt, announcing that the accounts of the Board had been transmitted to the Artisans' Bank, with the other accounts formerly in the hands of Mr. A.V. Stout, was received and read. It was ordered on file. A communication of Mr. Louis D. Pilsbury, Superintendent of the State Emigrant Refuge and Hospital on Ward's Island, announcing his resignation, to take effect the 31st inst., was received and accepted. Mr. James P. Fagan, an old employe of the Commissioners, was appointed to take his place. The salary amounts to $1,800 per annum. By the weekly statement, it appears 2,901 alien passengers have arrived during the week; $5,938 were received for commutation of passengers. The current expenses of June 27 and July 4 were $9,263 94, and the balance in bank is $14,214 14.

abstract: A few days ago, within about twenty-four hours of the successful landing of a gang of negroes, in Mobile Bay, twenty-three remarkably fine fellows, field hands, were placed on board of the Mobile steamer for this city, and having safely arrived, are to be sold on Friday, at the St. Charles Hotel, by JULIAN NEVILLE.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, within about twenty-four hours of the successful landing of a gang of negroes, in Mobile Bay, twenty-three remarkably fine fellows, field hands, were placed on board of the Mobile steamer for this city, and having safely arrived, are to be sold on Friday, at the St. Charles Hotel, by JULIAN NEVILLE. There is much discussion and inquiry as to the character of these negroes, whether they are of the recent, or whether they are a portion of the one hundred and ninety for whom graves were dug at Key West, but who, unreasonably enough, preferred rather the comfortable quarters of our river plantations to such narrow accommodations as Uncle Sam proposed to furnish them. One of the lot, a boy of seventeen, weighs one hundred and seventy, and is over six feet high. It is supposed he is of the Bozale tribe, and that his father was a renowned warrior of that warlike race.

abstract: About a thousand persons assembled on Tuesday on the ground of the Putnam Club, at Brooklyn, E. D., to witness a spirited content between the above Clubs, and their expectations were not disappointed, for, omitting the first innings, it was one of the closest games of the season. There was much bril
lead_paragraph: About a thousand persons assembled on Tuesday on the ground of the Putnam Club, at Brooklyn, E. D., to witness a spirited content between the above Clubs, and their expectations were not disappointed, for, omitting the first innings, it was one of the closest games of the season. There was much brilliant play on both sides, but each side had some weak points. Towards the end of the game the fielding was quite sharp, and every exertion was put forth on either side, and, owing to the equality of their play, the Putnams retained the advantage gained in the first innings. On the Union side, ABRAMS at second base was especially active, as were BOGLE at short and PARKER as catcher. KINLOCK made one very good catch. For the Putnams, BROWN and WANZIER played with their usual brilliancy, while MASTEN and BURR on the bases were very efficient. DAKIN pitched with uncommon steadiness, but was unfortunate in batting. WANZIER, BROWN, BURR and MASTEN, of the Putnam, and BALCOM, of the Union, were most successful at the bat.

abstract: Since the regular and guaranteed manufacture, and the considerable and satisfactory use of steel, as a substitute for wrought iron, is now established in this country as well as abroad since a metal a quarter stronger than wrought icon can be furnished at the price of wrought iron, the engineering and the commercial world, in fact the whole public, can congratulate itself on a great stride in advance.
lead_paragraph: Since the regular and guaranteed manufacture, and the considerable and satisfactory use of steel, as a substitute for wrought iron, is now established in this country as well as abroad -- since a metal a quarter stronger than wrought icon can be furnished at the price of wrought iron, the engineering and the commercial world, in fact the whole public, can congratulate itself on a great stride in advance. Iron, the very type and substance of universal strength, is left behind by science, which now produces a stronger and more universally safe and useful product out of the same crude material. To the innumerable uses of cheap steel, and its chemical nature and general manufacture, we have already referred. A somewhat more detailed observation of the process of making a metal which is likely to come into wide-spread and most important use, will possibly be generally interesting.

abstract: The United States vs. Henrico De Costa. In the proceedings of giving bail for Mr. De Costa, Mr. Pinkerton, of No. 11 Attorney street, was offered as bail, and notice was given that he would execute the bail piece on Tuesday. He did not appear, however, and the proceedings were adjourned till yesterday at 12 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Henrico De Costa. -- In the proceedings of giving bail for Mr. De Costa, Mr. Pinkerton, of No. 11 Attorney street, was offered as bail, and notice was given that he would execute the bail piece on Tuesday. He did not appear, however, and the proceedings were adjourned till yesterday at 12 o'clock. Judge Roosevelt was present at that hour, whon Mr. Steele, from the office of Beebe, Dean & Donohue, De Costa's lawyers, came, and said that Mr. Donohue had requested him to state that the bail offered was withdrawn, and a new notice would be given, and that Mr. Pinkerton, as he understood, was out of town. Judge Roosevelt said Mr. Pinkerton was present, and he desired to have him sworn, as he had been kept dancing attendance there for several days, and desired to bring the matter to a close some way, as he was going out of town to-morrow. Mr. Steele repeated his notice that the bail was withdrawn, and requested the Clerk to enter it on his minutes. Mr. Pinkerton was then sworn and in answer to the District-Attorney's questions, stated that he lived at No. 11 Attorney-street, and there was no other person there of the name; that he did not know De Costa; that no one had spoken to him about going bail for De Costa, and he would not do it, not being in that business; that he was not in the Clerk's office the day before, and knew nothing about the matter, except what he saw in the papers. Judge Roosevelt then pressed for a conclusion of the affair, but the Clerk said he would adjourn till 2 P.M., by which time Mr. Steele said he would try to communicate with Mr. Donohue. At 2 o'clock no other person appeared to go bail, and the Commissioner intimated that the matter was closed for the present. De Costa remains in prison.

abstract: THE ECLIPSE OF YESTERDAY. -- It took place just as the astronomers and the TIMES said it would. The crowd who were awake and stirring on their way to work beheld it. Few of them, probably, knew or cared much about umbra or penumbra, but the virtues of smoked glass were known to them. They halted in the highways on their route to their respective avocations and blackened their foreheads and noses therewith. It was a fine, cloudless morning, and everything was favorable for the observation of the solar phenomenon. The general feeling, perhaps, was one of disappointment. The obscuration was visible enough but the birds did not drop, frightened, from the branches of trees, neither did the "tame, villatic fowl" retire again to their roosts. There was light sufficient for all purposes of business and traffic, and many an unenlightened mind' bent on car or stage driving, wondered what so many people were look-at. One of these sages, to our Reporter's knowledge, concluded that a balloon was expected from San Francisco. The sun really behaved well on the occasion, the moon, good lady, did her duty, and the spectators of a scientific turn, talked of Oregon, Labrador, Spain and Ethiopia, of the expeditions which had been sent to those places, and of the supernatural effect of total darkness.

abstract: "His Grace," the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New-York, is certainly an Englishman. We know how heinous a charge this is to bring against the clerical glory of all Celtic America, yet surely nothing but that traditional incapacity of John Bull for knowing when he is beaten, can account for the pertinacity with which "His Grace" perseveres in maintaining the position taken by him at Fordham, that the Protestant world, outside of New-England, has done nothing for education. Of this pertinacity the TIMES is the chosen victim, and the Tribune the congenial vehicle. Its latest development appeared yesterday morning in the form of the following notable communication, of which we omit only a small bit of Archiepiscopal scurrility:

abstract: The exercises of Commencement at this College, on the 11th inst., were of a high order of excellence, marked by vigor of thought, propriety and eloquence of expression, and good taste in delivery.
lead_paragraph: The exercises of Commencement at this College, on the 11th inst., were of a high order of excellence, marked by vigor of thought, propriety and eloquence of expression, and good taste in delivery. Besides English orations, an oration was delivered in Latin on ALEXANDER II., Emperor of Russia, and a Latin Ode, "Ad Italiani Resurgentem." The degree of B.A. was conferred upon twelve graduates, and that of M.A. on three. The honorary degree of M.A. was bestowed upon the poet WHITTIER.

abstract: A very good estimate of the size of NewYork and of the work that is performed within its limits may be arrived at from the Sanitary Report of the City Inspector for the week ending last Saturday. During those seven days 255 nuisances
lead_paragraph: A very good estimate of the size of NewYork and of the work that is performed within its limits may be arrived at from the Sanitary Report of the City Inspector for the week ending last Saturday. During those seven days 255 nuisances were abated and 183 notices of nuisances were served, over 1,600 loads of night soil, 500 dead horses and cattle, and some 3,000 barrels of offal were removed from the City limits. The need of unceasing vigilance on the part of the authorities is demonstrated by the fact that 5,573 barrels of diseased meats and fish were seized during the same period, though it does not appear that the people who make a practice of offering unwholesome food for sale receive the punishment that they richly merit. In the department of street-cleaning, 277 laborers were employed, and some 16,000 loads of garbage were carted off.

abstract: The determination of the Post-office to appropriate the business of letter-carrying in this City to itself, and drive the Express Companies out of the field, though of course perfectly legal, will, unless great changes are made in the Post-office mangement, be grossly unfair to the public.
lead_paragraph: The determination of the Post-office to appropriate the business of letter-carrying in this City to itself, and drive the Express Companies out of the field, though of course perfectly legal, will, unless great changes are made in the Post-office mangement, be grossly unfair to the public. The Express Companies would never have obtained any business at all, or deprived the Post-office of one cent of receipts, if a large portion of the public had not been satisfied that the did their work better, more efficiently and more punctually than the Government. The rate charged by them for the carriage and delivery of letters was the same, and they owe the thriving business they have been doing solely to the fact that in the opinion of the public they were more trustworthy than the concern in the Old Dutch Church.
headline: {'main': 'The Post-office and Express Companies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Post-office and Express Companies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ANOTHER OF THE RIVER PIRATES SENTENCED. -- In the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday, JOSEPH PURCELL, river pirate, was convicted of stealing grain from the Atlantic Basin in March last, and was sentenced to five years' imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison. PURCELL was an accomplice of JOHN MINCH, alias "Buffalo Jack" (sent to prison a few weeks ago) and is the third person convicted for stealing about $1,500 worth of grain from the canal-boat Trafalgar, while lying in the Atlantic Basin, belonging to the Western Transportation Company. MINCH was at the head of this formidable gang, and they had vessels of suitable size to carry out their bold scheme. For several year's past they have committed their depredations without serious impediment. MINCH and several of his companions in crime have frequently been arrested, but as they generally confined their heaviest operations to stealing grain, owing to the fact that it was next to impossible to identify the stolen property, they have heretofore managed to escape punishment. The particular attention of the Police was called to this gang, and after many nights of watching they finally succeeded in capturing the principals, and obtaining evidence sufficient to convict them. JOHN MOYER, another of the gang, was sent to Sing Sing for five years on Tuesday last.

The particular attention of the Police was called to this gang, and after many nights of watching they finally succeeded in capturing the principals, and obtaining evidence sufficient to convict them. JOHN MOYER, another of the gang, was sent to Sing Sing for five years on Tuesday last.

abstract: The Commissioners met on Tuesday and heard the testimony for the defence. On behalf of Rich
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners met on Tuesday and heard the testimony for the defence. On behalf of Richmond County, John Martin and Henry Cranston, a boatman, Dr. Theo. Walser and Francis E. Jones, hotel keeper, were sworn. The drift of their testimony was, that portions of the furniture of Dr. Waller were removed on the afternoon previous to the fire without injury. Rebutting testimony was introduced to prove that nothing was removed until late in the evening, and that it was then done hurriedly, damaging the portion which was saved, and leaving much of it behind, which was destroyed with the residence. Ray Tompkins, who aided in the "removal of Quarantine" on that occasion, was examined as a witness, and testified that he was in Dr. Waller's house about the time of the fire to see if there was any personal furniture to be "saved." The Board adjourned to Thursday.

abstract: GEORGE T. INGHAM, a child five and a half years of age, fell from the roof of No. 113 Mulberry-street, on Tuesday afternoon, into a narrow space between that building and the one next to it. He had gone upon the roof to look at a balloon, and not having been seen afterwards, his parents supposed that he had wandered from home and lost his way. The Police were notified, and a search was prosecuted, but nothing could be learned of the little fellow until yesterday morning, when his body was found wedged in the aperture into which by a misstep he had fallen. The remains were extricated with great difficulty, and an inquest will be held upon them to-day.
lead_paragraph: GEORGE T. abstract: A regular meeting of this Board was held last evening. In the absence of the President, Mr. CURTIS, who is now in Europe, Mr. GREEN was elected on the fourth ballot to serve as President until his return. Mr. GREEN tendered his acknowledgments for the honor shown him in a brief speech, and immediately appointed Mr. DAVENPORT President pro tem., as he had some checks to sign for teachers, which would require his temporary absence from the Board.

abstract: -- The literary scandal excited at Paris by Madame GEORGE SAND�s quite unprovoked attempt to carry out EMERSON�s theory of genius, and "grind up her friends for paint," bids fair to become a very war of Troy for tediousness. It began with Madame SAND�s romance of Elle et Lui, in which she drew under the very thinnest disguise a most unflattering portrait of ALFRED DE MUSSET, then hardly cold in his premature grave. PAUL DE MUSSET, the accomplished brother of the deceased poet, perfectly familiar with the secret history of ALFRED�s relations with the authoress of Indiana, took upon himself the fraternal duty of relating that history in quite another light. His work, entitled Lui et Elle, is a marvel of keen, concentrated and sustained indignation, altogether merciless in its analysis of the heroine�s character and career. This fraternal vindication was rapidly followed up by another defence of ALFRED DE MUSSET, from the pen of a distinguished female writer. In her novel of Lui, Mme. LOUIS COLET has fully rivaled Mme. SAND�s own power of passionate description, and deals so unreservedly with the egotistical side of that lady�s nature, as almost to move the reader�s compassion towards a selfishness so mercilessly scourged. These blows took effect, and in the preface to her latest novel, Jean de La Roche, Madame SAND takes occasion to protest rather scornfull, against the tremendous inquisition which has been instituted into her past experience. The whole battle may now be presumed to have been fought out, and M. DE LESAIRE accordingly undertakes the task of historian, and sums up its record and its merits in a critical work, L'Histoire d'un Scandale, which is not the least interesting contribution to letters made by this most miserable quarrel.

abstract: POLITICAL. -- A mass meeting of the Republicaus in the Third Assembly District (Fourth and Tenth Wards) was held, last evening, in the Wigwam on Fulton-street, Gen. DURYEA presiding. abstract: The Annual Commencement exercises at Harvard University took place on Wednesday, and were attended by the largest company that has assembled there for years. The galleries and side pews were reserved for the ladies, and by 9  o'clock every seat and standing place were occupied. The graduating class this year is the largest that has ever left the College at one time.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Commencement exercises at Harvard University took place on Wednesday, and were attended by the largest company that has assembled there for years. The graduating class this year is the largest that has ever left the College at one time.

abstract: The funeral of Prince JEROME, like all splendid spectacles, attracted a great crowd. The day was fine, but somewhat sultry. The line of the procession ultimately decided upon -- the Rue Rivoli, Place de la Concorde, and the Pont des Invalides -- enabled the greatest number of people possible to have a good view of the gorgeous pageant: The Tulleries gardens, which it was for a time feared would be closed, were kept open as usual, and the terraces which command .the Place de la Concorde and line the railing of the Rue Rivoli, were closely packed from an early hour. The Place de la Concorde itself was not so full as I have often seen it on an illumination night: but still the troops and National Guards were hemmed it on either side by very dense masses, occupying, perhaps, half the vast arena. The shops were not generally closed, and although nothing could be more respectful than the attitude of the crowd as the coffin passed, there was nothing at all like that universally pervading sentiment of a really national mourning such as has been witnessed on former occasions -- at the funeral of the Duke of Orleans for instance. The troops lined the whole route from the gates of the Palais Royal to those of the Invalides. The clergy of St. Roch, assisted by the Emperor's chaplains, took charge of the corpse, and marched before and by the side of it, carrying lighted wax tapers. The funeral car was the very one used for the interment of the lamented Duke of Orleans, but it had been redecorated and was resplendent with silver ornaments. The pall bearers were M. FOULD, Minister of State; Admiral HAMELIN, Minister, of Marine; Marshal VAILLANT, and M. TROPLONG, the President of the Senate. Prince NAPOLEON was the chief mourner, and it was much remarked that he appeared profoundly afflicted. He followed the coffin bareheaded, wearing a black cloak over his general's uniform. The marshals commanding districts had been summoned to Paris to take part in the ceremony, and marched behind Prince NAPOLEON. Marshals NIEL and CANROBERT and the Duke of MALAKOFF were recognized by the crowd with much interest. A number of mourning and other carriages followed. The procession was so long that it took upwards of two hours to defile. Cardinal MORLOT, Archbishop of Paris performed the funeral service, and after an oration by the Bishop of Troyes, which will doubtless be published in the Moniteur to-morrow, the body was lowered into the vault of the chapel of St. Jerome, which the deceased prince some time since selected for his resting place. Nothing could exceed the, splendor of the mourning decorations of the chapel.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Prince JEROME, like all splendid spectacles, attracted a great crowd. The day was fine, but somewhat sultry. The funeral car was the very one used for the interment of the lamented Duke of Orleans, but it had been redecorated and was resplendent with silver ornaments. The pall bearers were M. FOULD, Minister of State; Admiral HAMELIN, Minister, of Marine; Marshal VAILLANT, and M. TROPLONG, the President of the Senate. Prince NAPOLEON was the chief mourner, and it was much remarked that he appeared profoundly afflicted. He followed the coffin bareheaded, wearing a black cloak over his general's uniform. The marshals commanding districts had been summoned to Paris to take part in the ceremony, and marched behind Prince NAPOLEON. Marshals NIEL and CANROBERT and the Duke of MALAKOFF were recognized by the crowd with much interest. A number of mourning and other carriages followed. The procession was so long that it took upwards of two hours to defile. Cardinal MORLOT, Archbishop of Paris performed the funeral service, and after an oration by the Bishop of Troyes, which will doubtless be published in the Moniteur to-morrow, the body was lowered into the vault of the chapel of St. Jerome, which the deceased prince some time since selected for his resting place. Nothing could exceed the, splendor of the mourning decorations of the chapel.

abstract: It is hard to quarrel with men who have so evidently tried to do their duty to the public as have the Coroner's jurymen impanneled to investigate the peculiarly appalling and mysterious murder of two citizens of New-York, in the open street and early on the night of the 30th of June last. And yet it is impossible, we think, for any candid person, unoppressed with the severe responsibilities of the jury-box, not to feel, on perusing the evidence offered in this case, that the finding which has committed CHARLES JEFFERDS, the stepson of one of the murdered men, to prison, there to await the further action of the Grand Jury, is hardly one in which he should have cared to concur. All the circumstances of this atrocious crime, so far as they were developed on the investigation in the form of facts, were strongly calculated to impose upon judicial inquirers the utmost reserve in condensing from them the terrible charge of murder against any individual whose name has thus far been brought forward in connection with the affair. Not a single witness, even of those who had enjoyed the fullest opportunities of observing the murderer before, during and after the murders, came forward prepared to testify to his identity. Some of them, indeed, thought they recognized in CHARLES JEFFERDS a certain vague resemblance to the shadowy shape which had flitted before their eyes on that calm Summer night, bearing in its hand the lives of two human beings. But though everything that could be done was done to nerve and fortify these dim impressions into sharp and positive forms -- though CHARLES JEFFERDS passed no small part of his time in putting on and putting off the "light coats" which it was hoped would fill at once the blurred and tremulous outline lingering in the memory of the witnesses -- yet no one person ventured to step beyond the cloudy frontier of general notions, and fix the finger of Nathan upon the suspected man. How, indeed, was it to be expected that any person at all worthy of credence, could do this? The history of jurisprudence has many sadly instructive chapters warning us that we are men, and that to err is eminently human. No evidence, it may almost be said, is more treacherous than the evidence of the senses, speaking to the details of any event which, at the time of its occurrence, greatly shook and stirred the whole nature of the spectator. The Duke of WELLINGTON assured Sir WALTER SCOTT that it was simply impossible for the coolest man in the world to be sure of the sequence of things in any great battle in which he was personally concerned. The fearful story of LESURQUES, condemned and executed on the testimony of eye-witnesses, as having appeared at high noon, eaten and drunk in their presence, and ridden away with his accomplices to commit a cruel murder, of which he knew nothing whatever; and the hardly less fearful case of RICHARDS, whose life having been sworn away positively by a gentleman who had been robbed on the highway in the morning, was only saved by the timely capture of the real culprit, stand in all the books to warn us how careful we must needs be in trusting to our own eyes and ears at moments of intense excitement, even under the broad light of day.

abstract: The efforts of Rev. J.R. MCDOWELL, in 1833 and 1834, to rouse the religious community to a consciousness of the extent and terrible consequences of the licentiousness, so prevalent in New-York, and other large cities, were productive of hostility and denunciation on the part of the viciously inclined and the timid, but among those who mourned over the ruin of the young, the artless and the confiding, they were regarded with interest and sympathy; and while these considered some of the measures prompted by his burning zeal, as injudicious and unwise, they could not withhold the meed of praise, from one who sacrificed reputation, distinction and even life itself, to the promotion of the cause of purity.

abstract: THE COST OF ENTERTAINING THE JAPANESE IN PHILADELPHIA. -- Mr. HACKER, Chairman of the Joint Special Committee on the reception and entertainment of the Japanese in Philadelphia, made a report, attached to which was the following statement showing the amount expended out of the $10,000 appropriated by Councils: Amount of hotel bill, $3,869; E. CONKLIN, for carriages, $1,500; music by bands for military parade, $423; expenses of Committee to Washington, Mayor's deputation, &c., $87 76; stereoscopic case, with views, presented to Embassy, $186; map of city and State, $22 50; additional carriage bills, $19; omnibuses, $25; baggage wagons, $40; incidentals, $96 54; advertising, $15; exhibition of views at hotel, $15; services at Academy of Music, $10; balloon ascension, $150; music for fireman's parade, $750, making a total of $7,208 80. Amount merged, $2,791 20. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 17.

abstract: Information was yesterday received at the Coroner's office, that the body of a female, horribly mutilated, had been found in the stable, No. 122 East Thirty-ninth-street, and that a great deal of excitement existed upon the subject. Coroner JACKMAN immediately summoned a jury and went to the place. He found the stable guarded by policemen, and a great number of persons standing about, retailing all sorts of horrors connected with the affair. Upon viewing the remains, which consisted of several human hands, a skull, thigh bones, and other fragments of mortality, those experienced in such matters were at once satisfied that they belonged to some student of anatomy. This supposition proved to be correct, as the bones were subsequently claimed by Mr. F.W. WARD, a student of medicine, who stated that he had obtained them from the Long Island College Hospital, for the purpose of dissecting, and that having just completed his term of study in the institution, he was about to proceed to his home in Massachusetts, and intended to take the remains with him. He had placed them where they were found until such time as he should be ready to depart. This statement satisfied the Coroner, who allowed Mr. WARD to remove the bones, and the excitement subsided as quickly as it had been raised.

abstract: The Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, and did no business of public interest. The reports from the Sanitary Squad were disposed of in the usual way. abstract: European advices to the 11th inst., a week later, have reached us, by the arrival of the Hamburg steamship T???utonia at this port, from Southampton on the 5th, and the Connaught at St. Johns, from Colway on the 11th inst. The news is generally of important. The Prince of Wales sailed for America at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 10th. It was reported that the proposed Conference of all the Powers will be held at Paris in October, their acquiescence being considered certain. Nothing further was positively known relative to GARIBALDI's movements against Messina, though there were reports of fighting near that city. The Neapolitan forces destined for its defence were estimated to number twenty thousand men. The proclamation of a more liberal Constitution at Naples had been received with marked indifference. The Turkish Government had been notified by France of the intention of the Great Powers to put a stop to the massacre of Christians in Syria.

abstract: In the clerk's office of this Court, yesterday, Robert M. DeWitt, the publisher, took the initiatory steps to a suit against Messrs. James and Erastus Brooks, the publishers of the New-York Morning and Evening Express, for alleged infringement of copyright, in reprinting from the book published by said DeWitt, the confession of Hicks, the pirate. The confession is alleged to have been thus reprinted verbatim, and on the same day the copyrighted book was published. Damages to the amount of $10,000 are claimed. A capias has been issued, returnable on the 26th inst., when the declaration will be filed.
lead_paragraph: In the clerk's office of this Court, yesterday, Robert M. DeWitt, the publisher, took the initiatory steps to a suit against Messrs. abstract: Mr. Alexander Herbemont, of Columbia, S.C., endorsed as a gentleman of high standing and respectability, shot Capt. Davidson, a railroad conductor, at the Central depot in Raleigh, N.C., on the 14th. The ball passed through Capt. Davidson's wrist and lodged in his abdomen. Mr. Herbemont was held to bail in $500. A dispute about baggage originated the difficulty.

abstract: It may require some courage to say in advance, who, of the half-dozen candidates for the Presidency, will be honored with the vote of New-York; but there is no hazard in saying that Gen. HOUSTON is not to be the man. There met on Wednesday at Schenectady a Convention claiming to represent the State, and aiming to nominate an electoral ticket, which should represent the views and purposes of the zealous friends of the Texan.
lead_paragraph: It may require some courage to say in advance, who, of the half-dozen candidates for the Presidency, will be honored with the vote of New-York; but there is no hazard in saying that Gen. HOUSTON is not to be the man. There met on Wednesday at Schenectady a Convention claiming to represent the State, and aiming to nominate an electoral ticket, which should represent the views and purposes of the zealous friends of the Texan. A round score of delegates made their appearance. The usual forms of organization had scarcely been perfected, when it became painfully apparent that a bare majority was addicted to him of San Jacinto; the sturdy minority having declared predilections for BELL and EVERETT; and the individual most conspicuous in conducting the proceedings being a rejected member of the State Convention which placed the Tennessean in nomination. There were, in these circumstances, obvious difficulties in transacting business. It was easy to nominate Capt. STOCKTON for Vice-President -- Capt. STOCKTON is the proscriptive dummy at all these snug little political games -- but when it came to naming an Electoral ticket of thirty-seven names, representing all the Congressional Districts of the State, and the State itself, it was inexpressibly mortifying to find that not more than eleven persons, all of whom were present, were assuredly loyal to HOUSTON; and what were these among so many? It was soon stated, not without pathos, that the City and County of Albany contained no adherent of the hero; a statement happily refuted by the President of the Convention, who, asserting himself as the lone star of that locality, indignantly quitted the chair and the assembly, by way of vindicating his fidelity to the cause. Then a Committee of Research to discover the lacking and too diffident candidates for the electoral honor was appointed, and the Convention -- it cannot be said to have adjourned -- exploded in utter confusion.

abstract: In view of the recent increase of crime, it may be well to ask whether there is not some defect in our present statutes, relative to capital offences which require amendment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times

abstract: The Republican State Central Committee met yesterday afternoon, at the Astor House, to designate the time for holding the State Convention, and to transact such other business as might be deemed necessary. All the members of the Committee were present except four, and every section of the State was represented. Besides the members, there were present Gov. E.D. MORGAN, Mr. LITTLEJOHN, Speaker of the Assembly; JAMES M. COOK, Superintendent of the Bank Department; Senator RAMSAY, Dr. THOMPSON, Ex-Health Officer of this port, and one or two others.

abstract: The stable of JOHN HOFFMAN, a market gardener, situated in Sixty-third-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, was maliciously set on fire between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and the flames quickly spread to the one and a half story dwelling adjoining, destroying both buildings in so brief a time, that Mr. HOFFMAN, his wife and three ...
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire was discovered in the unoccupied building, No. 75 Beach-street, owned by SHEPHERD KNAPP, and formerly used as an iron foundry. The flames spread rapidly and communicated to a two-story building in the rear, which was destroyed, as also were the three upper stories of the structure in which the fire originated. The loss upon both buildings amounts to about $3,000, which is met by an insurance of $5,000 in City companies. The lower floor of the premises was occupied as a store-room for beer, by Messrs. BOYD, BROTHER & Co. They had about $7,000 worth of beer in store at the time, all of which is supposed to have been somewhat damaged by smoke. It is thought that the fire was caused by sparks having been blown through an open window, and lodging upon some rubbish in the upper story.

abstract: The name Zouave is just now a household word. The occasion of its immediate prominence is, as is well known, the fact that a military corps of youths, hailing from the "City of Skunks," is now in our midst. Attired in singular garb; heralded by thousands of pens, as moral, brave, wealthy, skillful and wonderful, they have come suddenly upon us in the very doggiest of dog-days, and without waiting for rest, refreshment or a barber, have daily, nay hourly, astonished, delighted, surprised the few thousands of Gotham�s citizens who prefer the exciting sensations of our city life, to the quiet retiracy of a rural retreat. We see in the shop windows Zouave hats, caps, coats, canes, umbrellas and shoes. There is nothing which has hitherto been baptized JENNY LIND, SONTAG, PATTI or HEENAN, but now can be found with the Algerine prefix -- the African cognomen.

abstract: doubt may prevail of the military efficiency of our gallant visitors from Chicago, there is no possible room for doubt as to their popularity. The Academy of Music, which, in the advertisements of Managers, contains countless thousands, and in fact an irregular number of hundreds, was filled last evening to the utmost limit of comfort, the dramatic and operatic attraction being the performance of these consummate actors, who, in the general esteem, so well realize the role of the American soldier. It is safe, of course, to suppose that of the large body of spectators present, no inconsiderable number regarded the stated services of the chorus in those mimic armies with which ROSSINI and MEYERBEER are so apt to throng the stage, as quite equal in drill and conduct to these more practical warriors; but from the volume and warmth of the applause, it was clear that the bulk of those present were thoroughly gratified, not only with the novelty, but with the unerring accuracy of the evolutions. The Zouave may now be regarded as naturalized in the New World.

abstract: VISIT OF HEENAN TO TROY. -- HEENAN arrived in Troy on a visit to his sick father at 8 o'clock Wednesday morning. His progress and purposes are set forth thus lucidly, pathetically and grammatically by the Times: "He traveled with the utmost quietness and unostentation, partly owing to his natural repugnance to display, and partly to the nature of the melancholy news received by him relative to the serious illness of his father, at his residence in West Troy. Immediately after debarking from the train, he hastily took a carriage and was driven to the westerly side of the river, and upon reaching his home indulged in those filial sympathies and gratulations come to be so characteristic of him as a modest, unassuming youth, who has won his way to a fame, the dignity and character of which it is not our province to malign, so far as Mr. HEENAN is concerned, that connection being, of its kind, honorable in the highest degree. During his stay the Champion will observe strictly his thoughtful determination to avoid all ostentation, and will return to New-York, quietly, in the late P.M. train of this afternoon, which leaves this city at 5:05.

abstract: It appears that during the passage of the ship Ellen Austin to this port, the officers, or some of them -- we hope not for mere amusement -- tied the arms and knees of a passenger together, passed a stick between them, and then rolled him along the deck like a bale of goods. On complaining at the District-Attorney's office, the victim was informed that this mode of treating him was not a criminal offence under the United States laws, and that his only remedy was a civil action for assault and battery. This is very like informing a sickly hodman that he must drink port wine and "live high," and take horseback exercise.

abstract: "His Honor" the Mayor has condescended to send the Board of Aldermen a list of his charges against Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPEN, and the Board has appointed a Committee of three to examine into their truth, and it will, of course, hear the accused in their own defence. This is, so far, a very regular proceeding, and if the Committee do their duty properly, will leave the public little to complain of. But this is not the sort of proceeding which "His Honor" either desires or anticipates. What he wants is, in short, concurrence by the Board in any removals he pleases to make, on his version of the "cause." Any examination into the facts which decency calls for, he wishes to take place before himself alone, and either in the presence or absence of the accused, as his fertile fancy may suggest. As few of the present officials are his friends or nominees, and as he has still a large crowd of supporters to reward, the probability of his being an impartial judge in any such investigation may be readily estimated. What he wants is vacant places; and he is not very particular as to how he gets them, and his sitting to decide whether they ought to become vacant or not, is as great a caricature upon justice as JEFFRIES hearing the returns to the writs of quo warranto, by which JAMES II. sought to strip all the English towns of their charters. JEFFRIES was never known to find a charter valid and unimpeachable. As one of his admirers magniloquently remarked, "they went down before him as the walls of Jericho before the trumpet of the Lord." So also, we may rely upon it, there is no municipal functionary who will be able to defend himself against the charge of malfeasance in office, as long as FERNANDO is judge. The "single eye" casts a "baleful light" upon every official who is not content to employ all the ragamuffins of Mozart Hall in his office, and place bands of ticket-swindlers and pugilists upon all the public works. If anybody wants to know His Honor's notion of an efficient officer, let him look at Inspector DELAVAN, who, according to his own confession, has no longer any control over his own subordinates, and has had the scum of the Wood Democracy furnished to him as Clerks and Wardens, ENRIGHT, that eager friend of the traveler, being the crowning mercy of "His Honor's" dispensation.

As few of the present officials are his friends or nominees, and as he has still a large crowd of supporters to reward, the probability of his being an impartial judge in any such investigation may be readily estimated. What he wants is vacant places; and he is not very particular as to how he gets them, and his sitting to decide whether they ought to become vacant or not, is as great a caricature upon justice as JEFFRIES hearing the returns to the writs of quo warranto, by which JAMES II. sought to strip all the English towns of their charters. JEFFRIES was never known to find a charter valid and unimpeachable. As one of his admirers magniloquently remarked, "they went down before him as the walls of Jericho before the trumpet of the Lord." So also, we may rely upon it, there is no municipal functionary who will be able to defend himself against the charge of malfeasance in office, as long as FERNANDO is judge. The "single eye" casts a "baleful light" upon every official who is not content to employ all the ragamuffins of Mozart Hall in his office, and place bands of ticket-swindlers and pugilists upon all the public works. If anybody wants to know His Honor's notion of an efficient officer, let him look at Inspector DELAVAN, who, according to his own confession, has no longer any control over his own subordinates, and has had the scum of the Wood Democracy furnished to him as Clerks and Wardens, ENRIGHT, that eager friend of the traveler, being the crowning mercy of "His Honor's" dispensation.

abstract: Another four-oared boat race took place on Thursday, between three of the boats which rowed in the 4th July Corporation Regatta. It was got up to settle the question of superiority between the Stranger; of Poughkeepsie, rowed by W.H. Stevens, O. Wood, Daniel Leroy and E. Benneway; the Judge Voorhies, of Brooklyn, rowed by W. Mosgrove, Wm. Suller, J. Suller and Thomas Suller, and the McCay, rowed by Thomas Burns, Patrick Brady, J. Wood and Thomas Farrell, the stakes being $300. At the start the McCay was behind, but overtook and passed the other boats half way from the starting point and the outer stake boat. From this point the Stranger took the lead and kept it, closely followed by the McCay, the Judge Voorhies coming in some distance astern, in consequence of one of the crew hurting his hand. The Stranger won the race in 19 minutes and 23 seconds, the distance rowed being about 3 miles. About 1,200 persons were present, and everything was conducted in the most respectable manner and with great credit to the Managing Committee, Messrs. Burns, McCay, Holland, &c. The crew of Harbor Police boat No. 8, were very active in keeping the coast clear for the boats.

abstract: The steamer City of New-York, of about 500 tons, chartered by the United States Government, left Boston on Wednesday for the fishing grounds of the British North American Provinces. The steamer took as passenger Ex-Gov. HUBBARD, of New-Hampshire, one of the United States Commissioners under the Reciprocity Treaty, with other Washington Engineers and officials. At St. Johns, N.F., the British Commissioners will join the party, and together they will proceed to define the Fishing Boundaries as provided for in the treaty between this country and England. Among the party from the United States is a gentleman of Seabrook, N.H., of great experience in all matters connected with the fishing interest, and having a thorough knowledge of the localities which the Commissioners are about to visit. The expedition will return about the first of September. The City of New-York is under the command of Capt. R.B. PEGRAM, United States Navy.

abstract: REMARKABLE SELF-SACRIFICING CONDUCT OF A NEW-YORK SERVANT GIRL. -- The Ballymena (Ireland) Observer, of the 2d of June, records the story of the doings of an Irish girl, whose parents formerly resided in the neighborhood of the town in which that journal is published, substantially as follows: Her father, WM. MCCORD, a shoemaker and tenant of a small farm near Ballymena, died in circumstances of pecuniary embarrassment some years ago. At the time of his death his liabilities amounted to nearly £40, and his family were left without a shilling for themselves, or any means for the liquidation of these debts. Soon after his death, about the year 1853, his daughter, ANN JANE MCCORD, then scarcely 20 years of age, emigrated to America, where she obtained employment as a domestic servant. Having from the outset determined to pay every farthing of her dead father's liabilities, she hoarded the small earnings of her industry with the utmost care; and, after six years of incessant toil, her noble aspirations were crowned with success -- her ardent desire was accomplished, and the grand aim of all her self-sacrificing exertions was fully achieved. On the 9th of February last, she sent a letter from No. 99 West Twenty-fourth-street, New-York, remitting to Mr. JAMES MCCORD, of Castlegore, a bank order for the sum of £40, to be distributed by that gentleman in payment of her father's debts. The aggregate sum due was £34 3s. 3d. In a postscript she directed that one MCHENRY should be paid five shillings over the amount of his debt, and that the balance of the remittance, £5 11s. 9d., should be presented to her sister, Mrs. MARGARET WILSON. When the account was written, Mr. MCCORD had complied with the directions of the letter in every particular. The same account says that the payment was entirely unexpected on the part of the creditors, and the act exhibits an example of high and generous principle, for which the name and memory of ANN JANE MCCORD deserves to be honored in the place of her nativity, and it might have added, in every other land.

abstract: For some weeks past, the Base Ball fraternity have been anxiously looking forward to this great contest, and on Thursday afternoon accordingly the borders of the Excelsior ground, at the foot of Court-street, Brooklyn, were thronged by an inter???ted multitude, comprising not less than twelve thousand persons, a larger number than attended the great matches at Fashion Course. Amongst these were very many ladies, assembled from New-York and Brooklyn and remoter localities. Altogether the scene was one of unusual interest, for not only were the grounds thronged, but the neighboring house-tops were crowded with human beings, and even the masts and spars of the vessels lying near had their occupants. The arrangements were most admirable, no obstruction being offered to the fielders of either side, while ample accommodations were provided for the ladies. The Reporter's plank, it is true, might be lengthened on future occasions, or fictitious reporters should be excluded. The following is an account of the innings in detail:

abstract: AN IMPORTANT DECISION. -- The Cincinnati Gazette, of the 14th, gives the following abstract of a case lately decided in the Supreme Court of Ohio, by Judges LEAVITT and MCLEAN: The Chillicothe Branch of the State Bank of Ohio sent $50,000 in commercial bills to LUDLOW, Cashier of the Ohio Life and Trust Company Bank, at New-York, for collection. LUDLOW, instead of holding the paper till maturity, as was his duty, sold it and used the proceeds. Before the bills fell due the Trust Company failed, and subsequently the holders of the paper, who bought it from LUDLOW, sued the Chillicothe Bank, as indorser, the makers of the bills having been enjoined by the Ohio Bank from paying the same. The bills were indorsed by the Cashier of the Chillicothe Bank, "Credit my account -- J.B. Scott, Cashier." This, the Court decided, was sufficient notice to third parties that LUDLOW had no authority to negotiate the paper, and upon this ground the plaintiffs were nonsuited. Had it been indorsed in the usual way, as negotiable paper, the defendants would have lost their case. Mr. SCOTT's caution, in this particular, saved the Bank $50,000, and the establishment of the principle may prevent, in the future, a great deal of rascality similar to that practiced by the bold and reckless LUDLOW."

abstract: The rush at this office has been tremendous as the time for paying the Croton taxes is limited to the 31st inst. After that date an interest of five per cent will be added on all amounts remaining unpaid. The collections on Wednesday footed up over $11,000, and yesterday exceeded $12,000. It is expected that even this will be increased as the close of the month approaches. Those wishing to save the interest had better take heed and pay their water rent at once.

abstract: -- On Wednesday night, between 11 and 12 o'clock, fire was discovered issuing from the sash and blind factory of Mr. HENRY HAGEMAN, near the lower landing at Sing Sing The flames spread rapidly to the factory and blacksmith shop owned by Mr. WASHINGTON CARPENTER, and occupied by Mr. MELROSE. The buildings and their contents were entirely destroyed. It is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary. The firemen, by their exertions, saved the adjoining buildings from sharing in the conflagration. The loss will fall heavy upon Messrs. CARPENTER and MELROSE, as they were not insured, but the amount we could not learn. The loss to Mr. HAGEMAN is estimated at $4,000, also not insured.

abstract: We frequently see the announcement, under the head of "Ship News," of vessels cleared for "St. Thomas and a market." It is well known to business men, and even to schoolboys, that St. Thomas is one of the West India Islands. A flourishing trade is carried on between our ports and that island, and many honorable business men and shipping merchants are transacting business there; yet, strange to say, not more than half the vessels which clear at our Custom House for St. Thomas, with regular papers, go to that island.

abstract: A defective chimney flue in the premises No. 87 Centre-street, set the place on fire between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The flames were soon put out, Mr. JAMES GALLAGHER, who occupied the building as a brass foundry, suffering a loss of about $100. He was insured for $1,000 in the Howard Insurance Company.

abstract: The line of division between the two sections of the Democracy in New-Jersey is becoming more sharply drawn. SILAS A. KITCHELL O.H. PERRY, J.H. SNYDEX, and other prominent Douglas Democrats of Newark, N.J., have issued a formal "Protest against the Disorganizing State Central Committee." It is addressed to the "friends of regular organization." They Claim that the Democratic Party is more devoted to ...
lead_paragraph: The line of division between the two sections of the Democracy in New-Jersey is becoming more sharply drawn. SILAS A. KITCHELL O.H. PERRY, J.H. SNYDEX, and other prominent Douglas Democrats of Newark, N.J., have issued a formal "Protest against the Disorganizing State Central Committee." It is addressed to the "friends of regular organization." They Claim that the Democratic Party is more devoted to principles than to men, and that no doctrine has been more frequently reaffirmed than than of non-intervention by Congress with Slavery in the Territories. No valid excuse has ever been offered by which any delegate from New-Jersey to the National Convention could be absolved from obligation to support the nominee of the Baltimore Convention, and they have witnessed with surprise a recommendation signed by the Chairman of the Central Committee that they should join hands with the Seceders. They "deny the right of the Committee to make any such recommendation, and repudiate all such attempts to seduce them from their allegiance to their principles which are National, and their candidates, who coming from the North and South, and joining hands cordially upon the platform, prove to us that their hearts beat to the only national sentiment, 'Non-intervention.' They ask their Democratic friends in New-Jersey and the Union to stand fast to their National Platform, and their gallant standard bearers, DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, and repel all efforts, come from what source they may, to induce a combination with BRECKINRIDGE and LANE, as they would with LINCOLN and HAMLIN, viewing them alike as sectional. In Rahway, on Wednesday evening, a meeting was held to appoint delegates to the State Convention. Judge Savage offered a resolution instructing the delegates to vote against a Union ticket. After a long and exciting debate it was laid on the table by a close vote. A portion of the Douglas men then withdrew, and appointed delegates to contest the seats of those elected by the rest of the meeting. Anti-fusion delegates have been elected from Belleville.

abstract: THE JAPANESE DONATION TO THE POLICE. -- A check for $13,750, the sum appropriated by the Japanese Princes to those members of the Police force who were attentive to them while they sojourned in this City, has been placed in the hands of General Superintendent KENNEDY. To distribute the amount in a manner satisfactory to the Department, will prove a matter of some difficulty. The Commissioners, it is understood, suggest that the donation should be placed to the credit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund, but such a disposition of it would not meet with the favor of any man in the Department, as "the fund" is looked upon as a humbug. All the fines and presents made to officers since the organization of the Department have gone into its capacious coffers, which by this time must be in a very [???]ethoric condition, while there are only two beneficiaries, who receive but $100 each per annum, and even this pittance would not be given to the wife of a policeman unless he should be killed in the performance of his duty. Divided equally among the entire force, the Japanese windfall would give about $8 to each man but the equity of such a distribution is questionable, when the fact is taken into consideration that the extra work was only entailed upon a few. A suggestion has been made that the whole amount should be expended in the purchase of a uniform coat for each policeman, as many of the force are sadly in need of new garments of that description -- and still another suggestion has been made to parcel the money into amounts of $500 each, and have a lottery. As the matter now stands, Mr. KENNEDY is placed in a position somewhat analogous to that of the man who won the elephant at a raffle.
lead_paragraph: THE JAPANESE DONATION TO THE POLICE. -- A check for $13,750, the sum appropriated by the Japanese Princes to those members of the Police force who were attentive to them while they sojourned in this City, has been placed in the hands of General Superintendent KENNEDY. To distribute the amount in a manner satisfactory to the Department, will prove a matter of some difficulty. The Commissioners, it is understood, suggest that the donation should be placed to the credit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund, but such a disposition of it would not meet with the favor of any man in the Department, as "the fund" is looked upon as a humbug.
