Divided equally among the entire force, the Japanese windfall would give about $8 to each man but the equity of such a distribution is questionable, when the fact is taken into consideration that the extra work was only entailed upon a few. A suggestion has been made that the whole amount should be expended in the purchase of a uniform coat for each policeman, as many of the force are sadly in need of new garments of that description -- and still another suggestion has been made to parcel the money into amounts of $500 each, and have a lottery. As the matter now stands, Mr. KENNEDY is placed in a position somewhat analogous to that of the man who won the elephant at a raffle.

abstract: The outrages perpetrated by Senator DAVIS on the mechanics of the country, begin to be seriously felt by the Government. Orders received to-day from the army in the field, for a supply of trusses, cannot be filled, as these are "patented" articles, and under Senator DAVIS' law cannot be purchased except by special act of Congress. The Senator's bowels of compassion were insufficient to afford protection to the bowels of the soldiers.

abstract: The article which we copy this  morning from the Observer shows that the Pastor of the Church of the Puritans, who has now gone to Europe in search of a salary, is becoming personally involved in a very unpleasant branch of the controversy which has so thoroughly ruined his Church.
lead_paragraph: The article which we copy this morning from the Observer shows that the Pastor of the Church of the Puritans, who has now gone to Europe in search of a salary, is becoming personally involved in a very unpleasant branch of the controversy which has so thoroughly ruined his Church. Our readers may remember a statement which appeared in the TIMES some months since, to the effect that while Dr. CHEEVER was denouncing slaveholding as a crime, he tolerated the presence of a slaveholder in his Church, as a member. The Observer and Independent have recently revived the charge, and Dr. CHEEVER, in a letter which we copy this morning, gives it a substantial denial. He states that he did not know that the lady in question was a slave-owner, and that, as he had no means of finding it out, he cannot be blamed for permitting her to remain a member of his Church.

abstract: -- Three boys, sons of Mr. MCNAUGHTON and Mr. COONEY, residing near Stuyvesant, Columbia County, were drowned recently while bathing in the creek near that village. They had a holiday that afternoon, and Mr. MCNAUGHTON's boy, who was the oldest of the three, proposed to the others that they should go and have a bathe in the creek. The neighbors, in the earlier part of the afternoon, had seen the boys bathing, but apprehended no danger, as the water was very shallow. Not returning to supper, the parents became alarmed, and instituted a search, which resulted in finding the clothes of the whole of them upon the bank. One of the party then went into the creek in search of the bodies, and found them nearly together a few yards from the bank. They were quite dead. How they were all drowned is a mystery, as the water was not quite two feet deep. Mr. MCNAUGHTON's boy was about 11 years old, and Mr. COONEY's respectively aged ten and eight years. An inquest has been held upon the bodies, and a verdict of accidental death by drowning rendered.
lead_paragraph: -- Three boys, sons of Mr. MCNAUGHTON and Mr. COONEY, residing near Stuyvesant, Columbia County, were drowned recently while bathing in the creek near that village. They had a holiday that afternoon, and Mr. MCNAUGHTON's boy, who was the oldest of the three, proposed to the others that they should go and have a bathe in the creek. The neighbors, in the earlier part of the afternoon, had seen the boys bathing, but apprehended no danger, as the water was very shallow. Not returning to supper, the parents became alarmed, and instituted a search, which resulted in finding the clothes of the whole of them upon the bank. One of the party then went into the creek in search of the bodies, and found them nearly together a few yards from the bank. They were quite dead. How they were all drowned is a mystery, as the water was not quite two feet deep. Mr. MCNAUGHTON's boy was about 11 years old, and Mr. COONEY's respectively aged ten and eight years. An inquest has been held upon the bodies, and a verdict of accidental death by drowning rendered.

abstract: There is probably no class of persons who do so much injury to the cause of freedom on this Continent, as those who utter wild disapproval of slave labor, and then fall to weeping over the condition of Jamaica. They place a label on Slavery testifying that it is a "moral, social and political evil," and then, by way of hindering its abolition in the United States, drop a few philanthropic tears over the failure of free labor in the British West Indies. If this school of economists were at all earnest in its convictions, it would be entitled to a little respect; but the fact is, that it is simply lazy and muddle-brained.
lead_paragraph: There is probably no class of persons who do so much injury to the cause of freedom on this Continent, as those who utter wild disapproval of slave labor, and then fall to weeping over the condition of Jamaica. abstract: We have no disposition to impeach the motives of Ex-Gov. HUNT, or to question his sincerity and honesty in the course he is now pursuing. But we cannot regard that course as either sensible or patriotic. Gov. HUNT is a supporter of BELL and EVERETT -- but he avows his preference for DOUGLAS over LINCOLN, and scarcely conceals his readiness to rejoice in the election of BRECKINRIDGE, if that should prove the only alternative to the triumph of the Republican ticket. It would not be just to style him a Democrat, either in principle or party alliance; -- and in view of his confessed sympathy with Democratic candidates, he can scarcely claim recognition as a Whig. He is mainly and conspicuously an Anti-Republican. His creed just now is negative. His special desire and main endeavor, according to his own confession, are to defeat the Republican ticket. Yet he resents the imputation of inconsistency, although in time past he has unquestionably acted with the Republican Party and accepted position as a member of its organization.
lead_paragraph: We have no disposition to impeach the motives of Ex-Gov. HUNT, or to question his sincerity and honesty in the course he is now pursuing. It would not be just to style him a Democrat, either in principle or party alliance; -- and in view of his confessed sympathy with Democratic candidates, he can scarcely claim recognition as a Whig. He is mainly and conspicuously an Anti-Republican. His creed just now is negative. His special desire and main endeavor, according to his own confession, are to defeat the Republican ticket. Yet he resents the imputation of inconsistency, although in time past he has unquestionably acted with the Republican Party and accepted position as a member of its organization.

abstract: Arrangements have been made for a series of international matches, to be played annually, under the auspices of the St. George's Club, of New-York, and the Montreal Club, of Montreal, Canada East. The first match will be played at Montreal during the Prince of WALES' visit to that city.
lead_paragraph: Arrangements have been made for a series of international matches, to be played annually, under the auspices of the St. George's Club, of New-York, and the Montreal Club, of Montreal, Canada East. The first match will be played at Montreal during the Prince of WALES' visit to that city. The Eleven will be selected by the St. George's Club on the part of the United States, and the friends of cricket in America will be pleased to learn that for once, and a beginning, a sufficient number from the many fine American cricketers to be found -- if looked for -- will be selected by St. George to make the Eleven national enough in its character to have the right to sustain the honor of the American flag.

abstract: stand that the Prince on Wales and retinue will visit Boston some time in the month of September next. He comes this way at the invitation of Harvard University, to pay a visit to that institution. President FELTON will proceed to Montreal in a few weeks, to pay his respects to the Prince. As he will probably accept the proffered hospitalities of the city of Boston, we trust that ample arrangements will be made for his entertainment. -- Courier.

abstract: David C. Fuller, agent for George A. Cox, liquor dealer at No. 327 Greenwich-street, yesterday caused the arrest of John Gallagher, a young man residing at No. 212 Houston-street, who formerly acted as his clerk, on a charge of having fraudulently obtained from him in May last $80 worth of wines and liquors. It is alleged that Gallagher, after his connection with the complainant had ceased, called at the store and stated that he had orders for liquors to fill for John O'Brien, of No. 74 York-street, Brooklyn, and thus obtained the property. It was subsequently ascertained that no such person as O'Brien lived at the number indicated, and as soon as Gallagher could be found he was apprehended. He was held for trial in the sum of $1,000.

abstract: correspondent of the Missouri Republican writing from Tubucon, June 28, says: "Capt. R.S. EWELL started, on the 25th, with seventy-five men and several volunteers, for the purpose of meeting the Chiricahui Indians at Apache Pass, as I advised your readers last week. I left Tucson on the 23d in order to join him, but after traveling seventy-five miles, and when within a few miles of Fort Buchanan, I learned that he had set out one day sooner than he had at first intended, thus frustrating my intentions of accompany the command. I returned to the Hacienda de Santa Rita, which I had left soon after dining, and was there detained for several days by severe illness."

abstract: The schooner Washington Irving, which left Erie for this port a week ago, has not since been heard from, and there is no longer room to doubt that she is lost with all on board. The following is a list of her crew and passengers: Capt. Stephen H. Varmatta, Antonia Hary, Henry House, Owen Keep, Refer Silvy, and one passenger, Cornelius Leary. Owen Keep belonged in Buffalo, the others in Erie.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, Friday, July 20.

abstract: Hon. Thomas Y. How, who died suddenly at Auburn, of apoplexy, on Sunday last, was born in Sussex County, N.J., on the 15th of August, 1608. In 1820 he went to Auburn and assisted Dr. Rudd, then Principal of the Academy of that city. He entered Geneva College in the same year, graduating in 1828, when he immediately took up the study of the law. In 1836 he was appointed Surrogate of the county. Between that time and 1850 he took a prominent part in forwarding all enterprises in which Auburn was interested, and in that year was sent to Congress by the Democrats. About the same time he effected a consolidation of the two papers published in Auburn, giving the journal the name of the New Era. He discharged the duties of political editor himself for some time. In 1853 he was elected Mayor. At the time of his death Mr. How was connected with a number of benevolent societies.
lead_paragraph: Hon. Thomas Y. How, who died suddenly at Auburn, of apoplexy, on Sunday last, was born in Sussex County, N.J., on the 15th of August, 1608. abstract: The steamship Africa, from Liverpool, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with London papers of the 7th and telegraphic advices, via Londonderry, of the 8th inst. Telegrams from Sicily say that Gen. GARIBALDI was marching on Messina. The General was about to receive large supplies, both of men and stores; about 2,000 men were to sail for Sicily from Genoa, where great numbers of volunteers are assembled; and a French house is said to have taken a contract for some thousands of revolvers, rifles and muskets, for GARIBALDI's service. Naples, at latest dates, was tranquil, and the proclamation of martial law had been rescinded. The Neapolitan Assembly, it is stated, is convoked for the 10th of September. The Constitution of 1848 has been proclaimed anew, and its restoration has been accompanied by the reestablishment of the Press laws enacted in 1848 and 1849. These concessions of the King have created no confidence in the minds of the people. It is asserted in various quarters -- and the language of the Opinione of Turin would seem to justify the assertion -- that France is urgently pressing the Sardinian Cabinet to listen to the overtures of the King of Naples and consent to the conclusion of an alliance between Naples and Piedmont. The Government of the latter kingdom does not conceal its aversion to the proposition. The proceedings of the British Parliament are interesting. In both Houses, the revolution in Southern Italy had been discussed, and the speakers evinced the warmest sympathy for the Garibaldi movement. The resolutions of Lord PALMERSTON, on the Privilege question, had been carried seriatim in the House of Commons. Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in answer to a question, had stated that Gen. HARNEY had been recalled by the United States Government for not carrying out the arrangements of Gen. SCOTT for the solution of the San Juan dispute. As the announcement was made officially, we presume it is correct. Two unusually interesting letters appear from our Paris Correspondent; one describing the funeral of Prince JEROME, and the other giving an account of the fete champetre, with which our countrymen in Paris commemorated the national holiday. Letters from Beyrout state that the civil war in Syria is spreading, and that the greatest atrocities are committed against Christians. The whole of Syria, from Aleppo to Gaza, was in a state of the greatest commotion.

abstract: The Chicago Zouave Cadets, whose performances in the military line have astonished and delighted the New-York public for a week past, left this city last evening for Boston. They were escorted to the Norwich and Worcester boat by Companies A. and F., Sixth Regiment, under the command of Capts. FRANK and EBELSPACKER, assisted by detachments from the other Companies in the Regiment, and also by detachments from the Second Regiment, headed by Capt. REID, from the Eighth, headed by Capt. BUCK, from the Seventh, headed by Capt. SHUMWAY, and from the Seventy-ninth, headed by Capt. MANSON. A large collection of spectators was assembled on the wharf, and on the arrival of the Cadets at the boat a salute of 10 guns were fired. As the boat shoved out into the stream another salute of eleven guns was fired, and the Zouaves receded from view amid the cheers of the multitude on the wharf, which was responded to by repeated "sevens and a tiger" from the Cadets.

abstract: Islands, writes follows from Port Stanley to the Baltimore American under date of April 24: "I have just returned from a cruise after some missionaries who have been murdered near Cape Horn, and the vessel plundered of all her stores, furniture, sails, rigging, &c. Her crew consisted of nine persons, all of whom have been murdered except the cook, who I have with me. The schooner was called the Allen Gardiner. She belonged to the Patagonian Mission Society, and as she had been robbed of all her sails and rigging I could not bring her away with me. I returned to this place and took some of my spar, sails and rigging, likewise some men to man her with, and started after her again. I succeeded in getting her, but the weather being very bad, and as I had no navigator on board, I had to take her in tow with my hawser, and towed her from the Beagle Channel to the eastward of Staten Land, and from thence to here without as much as parting the hawser. It was a very disagreeable cruise and the British steamer of war should have gone for her; but as there was no profit or prize money to be earned and plenty of cold hands and feet to be had, it was left for me. I offered the Mission my vessel but they wanted me, and in fact I was the only one here who was acquainted about that part of the coast, and had not the United States Government allowed me and gave me permission to go and visit the Strait of Magellan, this poor fellow might have died of starvation or been murdered by the natives, and the vessel would have been a total loss. I dare say many vessels that are missing have been served the same way, and will always remain in. doubt or mystery. If I could afford it, I would go and search the coast from Staten Land to Cape Pillar this Winter, but I do not know whether the Government would allow it or not. The ship Sea Ranger, of Boston, has been run on shore on one of these islands; she was in a sinking condition. She was from Liverpool, bound to San Francisco. She is a total loss, but a small part of her cargo will be saved in a damaged state."

abstract: -- The famous English Eleven, who crossed the seas to break a lance, or rather a bat, with the cricket players of this country, have been playing a match against the Gentlemen of England at home. Their playing was better than anything they exhibited while in this country. One of their number, Mr. CARPENTER, who will be well remembered by our cricketers, scored the remarkable number of 119 in his innings, scoring six for one stroke of the ball. LILLYWHITE and CAESAR made very good play, the Eleven scoring the formidable number of 328 in their first innings, while their opponents scored only 160. The match was not concluded at last dates.
lead_paragraph: -- The famous English Eleven, who crossed the seas to break a lance, or rather a bat, with the cricket players of this country, have been playing a match against the Gentlemen of England at home. abstract: It is a great mistake to suppose that Mr. BUCHANAN will retire from the Presidency a perfectly disappointed man. It is true that he has achieved no memorable act of public service; that he has done his best to destroy the party which elevated him to power; that he has alienated the confidence of his personal friends, and been successfully used by his personal enemies in the prosecution of their plans. But he has completely achieved the one great object on which he set his heart from the first. By this we do not mean the defeat of Mr. DOUGLAS as the candidate of the united Democracy; for whatever triumph the President may have felt at the explosions of Charleston and Baltimore, must have been cruelly dashed by the perverse conduct of the seceders, who deliberately nominated a man whom our Old Public Functionary detests and despises with his whole heart. To be coerced into supporting Mr. BRECKINRIDGE is so bitter a thing for the President, that the election of Mr. DOUGLAS would not leave him utterly without consolation. It would be hard, certainly, to think that his favorite enemy had won a great prize: but then it would be pleasant to feel that his obnoxious friend had been floored.
lead_paragraph: It is a great mistake to suppose that Mr. BUCHANAN will retire from the Presidency a perfectly disappointed man. abstract: The Excise Commissioners have been compelled to defer their final session for the year until the 30th instant, that they may examine and pass upon the hundreds of applications for license already on their table. Some 1,500 of the more law-abiding dealers have deemed it wise to conform to the Statutes of the State. A few hundred more will probably avail themselves of the brief interval before the opportunity for legalizing their traffic shall cease for a twelve-month. Enough will have done so to satisfy the reasonable demands of the dram-drinking community; so that the process of weeding and wiping out the unlicensed grog-shops may be entered upon by the public authorities, without compelling any body to go dry.

abstract: Three negroes living near Clifton, Iroquois County, Illinois, were kidnapped on the 2d. The local papers give the following account of the transaction. On Sunday the Kidnappers met at the house of JOHN O'NEAL, about three-fourths of a mile west of Clifton, procured a team, and placed sentinels along the road and in and about Ashkum. On the afternoon of that day GEO. D. SMITH went into the village and procured a room. He then went out and enticed the unsuspecting five negro men into this place, and called for, and was supplied with whisky and cards. At a preconcerted signal, the whole company entered the house with knives and revolvers and attempted to take the negroes and fetter them. A general fight ensued, several of the negroes fighting desperately, and two made their escape. The three, SLATER, who leaves a wife, and who is a free negro from Boston, JOHN, from Maryland and WILLIAM, a little boy from Florida, were finally subdued and tied. They were immediately put into a lumber wagon in waiting and run under the whip to Ashkum. The alarm having been given in and about Clifton, the citizens of the neighborhood assembled, and the down train from Chicago coming along in a short time, they got aboard of the cars and went to Ashkum for the purpose of effecting a rescue. Arriving at that place the conductor ran into town without giving a signal, stopped but a moment, until the negroes could be rolled into the baggage-car, and started his train without even attempting to make the usual signal. A large company was there armed, ready to prevent a rescue, and the Clifton men were compelled to jump off the train without having accomplished anything. The three negroes were taken South, and have undoubtedly, ere this time, been sold.

abstract: A correspondent the Observer gives an interesting sketch of the Pastoral Conferences lately held at Paris. These Conferences are not synod or official assemblies, for the Protestants of the National Church in France have not obtained leave to revive this system; they are simply free meetings which exercise no authority. Pastors and elders of the National Church, and dissenters sit on the same benches, confer on religious topics for two or three days, and then adjourn. At the last Conference there were 76 pastors or ministers, and 27 elders or deacons in attendance. The first question discussed was that of revivals. Eighteen of those present made remarks on the subject, giving their views of the means by which revivals might be brought about, and of the manner in which they should he controlled. The question of the duties of French Protestantism at the present time next came up. Mr. WILLIAM MORROD made the principal report on the subject, urging the necessity of avoiding direct controversy with Popery, of taking care not to use names of men and creeds composed by men, and of cherishing purity of faith, unity of faith, and holiness of faith.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent the Observer gives an interesting sketch of the Pastoral Conferences lately held at Paris. abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors was held in the Common Council Chamber last evening. The Special Committee, to whom was referred the Annual Statement of the Mayor of the several sums of money deemed necessary to be raised by tax for the various purposes authorized by the charter to carry on the City Government, submitted a report.
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of the Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors was held in the Common Council Chamber last evening. The Special Committee, to whom was referred the Annual Statement of the Mayor of the several sums of money deemed necessary to be raised by tax for the various purposes authorized by the charter to carry on the City Government, submitted a report. As no separate account has been kept of each loan and the amount raised therefor, the Committee found some difficulty in determining the sums required for the Sinking Fund. An attempt was made to classify these accounts, but the Committee, after expending a vast amount of labor, found that it would be impossible to submit with this report a satisfactory statement, and, therefore, recommended the amount sent in by the Mayor, with the addition of $18,000 deducted in error the previous year. The Committee also recommended that an accountant be employed to open a set of books for the Sinking Fund of the city, so as to enter each loan in a distinct and separate account, and to credit thereto so much of the present Sinking Fund as shall, upon a proper apportionment, be found to belong to it, and further recommended that hereafter the accounts be kept separate. The Committee presented schedules and statements of the several sums of money which they deem necessary to be raised by tax for the various purposes contemplated by the City Charter, with resolutions of which these statements are explanatory. The following is a synopsis of the different purposes for which money is to be raised:

abstract: ELOPEMENT AND ARREST. -- A young gentleman named JOHN DUBOIS, bookkeeper at a wholesale store in Cortlandt-street, New-York, was taken before Recorder TILDEN, at Jersey City, yesterday morning, and held to bail in the sum of $300, on a charge of having eloped with a young married woman, named Mrs. SUSAN BOND. It appears that Mrs. B. disappeared from home on Tuesday night last, and the husband finding that a quantity of her wearing apparel was also missing, suspected something wrong. Upon further search some letters from DUBOIS (who was on intimate terms with the family) were discovered, the contents of which led to the suspicion that he was aware of Mrs. B.'s whereabouts, Mr. BOND placed the matter in the hands of Ex-Detective WILDEY, who is a relative, and he commenced to work up the case. On Thursday night the officer followed Mr. DUBOIS from his place of business, for several hours, until he finally crossed to Jersey City. After walking entirely around the block, Mr. DUBOIS entered the American Hotel, where Mr. WILDEY shortly after followed. From the bookkeeper or persons connected with the hotel, he could not gain any information, but finally, from a boarder, learned that a gentleman and lady answering the description had been stopping there for several days. Mr. WILDEY then proceeded to an upper parlor, where he found the truants sitting upon a sofa. Feeling highly indignant at the manner his relative had been betrayed, by a pretended friend, Mr. WILDEY dealt DUBOIS a heavy blow on the face, which caused the blood to flow freely. It is stated that he then drew a revolver, when the young woman sprang between him and her paramour, and others also interfering, further bloodshed was prevented. Mr. WILDEY then procured the assistance of officer GEORGE CLARK, and DUBOIS was conveyed to the cells, where he remained until yesterday morning, when he gave bonds to appear for examination. The husband refused to conciliate matters, and the wife returned home with an uncle.

abstract: We understand a deputation of Virginians have been for the last week or ten days earnestly urging upon the Directors of the Great Ship Company the propriety of running the Great Eastern as a regular packet between Norfolk, Va., and Liverpool. They have represented that she would have as much freight as she could carry both ways, and a full supply of passengers every trip, and that in the Fall and Winter there would be more cotton sent to her for embarkation than she could possibly accommodate.

abstract: contained a dispatch, three days since, from our city, to the effect that 103 negroes had been safely delivered, per schooner, to persons in this vicinity. It's a true bill, we hear. The sons of Afric were brought here, delivered to a steamboat, and are now, we take it for granted, safe, and not likely to undergo what the imported darkies so detest -- deportation. Whoever conducted this affair, has our congratulations on his or their success, as the case may be, whether the Africans came from the Gold Coast via Key West, or whether they made a straight-out trip by the shortest route from their native land.

abstract: The Syracuse Journal reports the proceedings at a Convention of Distillers of the State of New-York, which was held in that city on the 10th. CHAS. TALLMAN, of Syracuse, presided, and BYRON FORD, of Clyde, acted as Secretary. Resolutions were passed inviting the distillers of other States to unite in a reduction from and after Sept. 1, 1860, for the term of six months, to 40 per cent. of the natural day capacity of their respective establishments. They further resolved that the practice of selling the whisky, and giving with it the barrel, is unprofitable to the manufacturer, and altogether improper; and they, therefore, recommend to the distiller, from and after the first day of September next, to instruct his agent in market to offer for sale the whisky and the barrel each at its respective value.

abstract: BOLD ATTEMPT TO ROB A BANK. -- Burglars gained admission to the Bank in Medina, Orleans County, on the night of the 18th, and endeavored to open the safe by exploding powder in the lock. They used so large a quantity that the door of the vault was not only thrown open, but the windows of the Bank were forced out. Although the explosion took place at 1 1/2 o'clock in the morning, and in the midst of a severe thunder storm, it was so violent that the people in the vicinity were roused from sleep and rushed into the street to ascertain the cause. The robbers were obliged to decamp without having obtained any booty.
lead_paragraph: BOLD ATTEMPT TO ROB A BANK. -- Burglars gained admission to the Bank in Medina, Orleans County, on the night of the 18th, and endeavored to open the safe by exploding powder in the lock. They used so large a quantity that the door of the vault was not only thrown open, but the windows of the Bank were forced out. Although the explosion took place at 1 1/2 o'clock in the morning, and in the midst of a severe thunder storm, it was so violent that the people in the vicinity were roused from sleep and rushed into the street to ascertain the cause. The robbers were obliged to decamp without having obtained any booty.

abstract: Congress had been in session at Santiago some two weeks, but had done very little business, for which it was severely censured by the public journals of the country. Among other measures under consideration are the following, viz.: A project to create a new province between Concepcion and Arauco; for establishing offices in the ports of the Republic for the enlistment of sailors; for reorganizing the system of primary instruction; for organizing and defining the powers of the civil courts of Copiapo; and for amending and reorganizing the Consulates.

abstract: San Francisco has been stirred very deeply again to its marrow but this time with joy. The Supreme Court at Sacramento has reversed its own decision of 1857, and pronounced the Peter Smith title invalid. Now PETER SMITH was an innocent, crack-brained doctor, who lived here in 1849 and 1850. When the contract for taking care of the sick of the city was to be awarded, PETER got it.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Saturday, June 30, 1860.

abstract: The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 14th inst., arrived at this port last evening. She brings our California correspondence to the 30th of June, together with our usual semi-monthly batch of correspondence from New-Granada, and Central and South America. The treasure list by the Ariel adds up only $673,290. Our Panama correspondent mentions the fact that Mr. VANDERBILT had written to his agent at Aspinwall to receive no mail on board the Ariel, and no private letters without pre-payment at the rate of 30 cents per half ounce -- 200 per cent. more than the Government charge. In consequence of this order, it was expected that the mails from the South Pacific and Central America would have to remain over until Government made some arrangement for their transmission.
lead_paragraph: The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 14th inst., arrived at this port last evening. She brings our California correspondence to the 30th of June, together with our usual semi-monthly batch of correspondence from New-Granada, and Central and South America. The treasure list by the Ariel adds up only $673,290. Our Panama correspondent mentions the fact that Mr. VANDERBILT had written to his agent at Aspinwall to receive no mail on board the Ariel, and no private letters without pre-payment at the rate of 30 cents per half ounce -- 200 per cent. more than the Government charge. In consequence of this order, it was expected that the mails from the South Pacific and Central America would have to remain over until Government made some arrangement for their transmission.

abstract: SEIZURE OF COUNTERFEIT HAYTI MONEY. -- On Saturday Detectives RAYNOS and VAN WAGENER arrested a German, named HASLER, on board the brig Baltimore, lying at the Catharine Ferry-slip, on a charge of passing counterfeit money. When arrested he, had disposed of $15,000 of spurious money to the mate of the brig, which will sail to-day for Portau-Prince, Hayti. The bills were brought to the office of the Deputy Superintendent of Police. The body of the bill, which is surmounted by a coat of arms reads thus: "Le present billet circulerar dans lï¿½Empire pour la valeur de deux gourdes, en vertu de la loi du 16 April, 1851, et le Tresor public garanlit la valeur de cette ???omme au porteur du present." It is signed by "Le Chef de Bureau, de la Tresorerie Generale," countersigned by "Les Counseillers de la Cour des Comples." The accused is suspected to be one of a gang of counterfeiters, who have disposed of large quanties of spurious money to vessels trading with Hayit.

abstract: -- Senator DOUGLAS has been making quite an extended tour through the Northern and Eastern States. He stops at a great many places, without the slightest intention of making a speech at any of them; but, from the force of circumstances over which he has no control, he does make a speech at every one of them; and, what is still more remarkable, everything he sees everywhere reminds him of the great and glorious doctrine of Popular Sovereignty. The calcium light at Tammany Hall, -- the battle-field of Lexington, -- Bunker-Hill Monument, -- President FELTON in his silk gown and square cap at Cambridge, -- all suggested this great principle. The United States Armory at Springfield, and an interview with the Central Railroad Directors at Albany, had precisely the same effect. Wherever he goes, whomsoever he meets, whatever he hears, he cannot escape the reflection that the only thing which can possibly save this country from utter ruin is the election of a President pledged to the doctrine of Popular Sovereignty. He deems it absolutely essential that the people of every locality should have the full and perfect right of electing their own rulers, and making their own laws, without the slightest control or dictation from any quarter. If he will visit this section after next November he will find that the people agree with him perfectly, and that they not only assent to his doctrine in theory, but act upon it also.

abstract: By decree of the Executive of this Republic, the importation of foreign spirits is forbid after 31st of this month, and the present stock on hand has either to be exported before that time, or the Government will take it at cost price and charges, and when sold, (not before,) will pay the owners. The decree is considered illegal and unconstitutional by the foreign merchants residing in Salvador, nearly all of whom have protested against it. The Consiitution, it appears, provides that no alteration shall be made in the tariff without giving one year's notice in advance, as respects all articles imported from the Atlantic, and six months on those from the Pacific shores. A decree imposing 10 per cent, on the exportation of silver and gold in their natural state has also been issued. The privilege of establishing a Bank in the Republic has been granted to a Mr. SYDNEY OAKSMITH, of New-York.

abstract: Straws, we are told, show which way the wind blows; and in this sense, it is presumed, political demonstrations indicate, in some degree, their present and future condition. We have already had our BRECKINRIDGE and LANE and our DOUGLAS and JOHNSON ratification meetings, together with some previous outpourings of the Union Party. My impressions and observations regarding these were given you in a previous letter.

abstract: By your journal of this day I notice the order of the Postmaster General, and also several letters from City deliverers. The first claims attention from the whole community for various reasons, simply because our City Dispatch Post has been conducted with notorious inefficiency and bad management, and forcing us to use, for protection sake, the facilities of a "City Express Box," simply because their service was more reliable.
lead_paragraph: New-York, Tuesday, July 17, 1860.

abstract: ERATION. -- The world does move, Archbishop HUGHES to the contrary notwithstanding. Civilization makes progress, -- society becomes more and more tolerant every day, and acts of grace are of constant occurrence now which would have been deemed impossible a few years ago. We don't mean to imply that everybody everywhere is becoming perfect. The Grand Turk is not yet a Christian: -- the Pope has not canonized LUTHER, -- nor has the Emperor of Austria sent to GARIBALDI the order of the Golden Fleece. But the Tribune is preaching the doctrine of political toleration and boasting of its own practice of it! "This is a free country," says our mild-eyed neighbor, "and the friends of any popular man have a perfect right to support him for any office!" Whether they have the same right not to support him when he wants to run, we are not informed. But so far as it goes the Tribune's creed is excellent. It scouts the idea that "small parties are necessarily made up of fools or knaves," and proceeds immediately to apologize for having inadvertently said that "Ex-Governor HUNT is not to be reckoned among the fools."

abstract: This Republic continues tranquil. The newspapers of the country are discussing the propriety of introducing Coolies, with the view to the further development of the agricultural resources of Guatemala. An article has appeared in the official gazette, calling the attention of Government to the great success attending the Coolie system on the Island of Mauritius, where, according to the article quoted, there are at present 320,229 Coolies, most of whom have been introduced since 1834 -- since which time large quantities of sugar have been shipped every year from the island to Europe; and this year's crop is estimated at 140,000 tons, said to be equal to the crop produced by Cuba in 1835. This is certainly a very satisfactory exhibit, and may well excite among the people of Guatemala a desire to have the Coolie system tried in their country.

abstract: The history of the Galway steamship subsidy adds another leaf to that formidable doomsday book -- the Wrongs of Ireland. Two years ago, all that had ever been predicted of the greatness to be achieved by that westernmost Irish port, if made the point of departure for a line of transatlantic steamers, was suddenly carried to the verge of realization by the appearance and intervention of Mr. JOHN ORRELL LEVER, a Manchester capitalist, not without successful experience in ocean navigation. Recognizing the peculiar recommendations of the harbor, and all the splendid possibilities so eloquently said and sung by Father DALY, the Galwegian priest, in whose person are so harmoniously united the attributes of an Oberlin and a Bossuet, Mr. LEVER at once projected the steam communication that was to pour through the Irish town the wealth of the Western World, and with rare energy allowed but a few weeks to elapse before setting in motion the Indian Empire as the inadequate forerunner of other craft more stupendous, upon which British shipbuilders were to be promptly set at work. It could not be otherwise than that Irish enthusiasm should go wild over this flattering enterprise. Festivals were had, dinners were eaten, Father DALY toasted Mr. LEVER as the youthful saviour of the country, Mr. LEVER replied with encouragements and engagements which simply drove his auditory mad; and in truth it seemed that all the evils suffered by the Celt at the hands of the Englishman, from the days of HENRY BEAUCLERK, were to be repaired by this heaven-sent progeny of Manchester spindles.

abstract: The ??? of Friday night which astonished all our citizens who happened to be unhoused at the time was seen, it would appear, far over the country, and was, in its way, a most astonishing phenomenon. We have had the Japanese and the Zouaves. The Great Eastern still abides with us, and the Prince of Wales is coming. The foreign and domestic excitements, however, were, are, and are to be, of this earth, earthy, or of the sea, nautically. A celestial, or at least a supraterranean visitant was needed, and the meteor came. The rule of parallax, evidently not under, stood by our ordinary street sight-seers, proves, according to the reports from various distances, North, South, and West, (we have heard nothing yet from ships, East, at sea,) that the globe of fire with the glowing trail of light must have been from thirty to forty miles above the surface of our planet. That it could not have been much more elevated, the explosion which accompanied its disappearance would assure us, the atmosphere being rather less than fifty miles high, and the transmission of sound being of course limited to that region. It was seen at Philadelphia at about 9 1/2 o'clock, say the papers of that city -- rose suddenly from the horizon, about the size of the full moon, traversed an easterly line, dropping fire in its course, like a rocket, till it passed away in the southeast, like a red ball, about twice the size of the planet Mars. It was seen, under similar circumstances, at Danville, Penn., at New-Haven, along the whole line of the Hudson River, at Buffalo, Utica, Albany and Troy, also at Newport, Rhode Island, and undoubtedly at other places from which we have no report -- at each place, appearing to be at no great distance above the spires of the churches. Just so the moon, at her full, appears to shine directly over every street in every city, and over every ship at sea, in those portions of the earth which she illuminates.

abstract: Gen. A.B. NORTON, one of the delegates from Texas to the Baltimore Constitutional Union Convention, in a speech delivered at Austin on the 7th, explains the position which he and his friends occupy as regards Messrs. BELL and EVERETT. He said: "In the Baltimore Union meeting no certificates were asked for, and no pledges were given or required. Upon consultation, a majority of those present chose JOHN BELL as their leader, as they had a perfect right to do. We then and there avowed, that so far as we were concerned in Texas, we would continue the fight for the man of our choice, the old battle-scarred hero of San Jacinto, and not a man in that assemblage was expected or considered as pledged to pursue any other course than we are now pursuing, and I am proud to say, that the men who expressed themselves for JOHN BELL in that body, are chivalrous enough to allow the friends of Gen. HOUSTON, freedom of choice and action in the coming election, and they would rejoice in the triumph of HOUSTON, as we would in that of BELL, or any other national man over LINCOLN. In evidence of this, it may be stated, that scarcely a single press supporting JOHN BELL finds fault with the Union men of Texas for supporting Gen. HOUSTON, but on the contrary, all the clamor has been raised in regard to our action by these bolters from Charleston, HOUSTON's and BELL's bitter enemies.

abstract: ATTEMPTS AT SELF-DESTRUCTION. -- MARY LOCK-WOOD, a young married woman, residing at No. 85 Spring-street, attempted to make away with herself yesterday morning by jumping into the river at James'-slip. A colored man witnessed the occurrence and succeeded in rescuing her; but the immediately repeated the attempt. A second time she was fished out of the water, and having been taken before Justice KELLY, he temporarily committed her to the care of the matron of the City prison. She stated that her husband had recently deserted her, and consequently she had no desire to live�. ALDEN POWERS, a sea-captain, about 55 years of age, who has recently returned from a voyage, while intoxicated on Friday night, swallowed a quantity of laudanum for the purpose of suicide. Having been removed to the New York Hospital, an antidote was administered -- and he will probably survive the effects of the dose. The attempt was made upon his life at the Pearl-street hotel, where he was boarding at the time with his family.

abstract: The above match was played on the St. George's ground, Hoboken, on Saturday, and although a one-sided affair, it was one of the most interesting matches of the season, inasmuch as it was got up by the older members of the Club, to encourage the spirit of Cricket in the junior members. Several of the most promising junior cricketers were in the country, but as it was, they gave a Waterloo defeat to the Second Eleven, who were assisted by Brett, the Juniors having the assistance of Messrs. Bailey and H. Wright. There were a large number of spectators to see the match. The fielding of the Juniors was especially sharp, and the fast round-arm bowling of Geo. Wright, son of Mr. Sam�l Wright, (the veteran,) a boy of 14 years of age, was very destructive to the old cricketers� wickets. Williamson and Robinson also bowled well, the latter long-stopping finely, and both of them making an admirable display of batting. Stevens, who is also quite a boy, played with great judgment; but, like several others, was unfortunately run out. As a matter of course, Bailey and H. Wright played well for their large scores. The Second Eleven played with considerable spirit in the first innings for 79, of which Messrs. Trenor, Russell, Gillett, Hobbs and Salomans contributed well played-for scores. The whole affair was conceived and carried out in the best spirit, for the gratifidation of the Juniors, who are highly elated at their victory. The cricketers and their friends sat down to a substantial dinner in the Club House, which was served up by Mr. H. Wright in excellent style; after which play was resumed, and the Second Eleven disposed of for nineteen runs. The following is the score:

abstract: We hope that Congress, when it meets again, will devote a little of its time to the re-arrangement of the Federal Judicial system. If other districts need legislation as much as our own does, it will be time well spent. As will be recollected, the Federal Courts are composed of the Supreme Court, the Circuit Courts, and the District Courts. Each Judge of the Supreme Court is Circuit Judge, and when not sitting in the Supreme Court at Washington, is expected to hold Circuit Courts in his Circuit. The Circuit Courts have jurisdiction in appeals from the District Courts, and they have also a large original jurisdiction. Patent suits, copyright suits, actions between citizens of different States, &c., are brought in the Circuit Courts. And therefore, as there were times when the Circuit Judges could not be in their respective Circuits, and when this class of business would still need attention, the District Judges were in such cases authorized to hold the Circuit Courts for the transaction of all business which did not come up from the District Courts.
lead_paragraph: We hope that Congress, when it meets again, will devote a little of its time to the re-arrangement of the Federal Judicial system. If other districts need legislation as much as our own does, it will be time well spent. As will be recollected, the Federal Courts are composed of the Supreme Court, the Circuit Courts, and the District Courts. Each Judge of the Supreme Court is Circuit Judge, and when not sitting in the Supreme Court at Washington, is expected to hold Circuit Courts in his Circuit. The Circuit Courts have jurisdiction in appeals from the District Courts, and they have also a large original jurisdiction. Patent suits, copyright suits, actions between citizens of different States, &c., are brought in the Circuit Courts. And therefore, as there were times when the Circuit Judges could not be in their respective Circuits, and when this class of business would still need attention, the District Judges were in such cases authorized to hold the Circuit Courts for the transaction of all business which did not come up from the District Courts.

abstract: A truck, containing $300 of wearing apparel, the property of Mr. Haliburton Fales, of No.103 Waverly-place, was stolen on Saturday afternoon from an express wagon at the Hudson -- River Railroad depot in Chambers-street. John Ryan, a resident of the Five Points, whose frequent violations of the eighth commandment has made him an extensive acquaintance with the Police, was observed by Officer Hooper, crossing the Park with the trunk upon his shoulder. He arrested him on suspicion of having stolen it and subsequently it was claimed by Mr. Fales. Justice KELLY committed the prisoner for trial� Henry Noel, a Frenchman, stopping at the Commercial Hotel, Cortlandt-street, disbursed $20 on Saturday in the purchase of a plethoric wallet, which he thought was filled with bank-bills. His speculation was a poor one, however, as its contents consisted of pieces of newspapers, and he reluctantly came to the conclusion that he had been swindled. He told his grievances to Officer Williams, of the Railroad Squad, who informed him that he had been victimized by a West-street pocket book stuffer, and subsequently the policeman apprehended one Robert Neill, whom the Frenchman identified as one of the parties who had played tricks upon him. Neill was held to answer�. Bridget Asten, a young Irish girl, was arrested yesterday, by Officer SHEEHAN, of the Sixth Precinct, on a charge of having stolen a $50 bill from Delia Van Hall, her friend and room-mate. Delia and Bridget resided at No. 39 Elm-street, and slept together on Saturday night. Bridget had disappeared with the darkness, and Delia awoke to mourn her absence and the loss of the money. Justice KELLY would not believe the prisoners statement that she was innocent and consigned her to prison.

abstract: ROLL, the master of the negro boy whose sudden disappearance created so much excitement in Newark, New-Jersey, a few days ago, has offered $100 reward for the recovery of the fugitive. The Advertiser says: "We learn that the slave boy has an uncle in Brooklyn, and it is supposed that his relative concocted the plan for freeing him. It has been ascertained that some blacks in this city went to a Justice in this City on Saturday and asked his opinion concerning a plot to free the boy. Mr. ROLL was warned, but the plot was carried into effect. If the boy should be found in Brooklyn, it is doubtful if he would be surrendered, as the decision in the Lemmon Slave case might be held to cover his right to freedom -- Mr. ROLL having landed in New-York State on his passage to this City. Should he be found in New-Jersey he could be recovered under the State laws, as well as the Fugitive Slave law of Congress -- the former permitting visitors to bring a reasonable number of enslaved domestics into the State for a temporary period. Mr. ROLL is satisfied that no white person is complicated in the escape. It is stated that the boy recently stole some money from his master, and fear of punishment, or sale on his return may have influenced his action.
lead_paragraph: ROLL, the master of the negro boy whose sudden disappearance created so much excitement in Newark, New-Jersey, a few days ago, has offered $100 reward for the recovery of the fugitive. Mr. ROLL was warned, but the plot was carried into effect. abstract: Congress, which is still in session, is discussing the project of Mr. THOS. F. M???AGH???R, of New-York, for the construction of a railroad from Boca del Toro to Punta Mala. It is strongly opposed, on the ground that the territory over which the road is proposed to be built belongs to New-Granada, or at least is claimed by her, and that, therefore, Costa Rica has no right to grant priviliges to Mr. M. or anybody else in a territory over which it has no jurisdiction.

abstract: His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales is to drop all royal state on entering the American Republic. In the British Colonies it will, however, be preserved, and will doubtless prove irksome enough, both to him and to those about him. Col. BRUCE is understood to have strict orders to see that he is treated like Her Majesty the Queen in all respects, and Col. BRUCE is not the man to disobey orders.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC, Wednesday, July 18, 1860.

abstract: FELLOW SOLDIERS: Seated on my native soil, and amid the graves of my ancestors, I am penning this open letter for the great Southern public, as well as for you. I am here, amid the scenes of boyhood's days, urging Virginians to take the lead of the Southern States in carrying forward to successful accomplishment the object of the K.G.C., the speedy Americanization of Mexico, by and through the instrumentalities of an organization which has not only ???ked together the good people of the Southern States, but which has equally harmonized the really worthy and most advanced people of Mexico -- who feel and acknowledge that their destiny is chained to our own by every honorable interest, and by natural circumstances, over which man can exercise no control. But I fear that the people whom I love, and to whom I belong, have ceased to feel it a duty to lead, when the rights of the South are in question, or when other States are equally interested. This does not arise from any want of individual patriotism, but from some unseen cause, which, I am disposed to think, may be traced to the peculiar distribution of political sentiment through, the State, and by which a sectional jealousy has been generated that renders caution so necessary, that our people have lost much of that impulsive ardor which distinguished them in former days. I have at least done my duty to her, and it only remains to give to our brothers in her midst opportunities to win names and positions, which may at last be proudly acknowledged by the people of Virginia, as well as of the whole South. Yet Virginia will give us two thousand men and some money.

I have at least done my duty to her, and it only remains to give to our brothers in her midst opportunities to win names and positions, which may at last be proudly acknowledged by the people of Virginia, as well as of the whole South. abstract: Savannah and New-York joined hands on Saturday in the persons of their military representatives -- the Savannah Republican Blues and the New-York City Guard. Fraternally, convivially and martially they spent the day in visiting "the Institutions." Their strategy was developed in pacification, their artillery practice, in the firing of welcome salutes. They made "war to the knife," -- with the butter knife and the fruit knife; they charged freely -- not upon each other -- but upon sundry stores of provisions; their cannonade consisted mainly of the popping of corks; and the smoke of the battle arose from thousands of "best Havanas."
lead_paragraph: Savannah and New-York joined hands on Saturday in the persons of their military representatives -- the Savannah Republican Blues and the New-York City Guard. abstract: There is a white spot in our school maps, at the point which marks the centre of Arabia. But for the exertions of two Frenchmen, this spot might have remained marked with white, instead of black. As it is, letters must be inserted in the ...
lead_paragraph: There is a white spot in our school maps, at the point which marks the centre of Arabia. But for the exertions of two Frenchmen, this spot might have remained marked with white, instead of black. As it is, letters must be inserted in the new maps, and foot-notes will tell how two white men explored the unknown territory; how one relinquished his task, leaving it but half done, through sheer exhaustion of body and inability to endure further suffering; and how a more adventurous countryman of his took up the thread where it was dropped, and unraveled the mystery which his predecessor vainly strove to solve. The first of these adventurous men was the Frenchman ARNAUD, who traveled under the assumed name of Hakim-Yusuf, (Doctor Joseph;) the second was DU COURET, a Colonel in the French service, who came to be known as Hadji-Abd'el-Hamed-Bey. Both ARNAUD and DU COURET essayed to explore the mysteries of Central Arabia, but the former fell fainting by the way, having pushed so far only as the City of Mareb; while the latter penetrated to the Indian Ocean, and, making his way safely back to France, sat down to write his story of travel and adventure. A reduction of the French narrative of Les Mysteres du Desert into the prosaic English dress which brings the tale before us, under the unpretending title of Life in he Desert,* sets forth a curious array of Asiatic pictures. The novelty of the incidents, the freshness of the style, and the newness of the field explored, lend a peculiar charm to this story. It is, perhaps, well enough to remember at the outset of our reading that a French traveler is nothing if not a romancer; that the national characteristic is a tendency to exaggeration; and that grains of salt must be freely sprinkled over the dainty meats here provided for our table. Admitting these propositions as truths, and making all due allowance therefor, we get down into the marrow of this history of exploration, and, having blown away all extraneous matter, discover in it a great many things of sterling value.

abstract: HARDEN's CONFESSION. -- The confession of HARDEN will be published this week. The writer commences with his childhood, and goes on to give a description of his life until he began to teach school at or near Blairstown -- his manner of life while teaching -- his appointment as colporteur -- his license to preach -- describes the people among whom he was thrown, and the influences surrounding him -- tells of his success as a preacher -- gives a sketch of his first acquaintance with the DORLAND family -- describes his courtship and marriage -- tells how, where and why he poisoned his wife -- gives his flight, travels, arrest, &c. A number of essays of his own, and letters to friends while he was in prison, will be published with the confession, and the whole will make a work of from fifty to seventy-five pages. HARDEN's father, who will publish the work, has employed a few general agents for its sale. -- Trenton Gazette.

abstract: William Hare vs. The Steamship Victoria. -- This was an action on a bill of lading to recover the value of a quantity of fish, alleged to have been shipped on board the vessel in Haltfax, to be carried to New-York, and not to have been delivered according to the bill of lading. The owner of the vessel alleged that the master of the vessel, named Sluyter, bought the fish outright of one Allison. the assignor to the libelant of the bill of lading, and gave him in payment therefor a draft on his brother in New-York for the amount, and that as security only for this draft the bill of lading in question was given. Allison transferred the draft for value, with the bill of lading, to the libelant; and he wrote to the agent here that he knew nothing of the parties, and that if the draft was not paid he must hold the fish under the bill of lading. This letter was sent by the steamship, but was not delivered for several days after the arrival of the vessel, during which time the master discharged the fish, sold them as his own and pocketed the proceeds. The draft was not paid on presentation and the libelant thereupon called upon the vessel for the fish, and not getting it brought this action, claiming that Allison shipped the goods, and there was to be no delivery of the property to the master unless the draft was paid. The owner claimed that the vessel was not liable, as it was not a shipment of the goods by Allison, but a sale and purchase by the master.

abstract: FREDERICK HOFFMAN, the alleged defaulter, Judge LEONARD has established a claim to public approval. Justice CONNOLLY, it will be remembered, after listening to the affidavits of the officers of the Pacific Steamship Company, thought proper to fix the security necessary to the prisoner's temporary release at the handsome sum of $22,000.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICK HOFFMAN, the alleged defaulter, Judge LEONARD has established a claim to public approval. Justice CONNOLLY, it will be remembered, after listening to the affidavits of the officers of the Pacific Steamship Company, thought proper to fix the security necessary to the prisoner's temporary release at the handsome sum of $22,000. If the recognizance was designed to cover the losses suffered by the Corporation, or to bear any proportion to them, it is needless to say that five times that amount would have been inadequate. Such, however, could not have been the view of the committing magistrate; and in any other, never was bail more excessive. The family of the prisoner is represented as not in affluent circumstances; and former friends of men subjected to charges so overwhelming are not apt to rush forward with eagerness to their relief. Measured by the means within the prisoner's reach, directly or indirectly, the sum was merely absurd, and calculated to insure his incarceration through the long Summer. Moreover, the ill health of the captive is such that there is little likelihood of his renewing an attempt at flight; while it is at the same time so precarious that close and solitary confinement would probably act as fatally as a death-sentence. In these circumstances the sum required assumed a penal character; and but for the assumption which charity compels in favor of the Justice, it might be imagined he was rather yielding to a desire to gratify a supposed spirit of persecution on the part of the informers, than to satisfy the ends of public justice. It is reasonable, however, to acquit Justice CONNOLLY of so harsh an interpretation of what was doubtless a simple misapprehension of the spirit of the law.

abstract: A great sale of pictures has just taken place in London, in circumstances and with results which suggest some curious reflections on the social aspects of the Fine Arts. The collection exposed for sale comprised twenty-one works, the flower of a choice and famous gallery, known in England as the "Belvedere," originally collected by that most generous of Israelites, SAMPSON GIDEON, and now the property of his representative, the most evangelical of bankers, Sir CULLING EARDLEY. Why Sir CULLING EARDLEY should have stripped his treasury of its chief treasures is no affair of ours. But some of our readers may remember that less than a year ago, Mr. EARDLEY, the eldest son of the Low Church, financier, after being handed over by his father to the tender mercies of the Insolvent Court for contracting debts to the amount of $80,000 for photographs and photographic apparatus at Oxford, abruptly put an end to his collegiate career by running away to New-York, and marrying an American belle. So costly a love of the beautiful may have led the parental victim to the resolution of emptying his house of the gorgeous master-pieces, which had developed it in the bosom of his first-born, before the rest of his children should succumb to the same seductive influences. Be this as it may, we trust that no American amateur will allow himself to be deterred by a prospective fear of finding himself beset with filial daguerreotypes and foreign daughters-in-law, from prosecuting the work which has been of late begun so much in earnest among us; of naturalizing the arts in our American homes.

The collection exposed for sale comprised twenty-one works, the flower of a choice and famous gallery, known in England as the "Belvedere," originally collected by that most generous of Israelites, SAMPSON GIDEON, and now the property of his representative, the most evangelical of bankers, Sir CULLING EARDLEY. But some of our readers may remember that less than a year ago, Mr. EARDLEY, the eldest son of the Low Church, financier, after being handed over by his father to the tender mercies of the Insolvent Court for contracting debts to the amount of $80,000 for photographs and photographic apparatus at Oxford, abruptly put an end to his collegiate career by running away to New-York, and marrying an American belle. So costly a love of the beautiful may have led the parental victim to the resolution of emptying his house of the gorgeous master-pieces, which had developed it in the bosom of his first-born, before the rest of his children should succumb to the same seductive influences. Be this as it may, we trust that no American amateur will allow himself to be deterred by a prospective fear of finding himself beset with filial daguerreotypes and foreign daughters-in-law, from prosecuting the work which has been of late begun so much in earnest among us; of naturalizing the arts in our American homes.

abstract: -- Mr. YANCEY's letter to Mr. SLAUGHTER, in which he revealed his plan of plunging the cotton States suddenly into rebellion, excites considerable attention at the South. It does not command that general assent which seems indispensable to the success of the scheme thus prematurely disclosed; and Mr. Y. and his friends vent a great deal of virtuous indignation upon Mr. SLAUGHTER for having published what they declare was a private letter. Mr. S. defends himself from this imputation in a letter which we publish elsewhere. Mr. YANCEY's correspondent is not inclined to permit him just yet to "wade through SLAUGHTER to a throne."

abstract: From an parts of the country, as far as our exchange papers have had time to reach, us, we receive accounts of the great meteor of Friday last, seen about the same time that it was visible in this City, and presenting the same appearances. It is amusing to notice how persistently the spectators, hundreds of miles apart, agree that the marvelous visitor was only a short cistance above them. The only diversity in their respective descriptions, is that in some places an explosion was heard, while in others it was inaudible. From present accounts, we should judge it to have been from forty to forty-five miles high. We append some remarks from the Albany Journal of last evening:

abstract: The life of LESLIE was more than the life of a simple artist. It was rather the life of the cultured and generous citizen of the world than that of a man whose art selfishly subordinated all things to itself, or drove him from the society of men into the solitude of his cell, with no companions but his thoughts, his pencil, and his palette. Endowed with marvelously quick perception, an organization of exquisite delicacy, and the most natural and healthy of mental developments, he saw the world as it was, not as he would have it; accept

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN. -- On Saturday, owing to the uncertain state of the weather, not more than seven thousand people visited the mammoth ship and those who did so were mostly excursionists from neighboring counties of this State, with some few parties from New-Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Owing to the wind the awning had to be removed from the deck, but the visitors were more than repaid for the want of shelter by the delicious, cooling breeze which swept up from the river, strided the bulwarks and the wheel-house, and blew things around generally. On Sunday, Rev. C. DENISON preached to the officers and crew of the ship in the first dining saloon. His text was the 60th chapter of Isaiah, verse 5th: "The abundance of the sea shall be converted into thee." During the sermon, a fireman, named JOHN GRANT, who was intoxicated, made a disturbance, which resulted in his being handed over to an officer of the Ninth Ward Police, by whom he was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Jefferson Market Court, and locked up for the night. He left his cell yesterday morning a sober and perhaps a wiser man. On the dock, fronting the huge length of the ship, extemporized preaching was attempted by several parties, with partial success. Lager bier was consumed in vast quantities, but stronger liquors were only procurable by stealth. During the day, no visitors being admitted on board, the crowd outside who contented themselves with an external view must have numbered several thousands. Yesterday, notwithstanding the heavy rain in the forenoon, five thousand visited the ship. Arrangements have been made to bring large parties from the country this week, so that if the weather is at all favorable her decks, cabins, saloons and engine houses will be crowded every day. To add to her great attractions, DODWORTH's entire band will give afternoon concerts, and an evening cotillion party is, we are told, on the tepis, but we are doubtful of that event, and think it will never take place on the deck.

abstract: ITEMS -- Judge LOTT, of the Supreme Court, yesterday granted a motion to carry up the proceedings in the matter of Third-street widening before the Country Court on certiorari for review�. Judge LOTT also decided against giving PETER DAWSON, Ex-King of the Fourth Ward, New-York, a new trial�. A little son of JOHN ESER, of No. 19 Moore-street, Eastern District, was found drowned in a cistern, yesterterday, near his father's residence. The boy was missed last week, and it was supposed he had strayed away�. Capt. SPRAGUE, of this city, is organizing a Zouave Corps -- WM MCGRATH, a boy seven years old, had one of his feet badly crushed, yesterday, at the corner of Atlantic and Flatbush avenues, under a Railroad car. Three toes were subsequently amputated�. MICHAEL BRUCK, a boy thirteen years old, was almost instantly killed, on Saturday, in Front-street, by being run over by a coal cart. He was thrown from the cart�. A burglar entered the house of Mr. WATTLES, No. 85 Sands street, and was making a selection of articles to carry off, when his presence was discovered, and he was frightened away by the inmates of the house�. Mrs. SEENO, residing at the corner of Moore and Morrell streets, died in a fit on Sunday last�. A meeting of the friends of BELL and EVERETT was held last evening, in Granada Hall, J.R. BURTON presiding. A report of the action of the late State Convention was submitted, and a resolution was adopted, requesting the "Union" electors to meet in the several Wards and towns of the county on the 3d day of August, and select five delegates from each Ward and town, to represent the party in General Committee. Said delegates to assemble at the Globe Hotel on the 8th day of August. Twenty-five persons attended this meeting�. During the last year the Bridge-street Primitive Methodist Church has succeeded in removing all incumbrance from their property.

A burglar entered the house of Mr. WATTLES, No. 85 Sands street, and was making a selection of articles to carry off, when his presence was discovered, and he was frightened away by the inmates of the house�. Mrs. SEENO, residing at the corner of Moore and Morrell streets, died in a fit on Sunday last�. A meeting of the friends of BELL and EVERETT was held last evening, in Granada Hall, J.R. BURTON presiding. A report of the action of the late State Convention was submitted, and a resolution was adopted, requesting the "Union" electors to meet in the several Wards and towns of the county on the 3d day of August, and select five delegates from each Ward and town, to represent the party in General Committee. Said delegates to assemble at the Globe Hotel on the 8th day of August. Twenty-five persons attended this meeting�. During the last year the Bridge-street Primitive Methodist Church has succeeded in removing all incumbrance from their property.

abstract: The Atlantic and Harpers' for August are out; the former containing its customary variety, and the latter exceeding its average degree of excellence. The leading article of the Atlantic, "The Carnival of the Romantic," is a well-digested and suggestive review of the art of novel-writing. This is followed by "A Legend of Maryland," Eleusinia," ...
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic and Harpers' for August are out; the former containing its customary variety, and the latter exceeding its average degree of excellence. The leading article of the Atlantic, "The Carnival of the Romantic," is a well-digested and suggestive review of the art of novel-writing. This is followed by "A Legend of Maryland," Eleusinia," "Victor and Jacqueline," and sundry light essays, with the opening chapter of "A Journey in Sicily," and the continuation of "The Professor's Story." The poems of the number are: "Prince Adeb," "Midsummer," "The Poet's Singing," and "Anno Domini, 1860." An elaborate defence of "Tobacco," evidently the handiwork of some ardent lover of the weed, oversets King JAMES' "Counterblast," and utterly scouts the theories of Dr. ALCOTT. The apologist will shock a great many persons by his complete disregard of the dicta of accepted authorities. The reviews and literary notices are, as usual, judicious and able.

abstract: The New-Orleans Postmaster has followed the example of Mr. FOWLER, but has contented himself with the sum of $50,000 of Government money, and was good enough to leave behind a large amount of postage stamps. This tenderness with regard to the postage, stamps proves clearly he was not as bad a man as he might have been, and that if he could have got as much money as he wanted in other ways, he would probably never have touched a dollar of the post-office funds. The case is, therefore, one which undoubtedly deserves public sympathy, and we trust all those persons who are in the habit of weeping over defaulters will shed a few tears on this interesting occasion. To confine oneself to the abstraction of $50,000, when $100,000 might have been appropropriated just as easily, is proof of considerable soundness of character, and reveals a most affecting adherence to the lessons of early childhood.

abstract: that the crops of the South have received serious injury within the last month. Not for years has so long and so severe a drouth been experienced in the Southern States. In some sections no rain of any consequence has fallen since the 1st of April. This is especially true of Texas, certain Parishes in this State, and Middle Georgia, in which latter section, according to a writer in a Georgia paper, more rain has been known to fall in twenty-four hours than has been had there since the 1st of January. These, it may be said, are exceptional cases. True, but there is now but little difference in the condition of the crops in most of the cotton States. Our accounts from various districts of Georgia, Alabama, Florida, Mississippi, Arkansas, Texas and our own State, are, to say the least, discouraging. Crops in these States have been not only oppressed by a drouth unprecedented in its duration, but within the last month they have had to struggle for existence in the face of a sun of almost torrid brilliance and power, dewless nights, and the prevalence (in some districts) of high scorching winds, which shriveled up vegetation as if a sirocco had passed over it. The consequence of such weather in obvious. -- N.O. Com. Bulletin, 18th,

abstract: The extraordinary analogy in the actual condition of Turkey and Mexico is rendered all the more striking by the simultaneous intervention of the French Emperor in the affairs of both. At the very moment his representative announces at Washington the design of his master to restore order in the Spanish-American Republic, we gather from European advices that the Porte has been advised of the imperial resolve to suppress the insurrection in Syria, which is threatening to sweep the entire Christian population, numbering hundreds of thousands, from the Asiatic provinces of Turkey. Turning from the suggestive spectacle of a monarch whose arms and diplomacy have laid Europe at his feet, thus assuming the attitude of arbiter of two hemispheres, it may be worth while to glance at the parallel we have alluded to, and improve the moral.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary analogy in the actual condition of Turkey and Mexico is rendered all the more striking by the simultaneous intervention of the French Emperor in the affairs of both. Turning from the suggestive spectacle of a monarch whose arms and diplomacy have laid Europe at his feet, thus assuming the attitude of arbiter of two hemispheres, it may be worth while to glance at the parallel we have alluded to, and improve the moral.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Coroner JACKMAN investigated the circumstances attending the death of THOMAS J. BUTLER, a laboring man, who died on Sunday morning at his residence No. 648 Second-avenue. Up to Friday last deceased had worked in a stone quarry at Weehawken, N.J., and on that day he engaged in a fight with JOHN WARNER, a fellow laborer. Soon afterwards be became ill, and when he died WARNER was arrested on the suspicion that his death had resulted from injuries inflicted during the encounter. The post-mortem examination, however, demonstrated that congestion of the brain, superinduced by the heat was the cause of death, and consequently WARNER was discharged from custody.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner JACKMAN investigated the circumstances attending the death of THOMAS J. abstract: CAREW was called upon yesterday (July 20) to hold an inquest upon the body of a man named GOCH, who had committed suicide by taking a quantity of hydrocyanic acid. The body was found yesterday morning, lying on the side of the Lebanon Turnpike, a short distance from Arondale, and by its side a wineglass and a bottle partially filled with deadly poison. From sundry papers found in the pockets of the deceased, it is supposed that he was a physician, but being a stranger in the City, without friends, and without the immediate means to gain a livelihood, he chose rather to die than live a life of comparative want. He was apparently about 75 years of age, and was probably a former resident of New-York City. A letter recommending him as a competent physician, from a Mr. GRAHAM, of New-York, was among the papers found in the pockets of GOCH, and establishing the supposition of his once having lived in that City. Further than these facts, nothing of his history or to whom he was related could be learned. -- Cincinnati Gazette.

abstract: I am assured that GARIBALDI's Envoy to Paris was received by the Emperor to-day at St. Cloud as a private individual -- the diplomatic phrase is "in an officious character." Prince GIUSEPPE will probably by this time have arrived in London on a mission from the patriotic General, and Count CAVOUR has just sent the eminent ex-deputy, M. VALERIO, to Sicily. GARIBALDI, therefore, is at this moment playing a great part on the diplomatic stage.
