abstract: Hon. T.G. DAVIDSON, Member of Congress from Louisiana, has been making a fierce onslaught on DOUGLAS and SOULE at Baton Rouge. He declared that, after searching the political record thoroughly, he could find no single act of Mr. DOUGLAS which was friendly to the South, but plenty of acts and words which indicated Free Soil tendencies; and in respect to Mr. SOULE, he contended that his position in the Compromise discussion of 1850 was the reverse of that which he now occupies. Having thus demolished DOUGLAS, SOULE & Co., Mr. DAVIDSON concluded with a labored panegyric upon BRECKINRIDGE and LANE.

abstract: The advices from Mexico which we publish this morning are highly important, and confirm fully the reports which have reached us by telegraph relative to the progress of the Liberals. Our dates from the City of Mexico are to June 29, when the general impression was that the Liberals would be in possession of the capital in less than two months. Indeed, it was more than suspected that the garrison was all ready to pronounce in favor of JUAREZ. One regiment, which had been sent against a small force of the Liberals at San Augustin, had deserted the Church Party on the road. MIRAMON had been repeatedly defeated near Guadalajara, and his army was totally disorganized. At last accounts he was endeavoring to reach, the capital, where his prestige had become greatly damaged through his reverses. Another forced loan had been collected in the city, together with a "contribution" of one per cent. on capital. The English merchants had addressed Mr. MATTHEWS, the British Minister, on the subject, but he, having broken off all relation with the Government, could do nothing for them. They paid the money under protest. The Americans, of course, could not help themselves, as the party in power there fully understand the unprotected position in which they are placed by the refusal of our Government to interfere in their behalf. Meantime a new source of trouble has appeared in Southern Mexico. Advices received in Washington from Vera Cruz report that the State of Chiapas had been invaded by a party of fillibusters from Guatamala, who burned several haciendas, and carried off a large amount of booty.

abstract: By the mail steam which left Marseilles yesterday, M. THOUVENEL sent instructions to the Marquis DE LAVALETTE, directing him to inform the Porte that France, from feelings of humanity, as well as in consequence of former conventions concluded with Turkey, is bound to put a stop to the horrible massacres of the Christians in Syria. The Turkish authorities not being capable of protecting the Sultan's own subjects, France will concert with the other Powers the most efficacious means for preventing the bloody scenes of which Syria has become the theatre.
lead_paragraph: By the mail steam which left Marseilles yesterday, M. abstract: PATERSON, herdsman and steward of Hon. A.B. CONGER at Waldberg, near Haverstraw, N.Y., was consumed by fire, and five lives were lost. Beside Mr. PATERSON and his family, there were several other inmates in the house, farm hands, who boarded with him, making in all fifteen persons. THOS. LONG, assistant herdsman, first discovering the fire, gave the alarm by loud cries, and rushed into the several rooms to arouse and save the sleeping inmates. The fire had, however, gained such head way as to render his efforts in some cases unavailing, and not only were four others burned in their chambers, but he, too, fell a victim while in the discharge of his noble, self-imposed duty. JOHN BLACKHUEST was one of the men burned, but the names of the others are unknown. The total loss is $18,000. The origin of the fire is unknown.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, herdsman and steward of Hon. A.B. CONGER at Waldberg, near Haverstraw, N.Y., was consumed by fire, and five lives were lost. LONG, assistant herdsman, first discovering the fire, gave the alarm by loud cries, and rushed into the several rooms to arouse and save the sleeping inmates. The fire had, however, gained such head way as to render his efforts in some cases unavailing, and not only were four others burned in their chambers, but he, too, fell a victim while in the discharge of his noble, self-imposed duty. JOHN BLACKHUEST was one of the men burned, but the names of the others are unknown. The total loss is $18,000. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: Col. KEITT, of South Carolina, is out in favor of secession. He has written a long letter to some political friends, insisting upon the necessity of leaving the Union. He concedes the certainty of a Republican victory. He acknowledges fully and frankly that the Democracy is utterly demoralized and broken, -- that the South can no longer rely upon it, -- and that, unless all political symptoms are deceptive and false, Mr. LINCOLN is to be our next President. Under these circumstances he thinks the South can do nothing else but secede. Honor requires it, -- as well as safety and self-respect. He scorns the notion of waiting for any "overt act." Such a course would be unworthy a free and gallant people. The mere fact of a Republican triumph would be sufficient ground for secession, and would justify every Southern State, in the eyes of the world, in withdrawing instantly from the Confederacy. He urges, therefore, a Union of the Southern States, -- but declares that, if this cannot be had, he will counsel South Carolina "alone, if necessary, and at all hazards to secede."

abstract: ferent grace. The Toronto Leader says: ï¿½We are again to be disappointed. At least we fear we are. abstract: says the Newark Advertiser, is a very unsatisfactory production, adding scarcely anything to our knowledge of the criminal and his career beyond the facts developed on the trial and subsequently made public. The only new matter is some correspondence between HARDEN and his family, after his conviction. The confession contains none of those disgusting revelations which were anticipated, and is a more record of HARDEN's external life. Concerning his connection with Miss DORLAND -- his wife afterwards -- the impression sought to be created is that the engagement and marriage were thrust on him by his mother-in-law. The poisoning of his wife is openly confessed, but occupies only a little over a page, and merely confirms what has heretofore been published. He administered arsenic to her on on apple, saying it was a powder to prevent pregnancy. Several times afterwards he gave it to her. Little is said concerning HARDEN's feelings, except that after the murder he was haunted by fear and remorse.

abstract: The Philadelphia house of LIPPINCOTT & Co. announces for publication on the 25th inst. the Occasional Productions of the late Richard Rush. This work comprises a series of papers, many of which have never before been published, written by Mr. RUSH during his residence in Paris as American Minister. The leading political and diplomatic writings refer chiefly to the Court and Government of LOUIS PHILIPPE and the Revolution of 1848. The publication is made under the direction of the executors of Mr. RUSH.

abstract: Isaac L. Taylor, a young lawyer having an once at No. 84 Nassau-street, was required, yesterday, by Justice BHENNAN, to find a surety in the sum of $500 for his appearance to answer a charge of embezzlement. The complainant, Mr. Richard T. Deming, also a counselor at law; and acting as notary for the Artisans' Bank, alleged that on the 31 inst. he employed the accused to collect two promissory notes -- one for $250 and the other for $301 44 -- and return the proceeds by 10 o'clock on the morning of the 5th. An hour or two after the appointed time Taylor called upon Deming and informed him that both notes had been protested and he had left them at his residence, No. 18 Barrow-street, but that he would immediately go and bring them down. He failed to fulfill his promise, and it was not until the 7th, at a late hour in the afternoon, that Mr. Deming again found him, not withstanding the fact that he had persistently sought him, as he had learned in the interval that the note for the larger amount had been collected by the accused from Mr. Zeno Burnham, its maker. At this interview Taylor first stated that he had both notes in his pocket, but after some hesitation, admitted that he had collected one of them, and handed Mr. Deming $235 of the amount, retaining the balance of $66 44, which he is charged with having embezzled. The complaint was not made against the accused until the 14th inst, when a warrant was issued for his arrest. Yesterday he was taken into custody, and he asserts that he is not guilty of the charge.

abstract: Frederick Hodges, second mate of ship Ellen Austin, was arrested upon a warrant issued by United States Commissioner Stilwell, charged with cruel and unusual punishment of a seaman named Henry Jones. Upon the examination Jones testified that one occasion, while he with several other shipmates was aloft reefing topsails, one of them made a remark which caused him to laugh. This was interpreted by the second mate as a laugh at him, and when the men came down, while the others were sent forward, he; Jones, was taken into the cabin. He was seized by the first mate, James Kennedy, who bent his body forward and held his head between his knees. While in this posture, Hodges pulled up Jones' shirt and beat beat him on the bare back with ratline stuff, in one end of which was the usual eyesplice. His back was badly cut and bruised, and retains the black marks to this day. Shortly afterwards Hodges met him on the deck, when he knocked him down with his fist, and while he was lying helpless on deck, kicked him in the face with his sea boots until Jones' eyes were both closed and his face covered with blood. Two other men swore to the truth of Jones' statement. Hodges said he had a witness who was sick in the hospital, and the Commissioner adjourned the case to give defendant time to find, his witness. Meantime, Hodges was committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Strange to say, there are hundreds if not thousands of persons, of both sexes, in New-York City who have never taken a walk through the Ramble in the Central Park. There can be only one reason for this, and that must be, that they are unacquainted with its varied beauty, its cool shade, labyrinthian walks, and flagrant flowers. There are numbers of ladies who have never visited the Park at all, they hear that it is not yet finished, and many of them think that it is a rude, rough spot, covered with workmen, broken stones and dirt, and they would rather wait until it is in better order. So they have never walked through the Ramble, and know little or no thing about it.

abstract: The lecture read by Mr. DOUGLAS on .Thursday, to the Mayor and some of the citizens of Charlestown, on the occasion of his visit to Bunker Hill, upon the manner in which they should behave whenever they leave their own State; was a very amusing piece of didactic oratory. He has staked so much on the Squatter Sovereignty doctrine, that he seems to be falling into a monomania about it, and drags it about the country with him with as much assiduity as if it were a change of linen or a toothbrush. He is haunted with anxiety about squatters and their rights. He seems to be constantly afraid that somebody is going to meddle with them. He suspects everybody he meets of some design against squatter dignity, and keeps warning the world, in season and out of season, that squatters must be let alone.

abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- An inquest was held on Sunday by Coroner GAFNEY, of Jersey City, on the body of a lad named JAMES PLATT, residing in Woye-street, who was drowned on Friday last, while bathing in the Erie Basin. A verdict of "accidental drowning" was renderedï¿½. About 9 o'clock yesterday morning the body of a man named WM. PETRIE was discovered floating in the water at the foot of Washington-street, Jersey City. The deceased was last seen on Saturday, near the place, and appeared to be intoxicated. As he was a man of very intemperate habits it is probable that he fall into the water in attempting to go on board a schooner which was lying near. Coroner GAFNEY empanneled a jury and a verdict of "found drowned" was rendered.

abstract: "We learn that the thermometer marked 10??? in several open houses of the city yesterday. One of our citizens who has kept a diary of the weather for thirty odd years, says that the present is the hottest Summer since 1828. We have not known the mercury to range as high as 98° but once before in Montgomery, and that was, we believe, in 1856. Similar accounts are given by newspapers published in nearly all the Southern States. From the seaboard to the Mississippi the thermometer ranged from 95° to 100° for several days last week. The New-Orleans Picayune says that the heat is almost unprecedented. In several cities the heat has been attended with unusual mortality -- deaths from sunstroke having been frequent. In Baltimore the highest point the mercury has attained in shaded locations, unaffected by the rays of the sun, is about 88° or 89°, though it has gone three or four degrees higher in the afternoon where the sun strikes the west side of buildings. The heat here, on account of a dry spell, lately, is indeed quite intense. The country is undergoing what may be called "the fiery term."

abstract: Five several attempts have now been made to obtain the release of Henrico Da Costa upon bail, before the United States Commissioners, each of the persons offering themselves as security having been rejected as incompetent, while the last, Wm. D. Haight, was yesterday arrested upon a warrant charging him with perjury, and was committed in default of $8,000 bonds, Mr. Haight who claimed to own two houses, one in Morton-street, and the other in Fourth-street, underwent a searching examination yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON, Mr. Wilcoxon conducting the case for the Government, and Mr. Donohue being counsel for Da Costa Copies of several papers were offered in evidence to prove that judgments and other liabilities against Haight had been discharged. One of these was a judgment of $129 60 against Charles Lent and Wm. D. Haight, satisfied and discharged March 9, 1858. Another of $737 40, of Jacob L. Dodge against Wm. D. Haight, which was satisfied Feb. 9, 1858; another, a receipt of J.E. Hewelling for $70, paid N. Mackey on Wm. D. Haight's bond, June 16, 1860.
lead_paragraph: Five several attempts have now been made to obtain the release of Henrico Da Costa upon bail, before the United States Commissioners, each of the persons offering themselves as security having been rejected as incompetent, while the last, Wm. D. Haight, was yesterday arrested upon a warrant charging him with perjury, and was committed in default of $8,000 bonds, Mr. Haight who claimed to own two houses, one in Morton-street, and the other in Fourth-street, underwent a searching examination yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON, Mr. Wilcoxon conducting the case for the Government, and Mr. Donohue being counsel for Da Costa Copies of several papers were offered in evidence to prove that judgments and other liabilities against Haight had been discharged. One of these was a judgment of $129 60 against Charles Lent and Wm. D. Haight, satisfied and discharged March 9, 1858. Another of $737 40, of Jacob L. Dodge against Wm. D. Haight, which was satisfied Feb. 9, 1858; another, a receipt of J.E. Hewelling for $70, paid N. Mackey on Wm. D. Haight's bond, June 16, 1860.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 9th inst., the Marquis of NORMANBY was anxious to correct the erroneous impressions which might have been created a few evenings since by the somewhat disparaging tone in which his noble and learned friend (Lord BROUGHAM) had spoken of certain correspondents from whom he had received information with respect to the acts of the Provisional Government at Florence.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 9th inst., the Marquis of NORMANBY was anxious to correct the erroneous impressions which might have been created a few evenings since by the somewhat disparaging tone in which his noble and learned friend (Lord BROUGHAM) had spoken of certain correspondents from whom he had received information with respect to the acts of the Provisional Government at Florence. Upon the information derived from those gentlemen he placed as full reliance as that which he would repose in statements coming from any member of that House, even from the noble and learned Lord himself. They stated that the Provisional Government, which had been much supported, and he might say nursed into existence, by the action of the noble Lord, the Secretary for Foreign Affairs, had violently gagged the Press, and would not allow a syllable to be circulated in opposition to its views. But now the Provisional Government was at an end, and as an immediate consequence a newspaper had been published by some of the most eminent men of liberal opinions in Florence, and had been in existence for the last six weeks. In that newspaper the statements made by his correspondents as to the misdeeds, the tyranny, and the duplicity of the Provisional Government had all been substantiated; and the agents of the Government, instead of attempting to deny the facts, had endeavored first to suppress the paper, and, failing in that, as a last resource they bought off the printer and other persons connected with the paper. The result was that the publication had been suspended for ten days, but it was now again in existence, and such was its circulation, and such was the credit attached to its statements, that it was now published daily instead of three times a week. The result of the discredit attempted to be thrown on the facts stated by his correspondents was that they had become matter of notoriety at Florence from being published by some of the most respectable inhabitants, As he had always foreseen, the only result of an interference in Tuscan affairs was that the Mazzinian party was now stronger and bolder than ever. The latest information which he had received mentioned that three committees for barricades were now established in Florence itself. The noble and learned lord seemed likewise to throw great discredit on what he had said with reference to the statements in the French papers. But those details of the atrocities which had been committed were all confirmed the next day in the other House by the noble lord the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. He had not directly charged the Provisional Government with these acts, but he said they were done by persons acting under their authority; for, when the regular Government was overthrown, and was assumed by a person in the station of Gen. GARIBALDI, he had no right to permit the commission of outrages; and it was not sufficient to say merely that he had in no way connived at them. The reports from our own Admiral on that station declared Gen. GARIBALDI personally to be a man of great moderation; but he was certainly not in a position to hold diplomatic intercourse with our Government if he was unable to prevent these atrocious crimes.

abstract: AGE. -- For about ten days serious fires have been burning in the pine forests of New-Jersey, and many square miles of timber have been burned over. In some instances dwellings have shared the fate of the woods, and their occupants have been compelled to fly for their lives. There are no less than four of these fires burning the most serious of which appears to be ten or fifteen miles southwest of the Weymouth station, on the line of the Camden and Atlantic Railroad. Between this point and some distance below Egg Harbor City the flames have extended, and south of the last named place there seems to be a semi-circle of burning woods. East of Egg Harbor City the fire has come up to the line of the railroad, and the ruins of trees are smouldering for some distance along the track. The travel along the road has not been interfered with by the fires, and it is not probable that it will be impeded. The fires have originated from coalings and from sparks from the locomotives. There is no possibility of the flames being extinguished until sufficient rain falls to accomplish it. At Atlantic City the fires assume a formidable appearance. The cloud of smoke, reaching a line many miles in extent, arises to such a height as to spread over the western heavens and beyond the zenith, and it gives the sun, during the last half hour of the day, a murky appearance. The extent of the fires may be judged from the fact that the smoke so plainly visible at Atlantic arises some twenty miles distant from there. The cinders from burning brush have been carried by the wind clear to the sea, and the banks of the inlet at Atlantic are lined with blackened rubbish from the fires. The dry weather has rendered the woods very combustible. -- Newark Mercury, 23d.

abstract: It seems a settled thing that we are to have a new batch of Federal Judges for Utah Territory. The old ones have not been able to earn their salaries in the discharge of their official duties, through some e formidable reason, real or fancied. And it may not be out of the way for me here to state the feelings and sentiments of the mass of the people with respect to the Federal Territorial Judiciary in general, and the late incumbents of the Judicial Bench of this Territory in particular.

abstract: Although the rain prevented the contemplated inspection of the Savannah Blues yesterday, it could not interfere with the dinner given in their honor at the Metropolitan Hotel, in the evening, by the City Guard. The Messrs. LELAND proved themselves efficient commissaries and prepared a quality and quantity of comestibles worthy of a soldier's appetite. The large dining hall was tastefully ornamented for the occasion with flags and the banners of the two Companies, while the table was garnished with a number of appropriate confectionary devices. Among these were statuettes of the City Guard and Savannah Blues, bust of WASHINGTON, surmounting a temple, equestrian statue of WASHINGTON, symbols of war and of friendship, a large camp of the City Guard, and other ingenious devices of the plastic art, together with flowers "of rare and roseate shadows." Capt. MANSFIELD LOVELL, of the City Guard, occupied the head of the table. On his right were Capt. Anderson, of the Savannah Blues; Lieut. Webb, of the Army; Capt. Schley, of the Blues; Hon. John McKeon, Judge-Advocate de Lyon, of the Blues; Lieut. Thomas, of the Army, and Chaplain Baker, of the Ninth Regiment. On the left of Capt. Lovell were Mayor Wood, Brigadier-General Hall, H.W. Stiles, of the Blues, formerly Minister to Austria; Lieut. Oliver, Councilman Lent, Lieut. Banks, of the Grays, and Lieut. McFarland, of the Blues. Facing Capt. Lovell were Lieut. Chas. E. Prescott, of the Guard, a number of officers of the Second Brigade of Hudson County, N.J., and other gentlemen of note.

abstract: Norway, thanks to her State Constitution, has never displayed the spirit of proscription and persecution which has at times been rampant in Sweden; but there have been considerable civil disabilities under which the dissenters from the Established (Lutheran) Church have labored, such as inability to hold office, liability to taxation for the support of the Established Church, &c. One of these, the restriction of office to members of the State Church, seems to be in a fair way of removal. At the present session of the Storthing, or National Legislature, a resolution to suppress the article which contained this restriction, received 67 votes in its favor to 44 against it, only 7 short of the constitutional two-thirds. At the next session of the Storthing, in 1863, it will undoubtedly pass by the constitutional vote.
lead_paragraph: Norway, thanks to her State Constitution, has never displayed the spirit of proscription and persecution which has at times been rampant in Sweden; but there have been considerable civil disabilities under which the dissenters from the Established (Lutheran) Church have labored, such as inability to hold office, liability to taxation for the support of the Established Church, &c. One of these, the restriction of office to members of the State Church, seems to be in a fair way of removal. At the present session of the Storthing, or National Legislature, a resolution to suppress the article which contained this restriction, received 67 votes in its favor to 44 against it, only 7 short of the constitutional two-thirds. At the next session of the Storthing, in 1863, it will undoubtedly pass by the constitutional vote.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the chair. A communication was received from the Board of Officers of the Fire Department, asking that the striking apparatus in the City Hall tower be repaired, and that the telegraph be extended to the City Hall bell-tower. Referred to the Fire Department Committee, Western District. The matter of accepting a deed of cession of Pacific-street, between New-York and Troy avenues, was referred to the Committee on Opening Streets. The Mayor returned, with out his approval. a resolution authorizing the Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies to purchase $10,000 worth of hose, for the reason that only $7,000 has been appropriated, and suggesting that the resolution be so amended as to come within the appropriation. Referred to the Finance Committee. A communication was received from the Mayor inclosing a report of the Commissioners on Williamsburgh claims, recommending that they be paid as reported, viz.:

abstract: HOOLEY  CAMPBELL'S MINSTRELS AT NEWARK.  Hooley  Campbell's Minstrels have arranged to  appear to-night and to-morrow night in Concert Hall, Newark.
lead_paragraph: HOOLEY CAMPBELL'S MINSTRELS AT NEWARK. -- Hooley Campbell's Minstrels have arranged to appear to-night and to-morrow night in Concert Hall, Newark. This company has been selected from among the best performers in the several prominent companies in the City of New-York and elsewhere, and has performed with great success at the French Theatre, and recently in the principal theatre in Boston. Those of Newark who are partial, to negro minstrelsy, as rendered by the best artists in the country, will do well to visit Concert Hall during the performances there of Hooley & Campbell's Minstrels.

abstract: For an unreasonable number of years the steamship Great Eastern has attracted a large share of the curiosity, interest and enthusiasm of Europe and America. At first it was proposed that she should be built. This proposition was received with what the reporters style "derisive laughter."
lead_paragraph: For an unreasonable number of years the steamship Great Eastern has attracted a large share of the curiosity, interest and enthusiasm of Europe and America. At first it was proposed that she should be built. This proposition was received with what the reporters style "derisive laughter." Then the public were astounded to know that the enormous amount of capital requisite to build the monster had been subscribed, and her stock had been taken by bona fide capitalists; then the keel was laid, and the shouts of hundreds of thousands testified how deep was the interest felt in the enterprise and how anxious were all the good people of England to have success perch upon the banners of this mammoth of the deep. As she went on from success to success, the enthusiasm of Britannia's sons waxed greater, and swelling with pride in their own achievement they exultingly cried "Huzzah! huzzah! Are we not the people, and does not victory lie with us, Lord?" Scarcely had this impious boast passed the lips of the conceited Briton, when failures and delays, disappointments and disgraces began in rapid succession to attend the enterprise. Nothing went right; the directors disagreed, the builders made mistakes, the workmen failed to execute as directed, the machinery wouldn't work, and the ship's great bottom was covered with barnacles. After a while new hands took hold of her, more energetic managers were placed in charge, and the great publics on each side of the water were told to open wide their eyes and prepare to be astonished. The illustrated papers gave us picture after picture, and sketch upon sketch all showing what the Great Eastern would be, but few showing how she was. Still she moved not.

abstract: The political contest is assuming a curious shape. The shattered condition of the Democratic Party has destroyed everything like an organized opposition to the Republicans, based upon principle, and converted the whole campaign into a desperate struggle not to get into power themselves, but to keep their opponents out. The highest ambition of the motley Anti-Republican host just now, is to play the dog in the manger.
lead_paragraph: The political contest is assuming a curious shape. The shattered condition of the Democratic Party has destroyed everything like an organized opposition to the Republicans, based upon principle, and converted the whole campaign into a desperate struggle not to get into power themselves, but to keep their opponents out. The highest ambition of the motley Anti-Republican host just now, is to play the dog in the manger. Not a solitary man among them believes that either DOUGLAS, BELL or BRECKINRIDGE can possibly be elected President by the people. Everybody surrenders this expectation. But they all have a lingering hope that, by uniting their forces, they may possibly prevent any election at all; and the great aim of each faction just now is, not to vindicate its own position, -- not to justify its own principles and policy, -- but to hit upon some expedient by which they can slur over their differences and unite their votes, so as to defeat the election of a President.

abstract: The London Times, of the 22d ult., forebodes a famine in England, owing to bad weather and consequent short crops. The prospect of the grain crops in France is also said to be unpromising. On the other hand, the cereal crops in the United States and Canada never promised better.
lead_paragraph: The London Times, of the 22d ult., forebodes a famine in England, owing to bad weather and consequent short crops. The prospect of the grain crops in France is also said to be unpromising. On the other hand, the cereal crops in the United States and Canada never promised better. A larger crop of wheat than we ever had before, by, perhaps, one-fourth, is now secured, or in the process of harvesting. The crops of hay and oats are also large, and the promise of the king of our cereals -- Indian corn -- was never better. Nothing short of a large export demand can keep the price of this abundant cereal from falling below remuneration to the grower. Of the last year's crop, it is said that the large farm cribs of Illinois are still nearly full of last year's corn, yet the receipts at Chicago have averaged over 100,000 bushels a day, from the Illinois canals and railroads, through the season.

abstract: The announcement that the Savannah Republican Blues would be reviewed by the Mayor yesterday proved premature, as the requisite arrangements were not made. "His Excellency" will review the Blues this afternoon, on their way to the steamer Florida, in which they are to return home. Yesterday morning the Blues paraded in Bond-street, for inspection of muskets by Capt. ANDERSON, and drew an admiring crowd. Late in the afternoon they paraded under escort of the City Guard, in Broadway, and attracted a host of admirers, between Union-square and the Park. In the evening, the officers of the Blues and the City Guard were entertained at dinner by the officers of the Seventh Regiment, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The rank and file, escorted by the privates of the City Guard, attended Niblo's Theatre, by invitation of Mr. NIXON, and enjoyed the spectacle of "Aladdin," the aquaria and the garden, as much as the thousands of civic visitors present. At the close of the first act, the Blues were honored with three cheers, proposed by Mr. A.H. DAVENPORT, from among the audience. The Blues acknowledged the compliment by giving three cheers for the citizens of New-York. The Florida leaves at 4 P.M. to-day, and the Blues will be escorted to the steamer by the City Guard, and such detachments from the First Division as may volunteer.

abstract: Yesterday morning the body of a man was found floating in the slip of the New-York Balance Dock Company, at Pier No. 41 East River. The flesh of the head, arms and legs had disappeared, the thigh bones were fractured, and the remains were mutilated and decomposed to such an extent that it seemed impossible to establish their identity. By means, however of a peculiarity in the cravat which still remained about the neck of deceased. Mr. THOMAS COULTAS recognized the remains as those of his father, Mr. JOHN COULTAS, who has been missing since the 1st of February last. Subsequently, Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body, and the testimony showed that Mr. COULTAS probably lost his life on the day of his disappearance by the explosion of a steam-boiler which was used for pumping water out of the dock. Some time after the explosion the hat belonging to deceased was found, having blood stains upon it, and this circumstance led to the belief that he had been blown up, although no direct proof that such was the case has been obtained until now. The cause of the explosion was not satisfactorily demonstrated by the evidence. Mr. HENRY FARNER, the company's engineer, testified that he deemed the boiler perfectly safe, as it had only a day or two previously been inspected by the officers appointed for that purpose, who furnished the usual certificate, and at the time of its destruction but 60 pounds of pressure was carried. The Jury could inculpate no person in the matter, and a simple verdict of "death from injuries caused by the explosion" was rendered. Deceased was a native of England, 70 years of age, and acted as a watchman for the Company.

abstract: DILLAYE. Our readers may remember the hue and cry which was made a few months ago over the arrest of STEPHEN D. DILLAYE, Esq., a prominent politician of this State, for forgery, and his trial at Pittsburgh. Mr. D. had been a very active Democrat, and had taken a very conspicuous part in the party politics of the State for several years.
lead_paragraph: DILLAYE. Our readers may remember the hue and cry which was made a few months ago over the arrest of STEPHEN D. DILLAYE, Esq., a prominent politician of this State, for forgery, and his trial at Pittsburgh. Mr. D. had been a very active Democrat, and had taken a very conspicuous part in the party politics of the State for several years. His zeal in the service was rewarded by an appointment as Appraiser in the New-York Custom-house, given him in 1856 by Mr. GUTHRIE, then Secretary of the Treasury. From this position he was removed by Secretary COBB, ostensibly upon charges preferred by the Secret Agent of the Treasury Department, but really, as Mr. D. alleges, because he had interfered with some of the selfish and unprincipled schemes of certain leaders of the Democratic Party in this City. Mr. DILLAYE, at the time, published through our columns a very sharp personal reply to the charges which were made against him, including a very bitter personal attack upon Secretary, COBB and his alleged tools in the persecution to which he had been subjected.

abstract: The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 14th and Queenstown on the 15th inst., passed Cape Race on Monday evening, and her news has been briefly telegraphed. It is affirmed that GARIBALDI is determined to besiege Messina. The General has received an important addition to his forces in the Neapolitan steam corvette Veloce. From Syria we learn that the insurrection there continued. FUAD PACHA had gone there on a special mission, and until that was settled England and France would abstain from active interference. A British squadron, however, had been ordered to the Coast of Syria. Late intelligence from China indicates that hostilities would immediately commence between the Chinese and the English. The latter had sailed for the Peiho.

abstract: -- By this publication, so much valued by the graduates and other friends of the College, it appears that when printed 2,434 graduates were supposed to be living, of whom only 31 took their first degree before the beginning of the nineteenth century in 1801. The venerable JOSIAH QUINCY, the oldest graduate, is the sole survivor of the class of 1790, and there is also but one of the classes of 1791, 1793 and 1795; of the classes of 1792 and 1794, all "have returned to the stars;" of that of 1796, 4 are yet living; of 1798, 5, and of each of the classes of 1797, 1799 and 1800 6. Total, 31. At the time of the publication of the triennial of 1857, 2,394 graduates were living, 50 of whom left College before 1801. By the death of Mr. WELLES, on Saturday last, the number of the survivors of the graduates in 1800 is reduced to 5, and of those before 1801 to 30 only. -- Boston Traveller.
lead_paragraph: -- By this publication, so much valued by the graduates and other friends of the College, it appears that when printed 2,434 graduates were supposed to be living, of whom only 31 took their first degree before the beginning of the nineteenth century in 1801. Total, 31. At the time of the publication of the triennial of 1857, 2,394 graduates were living, 50 of whom left College before 1801. abstract: The total number of visitors was nearly 19,000, and from about noon till near the hour of closing there could not have been less, at any one time, than from 6,000 to 7,000 people on board. The Thomas Powell brought 800 from Poughkeepsie. Excursion trains from all parts of the State, and from adjacent States, were overladen with the curious, male and female, whom the fame of the great ship had attracted to the City. Before entering, the vast crowd were formed into lines, under the superintendence of the Police, and everyone took his turn for admission, en taille. The throng did not cease till near the hour of closing, and then the getting off was even more, difficult than the getting on. The ladies, of course, confined themselves to the deck, saloons, dining rooms, state rooms, and the first and second tiers of the engine-room, but the men went by hundreds into the depths, underneath the enormous cylinders, visited the mammoth boilers, dropped down into the bowels of the ship, and crawled along her screw, far below the water line. The crowd in these latter places was so dense that an average tortoise pace was, in comparison, equal to a Flora Temple trot, Altogether, the Great Eastern was a vast success yesterday, and if such crowds could be calculated on, for two or three weeks more, her managers would, doubtless, postpone her Cape May trip, and her departure for England, till the excitement ceased. Apropos, of that Cape May trip, we learn that over five hundred tickets have already been sold, the number of voyageurs to be taken being limited to two thousand.

Apropos, of that Cape May trip, we learn that over five hundred tickets have already been sold, the number of voyageurs to be taken being limited to two thousand.

abstract: The Board of Pilot Commissioners met yesterday. After the usual business transactions, a statement was made that a pilot, whose license had been revoked for drunkenness, had been arrested for piloting a vessel, and that he was now in prison. A complaint was made against JOHN MAGINN for violation of pilot regulations, and he was notified to appear for trial on Tuesday next. A letter from the Street Commissioner complained that the lives of the operatives engaged in blowing up Diamond Reef were frequently endangered by vessels coming in contact with the sloop and diving bell. The Sound steamers, and tugs with barges in tow, were the principal ones complained of. The Board issued directions to their pilots to exercise extra care when near the reef; and a letter was sent to the Commissioner, to the effect that they would cooperate in every way in their power to prevent a repetition of such carelessness in future.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Pilot Commissioners met yesterday. After the usual business transactions, a statement was made that a pilot, whose license had been revoked for drunkenness, had been arrested for piloting a vessel, and that he was now in prison. A letter from the Street Commissioner complained that the lives of the operatives engaged in blowing up Diamond Reef were frequently endangered by vessels coming in contact with the sloop and diving bell. The Sound steamers, and tugs with barges in tow, were the principal ones complained of. The Board issued directions to their pilots to exercise extra care when near the reef; and a letter was sent to the Commissioner, to the effect that they would cooperate in every way in their power to prevent a repetition of such carelessness in future.

abstract: An appeal to the public is seldom more than a thinly-vailed demand for popular favor. I have no such appeal to make; and yet I desire to be heard upon a matter which pertains to public, as well as private rights; for, whatever is an attack upon the good name or citizenship of an American citizen, is an infringement upon those immunities, it is the duty of every man to protect.
lead_paragraph: An appeal to the public is seldom more than a thinly-vailed demand for popular favor. I have no such appeal to make; and yet I desire to be heard upon a matter which pertains to public, as well as private rights; for, whatever is an attack upon the good name or citizenship of an American citizen, is an infringement upon those immunities, it is the duty of every man to protect. I do not, therefore, invite public attention to the facts I am about to present, alone to vindicate my character from the attacks which have been made upon it; or, simply to call in review the means which the Special Agent of the Secretary of the Treasury has set in motion to calumniate me; but I do it that the people of the United States may appreciate the means to which a public officer, high in official position, has dared to resort, in this Government which claims to be free and to protect its citizens, to stigmatize and disgrace an individual who manfully rejected the tyranny of his insolence, and had the courage to expose the corruptions of his office -- an officer, who has made his own injustice the apology for adopting.

abstract: KET. -- The Directors of the Great Eastern, resisting the attractions of Philadelphia, its anthracite and its $30,000, were enamored of Baltimore and its Cumberland coal, and not indisposed to coquette feebly with Norfolk. They sent an agent accordingly to the Monumental City, offering to send thither the wondrous vessel, in consideration of the authorities bestowing upon it, and stowing away in it, 2,500 tons of semi-bituminous coal. The Directors alleged that they were the more willing to make this move, inasmuch as they had a half-formed purpose of placing the ship in service between Norfolk and England; a project that rendered communication with Southern people and views desirable. To these seductions Baltimore has turned a deaf ear. It is indisposed to gratify its curiosity at a serious outlay of its metals and minerals; and least of all, to abet a plan of raising Norfolk, with its vast natural advantages, into dangerous rivalry with its own promising future. Baltimore, we conceive, has done wisely.
lead_paragraph: KET. -- The Directors of the Great Eastern, resisting the attractions of Philadelphia, its anthracite and its $30,000, were enamored of Baltimore and its Cumberland coal, and not indisposed to coquette feebly with Norfolk. To these seductions Baltimore has turned a deaf ear. It is indisposed to gratify its curiosity at a serious outlay of its metals and minerals; and least of all, to abet a plan of raising Norfolk, with its vast natural advantages, into dangerous rivalry with its own promising future. Baltimore, we conceive, has done wisely.

abstract: ENRIGHT, who keeps an emigrant boarding-house, and is said to make a large profit thereby, -- ENRIGHT, the emigrant ticket dealer, who is supposed to make large profits in that capacity also, -- ENRIGHT, who intimately knows the inside of cells, for alleged charges for ticket swindling, and who always manages, whenever sent thither, to be found at large a few hours afterwards, -- ENRIGHT, whom recently Mr. DELAVAN and Mayor WOOD appointed Health Warden of this port, -- ENRIGHT, who had the good grace to succumb before the public outcry at such an appointment -- that same identical ENRIGHT has got into trouble again.

abstract: On the morning of Saturday last the people of Bound Brook were alarmed and horrified to hear that a man named LEWIS had murdered his wife and committed suicide. LEWIS was the keeper of a store on a road through the mountains, situate about a mile and a half from the village, and it was the frequent resort of loafers, who met there to drink ale and lager. There are several "rum holes" in the neighborhood, and this vicinity has for a long time been considered a hard place.

abstract: Col. O.A. LOCHRANE, of Marietta, Ga., writes to the Southern Confederacy, on general politics. He differs from DOUGLAS in his views of Popular Sovereignty, but differs equally with the Administration party in its attempt to crush him. He contends that DOUGLAS' nomination is national as much as BRECKINRIDGE's; for while Northern delegates voted for the latter, Southern delegates voted for the former -- and hence one nomination is as national as the other. The race, in Col. L.'s opinion, will be between DOUGLAS and LINCOLN, but he thinks the latter will not be elected by the electoral vote.
lead_paragraph: Col. O.A. LOCHRANE, of Marietta, Ga., writes to the Southern Confederacy, on general politics. abstract: As long as there was a reasonable chance that the one section or other of the Democratic Party would be able to place its candidate in the White House, or that an arrangement could be effected for concerted or harmonious action at the polls, Disunion was never named in Democratic councils. In fact, six weeks ago it was impossible to find a disunionist anywhere. All the fire-eaters denied that they had ever dreamed of such a thing. WISE had "folded his pale hands" as meekly as if he had never expressed the smallest thirst for a campaign against the Yankees and the British Abolitionists. YANCEY was almost as ardent in his devotion to the Union as EDWARD EVERETT, and TOOMBS was silent, the strongest evidence of pacific intentions which TOOMBS has ever afforded. More wonderful still, the Northern Democrats, for the first time in two years, had ceased to express any apprehensions with regard to the safety of the Government. They were evidently reveling in the novel sensation of confidence, or rather of absence of terror, and were lulled into the foolish, fond belief that ruin was not impending over them. Drygoods began to flow in freely, and the jobbers got so saucy and defiant that some of them were actually heard to speak disrespectfully of HAMBLETON, of the Confederacy, and declare that the next time he came round for his blackmail they would snap their fingers in his face. Even the real estate men, whom dissolution would affect most seriously, have been for a month or two unusually calm.

abstract: NAPOLEON -- The English papers print a letter addressed by GARIBALDI to Mr. THOMAS PARKE, a Liverpool shipbuilder, in regard to the purchase of two war vessels for the revolutionary service. The patriot reminds his correspondent that England has no sincere allies but free peoples; that the regeneration of Italy will supply the want so far as the Continent is concerned; and the new nation will "be one of the greatest obstacles to the schemes of the Emperor of the French." In other words, the success of the revolutionary movement is to benefit England by raising up a powerful ally against NAPOLEON III.

abstract: Theodore Lynn, keeper of a boarding house at No. 2 Carlisle-street, in the First Ward, was yesterday committed for trial by Justice WELSH, on a charge of having attempted to kidnap John Rand, a German sailor, who had been stopping at his house. Rand declared in his complaint that the accused, with the design of sending him to sea against his inclination, approached him on Monday night, having a loaded revolver in one hand and a pair of handcuffs in the other, and threatened to shoot him unless he submitted to be ironed. Fearing that resistance would cost him his life, he yielded to the ruffian's demand, and after the handcuffs had been placed upon his wrists, he was led into a bedroom, where a rope having been "rove" through the irons, he was triced up to a ring- bolt, secured in the ceiling of the apartment. Officer Miller, of the First Precinct, was apprised of Rand's condition and went to release him, but Mrs. Lynn refused him admittance to the house, and he immediately made the facts known to Sergeant Johns, at the Police Station. Both returned to the boarding-house, and again demanded admission, which was a second time denied. Instead, however, of entering by force, which they had a right to do, Sergeant Johns shirked the responsibility and waited until the arrival of Capt. Silvey, his superior officer, for whom he had sent. When the Captain reached place the door was forced at once, and the almost exhausted sailor was released from his painful posture. Meantime Lynn had escaped, but after a protracted search he was arrested in Brooklyn, at a house where he had concealed himself. The complainant was committed to the House of Detention to insure his attendance as a witness when the case shall be brought to trial. These cases of what is technically called "shanghaeing" seamen only occasionally come before the Police Courts. They are said however, to be of frequent occurrence, and whenever successful, the keeper of the boarding-house receives for his ruffianism the advance wages of his victim.

abstract: YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. The monthly meeting of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association was held at their rooms, cor  ner of Broadway and Twelfth-street, on Monday evening, the President, Mr. GOODRICH, in the Chair. Reports were received from the Church, Visiting,  Employment and Boarding-house Committees, all of which appear now to be in good working order.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. The monthly meeting of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association was held at their rooms, cor ner of Broadway and Twelfth-street, on Monday evening, the President, Mr. GOODRICH, in the Chair. Reports were received from the Church, Visiting, Employment and Boarding-house Committees, all of which appear now to be in good working order. Mr. HRATH, the Corresponding Secretary, stated that he had received numerous letters from kindred Associations throughout the land, extracts of which were read. The paper of the evening upon "Action" was read by RICHARD C. MCCORMICK, Esq., and was discussed by Dr. HOWARD and Mr. CORBET. A very impressive address by Mr. GRIMBLE, of the New-Orleans Association, was then listened to with much interest. Rev. Mr. WHITE was then called upon, but on account of the lateness of the hour spoke for only a few minutes. A number of gentlemen were elected, and others were proposed for membership. After singing and prayer the meeting adjourned.

lead_paragraph: The Committee on Streets of the Board of Councilmen held a meeting yesterday afternoon ALEX. L. SHAW, Esq., presiding, and HARRIS BOGERT, Esq., a member of the Committee, present. There was a very large representation of property owners on Catharine-street, and the first speaker was Mr. Jas. W. Dominick, who owns Nos. 4, 6, 10 and 12, and who strenuously opposed the project. He presented a list comprising about 300 names of actual real estate owners on the street in question, and those adjacent to it. Mr. Rose, Ex-Collector of City Revenue, opposed the widening, and said they had only lately been assessed for a sewer, for the widening of Canal-street, and the opening of the Bowery, and that he was informed that the street was to be paved with Belgian pavement, which would make another assessment. Mr. Joseph Petty also opposed the project, and, referring to William-street, New Canal-street and others asked what benefit they had derived by opening.

abstract: -- The death of Mr. GALES revives a reminiscence of the only time his paper, the National Intelligencer, ever suspended publication. It was a warm and able advocate of the Madison war policy, seconding the efforts of CLAY and his compeers, and so powerful was its influence that when Gen. ROSS, in command of the British troops, entered the capital after the unfortunate affair of Bladensburgh, his first inquiry was not for the Capitol, the President's house, or the departments, but for the National Intelligencer office, and it was the first establishment demolished, causing a short cessation in its regular publication. With this exception the Intelligencer has been published regularly for sixty years. -- Albany Evening Journal.
lead_paragraph: -- The death of Mr. GALES revives a reminiscence of the only time his paper, the National Intelligencer, ever suspended publication. With this exception the Intelligencer has been published regularly for sixty years. -- Albany Evening Journal.

abstract: -- The New-Orleans Commercial Bulletin, in an article which we copy in another column, exposes and denounces the Disunion schemes which are on foot in the Southern States. That able journal detects in the movements of the Breckinridge faction a purpose to carry into execution the conspiracy revealed by Mr. YANCEY in his famous letter, and makes a variety of extracts from leading organs of that party to sustain its views. It denounces these treasonable plots, and especially the secresy in which they are matured.

abstract: such meetings as that of the Academy of Medicine, reported in another column, the better. They neither redound to individual credit, nor the benefit of the Society and the profession. So long as such personalities as characterized this and other recent meetings of the Academy are allowed either by inefficiency or willfulness of the Chair, or the culpable negligence of the body itself, the better men will continue to absent themselves from its sessions, and from a staid and erudite body the Society will degenerate to the level of Tammany Hall or a bear-garden. It is unpleasant to record such unbecoming conduct on the part of this heretofore dignified and honored institution, and we do it now only with the hope that this public allusion to such scandals may arouse the members to a sense of propriety, and that the general sentiment of reprobation which is felt against such waste of time (to say the very least) may serve to put a final stop to any similar infringements against the common laws of such assemblages, and those feelings of decency and propriety which should animate the breast of every one familiar with the freedom -- not license -- of free institutions.

abstract: For the third time within as many weeks, it has been the fate of the Gotham Club to have a tie game as the termination of their labors, the Jefferson this time having the honor of participating in the tie. In justice to the Gotham it must be stated that they were unusually weak, no less than four or five second nine players taking part in the match, the regular catcher and pitcher being amongst the absentees. The general play of the Jeffersons was very creditable, the fielding of Vincellette at short, Read at right field, and Greer at left field, being especially praiseworthy, and Tyson and Springteen manning their bases in excellent style. Connor made a splendid bound catch, and otherwise played well, while Springsteen batted in fine style. For the Gothams, Forsyth's batting and his fielding at short were very creditable performances; Hopkins was efficient at first base; Connell made a good show as catcher and at left field; Burtis made a good fly catch and batted finely, and Sweet made some fine catches, but missed one or two easy chances.

abstract: Yesterday the Street Commissioner opened bids for ten different jobs for repairs to and construction of piers. After the opening, it is reported, a well-known Senator, who had rendered bids for some of the jobs, put in the name of another party, and assaulted a person who had been successful in bidding for some of the contracts. Before anything serious resulted, however, the numbers of corporation contractors present had stopped the fracas by their interference. The Senator had made his bidding and been disappointed, it was said, through a well-known individual who strongly favors the Broadway Railroad scheme.

abstract: About 10 o'clock on Monday night flames were discovered issuing from the lower part of the large paint factory at the end of Mill street, Poughkeepsie, owned and occupied by Mr. WEDDLE. An alarm was instantly given, but some time elapsed before the firemen could reach the spot, owing to its distance from the engine-houses. The contents being principally composed of oil, turpentine, varnish and other inflammable materials, the whole building was in a short time enveloped in flames. There were probably from seven to eight thousand persons at the conflagration, many of whom assisted the firemen, doing considerable service. The building was entirely destroyed, together with its contents, which consisted of a large stock of oils, paints, varnish, turpentine, &c, as well as the machinery, tools, benches, and other articles too numerous to mention. The owner being absent at the time, our reporter could not learn the exact amount of the loss, but it is estimated by others at from $20,000 to $25,000. It was a very large brick building, formerly owned by Mr. WINFIELD, and used as a silk manufactory. It was five stories high, with 50 feet front and about 150 feet in the rear. Another factory of about the same size, adjoining, owned by PALTON BROTHERS, used as a carpet and pin factory, was damaged by fire and water to the amount of between $2,000 and $3,000. Mr. PELTON's is fully insured. The firemen worked with a will, and when it was found impossible to save the paint factory, turned their whole attention to the surrounding buildings, which were liable at any moment to burst forth in a blaze, so great was the heat. The wind was blowing quite freely during the whole time. The factory of PELTON BROTHERS caught fire in the roof by a blazing shingle failing upon it from the burning building. The grocery store and a dwelling house on the opposite side of the street had a narrow escape, and were badly scorched. The store was occupied by Mr. DORAN, the contents of which were much damaged by the water. Damage to building and contents $250. We could not learn whether there was any insurance on the building and property owned by Mr. WEDDLE. The fire was no doubt the work of an incendiary. Some four or five years ago, the carpet and pin factory adjoining the paint factory was entirely destroyed by fire, and the paint factory, then a silk manufactory, was damaged to the same amount that the carpet factory was by this fire; or, in other words, at a recent fire the damage sustained by the owners of the two factories was directly the reverse of that of Monday night.

abstract: The Academy of Medicine held its semi-monthly meeting in the small chapel of the University, on Wednesday evening last, Dr. BUCK, Vice-President, in the chair. There being no business on hand, Dr. PERCY read the law relative to poisons, passed at the last session of the New-York State Legislature, and stated that it was printed on cards, and made a motion that the Academy purchase a sufficient number of them, and send one to each druggist and apothecary in New-York City.

abstract: William Winans et al., Administrator of Reuben Withers and James M. Waterbury, vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company et al. The plaintiffs in this action held an assignment from Oliver Charlick of a claim to a fifth portion of the profits of the lease of the Williamsburgh Ferry, amounting as calculated by them, to $200,000.
lead_paragraph: William Winans et al., Administrator of Reuben Withers and James M. Waterbury, vs. The Williamsburgh Ferry Company et al. The plaintiffs in this action held an assignment from Oliver Charlick of a claim to a fifth portion of the profits of the lease of the Williamsburgh Ferry, amounting as calculated by them, to $200,000.

abstract: The Republican Blues of Savannah yesterday took leave of New-York, and returned to their Southern home, on board of the steamer Florida. Like the reception which greeted them upon their arrival less than a week ago, the departure of this fine body of military was signalized by every possible demonstration of respect and esteem which it is customary to bestow upon strangers visiting this City, under similar circumstances, from any quarter of the Union. The visit appears to have been mutually agreeable, and, to the visitors themselves, has been productive of much substantial enjoyment, if their declarations are to be received as the expression of their true sentiments. A considerable portion of the Company -- nearly one-half -- remained behind for the transaction of business or for pleasure, forty-six only, besides the Officers, having returned. By previous arrangement, the Blues met at the Armory of the City Guard, in Broadway, at 3 o'clock P.M., where they were received, and invited to join in a parting collation. During this informal repast, sentiments of mutual good will were exchanged between the officers and soldiers of the two Companies.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Blues of Savannah yesterday took leave of New-York, and returned to their Southern home, on board of the steamer Florida. Like the reception which greeted them upon their arrival less than a week ago, the departure of this fine body of military was signalized by every possible demonstration of respect and esteem which it is customary to bestow upon strangers visiting this City, under similar circumstances, from any quarter of the Union. A considerable portion of the Company -- nearly one-half -- remained behind for the transaction of business or for pleasure, forty-six only, besides the Officers, having returned. By previous arrangement, the Blues met at the Armory of the City Guard, in Broadway, at 3 o'clock P.M., where they were received, and invited to join in a parting collation. During this informal repast, sentiments of mutual good will were exchanged between the officers and soldiers of the two Companies.

abstract: The final destination of the "small parties of emigrants," who have for several months past, with the knowledge of the authorities at Washington, been leaving New-Orleans and other Southern ports for Central America, has now transpired. Gen. WILLIAM WALKER has, ere this, probably landed either at Truxillo or Omoa, and is on his way through Honduras to Nicaragua. It appears that his men have been quietly assembling at Ruatan, where he himself landed about the 25th of June, and on the 27th the whole party, numbering probably three hundred men, sailed in the direction of Omoa. This latest attempt against Nicaragua is probably a renewal of the expedition of some two years ago, which was broken up by the wreck of the schooner Susan on the shoals of the harbor of Omoa. WALKER's intention is, no doubt, to proceed across the country to the Pacific, where vessels will convey the expedition to Realejo, from which point it will immediately move into Nicaragua, before any notice of their coming has been received. It is announced, in the interest of WALKER, that this expedition is intended to be entirely a "peaceful" one -- that a proclamation has been already prepared, in which all hostile intentions are disclaimed, and an amnesty is promised to all who, in the past, may have committed offences against the deposed President.
lead_paragraph: The final destination of the "small parties of emigrants," who have for several months past, with the knowledge of the authorities at Washington, been leaving New-Orleans and other Southern ports for Central America, has now transpired. abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Supervisors and Aldermen was held in the Common Council Chamber last evening, to consider the report of the Committee fixing the amount of taxes to be levied for various purposes in 1861. The whole session was occupied with the resolution appropriating money for Public School purposes. A motion to add $10,000 with which to purchase books for all scholars who attend the schools was presented at the last meeting, and was then referred to the Corporation Counsellor, to be certain whether, in his opinion, the Joint Board had a right to vote money for such a purpose. In reply to this the Counsellor says that the Joint Board has no lawful authority to vote money for the purpose of furnishing free books to the Public Schools. He says that section 9 of the act of April,l850, organizing the Board of Education, (p. 178 of Charter,) contemplates the preparation of an estimate, by the Board of Education, of moneys requisite to be raised for school purposes, and the determination by the Common Council of the sums which shall be raised for such purposes. And section 22 of title 2 of the Charter authorizes the raising by the Joint Board of all moneys authorized for the use and benefit of the Public Schools, Section 2 of the act of April 4, 1850 gives the entire charge and direction of the School moneys to the Board of Education, subject only to the limitation contained in the division and classification of the moneys, as Special School Fund and General School Fund.

He says that section 9 of the act of April,l850, organizing the Board of Education, (p. 178 of Charter,) contemplates the preparation of an estimate, by the Board of Education, of moneys requisite to be raised for school purposes, and the determination by the Common Council of the sums which shall be raised for such purposes. And section 22 of title 2 of the Charter authorizes the raising by the Joint Board of all moneys authorized for the use and benefit of the Public Schools, Section 2 of the act of April 4, 1850 gives the entire charge and direction of the School moneys to the Board of Education, subject only to the limitation contained in the division and classification of the moneys, as Special School Fund and General School Fund.

abstract: Hon D.S. DICKINSON was honored among his own people, at Binghamton, on Monday last. The Republican of that place announces that, at a very early hour in the morning, "the firing of rockets and Roman candies, the sound of martial music and the roar of cannon gave loud indications that something unusual was on hand;" and it turned out that the occasion was a. demonstration in honor of Mr. DICKINSON and the Breckinridge ticket. A. procession was formed, which marched to Mr. D.'s residence, and called him out for a speech. He responded in the following strain:

abstract: PHELAN has brought here one of his best tables, and the Yale and Harvard representatives have just finished a match game. The time was two hours and a half, and Harvard won by eighty points. The hall was crowded with students, and there was great enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Wednesday, July 25.

abstract: An extra from the Bonham (Texas) Era office, of the 17th, received to-night by the Overland Mail contains a letter from CHAS. R. PRYOR, editor of the Dallas Herald, stating that the fire at that place on the 8th led to the discovery of a diabolical plan to devastate the whole of Northern Texas white men, friends of the Abolition preachers BLUNT and McKINNEY, who were expelled from the County last year, are the instigators.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, July 25.

abstract: Yesterday morning, at 1 o'clock, a more destructive fire than the City of Newark has experienced for many years broke out in the large four-story building No. 7 Mechanic-street, occupied by Mr. Sauerbier as a tool factory. The Fire Department were promptly on hand, but the fire had communicated to the adjoining coach manufactory of Messrs. Turnbull & Gomersall, which, with its contents, was entirely destroyed before the fire could be arrested. On the east side of Turnbull's factory, a building occupied, as a lager-bier saloon was entirely destroyed, and part of a building used by Messrs. Gardner & Bonnel for storing mahogany, was burned, and the fire was here checked on the last. The building occupied by Mr. Sauerbier was full of stock and machinery, and his loss is about $20,000 -- insured for $5,500. The building and engine were owned by Mr. Hosmer, whose loss is about $5,000 -- insured for $2,750. The fourth story was occupied by J.C. Wesner, cabinet maker, and the third story by Messrs. T. & D. McNamara, who lost everything. The building occupied by Messrs. Turnbull & Gomersall was owned by Mr. Alexander Turnbull, valued at $7,000, insured for $4,000. Messrs. Turnbull & Gomersall's loss on ready made stock, fixtures, &c., is $9,000 -- insured for $3,000. Mr. N. Vanness's loss on stock, &c., is about $2,000 -- fully insured. The building is owned by Mr. John P. Jube, whose loss is $700 -- fully insured. Messrs. Gardner & Bonnell had $500 worth of lumber damaged and burned -- fully insured. The building, owned by Mr. M.L. Ward, was damaged to the amount of $200 -- insured. Total losses, $44,000. Insurance $18,600.

abstract: Just as we expected, and cautioned people against, cattle dealers, and owners also, were excited over the advance in the price of beef secured by the forestalling operations of the New-York dealers during two weeks past. The result is, we have had nearly five thousand head of beef cattle forced into this week's market, when less that four thousand head were really needed.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY EVENING, July 25, 1860.

abstract: The Republican Club of the Seventeenth Ward, Brooklyn, held a mass meeting in their wigwam at Greenpoint last evening. The wigwam was crowded to excess, and among the auditors were a number of ladies, Mr. Joint MCDERMOTT, in behalf of Mr. G.W. BAILEY, presented the Club an "original" walnut rail, ten feet long, split by Mr. LINCOLN some thirty years ago. It was placed on the platform. A certificate accompanied the rail, signed "JOHN his [???] mark HAWKS," stating that the rails were sent to JOHN HOPFER, at Springfield, and were from a lot of three thousand made by LINCOLN and HAWKS thirty years ago, at a place near Decatur, III. Mr. HOPPER's affidavit, that one of the rails described, was sent to JOHN N. STEARNS. At the conclusion of these proceedings GEO. W. CURTIS was introduced to the audience, and was heartily received. He commenced by referring to the prospects of the Republican cause on Long Island, and passed from that to the consideration of the Slavery question -- the agitation of which, he said, had been forced upon the country by the Democratic Party -- to the allegation that the Constitution authorizes Slavery, that the fathers of the Government disfavored the institution, and anticipated its gradual and peaceful abolition. He quoted as authority for this, STEPHENS, of Georgia, and BROOKS, of South Carolina. The recent threats of Mr. KEITT, he likened to the valient Chinese who, going to battle, send loud and discordant music before them, and if their enemies do not run away they run away themselves. Mr. DOUGLAS is held responsible for all the bloodshed in Kansas, and through him the Democratic Party.

abstract: Shortly before 12 o'clock yesterday noon as embarrassing a fire as any with which the firemen have ever contended, occurred in the cellar of the large brick warehouse, situated at the corner of Broad and Stone streets. Mr. SPENCER D.C. VAN BOKKELEN, a dealer in provisions and naval stores, occupied the entire premises, excepting the second floor, in which the business of R.R. BARTHOLD, commission merchant, was conducted.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 12 o'clock yesterday noon as embarrassing a fire as any with which the firemen have ever contended, occurred in the cellar of the large brick warehouse, situated at the corner of Broad and Stone streets. Mr. SPENCER D.C. VAN BOKKELEN, a dealer in provisions and naval stores, occupied the entire premises, excepting the second floor, in which the business of R.R. BARTHOLD, commission merchant, was conducted. In the cellar at the time was about ten thousand dollars' worth of property, the bulk of which consisted of barrels of spirits turpentine, resin, pitch, beeswax, tallow, lard, and other articles of almost as inflammable a nature. The first knowledge of the existence of the tire was obtained by the sudden belching from the cellar-door of a body of dense smoke, which caused an instantaneous alarm, and with their usual promptness the firemen assembled, and were at work.

abstract: In some important respects the John Brown invasion was a most fortunate occurrence. It has certainly had a very happy effect upon the politics of the country in several ways. In the first place, it challenged the attention of the whole North to the tendency of the ultra-Abolitionism of the day. It showed reflecting men in what direction the fierce harangues and denunciations of the fiery Anti-Slavery crusaders of the North were leading them. And it aroused the conservatism of the North -- the sober, sensible conservatism of the Republican Party -- and led at once to the practical repudiation of the ultra-abolition element which had been stealthily fastening itself upon that party, and assuming control of its policy, for some months previous. It brought the clear, high-toned, national, statesmanlike conservatism of Gov. SEWARD into direct antagonism with the frantic, fanatical treason of WENDELL PHILLIPS and his clan, and the result is partially seen in the position of strength and public confidence held by the Republican Party at the present moment.
lead_paragraph: In some important respects the John Brown invasion was a most fortunate occurrence. It has certainly had a very happy effect upon the politics of the country in several ways. In the first place, it challenged the attention of the whole North to the tendency of the ultra-Abolitionism of the day. It showed reflecting men in what direction the fierce harangues and denunciations of the fiery Anti-Slavery crusaders of the North were leading them. And it aroused the conservatism of the North -- the sober, sensible conservatism of the Republican Party -- and led at once to the practical repudiation of the ultra-abolition element which had been stealthily fastening itself upon that party, and assuming control of its policy, for some months previous. It brought the clear, high-toned, national, statesmanlike conservatism of Gov. SEWARD into direct antagonism with the frantic, fanatical treason of WENDELL PHILLIPS and his clan, and the result is partially seen in the position of strength and public confidence held by the Republican Party at the present moment.

abstract: The Bell and Everett party held their Convention at Dolton's Hall, a room capable of seating about 400 persons, and located directly opposite the American Hotel, the headquarters of the party. It was not a Convention of delegates, but a mass meeting of all who favored the election of BELL and EVERETT and stood upon the platform of the "Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws," Every County in the State was represented, and the attendants upon the Convention numbered not far from three hundred. The largest delegation was from Camden and numbered about fifty. They arrived about 11 o'clock A.M.; and, preceded by a band of music, marched from the depot to the American Hotel, where they were received by their brethren with repeated cheers. A caucus of the party was held at, 10 o'clock, at which the order of business of the Convention was arranged, and the time of meeting fixed at 12 o'clock M.
lead_paragraph: The Bell and Everett party held their Convention at Dolton's Hall, a room capable of seating about 400 persons, and located directly opposite the American Hotel, the headquarters of the party. A caucus of the party was held at, 10 o'clock, at which the order of business of the Convention was arranged, and the time of meeting fixed at 12 o'clock M.

abstract: The Richmond Whig warmly seconds the policy advocated by Gov. HUNT of substantially uniting the Bell and Douglas strength, -- though it has much more cogent reasons for doing so than our Ex-Governor. It insists that the main object of all lovers of the Constitution in the Southern States should be to defeat the Breckinridge ticket, which actually represents the Disunion sentiment of the South. Wherever, therefore, it can be done with any good result, the Whig says, the friends of DOUGLAS and BELL ought to unite in the South, so as to prevent the vote of any Southern State being given to BRECKINRIDGE. DOUGLAS himself, it urges, has not the slightest chance of an election by the people. His only hope lies in carrying the election to the House and being one of the three candidates whose names will be there presented. This can only be done by "squeezing BRECKINRIDGE out" -- and therefore it is for the interest of DOUGLAS that his friends should cast their votes for BELL in every Southern State which they have no hope of carrying themselves.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Whig warmly seconds the policy advocated by Gov. Wherever, therefore, it can be done with any good result, the Whig says, the friends of DOUGLAS and BELL ought to unite in the South, so as to prevent the vote of any Southern State being given to BRECKINRIDGE. DOUGLAS himself, it urges, has not the slightest chance of an election by the people. His only hope lies in carrying the election to the House and being one of the three candidates whose names will be there presented. This can only be done by "squeezing BRECKINRIDGE out" -- and therefore it is for the interest of DOUGLAS that his friends should cast their votes for BELL in every Southern State which they have no hope of carrying themselves.
