abstract: ABOUT THE DOG-POUND IN THE DOG-DAYS. -- If Launce -- SHAKSPEARE's Launce -- were living, and in New-York, he would have to keep tightly muzzled that unfortunate dog of his, which was bent upon making mischief wheresoever he went. Otherwise the boys of the Dog-pound would be after him, would deliver him incontinently to cruel men for the sum of 25 cents, and he would suffer death for the crime of being a waif and astray. The Dog-pound has its statistics, as well as the Mayor's Office, and from them we learn that the total number of dogs received since June 14 -- the first day of the present season that the law Trent into operation -- until the present time, is 3,007, at an expense to the City of $751 75, or one quarter apiece for dogs to which no quarter was given. The new regulations provide that no dog shall be received from boys; the boys catch the dogs and deliver them over to a class of men known as dog-brokers. These brokers, having an eye to business, preserve handsome, good-conditioned dogs, "Tray, Blanche and Sweetheart," from the condign death. They "take them up tenderly, lift them with care," and transport them to canine habitations, where they abide long enough to forget their former owners and localities, and are good for the late Fall trade among strangers. A Newfoundland dog, unless he is advanced in years, and his teeth might be greatly improved by a dentist, is never drowned. Old and toothless, he is sacrificed. An Isle of Skye terrier -- you might as well think of drowning a born prince! Good dog of any kind, capable of being sold to advantage, is never put to the disadvantage of a watery grave. But the curs, the mongrels, the ordinary biters, yelpers, snappers and barkers, the rough and tumble dogs, the whelps of low degree, -- at sunset on each day, 25 cents having been paid by the City for every canine son and daughter of them, the decree goes forth, the water is turned on, swimming is useless, and they die. From the days of Ulysses and Madoc, dogs have rendered such good service to mankind that it is hard to think of such an end for them, but they must be put to death notwithstanding, for hydrophobia is dreadful. One dog-broker, yesterday, drew $37, in the brightest fold, for 148 certificates for dogs delivered at the Pound to the Second Marshal. These are the canicular days now. Every dog has his day, and the Pound, every day, has many dogs. Those who value their canines must keep them at home, or well muzzle them. Care canem.

abstract: The next arrival from Honduras will no doubt bring definite information of the landing of Gen, WILLIAM WALKER, with a small party of adherents in Honduras, en route, via that isthmus and Guatemala, for his old stamping-ground. Nicaragua. This last attempt is evidently the renewal of WALKER's abortive expedition of the schooner Susan, which left Mobile about two years ago, and got wrecked in the effort to enter the port of Omoa, compelling the abandonment of the enterprise.

abstract: We have a word of rebuke and exhortation for the public. The Aldermen and Councilmen are shocked at the vulgar and impertinent curiosity which is manifested on every side to know the details of their little bill of $105,000 for "entertaining" the Japanese menagerie while in this City. Our City guardians cannot understand such silly and offensive prying into private affairs. They are not used to it. They have been in the habit of managing little matters of this sort in their own way; they are not accustomed to being catechised in this extraordinary manner about details with which the public has nothing whatever to do. Their dignity is touched; -- some of the more astute and quick-witted among them think their integrity has been suspected. BOOLE feels hurt, and some of his colleagues on the Committee do not hesitate to say that many of the remarks that have been made look like insinuations against their personal character.

abstract: DROWNED. -- Coroner GAFENEY held an inquest on Tuesday night on the body of a colored woman named ANNA ELIAS, who was found in the water at the foot of Essex-street, Jersey City. Deceased was about 40 years of age, and bad been employed on board the tow-boat Satellite as stewardess. It is supposed she was drowned while attempting to go on board on Saturday night. A verdict of "Found drowned" was rendered.
lead_paragraph: DROWNED. -- Coroner GAFENEY held an inquest on Tuesday night on the body of a colored woman named ANNA ELIAS, who was found in the water at the foot of Essex-street, Jersey City. abstract: The news of the acquittal of Judge TERRY, who slew BRODERICK, need excite no surprise. There is even less reason to doubt that the result was the fruit of pre-arrangement, than that the dead Senator fell the victim of a conspiracy of which TERRY was the instrument. From the moment of the man's arrest it was patent that his friends, including the whole political faction opposed to the political course of the murdered man, whose frank and daring honesty had been a constant ground of offence to the mercenary pensioners of the Administration, were resolved to see him scatheless out of the sanguinary scrape.

abstract: At this season, when John Bull is shaking in his boots with apprehension of red breeches, GARIBALDI knocking the shackles from oppressed Italy, and Spain, flushed with new conquests of the Moor, vainly thinks of renewing her supremacy in Mexico -- while Russia is again feeling the pulse of the "sick man," and Saxon and Gaul are teaching the science of war to the Tartar, we cannot, as sentinels of the public, be too watchful of the interests of our little Navy.
lead_paragraph: At this season, when John Bull is shaking in his boots with apprehension of red breeches, GARIBALDI knocking the shackles from oppressed Italy, and Spain, flushed with new conquests of the Moor, vainly thinks of renewing her supremacy in Mexico -- while Russia is again feeling the pulse of the "sick man," and Saxon and Gaul are teaching the science of war to the Tartar, we cannot, as sentinels of the public, be too watchful of the interests of our little Navy.

abstract: -- The Christian Banner, published at Fredericksburgh, Va., a paper devoted to the interests of Christianity and the South, is in a drooping condition. The editor is sick, and his subscribers do not seem inclined to pay up. Their delinquency seems to agitate his mind to such a degree that he cannot even shuffle off his load of mortality composedly. The leader, in which he "entreats" his non-paying friends, is a curious mosaic of matters relating to this world and the next. He closes the pathetic appeal as follows: "Our delinquent subscribers, it seems, are determined not to pay us, and we haven't got money to live on, much less to pay our debts and travel on. What the end will be we know not, and, if our debts were paid, we don't much care, we've got a clear conscience, shaped and formed by the Word of God, and having done all we can, and the best we can, we humbly and calmly resign all into the hands of Him who will measure out to every man according as his works shall be. Come, friends, pay up, pay up, do pray pay up your debts, and if we die, let us die in piece."If the subscribers to the Christian Banner do not immediately come forward, they are indeed more senseless things than either stocks or stones. It is a pity that the editor should not be allowed the luxury of paying his debts, to say nothing of having "money to live on and travel on." The motto of the Banner is "onward and upward," yet its friends should not allow it to financially "go up." Where are the chivalry?
lead_paragraph: -- The Christian Banner, published at Fredericksburgh, Va., a paper devoted to the interests of Christianity and the South, is in a drooping condition. abstract: The whole civilized world will be glad to learn that France and England, deeming the claims of humanity stronger than the obligations of a traditional policy, have resolved to interfere for the protection of the Christian subjects of the Ottoman Empire. It is to be hoped that this interference will be no mere pretence, and that the atrocities so recently committed in Asiatic Turkey will not only be checked, but that some substantial guarantee against future outbreaks will be secured. It is a suggestive fact that the Anglo-French fleet now in the harbor of Beyrout has been dispatched there to over-ride that same weak and despicable authority, which the Western Powers a few short years ago so carefully endeavored to prop up. Their present attitude tells, in language not to be mistaken, that even they are convinced how foolish and how useless were their efforts to sustain a decayed and broken-down despotism. The Emperor NICHOLAS spoke truth when he described Turkey as "the Sick Man." France and England may have prolonged his life by a brief span, hut his dissolution they could not avert. The folly of supposing that the supremacy of ABDUL MEDJID was ever worth fighting for is now made practically clear to every looker on; and the presence of a foreign fleet, for the protection of the Porte's own subjects, in the roads of Beyrout, is almost an admission that the Crimean war was a huge mistake.
lead_paragraph: The whole civilized world will be glad to learn that France and England, deeming the claims of humanity stronger than the obligations of a traditional policy, have resolved to interfere for the protection of the Christian subjects of the Ottoman Empire. Their present attitude tells, in language not to be mistaken, that even they are convinced how foolish and how useless were their efforts to sustain a decayed and broken-down despotism. abstract: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Saturday, July 21, 1860. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE'S carefully-prepared speech  at Frankfort, on the 18th, is much criticised. It is regarded as an electioneering appeal to Kentuckians ostensibly for "the great cause," but really for his embarrassed and rather despondent self.

abstract: The Tribune states that surveyors, employed by the State Commissioners of the Land Office, are now in this City, surveying the lands made by filling out in the North and East Rivers beyond the line of low-water mark, which is the boundary of the City and the limit of its ownership. They are doing this under the law of last Winter, designed to define the claim of the State to these lands, -- and authorizing their sale to the City at a price to be fixed by the Commissioners of the Land Office, or, if the City declines to purchase, then at auction to the highest bidder. Of the general effect of this law the Tribune says:

abstract: This Committee held a session yesterday afternoon in Room No. 8 City Hall -- CHAS. G. CORNELL, Esq., Chairman, presiding, and Messrs. GILBERT M. PLATT and GEO. ETARR, members of the Committee, present. Mr. Williams, Treasurer of the Children's Aid Society, appeared before the Committee in regard to an appropriation of $3,000 which amount has already been passed by the Board of Councilmen, and referred to this Committee for action. Messrs. Williams and Brace stated that the amount expended by the Society amounted to $80,000, all of which was raised by private donations. This demand on the City was the first that the Society ever made, and they hoped that they should never have to apply again. The Committee promised to take these facts into consideration and report at the next meeting of the Board. Several other minor matters were disposed of and the Committee adjourned.

abstract: It seems we were slightly mistaken in supposing that no steps would be taken to resist payment of the nice little bill of $105,000 which the Common Council Committee have brought in against the City for "entertaining" the Japanese. Mr. LEVI S. CHATFIELD, as a City tax-payer, has stepped forward and applied for an injunction to restrain the Comptroller from paying the bill.
lead_paragraph: It seems we were slightly mistaken in supposing that no steps would be taken to resist payment of the nice little bill of $105,000 which the Common Council Committee have brought in against the City for "entertaining" the Japanese. Mr. LEVI S. CHATFIELD, as a City tax-payer, has stepped forward and applied for an injunction to restrain the Comptroller from paying the bill. Notice has been served upon that officer informing him that the motion will be made on the first Monday of August, at the Special Term of the Supreme Court. The following is the COMPLAINT, in which Mr. CHATFIELD sets forth at length the reasons on which it is based:

abstract: At a Republican meeting held at St. Louis, on the 23d, Hon. F.P. STANTON, of Kansas, made a speech. He said he was present, at the request of Mr. BLAIR, to assist in some measure to return him to the seat in Congress which he had vacated. Mr. BLAIR needs no vindication from me. He has a reputation all over this country; he has a national reputation, and can better serve your local interests by reason of that national reputation, than almost any man you could send to Congress; and not only to serve your local interests, but also to serve this nation. He can assist to elevate St. Louis to that high position which she is destined to hold in this Confederacy, and make her honored everywhere. There is, gentlemen, in my bosom a fellow feeling that binds me to your gallant representative, and that is a concurrence in the policy of sending the free blacks to some part of Central or South America, where they can be separated and left to elevate themselves, and to relieve this country of their presence. Some years ago I had the honor of representing in Congress, a neighboring city, which although not quite so large as St. Louis, is fast assuming a great importance in the history of the Mississippi Valley. I mean the City of Memphis, Tennessee. When I held the post of Chairman of the Naval Committee, I reported a bill to the House that was afterwards nicknamed "The Ebony Line of Steamers." It proposed to establish a line of steamers to the coast of Africa to assist the Colonization Society to transport free blacks desirous of emigrating to that country to reach it. It would have relieved us of a burden that is now seriously felt. But it failed to pass, and that was the last of it. Neither Mr. BLAIR's proposition nor mine proposed in the least to interfere with the rights of slaveholders, or with slave property. It was only to enable free blacks emancipated by their masters, or born free, to escape from a community not congenial to them, and go to a country where the race could be regenerated. This circumstance tends to form a bond of connection and sympathy between Mr. BLAIR and myself. Rut his reputation, his talents, his bravery and ability ought to be better known to you, among whom he has labored, than to me, and that is the stronger reason to induce you and me, and all men to labor to return him to the position he so nobly abandoned. [Applause, during which a small boy attempted to raise a feeble cheer for DICK BARRET.] He is not the man I know to dodge a vote or say he can't vote because he don't understand the question. I vouch for the fact that he will make himself familiar with everything upon which he may be called to vote. He never has been and never will be caught in such a condition as to be obliged to confess that he doesn't understand a question, and therefore bolt it.

abstract: The Independent is evidently inclined to keep Dr. CHEEVER exclusively for its own castigation. It has been very severe upon his course in soliciting British aid in support of his church, but is greatly distressed that the TIMES should have given heed to its own statement, that he permitted a slaveholder to belong to his church, while he was denouncing slaveholding as a crime. The Independent dwells especially upon the fact that Dr. C.'s accusers in this matter are anonymous, -- although the lady, who who was the slaveholder referred to, is herself the authority for what has been said. It is true, as our neighbor alleges, that Dr. C. is a clergyman, and that his veracity should not, therefore, be lightly questioned. But the Independent will very cheerfully concede that he is not infallible, and that his assertions are not to be taken as conclusive in his own behalf, against the testimony of others equally respectable.

abstract: The late Rev. Dr. Van Rensselaer, of Burlington, N.J., was of the Van Rensselaer family of Albany, and a prominent divine of the Presbyterian Church. A Philadelphia paper says: "As editor of the Presbyterian Magazine, and Secretary of one of the Boards of that Church, the deceased was liberal, courteous, active and efficient, and his loss will be a great one to the councils of the denomination In this city, where his office was located, he was esteemed as in the very highest sense a Christian gentleman, using the words in their profoundest meaning. Though engaged in polemics, by virtue of his position, none of his friends have borne higher testimony to his high sense of fairness and honor, than have these who have been opposed to him."

abstract: occurred at the St. Nicholas Hotel, between a man named PURFIL, residing at No. 15 Amity-street, and a Philadelphian named HYMAN, resulting in the stabbing of the farmer. It appears that' angry words passed between them in the bar-room, when PURFIL raised his cane to strike HYMAN, and the latter drew a large bowie-knife and plunged it into the back of the farmer twice, Capt. HELMS, of the Eighth Ward Police, was promptly upon the spot, and had the wounded man removed to the drug-store of RUSHTION & CLARK, where his wounds were dressed, and he was conveyed home. HYMAN was locked up to await the result of the injuries inflicted.

abstract: Hartford Times states that Dr. BUTLER, the Superintendent of the Retreat for the Insane in that city, has projected an admirable plan for increasing the comfort of his patients. He proposes to establish a conservatory, a bowling-alley, a museum and reading-room, in connection with she Institution; to provide a melodeon for the Chapel, and a piano for the amusement hall; and to decorate the grounds. Messrs, OLMSTED and VAUX, the Superintendent and architect of the New-York Central Park, have examined the grounds of the Retreat, and pronounce their capacity for landscape effect to be second to no other grounds of similar extent in New-England. Mr. OLMSTED has made and presented to Dr. BUTLER an artistic and beautiful plan for this purpose, which fully develops the natural beauties of the lawn. It has been adopted by the Directors. A careful estimate of the total cost shows that all these improvements may be secured at an outlay not exceeding $12,000. Dr. BUTLER solicits aid to raise this sum. The first subscription (from Chief Justice WILLIAMS) is $1,000.

abstract: -- The Providence Journal says: "If we may judge by the number of communications which we have received, there is a deep and growing interest in the effort which our citizens are now making to secure a fitting monument to ROGER WILLIAMS. As was to be expected, there is a great diversity of opinion respecting the form of the memorial which should be reared in his honor. The Committee who have the matter in charge have deemed it best to have a lofty shaft crowning Prospect Hill, and standing hear the spot where his remains rested so long. Some men prefer that we should show our appreciation of him by founding some great benevolent institution, with which his name should be forever lovingly linked."
lead_paragraph: -- The Providence Journal says: "If we may judge by the number of communications which we have received, there is a deep and growing interest in the effort which our citizens are now making to secure a fitting monument to ROGER WILLIAMS. As was to be expected, there is a great diversity of opinion respecting the form of the memorial which should be reared in his honor. The Committee who have the matter in charge have deemed it best to have a lofty shaft crowning Prospect Hill, and standing hear the spot where his remains rested so long. Some men prefer that we should show our appreciation of him by founding some great benevolent institution, with which his name should be forever lovingly linked."

abstract: of the escape of forty convicts from the Missouri Penitentiary on the 23d inst. The fellows made a simultaneous attack upon the gate of the prison, and succeeded in forcing it open and effecting their escape. Twenty of them were recaptured, and about twenty more of them are still at large. In the effort seven were severely wounded and three were killed outright by the guards of the prison -- At the House of Refuge, Rochester, N.Y., a similar stampede occurred on the 24th. Just after dinner, when the boys were in the yard, they pried open the rear gate, and about one hundred rushed out; and took to the fields in all directions for liberty. Mr. WOOD, the Superintendent, was in the city at the time this affair occurred, and knew nothing of it for some time after. The boys left in the Refuge were secured and all the employes of the concern who could be scared started in pursuit of the fugitives. A messenger came to the city and called upon the Police to go out in search of the boys.

Mr. WOOD, the Superintendent, was in the city at the time this affair occurred, and knew nothing of it for some time after. The boys left in the Refuge were secured and all the employes of the concern who could be scared started in pursuit of the fugitives. abstract: BURGLARIES. The house of Mr. MIGRA, NO. 403 Pacific-street, was entered by burglars on Wednesday night. After looking about the premises awhile, and finding nothing valuable that they could conveniently get hold of, the thieves carried away a portfolio containing important papers....At an early hour yesterday morning the office of P. CASSIDY, iron founder, on ...
lead_paragraph: BURGLARIES. -- The house of Mr. MIGRA, NO. 403 Pacific-street, was entered by burglars on Wednesday night. After looking about the premises awhile, and finding nothing valuable that they could conveniently get hold of, the thieves carried away a portfolio containing important papers....At an early hour yesterday morning the office of P. CASSIDY, iron founder, on Bridge-street, near the East River, was entered by thieves, who forced the safe open with gun-powder, and obtained $3 only for their trouble....On Wednesday afternoon, the house of GEO. GORMAN, on Classon, near Atlantic-avenue, was robbed of property valued at $200. One of the thieves was arrested by the Ninth Precinct Police, soon after he left the premises, and nearly all of the stolen property was recovered.....A carpenter-shop on First-place was also entered on Wednesday night, and a quantity of tools taken away......On Tuesday night the store of SCRANTON & Co., No. 130 Atlantic-street, was entered and robbed of $50 in pennies. Four boys were arrested yesterday on suspicion of having committed this burglary.... House No. 68 South First-street was robbed Wednesday afternoon, of property valued at $150.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Baltimore Sun states that Col. CLEMSON, whose departure for Europe for the purchase of seeds, etc., for the Patent-office, was also commissioned by Gov. THOMAS of Maryland, to procure a stock specially adapted to the wants of that State. It is intended to purchase large amounts of Mediterranean wheat, Italian barley, rye, &c. The Cork oak acorn, the Persian walnut, madder, &c., will also form a portion of the importations. Some of these interesting, articles will not, however, be ready for another year, and a few varieties of difficult germination will be sown in the propagating houses attached to the agricultural division and be distributed later in the form of young plants.

abstract: DEMOCRATIC TROUBLES IN VIRGINIA. -- The Virginians of the Kanawha District have had dissension sown in their ranks by one BROWN. At a general gathering in the Court-house of the County, July 16, a series of resolutions was introduced which praised BRECKINRIDGE and LANE in extravagant terms, but before the question could be taken, Mr. JAMES H. BROWN, representing neither BRECKINRIDGE nor DOUGLAS, but the "Union" Party of the County, offered a new set of resolutions as a substitute, declaring it to be the duty of "every true Democrat" to harmonize the dissensions in the party, "rather than by family bickering, to widen and deepen them." The introduction of these conflicting sets distracted the Democracy, but after much heated discussion, Mr. BROWN's substitute was knocked overboard, and the action of the Baltimore Seceders endorsed by a majority of the meeting.
lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATIC TROUBLES IN VIRGINIA. -- The Virginians of the Kanawha District have had dissension sown in their ranks by one BROWN. BROWN, representing neither BRECKINRIDGE nor DOUGLAS, but the "Union" Party of the County, offered a new set of resolutions as a substitute, declaring it to be the duty of "every true Democrat" to harmonize the dissensions in the party, "rather than by family bickering, to widen and deepen them." The introduction of these conflicting sets distracted the Democracy, but after much heated discussion, Mr. BROWN's substitute was knocked overboard, and the action of the Baltimore Seceders endorsed by a majority of the meeting.

abstract: The Cincinnati Gazette has a long story of a complicated swindle. One CHAS. OLIVE is under bonds in Cincinnati, to answer for the double crime of forgery and mail-robbery, under the following circumstances: "One of the counts was that he had forged letters and a draft upon certain parties in Cincinnati, and Springfield, Ind. Rev. Mr. SCOTT, a Methodist preacher of Ireland, was raising funds for the Protestant cause in that country, and at Springfield, Ind., notes were given him by HENRY O'BYRNE, JAS. LYTLE, and ERRIC RICHMAN, each for $100, payable in June.

abstract: The taking of the census in some of the lower Wards of Philadelphia, according to the Ledger, exhibits many strange phases of human life, particularly in the vicinity of Bedford, Small, and other streets of a like character. In the space from the south side of South-street, to the north side of Fitzwater, and between Twelfth and Thirteenth streets, the population foots up 2,000. The houses occupied by them are generally three-room buildings, and in most of them a family occupies each room; this is particularly the case in one row, where the proprietor rents them only by rooms. In some of these houses the occupants appear to be comfortable, notwithstanding their close quarters, but in others there appears to be difficulty in getting along. In Emeline-street, which is the negro quarter, may be found a white woman with a husband formerly a slave in Delaware, and in another place two white men had the honor of giving the names of two colored women as their lawful wives. In some of the cellars the most abject poverty is apparent, the occupants, black and white, fraternizing together, being engaged in bone and rag-picking, the result of the day's labor being in one corner of their wretched room, while the individuals occupy the other.
lead_paragraph: The taking of the census in some of the lower Wards of Philadelphia, according to the Ledger, exhibits many strange phases of human life, particularly in the vicinity of Bedford, Small, and other streets of a like character. The houses occupied by them are generally three-room buildings, and in most of them a family occupies each room; this is particularly the case in one row, where the proprietor rents them only by rooms. In some of these houses the occupants appear to be comfortable, notwithstanding their close quarters, but in others there appears to be difficulty in getting along. In Emeline-street, which is the negro quarter, may be found a white woman with a husband formerly a slave in Delaware, and in another place two white men had the honor of giving the names of two colored women as their lawful wives. In some of the cellars the most abject poverty is apparent, the occupants, black and white, fraternizing together, being engaged in bone and rag-picking, the result of the day's labor being in one corner of their wretched room, while the individuals occupy the other.

abstract: MAN, the Poughkeepsie wife-poisoner attempted to escape from the jail at Poughkeepsie a night or two since. He crawled through the gruf hole of his door. The hole was small, but, by stripping himself naked, he managed to get through. He had placed his clothes within reach from the outside, and had broken a heavy chair and armed himself with one of the legs, determined to resist all who might attempt to stop him. The other prisoners heard him and gave the alarm, when Mr. PALMER, the jailor, and officer SPARKS, went up stairs and seized him. He was taken back to his cell and chained to the floor.
lead_paragraph: MAN, the Poughkeepsie wife-poisoner attempted to escape from the jail at Poughkeepsie a night or two since. He crawled through the gruf hole of his door. abstract: A NEW ENGINE. -- On Wednesday a Committee from Engine Company No. 1 of Jersey City visited Philadelphia and purchased a magnificent double-deck engine, which is said to be lavishly decorated, and every way a superior machine. It will be brought home some two weeks hence, when the Company are to receive a fitting reception from the Department. This Company have in their possession an "old goose neck," and the first engine ever used in Jersey City, it having been in active service since 1829.

abstract: by Mr. SICKLES to state, in reply to the announcement made in our columns yesterday, on behalf, of Mr. WOOD, "that the Mayor has not altered his relations with Mr. SICKLES, and would not, under any circumstances, support him for Congress;" that Mr. SICKLES has not yet determined whether or not he will be a candidate for reelection to Congress; and although he will consult respectfully the wishes of his constituents upon this subject, his decision will not be influenced in the least either by the opposition or the support of Hon. FERNANDO WOOD. Mr. SICKLES is also somewhat surprised at the avowal of Mr. WOOD's opposition, as he is not a resident of the district, and Mr. S. has not solicited his aid. -- Daily News.

abstract: The Pony Express, with advices from San Francisco to the 11th inst., four days later, arrived at St. Josephs, Mo., yesterday. The steamer Sonora sailed for Panama on the same day on which the Express left, having on board upwards of a million in treasure, of which $983,000 is destined for this City. No mails were taken on board the Sonora, and all mail matter for Mexico, Central America, the Isthmus, South America and the West Indies, was forwarded by express. The Democratic politicians in California were in the greater state of anxiety relative to the proceedings of the Baltimore Convention, the latest news received there being only to the time of the organization -- the expresses and mails being all behind time. There is no mining news from Carson Valley. Great numbers of emigrants were arriving there from Salt Lake. Later advices are received from British Columbia, but they present no feature of special interest. The Puget's Sound Indians and the Coast Indians were amusing themselves by butchering each other. News is also received from the Sandwich Islands. The Hawaiian Legislature was in session. The various departments of the Government were reported to be in a satisfactory condition.

abstract: We have to record another another great fire in Poughkeepsie, making the third conflagration -- serious in extent, and yet more serious in connection with the suspicions to which they give rise -- that has occurred in that town within the past three days. There can be no doubt that each of these destructive fires was the work of incendiaries. It will be well for the good citizens of Poughkeepsie, at once to form a nocturnal Vigilance Committee, and preserve what property is left to them.

abstract: We mentioned briefly a day or two since that an imposing demonstration in favor of DOUGLAS had been made in New-Orleans. For some unexplained reason the full report of that meeting did not appear in the local Press until three days afterwards. The True Delta finally gave the particulars, with reports of the speeches made on the occasion by Hon. PIERRE SOULE and Mr. JOHN FORSYTH. abstract: in the education of deaf mutes will be glad to learn that measures have been taken for the relief of members of that unfortunate class who reside in California. The San Francisco Bulletin has the following: "Taking advantage of an invitation by one of the managers of the Deaf and Dumb and Blind Institution, we yesterday paid it a visit, and were so much interested by what we there saw, that we are induced to call the attention of the public to the subject, convinced that so soon as our readers generally are made aware of the existence of this school for the education of deaf mutes and the blind, they will contribute liberally to its support. It was only during the last session of the Legislature, that an appropriation of $10,000 was made for the erection in San Francisco of a suitable building for the accommodation of the deaf and dumb and blind. This will be done as soon as possible; but, in the meantime, a small house has been rented at No. 17 Tehama street, and here the school was first opened some six weeks ago. There are at present but nine pupils, four of whom are girls; but three more are to enter next week. These are all deaf mutes. They are under the tuition of Mr. CRANDELL, who is himself deaf and dumb. The class for the blind will be opened in a fortnight, a good teacher having been already engaged. Of these nine scholars four reside at the school, (two of them indeed have no other home,) while the remainder live with their parents or guardians in town."

abstract: The city is full of strangers to-night, and great excitement prevails. The Hartford Wide-Awakes, numbering 500 men, turned out, and in torch-light procession paraded on the Park. They received the Newark Wide-Awakes, numbering 300, at 10 o'clock, and, accompanied by thousands, they marched through the city, entering the City Hall at 11. There they gave a splendid banquet to their visitors. The Hall was beautifully decorated by the ladies of Hartford.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: Times, 21st, says: "We are again called upon to record a case of kidnapping in this vicinity. Two free negro men have resided for the last six months in the South part of this county, with Mrs. SAMPSON, a colored woman, near the Delaware Mission. They were banished from Arkansas under the recent law, and have been industriously employed all the season in raising a crop of corn. On Wednesday night the house of Mrs. SAMPSON was broken into by three men, the negroes seized and forced into a close carriage and driven off in the direction of Delaware. No paper or authority was shown. The residence and names of the captors are unknown, but suspicion points to the same men who captured HOPE KUNARD. These negro men had certificates of good character from several men in Arkansas, and certificates of freedom from the clerk of one of the courts, which had been exhibited to several white persons in the vicinity."

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN -- There was no failing off to the throng of visitors yesterday, on board this leviathan of the deep, but there was a great scattering in the afternoon, when the storm came on. The rush for shelter was an event to be remembered, and inasmuch as all who were on deck could not get into the saloon entrances, or down the stairs of the engine rooms, or in among the donkey engines, or in fact anywhere where shelter was promised, at one time, the pushing and squeezing may be faintly guessed at, but cannot be fitly told. The huge awnings kept off the fierce torrent pretty well, the water, as it poured off their edges, making a cataract on all sides of very respectable appearance. Almost everybody, except those' who were to fortunate as to have been exploring the saloons, state-rooms, holds, engine, wheel or steering rooms, at the time, suffered considerably, but crinoline came off the worst. Not a few fair ladies resembled, as a wicked scoffer expressed it. "barn door pullets, considerably drenched." When the storm, after raging for about an hour, subsided, things in general had a bedraggled appearance. Previous to the commencement of the storm, about 3 o'clock, about 15,100 persons had gone aboard. During the storm, and subsequently, comparatively few arrived. Respecting the Cape May trip, on Monday next, over 590 tickets have been sold. The staterooms are reserved for the exclusive accommodation of ladies. Gentlemen will have an extensive choice of berths. The steamer Delaware will accompany the Great Eastern, and will keep up with her -- if she can. The Philadelphia papers are advertising numerous excursion parties to Cape May for Tuesday next, to see the wonder.

abstract: That straggling little hamlet out on Long Island, known by the ambitious title of "East New-York," the habitation of some dozens of voters, and the terminus of two horse-railroads, was to have been the theatre of a grand political demonstration yesterday afternoon, if it hadn't rained. A Breckinridge ratification meeting was advertised to come off there at 3 o'clock, when a Breckinridge pole was to have been raised in front of the "Kings County Hotel," which should point a good deal higher than any church-steeple in that neighborhood -- so high, indeed, that it should greet the sun in his coming, and the rays of departing day should linger and play not vainly on its vane. But all this fun and patriotism was put a stop to by a most untimely shower, which sprung up about 2 1/2 o'clock, and did not cease its outpourings until it had bathed the entire hamlet and all its inhabitants in a miniature specimen of a deluge. The nomination of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE accordingly remains unratified by the East New-Yorkers, and the "pole," that was to have reared its head against the sky, lies supine upon the ground, waiting for a more auspicious day.

abstract: Peter O'Brennan, aged 18 years, was arrested on Wednesday evening, charged with stealing two engraved copper plates of the Map of Canada from the store of Mr. E.H. Ensign, No. 156 William-st. The plates were valued at $500. The prisoner confessed having sold them to John Levy, a junk dealer, at No. 37 Frankfort-street, for $3. They were found in Levy's shop, and he was, in his turn, arrested as a "receiver," and, together with Brennan, was locked up by Justice WELSH for trial.

abstract: (N.C.) Express states that the case of SOLOMON HALL's will occupied the Supreme Court of that county eight days, and was finally compromised after the Jury had retired. Mr. HALL had made a will leaving one hundred negroes and other property to his only child, a daughter, who afterwards married Mr. NEELY against his wish, whereupon he made another will, leaving his negroes free, and leaving most of his property to them. The suit was to set aside the last will. An hour after the case had gone to the Jury, Mrs. NEELY proposed to receive $13,000 and $2,000 which the will gives her, the estate to pay the Court cost, $800. She is to pay her own lawyer $5,000. The proposition was adopted. The negroes will be sent to Liberia. The Jury stood nine against and three for the will; but it is said the Judge would have set aside the verdict if it had been against the will.

abstract: At "sharp six" o'clock yesterday morning the Second Company, National Guard, was ordered out for the purpose of receiving the Chicago Zouaves on their return from Boston and escorting them to West Point, and about fifty men responded at that very early hour for New-Yorkers, assembling at Pier No. 2, North River. Soon after the appointed time the steamer Connecticut, of the Norwich and Worcester line, ...
lead_paragraph: At "sharp six" o'clock yesterday morning the Second Company, National Guard, was ordered out for the purpose of receiving the Chicago Zouaves on their return from Boston and escorting them to West Point, and about fifty men responded at that very early hour for New-Yorkers, assembling at Pier No. 2, North River. Soon after the appointed time the steamer Connecticut, of the Norwich and Worcester line, having the Zouaves on board, hove in sight, and was greeted with a round salute from the twelve-pounders brought to the spot for the occasion. As soon as the Connecticul was made fast to the whar[???] the Zouaves marched ashore, headed by Col. ELLSWORTH, and were received with the customary ceremonies. Both companies then boarded the steamer Taminend. lying at the end of the pier, and chartered for the occasion, where, after dispensing with their more cumbersome equipments, they partook of a hearty breakfast, prepared under the supervision of GUSTAVUS RATZ, a member of the First Company. The Taminend started at 7 A.M., and the tardiness of her progress soon convinced the passengers that there was little possibility of returning -- as was first contemplated -- in time for the Philadelphia boat.

abstract: If our Government has not already disposed of all the antiquated and unseaworthy vessels which figure in our Navy list, an admirable opportunity for employing them now presses upon the attention of the country. The latest advices from Hong Kong announce the departure from that port of a large British force, bound for the Pei-ho. Chusan had already been occupied by the French and English forces -- the French, alert as usual, taking advantage of the hesitating steps of their allies to seize upon the best portions of the island, and hoisting the Imperial tri-color over the very stone walls which were painfully erected by the English for their own accommodation, at the time when they seized upon Chusan dining the previous operations.

abstract: MR. GUTHRIE. -- We published a day or two since Mr. DILLAYE's statement in regard to the circumstances of his arrest and trial at Pittsburgh on a charge of forgery, and the political motives which, as he alleged, were at the bottom of the whole proceeding, We made this publication as an act of justice to Mr. DILLAYE, who complained of the injury done him by the original publication of the case in the columns of the TIMES. It can scarcely be necessary to state that we had no thought or intention of indorsing his allegations against the individuals whom he supposed to be concerned in his persecutions. His resentment was especially directed against Mr. J.B. GUTHRIE, who had been employed in the Treasury Department as a Secret Agent of the Government, and upon whose charges Mr. DILLAYE had been removed from his position as Appraiser. We know nothing whatever of the character or conduct of Mr. GUTHRIE in this matter, and are certainly not in the least inclined to give any countenance or support to the aspersions upon them contained in the letter of Mr. DILLAYE. We leave his statements to rest exclusively, so far as we are concerned, upon his own responsibility.

abstract: To the intelligent foreigner, who has studied DE TOCQUEVILLE, and looks with interest at the working of American institutions, the most striking peculiarity of the actual Presidential canvass must be the professed readiness of popular leaders to defeat the popular will. Of the six candidates named, two alone calculate upon and work for an election by the people.
lead_paragraph: To the intelligent foreigner, who has studied DE TOCQUEVILLE, and looks with interest at the working of American institutions, the most striking peculiarity of the actual Presidential canvass must be the professed readiness of popular leaders to defeat the popular will. Of the six candidates named, two alone calculate upon and work for an election by the people. The remainder, while professing absolute allegiance to the democratic principle, pretend to base their hopes of elevation to office upon the defeat of the popular will, and an election to be effected in one or the other branch of Congress of some candidate against whom a majority of the people will have pronounced. Setting aside the audacity of those who are now appealing to the masses of the people for suffrages which it is their design, if practicable, to nullify and dispense with, and the circumstance that a provision inserted in the Constitution as a last resort, to save the country from anarchy in case the people fail to elect, is to be used like a clever rule of legerdemain to make a President of the last man whom two-thirds of his countrymen would wish to see in that office, it may be worth while to inquire carefully into the probable result of this disfranchisement of thirty millions of population. And it is important in this connection to remember that the politicians who adopt this policy are those who are loudest in their professions of attachment to the Union, and in their assertions that its salvation is the disinterested aim of their labors.

abstract: Every one who has had to swallow his daily dose of quinine, ipecac, cod-liver oil, or any of the nauseous drugs that fill the pharmacopoeia, must have heartily echoed the line of Macbeth: "Throw physic to the dogs I'll none of it!" and will be delighted to learn that Dr. THOMOSON, of Philadelphia, who has been investigating the question of neutralizing the nauseous taste of drugs, has come to the conclusion that the taste ...
lead_paragraph: Every one who has had to swallow his daily dose of quinine, ipecac, cod-liver oil, or any of the nauseous drugs that fill the pharmacopoeia, must have heartily echoed the line of Macbeth: "Throw physic to the dogs I'll none of it!" and will be delighted to learn that Dr. THOMOSON, of Philadelphia, who has been investigating the question of neutralizing the nauseous taste of drugs, has come to the conclusion that the taste of nearly ever article in the materia medica may be either nullified or masked without interfering at all with its essential properties; and consequently that physicians have no right to ask a patient to swallow loathsome potions when the same medicines can be given without offending the most delicate pala[???]es. We hail this as the harbinger of brighter days in the sick room, when the visit of the physician will no longer be looked forward to with dread as the prelude to some potion that would turn the stomach of a hyena.

abstract: The Lafayette (Ind.) Journal has a long account of the elopement of a farmer's daughter with a "traveling, merchant," one O.S. BERRY. It seems tha BERRY, some weeks ago, sold a cider mill to a very respectable farmer in Clinton County, named MARTIN, who has "two fair daughters," aged respectively 20 and 17, and three stalwart sons. BERRY, by his smooth talk, at once made friends with the family, and a decided impression on the youngest daughter. The parents invited him to visit the house whenever convenient, an invitation which was accepted. Since that time he has been in the habit of calling once or twice a week, when he was treated in the most hospitable manner. On Saturday last, he invited the young lady, to whom he had been paying particular attention, to take a walk, and while out persuaded her to elope with him, making an appointment to meet her on Tuesday morning, when they would go to Lafayette and take the 2:20 A.M. train for Chicago, where the nuptial rites could be solemnized. Making an excuse to visit a neighbor, the young lady met him at the time appointed, and the two reached Lafayette Tuesday evening, and took quarters at a private boarding-house, where BERRY had been in the habit of stopping when, in the city. By some means the father learned that his daughter was not at the neighbor's she had proposed to visit, but had been soon in a buggy with BERRY. Suspecting all was not right, himself and sons started out to hunt the missing daughter, and traced the couple to Lafayette.

abstract: During the present Summer two young ladies from the City of New-York were visiting at the residence of the Superintendent of the Great Forest Impiovement Company's mines, in the Schuylkill coal region. The younger was but eighteen years of age, and both possessed that love of adventure which appears natural to a city belle when relieved from the contracted and confining influences of metropolitan life. After sojourning some weeks amid the wild and beautiful scenery of "Woodside," they became anxious for a novel excitement, and determined to "go down into a mine." This idea once conceived, could not be reasoned away; into a mine they must go, and the deepest one must be selected for the excursion.

abstract: The Young Men's National Union Club met at their rooms, No. 654 Broadway, last evening, for the purpose of ratifiing the action of the Convention which met recently at Utica. The chair was occupied by E.P. NORTON, Esq., and Mr.H.H. ALDEN acted as Secretary. On calling the meeting to order,
lead_paragraph: The Young Men's National Union Club met at their rooms, No. 654 Broadway, last evening, for the purpose of ratifiing the action of the Convention which met recently at Utica. The chair was occupied by E.P. NORTON, Esq., and Mr.H.H. ALDEN acted as Secretary. On calling the meeting to order, the President regretted that sickness and other satisfactory causes had prevented the attendance of the speakers who had been selected for the occasion, and that the want of publicity and the weather combined, should have resulted in a meagre assemblage. He said, however, that another time would be named and published on which the speakers selected might be heard. He then reviewed the positions of the other parties in the field, and concluded with the declaration that the main object of the Republican Party, in continuing the agitation of the Slavery question, was to embitter the North against the South; that the National Union Party sought a restoration of peace and harmony; and that with that object in view, the National Union men were willing to cooperate with any set of men who would adopt Union principles. In proof of what he had said in relation to the objects of the Republican Party, he stated that the Republican Executive Committee at Washington was flooding the country with the speeches of Messrs. SUMNER and LOVEJOY.

abstract: August Hampt, a German, was arrested yesterday, and committed to prison on a charge of embezzlement, preferred by Herman F. Polhman, keeper of a shirt-store at No. 396 Pearl-street, by whom he was formerly employed. In connection with his store, Polhman carried on a laundry business at No. 61 Rose-street, and installed the accused as foreman of the washerwomen. In this capacity his services were satisfactory to his employer, who believed him to be honest, and therefore regretted when, at the end of a few months, he tendered his resignation. During the present week, however, Hampt informed Polhman, through the medium of a friend, that he had filched various sums of money amounting in the aggregate to $150, from him while he was in charge of the laundry; and his conscience was so troubled that he desired to make restitution. Polhman was surprised at the message, but saw in it a clue to the perpetrator of another swindle upon himself, whereby he had lost twenty dozen shirts, valued at $175. He accordingly caused the arrest of the conscience-smitten Hampt on a charge of having stolen the garments, but the accused asserts that although guilty of embezzlement, the other accusation is unfounded.

abstract: will be a meeting at St. Nicholas Hall, Saratoga, on next Tuesday, of the Young Men's Democratic State Convention. A full delegation from this City, and delegates from all the Counties in the State will be in attendance. It is expected that interesting speeches will be made, and the action of the body is regarded with a good deal of interest, as both the Breckinridge and Douglas men feel confident of possessing a majority in the body. J. AUGUSTUS PAGE is Chairman, and J.W. CORLIES Secretary of the Young Men's State Central Committee, and on them will devolve the primary organization of the Convention.

abstract: General for the Pontifical States has politely invited us to examine a present for Commander M.F. MAURY, from the Pontifical Government. It consists of a morocco case ornamented with the Pontifical arms, and containing thirteen heavy silver medals commemorative of important events during the present Pontificate, of which it constitutes, in fact, the entire collection. The gift is presented by the Pontifical Government in testimony of its thanks for the part which Commander MAURY has taken in the presentation, by the United States Government, of fifty copies of MAURY's sailing directions, and also of its high appreciation of the merits of the work. -- Freeman's Journal.

abstract: While the Christian world is ringing with the hideous echoes of the recent massacres of the Christians in Syria, and the most clamorous partisans of the Western Powers in the Crimean war seem ready to prostrate themselves in recantation and expiation at the feet of the Czar, it is, perhaps, hardly worth while to say even a single word in behalf of that strange people of the Libanus whose scimitars have done all this fearful work. Certainly there can be no doubt that the destruction of the Maronite towns and people is a flagrant and horrible proof of the utter incompetency of Turkey to fulfill the obligations which she accepted as the price of her existence, from the Christian nations at the peace of Paris. Certainly, too, it must be admitted that Christendom and civilization are alike disgraced by the diplomatic recognition of an empire in which the profession of Christianity puts its votaries practically beyond the pale of any law that can be enforced, and subjects them to the conditions of life in the primeval wilderness, where every man is his own police and court, and code. Yet when we reflect that Turkey entered into no engagements with regard to her Christian subjects, at Paris in 1856, more binding than those which were assumed at the same time and place with regard to the free navigation of the great central river of Europe, the Danube, by Austria; and that however short the Sultan has fallen of keeping his sovereign word, the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH has still more openly laughed at his own, we may well hesitate at indorsing in America the vehement language applied in Europe to the first of these defaulting potentates by journalists and statesmen who deal far more gently with the second. And however disagreeable it may be for English Senators and French Envoys to be forced to chat over the dinner-table with the Ambassadors of a State within the borders of which the age of GENGHIS KHAN is acting out once more, in all its historic terrors, it must not be forgotten that the same Christian gentlemen do not think themselves dishonored by the most familiar intercourse with the representatives of an Austrian Emperor, who is inflicting upon the Christians of Venice the utmost extremity of suffering and of insult; or of a Neapolitan King, who stands convicted of ordering with his own hand the wholesale slaughter and ruin of Christian cities in his own dominions. While Christendom consents to look on quietly and diplomatically upon the furious efforts of impossible Christian Governments to maintain themselves at the expense of all Christian liberties and all human rights in Europe, it seems a little hard, to say the least of it, that the death-penalty should he so peremptorily pronounced against a Mohammedan Government which is merely unable to protect those sanctities of civil order which the Hapsburgs and the Bourbons are doing their best utterly to annihilate.

abstract: -- The Journal of Commerce not long since had an article on the liquor trade, which must have seriously agitated those of its readers given to the imbibition of other fluids than water. It was calculated to destroy all faith in importations and make the most trusting of topers suspect the integrity of his libations. According to the Journals statement, the entire products of the vineyords of Europe, if exported, would be insufficient to supply the natural trade of the City of New-York alone. But another paper, which, bristling with statistics, enters the vineyard in defence of the grape, meets this assertion by showing that the wine crop of France alone is 980,000,000 gallons, while the aggregate European production falls little short of 2,000,000,000. This showing certainly leaves "ample scope and and verge enough" for the importation of pure wines, and does away with the idea that the introduction of the logwood element is caused or justified by the sterility of European wines. Were but a tenth part of this vintage imported, the streets would be fairly flooded with port, and every man, woman and child in the country could swim in genuine sherry.

abstract: Advices from Messina to the 8th inst., transmitted by way of Marseilles, state that Col. MEDICI was at the village of Barcelona, waiting volunteers. He had reconnoitered the heights of Messina. The attack of Milazzo was fixed for the 10th inst. Assassinations took place at Messina on the night of the 7th. The Neapolitan army was demoralized. The soldiers were deserting.

abstract: VOLUNTEER ASTRONOMICAL EXPEDITION. -- His Excellency Sir ALEXANDER BANNERMAN, Governor of New-foundland, received a communication from Prof. BACHE, Superintendent of the United States Coast Survey, asking him to give every facility in his power to the company of volunteer astronomers then about to embark for Cape Chudieigh for the purpose of observing the eclipse of the sun on the 18th inst., and recommending the expedition to his care and kindness and that of officials of his Government. Cape Chudieigh is near the entrance of Hudson's Strait, and the extreme part of the coast of Labrador which the Governor of Newfoundland has the power to superintend. It is stated in the Newfoundland papers that the circumstance of the visit of the Prince of Wales alone prevented Sir ALEXANDER himself from forming one of the volunteer company. His Excellency immediately transmitted directions to the superintendents of the settlements occupied by the British houses in the wild territory to the visited to give every information and aid to the astronomers. Should the expedition, on its homeward voyage, call into St. Johns, they will meet with a hearty welcome. -- Boston Journal.
lead_paragraph: VOLUNTEER ASTRONOMICAL EXPEDITION. -- His Excellency Sir ALEXANDER BANNERMAN, Governor of New-foundland, received a communication from Prof. BACHE, Superintendent of the United States Coast Survey, asking him to give every facility in his power to the company of volunteer astronomers then about to embark for Cape Chudieigh for the purpose of observing the eclipse of the sun on the 18th inst., and recommending the expedition to his care and kindness and that of officials of his Government. Cape Chudieigh is near the entrance of Hudson's Strait, and the extreme part of the coast of Labrador which the Governor of Newfoundland has the power to superintend. abstract: A STEAM BARGE ON FIRE CONSTERNATION OF THE PASSENGERS. About 6  o'clock last night, great excitement was caused in Hoboken by the announcement that a barge containing passengers was on fire in the river, and was heading for the shore. It was at first supposed to be an excursion boat in which event the loss of life would undoubtedly have been very great.
lead_paragraph: A STEAM BARGE ON FIRE CONSTERNATION OF THE PASSENGERS. About 6 o'clock last night, great excitement was caused in Hoboken by the announcement that a barge containing passengers was on fire in the river, and was heading for the shore. It was at first supposed to be an excursion boat in which event the loss of life would undoubtedly have been very great. It proved to be the steam barge T.C. Durant, Capt. SHOEMAKER, of Coeymans, Albany County, N.Y. She left her dock, foot of North Moore-street, about 6 o'clock, with some fifteen passengers, including six women and some children. Shortly after getting out into the river, a fire was discovered in the after part, under the main deck, near the boiler. The excitement amongst the passengers became very great, and the female portion ran about the deck screaming and acting in a most frantic manner. In a few moments the flames had made considerable headway, and in less than ten minutes the stern of the boat was enveloped in names. The Captain at once ordered her to be run ashore at Hoboken; and as they were on their way, the steamboat Shultz ran across her bow and attempted to take a line, but were unsuccessful. In the meantime, some of the less excited persons were engaged in preventing others from leaping overboard. The pilot succeeded in running the barge, alongside of a dock near the Yacht Club house. Some of the firemen were already present, and in a few moments all the passengers, who were clustered together at the bow, were safely landed, without accident. The firemen then directed their attention to battling the flames, which now raged fiercely, and by 7 1/2 o'clock had almost entirely extinguished them. The excitement in Hoboken for a while was very great, and men, women and children came running from all directions, until several thousand were assembled. There was but little freight on board, nearly all of which was removed. The boat was owned by Messrs. SHOEMAKER and JOHNSON, of Albany County, and is valued at about $12,000. The loss will probably be about $5,000, which is covered by insurance. The women, who came ashore without their bonnets or shawls, were kindly cared for by the citizens.

abstract: CLOSE OF THE FLUSHING PUBLIC SCHOOLS. -- The close of the Public Schools at Flushing and the vicinity, for the usual Summer vacation, took place yesterday, on which occasion there was a general pic-nic in the grove of Flushing Woods. The schools from Whitestone and Strattonport were brought up by the steamer Enoch Dean, and the pupils from Little Neck, Black Stump and other localities, poured in to swell the throng of happy Summer-emancipated children. The whole company, to the number of over one thousand, met at the Public School in Flushing, where they were marshaled under the supervision of Mr. GATES, the Principal of the School, and his lady assistants. Gen. HAMILTON acting as Grand Marshal, led by two bands of music. The children marched to the grove known as "St. Ronan's Well," where the day was spent in various recreations. During the afternoon Rev. Mr. HOLLOWAY, Minister of the Dutch Reformed Church, and others, made addresses, and the children of the different schools sang favorite songs. The day passed off without accident, and greatly to the gratification of all interested.

abstract: The return match between the Albany County Club, of Albany, and the second eleven of the St. George's Club, of New-York, was played yesterday on the St. George's ground, Hoboken, and resulted in a decided victory for Albany, in one innings, and thirty runs to spare. The previous match, which was played at Albany early in the season, was won by St. George, and the deciding match will have to be played before the question of superiority can be claimed by either party.

abstract: M. OUTREY, the French Consul at Damascus, who left Paris on Saturday to return to his post, received precise instructions previous to his departure to concert measures with the naval officer commanding the ships of war on the coast of Syria to repress by force, if necessary, the attacks made by the Turks on the Christians. The Emperor is determined to put an end to the half measures which have hitherto been adopted, and to act with vigor.

abstract: The body of JOSEPH KENNY, an Englishman, 35 years of age, was found yesterday in the water at the foot of Murray-street. Coroner JACKMAN investigated the case, but was unable to ascertain under what circumstances deceased was drowned....On the 4th inst., CATHARINE MAILIFF, an infant, whose parents reside at No. 176 East Thirty-first street, sat down upon the hot cover of a stove, which her mother had placed upon the floor. She was not seriously burned, but inflammation supervened, and she died yesterday from its effects. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the body.

abstract: wealthy druggist of Hagerstown, Md., died, on the 17th inst., leaving the following bequests: $20,000 to four Boards of the Old School Presbyterian Church, viz.: $5,000 to the Board of Education; $5,000 to the Board of Publication; $5,000 to the Board of Foreign and $5,000 to the Board of Domestic Missions. He also devises $5,000 to the Presbyterian congregation of Hagerstown for the enlargement and improvement of its church edifice; $1,000 to the Charity School of this town; $2,000 to the Mayor and Council of Hagerstown for the purchase of fuel for the poor; $1,000 to his colored servant woman, which at her death is to rovert to the town, and be appropriated as the preceding legacy, and $[???]00 for the purchase of the spring on the premises of the heirs of the late GEORGE HEKNEBERGER, in North Potomac street, (known as Miller's Spring,) for the use of the public.

abstract: Western Missouri have experienced weather which puts our dog-day heats to shame. The wind blew for four hours, on the 13th inst., at Grasshopper Falls, as if it came from the mouth of an oven. The thermometer rose to 110° in the shade! Animals were variously affected. Chickens and pigs died. Cattle suffered more, perhaps, from fright than heat. The Border Star (Mo.,) says that the wind there was like the breath of a furnace. The Independence Herald, of the same State, says it was so intense as almost to scorch the face. People had to close their doors and windows to keen it out, though the thermometer was [???] 105°.
lead_paragraph: Western Missouri have experienced weather which puts our dog-day heats to shame. The wind blew for four hours, on the 13th inst., at Grasshopper Falls, as if it came from the mouth of an oven. The thermometer rose to 110° in the shade! Animals were variously affected. Chickens and pigs died. Cattle suffered more, perhaps, from fright than heat. The Border Star (Mo.,) says that the wind there was like the breath of a furnace. The Independence Herald, of the same State, says it was so intense as almost to scorch the face. People had to close their doors and windows to keen it out, though the thermometer was [???] 105°.

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN. -- To-day, we would remind those unfavored persons who have not yet been on board this ship, affords the last opportunity for a visit to her, unless the managers can be induced, on her return from the trip to Cape May, again to place her on exhibition, which, at present, is an extremely doubtful matter. Yesterday, the crowd was immense, so much to, indeed, that but little more than the crowd could be seen. Getting down to the saloons, engine and steerage rooms, was, perhaps, a little better than getting up again, but the crush in either case was fearful. The entire deck was one mass of human beings, and locomotion was almost impossible. As it was, on Broadway, at the advent of KOBSUTH, or at the Atlantic cable celebration, so it was yesterday on board the big ship. You were jammed, you were crammed, you were squeezed, you were -- not quite, but very nearly -- crushed. Seeing the ship, under such circumstances, is of course out of the question, but you can still get on board, and by patience, perseverance, and disregard of time, conrive to make your way from stem to stern. If time s of no consequence to you at all, you may wait an hour or so for an opportunity to ascend the wheel-houses, but unless you are very patient indeed, and very forbearing withal, you will eschew the machinery, especially the screw engine room. Among the visitors yesterday, were the Washington Templars, who were, however, so absorbed in the crowd, that very few persons were aware of their presence. The Great Eastern will positively start on the trip to Cape May on Monday, at 2 P.M. Rather more than 700 tickets had been sold up to last night. What will be done with her, on her return, is not yet fully determined on. Gen. MAHONE, President of the Norfolk and Petersburgh Railroad, has come to the City to offer inducements for her to visit Hampton Roads, and the Norfolk Board of Trade have held a meeting and authorized its President to open a correspondence with the managers of the ship, to ascertain from them whether they would be willing to cooperate with the friends of "direct Southern trade," by running their ship from the Chesapeake Bay to some port or ports of England, should it be found, after dilligent inquiry, that ample tonnage can be concentrated on that point for her profitable employment. So, at least, say the Norfolk papers.

So, at least, say the Norfolk papers.

abstract: The following important intelligence has been communicated to me from an official source. It was decided yesterday at the council to offer the constitution of 18[???]2 to the Sicilians, on the ground of its being the law of the land, and never having been abolished. According to the idea of the Government, the relations between Italy and Naples would be precisely these of Norway and Sweden -- one King, two separate constitutions, parliaments, armies and administrations. Certain modifications, rendered necessary by the altered condition of the country, would be reserved for the Sicilian Parliament to make, and the article in the old constitution, providing, under certain circumstances, for the complete separation of the two branches of the kingdom under two sovereigns is abolished. England and France have been informed of the propositions, and have been requested to give their good offices, and I can now state that the answers have been received. France assents; England hesitates until an unconditional promise is given not to renew hostilities against Sicily. I know that the Neapolitan Government agrees in principle with England, but is under the apprehension that the avowal of such an intention might impede rather than promote the reconciliation. There is the fullest intention on the part of the present ministers to disembarrass themselves as soon as possible of foreign troops, and, in fact, I have the fullest confidence in their honesty.
lead_paragraph: The following important intelligence has been communicated to me from an official source. Certain modifications, rendered necessary by the altered condition of the country, would be reserved for the Sicilian Parliament to make, and the article in the old constitution, providing, under certain circumstances, for the complete separation of the two branches of the kingdom under two sovereigns is abolished. England and France have been informed of the propositions, and have been requested to give their good offices, and I can now state that the answers have been received. France assents; England hesitates until an unconditional promise is given not to renew hostilities against Sicily. I know that the Neapolitan Government agrees in principle with England, but is under the apprehension that the avowal of such an intention might impede rather than promote the reconciliation. There is the fullest intention on the part of the present ministers to disembarrass themselves as soon as possible of foreign troops, and, in fact, I have the fullest confidence in their honesty.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 13th inst, Sir R. P[???]L moved an address for copies or extracts of papers relating to the threatened annexation of Sicily to Piedmont, and for any information received by Her Majesty's Government as to the probable demands of France consequent upon the event of that annexation taking place; also for any papers showing that Her Majesty's Government have within the last few weeks intimated to the Government of Turin that the continued aggressive policy of that Government would not be viewed with indifference by Great Britain. He took occasion to invite the attention of the House to the subject, observing that the question of Sicily directly concerned this country commercially as well as in a political point of view, and that Sardinia, in this question, was but a tool in the hands of the Emperor of the French. He called upon Lord J. RUSSELL frankly to express his views upon this question, and to declare the policy he was following. Adverting to the efforts made to attach Sicily to Sardinia, he asked whether the man who had sold the citizens of Nice and the mountaineers of the Alps, who had bartered the liberty and the interests of brave and devoted subjects who had served the House of Savoy, ought to be selected to be King of Italy. He reminded Lord J. RUSSELL of the policy he had pursued in 1848, and asked whether he adhered to the same policy now, or whether he desired that Italy should be united to Sardinia, a mere instrument, he repeated, of the Emperor of the French. As Lord JOHN had not approved the proceedings of GARIBALDI, he hoped he did not desire this union, and that the political independence of Sicily would be secured by the guarantee of the European Powers.

Adverting to the efforts made to attach Sicily to Sardinia, he asked whether the man who had sold the citizens of Nice and the mountaineers of the Alps, who had bartered the liberty and the interests of brave and devoted subjects who had served the House of Savoy, ought to be selected to be King of Italy. He reminded Lord J. RUSSELL of the policy he had pursued in 1848, and asked whether he adhered to the same policy now, or whether he desired that Italy should be united to Sardinia, a mere instrument, he repeated, of the Emperor of the French. abstract: Petition of Isabella Knapp. -- This was an application before Justice LEONARD, at Chambers, for the discharge of the prisoner, who had been sent to the Workhouse on the charge of vagrancy. According to the record the prisoner was a prostitute, and had been committed as such for two months. Justice LEONARD cited title 2, chap. 20, part 1, sec. 3 R.S., showing that vagrants should be committed to the House of Correction for sixty days.

abstract: The celerity with which the Zouaves move, not only when they drill, but when they travel, deservedly excites admiration. It is doubtful if, in the history of military excursions, any body of men was ever known to go over more ground in the same length of time, or exhibit more persistent industry in their movements, than the Zouaves have shown since they left home for their Eastern tour; and whatever may be the merits of their peculiar drill, the virtue of improving time and enduring fatigue, must be accorded to them in an eminent degree. These qualities are supposed to be owing, in part, to the strictly abstemious habits which belong to their system of military discipline.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship City of Washington, off Cape Race, yesterday morning, we are put in possession of advices from Europe four days later than those previously received. The news is unimportant.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship City of Washington, off Cape Race, yesterday morning, we are put in possession of advices from Europe four days later than those previously received. The news is unimportant. The British Government was reported to have received information that a fearful massacre of Christians had taken place at Damascus, in which five hundred of them had been killed, including the Dutch Consul. The American Consul was also reported to have been wounded. Full particulars had not come to hand. From Naples, we learn that notwithstanding the late steps towards concessions taken by the King, the people refused to be satisfied. The city was in a highly excited state. Patrols were constantly traversing the streets, and every one was full of apprehension. A dispatch via Turin, dated the 11th, asserts that a conflict had taken place between, the troops and the people, in which several persons were killed. The King had dismissed his Ministry, and formed a new Cabinet. We have nothing further relative to the movements of GARIBALDI.

abstract: In the present thermometrical range of the weather, atmospherical and political, it is of the utmost importance that facts should come to us at a reduced temperature. From all inordinate and violent excitements we crave immunity; for surely at 90Â° Farenheit, with the effects of Summer, of a stormy session of Congress, and of a half dozen convulsive Conventions upon us, there is every reason to seek deliverance from influences which accelerate the pulse, and fan to fiercer heat the flames of partisan combustion. It is most unfortunate, therefore, that this should be the crisis for occurrences such as the telegraph reports from Texas, where the whole of the important and thickly-settled region adjoining the Northeastern boundary is stated to be in a condition of abnormal excitement, owing to the wicked and malicious intrigues of certain Northern Abolitionists. Whole towns are said to have been burned, property valued at three-fourths of a million dollars, a portentous sum in a new district, destroyed; and this as a mere prelude, to an uprising of slaves which was to convert universal arson into universal slaughter and revolution. Partial confirmation of this startling intelligence, which came overland to St. Louis, has descended the Red River to New-Orleans, whence we learn that three of the white conspirators had been arrested in Washington County, a point, strange to say, quite distant from the conflagrations, and toward the centre of the State. When we are told that great excitement exists "at the discovery of this fiendish plot," and that "prompt measures were being taken for the preservation of life and property," we may readily appreciate that the lives of these Washington County captives are not worth a pin's fee. They will doubtless be dispatched with the short shrift afforded by Judge Lynch.

From all inordinate and violent excitements we crave immunity; for surely at 90° Farenheit, with the effects of Summer, of a stormy session of Congress, and of a half dozen convulsive Conventions upon us, there is every reason to seek deliverance from influences which accelerate the pulse, and fan to fiercer heat the flames of partisan combustion. It is most unfortunate, therefore, that this should be the crisis for occurrences such as the telegraph reports from Texas, where the whole of the important and thickly-settled region adjoining the Northeastern boundary is stated to be in a condition of abnormal excitement, owing to the wicked and malicious intrigues of certain Northern Abolitionists. Whole towns are said to have been burned, property valued at three-fourths of a million dollars, a portentous sum in a new district, destroyed; and this as a mere prelude, to an uprising of slaves which was to convert universal arson into universal slaughter and revolution. Partial confirmation of this startling intelligence, which came overland to St. Louis, has descended the Red River to New-Orleans, whence we learn that three of the white conspirators had been arrested in Washington County, a point, strange to say, quite distant from the conflagrations, and toward the centre of the State. When we are told that great excitement exists "at the discovery of this fiendish plot," and that "prompt measures were being taken for the preservation of life and property," we may readily appreciate that the lives of these Washington County captives are not worth a pin's fee. They will doubtless be dispatched with the short shrift afforded by Judge Lynch.
