abstract: The American career of the Prince of Wales has thus far been creditable and satisfactory to all concerned. The people of Newfoundland, so unused in their remote and specially slow corner of creation to the luxruy of new sensations, might fairly have been expected to have committed any number of extravagances upon such extraordinary provocation.
lead_paragraph: The American career of the Prince of Wales has thus far been creditable and satisfactory to all concerned. The people of Newfoundland, so unused in their remote and specially slow corner of creation to the luxruy of new sensations, might fairly have been expected to have committed any number of extravagances upon such extraordinary provocation. It is simple justice to these bluest of blue-noses to say that their well-grounded enthusiasm, based as it is upon a hereditary principle of loyalty and of personal regard for an amiable sovereign, has in no instance transcended the limits of decorum; and indeed may justly furnish a model for the conduct of other populations to be gratified with the presence of the royal visitor. There were cordial addresses, and multitudinous huzzas; there were levees, and there was a ball; through all which formal but necessary ordeals the Prince and the people passed with exemplary propriety; and the former resumed his journey after receiving and leaving the happiest impressions. Such at least is the representation of St. Johns authorities, and of our correspondents.

abstract: NON. -- On Tuesday, at Portsmouth, N.H., Miss ANN MARIA MARTIN died from the effects of a singular wound received on Saturday, when a salute was fired from the yacht Zinga. Expecting a display of fireworks from the Zinga, as she was coming in, a large number of people had gathered on the wharf. A salute from a cannon was fired on board the yacht. The wad was of waste cotton, and of course was very dense; and although the muzzle of the gun was judged to be depressed far below the wharf, yet, being pointed towards the people, the wad struck Miss MARTIN, broke several steel hoops in her skirt, and one of them cut a fearful gash across the lower portion of her body, allowing the intestines to protrude. She was taken home as soon as possible, though the bystanders had no idea of the nature of the terrible injury she had received. To some who crowded around her and annoyed her with questions, where she was hurt, and how much, she replied in great agony, "You do not know how much I am hurt. Take me home, that I may die with my mother."
lead_paragraph: NON. -- On Tuesday, at Portsmouth, N.H., Miss ANN MARIA MARTIN died from the effects of a singular wound received on Saturday, when a salute was fired from the yacht Zinga. Expecting a display of fireworks from the Zinga, as she was coming in, a large number of people had gathered on the wharf. A salute from a cannon was fired on board the yacht. The wad was of waste cotton, and of course was very dense; and although the muzzle of the gun was judged to be depressed far below the wharf, yet, being pointed towards the people, the wad struck Miss MARTIN, broke several steel hoops in her skirt, and one of them cut a fearful gash across the lower portion of her body, allowing the intestines to protrude. She was taken home as soon as possible, though the bystanders had no idea of the nature of the terrible injury she had received. To some who crowded around her and annoyed her with questions, where she was hurt, and how much, she replied in great agony, "You do not know how much I am hurt. Take me home, that I may die with my mother."

abstract: The Spaniards have long been laboring under the reproach of an excessive passion for rhet oric. There is no QUATTLEBUM SO explosive, no CUSMING so metaphorical that he must not have his fling at the pompous declamations of Spanish oratory. We dare say that KWTTI himself never speaks of Spanish pronunciamentos without a compassionate curl of the lip. But at least one Spanish orator has just earned the right to a very different reputation.
lead_paragraph: The Spaniards have long been laboring under the reproach of an excessive passion for rhet oric. There is no QUATTLEBUM SO explosive, no CUSMING so metaphorical that he must not have his fling at the pompous declamations of Spanish oratory. We dare say that KWTTI himself never speaks of Spanish pronunciamentos without a compassionate curl of the lip. But at least one Spanish orator has just earned the right to a very different reputation. When the news reached Madrid that the Spanish Pretender, the Count DE MONTEMOLIN, had retracted at Paris the renunciation which he had freely made in Spain of his rights to the throne, a member of the Cortes asked the Minister why her Majesty's Government had made no allusion to this important event. Here was an excellent opportunity for a magnificent burst of loyal and patriotic fireworks. The Minister might have invoked all the great ghosts of Spain, from PELAYO down, out of their graves; discussed the whole field of dynastic rights and popular sovereignty, and wound up with thrilling appeals to the Cortes and to the country to stand by the throne of ISABELLA and the Constitution. He did nothing of the sort, but getting up for a moment in his place, simply answered that "Her Majesty's Government had published neither the renunciation of the Count DE MONTEMOLIN, nor his retractation of his renunciation, because the Government attached no more importance to the one of these documents than to the other;" and thereupon sate down. Columns of eloquence in small type could not have conveyed so complete a sense as do these few words, of the power of a free constitutional government, and of the ridiculous impudence of the dynastic vagabonds who persist in pestering Europe and the world with the exhibition of their bigotry, their vanity, their selfishness and their dishonesty. We may indeed look for a new era of Spanish history when we find the contemporaries of ESPARTERO and ZUMALACARREGIN capable of taking so quiet and sensible a view of the questions which hut a few years since convulsed the Peninsula from end to end.

abstract: Affairs in this Province are looking blacker and blacker. Yesterday we had the fearful news of the village of Deir-el-Kamar being sacked, burnt, and every Christian male, to the number of two thousand and more, being put to the sword by the Druses, who a fortnight before had disarmed them, in cold blood. The women and children were allowed to escape, and reached the mouth of the Damoor River, half-way between this and Sidon, yesterday, whence they were brought up last night and this morning, to the number of 1 100, by Her Britannic Majesty's shps G[???]et and Mohawk. Of the men of Deir-el-Kamar, not more than thirty have escaped. The town is all burnt. The refugees say that the Turkish soldiers sided with the Druses, helping them to butcher the people, and that they, the Sultan's troops, were the only people who insulted the women, of whom not a few me[???] with the worst treatment by them.

abstract: Advices have reached us from the Western Departments of the Army. The troops at the several stations were in good health of the date our news left, viz: the middle of June. The Ordnance Department of Fort Leavenworth, agreably to instructions from Headquarters, has been converted into and will henceforward be known as an Arsenal. All well and peaceable at the fort.

abstract: Yesterday the two vessels captured by the Neapolitans -- one the small steamer Utile, and the other the American clipper -- arrived at Genoa after a stoppage of three days at Portoferraio. The volunteers would have gladly gone on to Sicily, if they could; but our Minister at Naples, Marquis DI VILLAMARINA, had pledged his word of honor that they should come to Genoa, and as he is not a Bourbon, nor a Bourbon's Minister, his word could not be broken. They were kept at Gaeta for eighteen days, badly used at first, but rather better towards the last. Their surprise was great, having known nothing of what had been going on at Naples in the interim, to see the Neapolitan men-of war hoisting the tri-colored flag; but as they did not see in the middle of it the arms of Savoy, they were puzzled immensely. But they greeted the flag, nevertheless, with cries of "Long live Italy! Long live GARIBALDI!" Being now at Genoa, they have heard how matters stand, and rejoice at the freedom gained, though grieving at the same time at their having been unable to strike one good blow for it on a battle field.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the two vessels captured by the Neapolitans -- one the small steamer Utile, and the other the American clipper -- arrived at Genoa after a stoppage of three days at Portoferraio. The volunteers would have gladly gone on to Sicily, if they could; but our Minister at Naples, Marquis DI VILLAMARINA, had pledged his word of honor that they should come to Genoa, and as he is not a Bourbon, nor a Bourbon's Minister, his word could not be broken. They were kept at Gaeta for eighteen days, badly used at first, but rather better towards the last. Their surprise was great, having known nothing of what had been going on at Naples in the interim, to see the Neapolitan men-of war hoisting the tri-colored flag; but as they did not see in the middle of it the arms of Savoy, they were puzzled immensely. But they greeted the flag, nevertheless, with cries of "Long live Italy! Long live GARIBALDI!" Being now at Genoa, they have heard how matters stand, and rejoice at the freedom gained, though grieving at the same time at their having been unable to strike one good blow for it on a battle field.

abstract: The Commissioners to whom is assigned the duty of locating the City streets to the northward of One Hundred and Fifty-first-street, have denounced the rectangular system as unsuited to the ground. They are at a loss how to carry their lines arbitrarily to the summit of Washington Heights, and down precipitately on one side to the level of Spuyten Duyvil, and on the other to the bank of the Hudson. Obviously, the natural features of the ground would have to be erased, or the map abandon its right angles.
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners to whom is assigned the duty of locating the City streets to the northward of One Hundred and Fifty-first-street, have denounced the rectangular system as unsuited to the ground. abstract: An Arabic Journal, Birgis-Baryst the "Eagle of Paris," published at the French capital, contains in one of its latest issues, a letter written at Damascus by the Emir ABD-EL KADER, who is living in retirement in that city, on the state of things in Turkey and Syria. The letter bears date June 10, and must have been written shortly before the Syrian capital, the "eye of the whole East," as JULIAN called it, was called upon to bear such fearful witness to the imbecility which the Emir denounces and deplores as the sure forerunner of the fall of the last great Islamitish empire. Apart from the curious interest which attaches to the appearance of the great Prince of the Desert in the character of a writer for the Press, this letter has a striking value as the sad and deliberate verdict of one of the ablest of living Mohammedans, upon the condition of the faith which he professes and of its votaries, as contrasted with the state of Christendom. The Emir begins by complimenting the Arabian Editor on the wisdom he has shown in pointing out that the obstinate prejudices, and the slow adaptability to circumstances of the Ottoman functionaries, are two great causes of the impotence of the Sultan's Government, and then goes on to say:

abstract: THE NEWEST STREET LETTER BOXES. -- When the new letter boxes were first placed on corner lamp-posts nearly throughout the City, they were regarded as a very convenient institution, until big and little thieves were detected in the act of filching from them the letters of which they were the depositories. Then they lacked immediately the good will of the public, and money letters, and epistles of consequence and confidence, were no longer intrusted to their unsafe keeping. They were too shallow for use, a child with a piece of cane, four inches long, being able, with little ingenuity, to rifle their contents. Within a day [???] two past, a newer style of letter box, having much the appearance of the original, but being twice their size and height, with the admission lid on the top, instead of at the side, and duly protected against rain as well as robbery, have been placed at the corners of some of the cross streets and Broadway. They look as if they would answer the purpose very well, and as they insure safety, are a decided improvement on the fire stock. Apropos all these letter boxes, however, on Saturday, a printed label was affixed to each of them, apprising letter-dropping citizens that all letters, intended for the mail, in audition to the three cent red stamp, must carry, in addition, a one cent blue stamp, to pay for the trouble of opening and closing the boxes, and conveying the letters to the General Post-office for distribution. As these boxes are de facto branch offices of that same general office de jure, no such extra cent should be charged. It is an incentive to grumbling. It is not the value of the blue stamp that makes letter writers look blue. Tis he principle.

abstract: Perhaps nothing is more astonishing in the constitution of American society, than the extraordinary elasticity which our people display under the pressure of deluges, conflagrations, commercial crises, and disasters generally. We have the talent of a trained goldfinch for "shamming dead," and the genius of a Mantalini for suicide. Probably no nation has ever existed which could stand so much ruining.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps nothing is more astonishing in the constitution of American society, than the extraordinary elasticity which our people display under the pressure of deluges, conflagrations, commercial crises, and disasters generally. We have the talent of a trained goldfinch for "shamming dead," and the genius of a Mantalini for suicide. Probably no nation has ever existed which could stand so much ruining. But great as our recuperative energies admittedly are, we think everybody must confess that they have never been exhibited in so brilliant a light as during the past week. The New-York Herald endorsed by some newspaper in Canada as the "leading organ of the American Democracy," and by itself as the first of all journals, past, present, or to come, startled the community from its dreams of peace, prosperity and the Prince of Wales, on Tuesday, July 24, by announcing with all the solemnity of a double-leaded "leader," that the account of the Republic would be finally closed on the 4th of March, 1861. It stated, of course on the authority of President BUCHANAN, that the "Breckinridge movement in the North would avail nothing; that the dissolution of the Union is a fact already determined upon; and that the crisis is imminent." The plans of the South for a rupture of the Confederacy were set forth in detail, and all sensible people were called upon to wind up their affairs without delay. Pandora's box was opened, and Hope sitting forlornly on the edge, had nothing more cheering to offer a bewildered and prostrated nation than the emphatic suggestion that, "between this time and November, something might be saved from the wreck."

abstract: IN[???]RY FIRE -- About 1 o'clock, on Sunday morning, a fire broke out in the carpenter's shop, owned and occupied by the Cunard Company, and situated at the foot of York-street, Jersey City. So rapidly did the names spread, that in less than a Quarter of an hour the whole roof of the extensive coal shed, owned by the same company, was completely enveloped in flames. A fresh breeze was blowing in a south-easterly direction, and before the fire could be checked, it extended to the building occupied by KETCHUM & Co., Machinists, and owned by WM. EWAN. A small frame building, situated in the rear of the machine shop, and containing the engine and heavy part of the machinery, was, with its contents, totally destroyed. The flames extended on the north to the Custom-house, which is a fire-proof building, and therefore the damage was mostly by water. The following is a list of the losses: Cunard Company, $5,000 on shed and coal, and $1,000 on goods damaged by water in Custom-house -- fully insured in the Eagle Insurance Company of New-York; KETCHUM & Co., $2,500 -- insured for $2,000 in the Jersey City Insurance Company; WM. EWAN, loss on buildings about $1,500 -- insured. The Fire Department are entitled to great credit for the prompt manner in which they checked the conflagration, which, at one time, threatened to be the largest in Jersey City for many years. The extensive lumber-yard of BURST & Co., immediately adjoining, was in imminent peril, as was also the shipping at the dock, one of the Cunard steamers being obliged to get up steam and back out into the river. As there was no fire used in the vicinity of the carpenter's shop, there can be no donbt but it was the work of an incendiary.

abstract: The selection of candidates for the West Point Military Academy and Annapolis Naval School devolves alternately upon members of Congress, so that all sections of the country may be represented in those valuable institutions. The result hitherto, however, has not been to secure an equal representation of all the States in the graduating classes as cadets, either from physical or mental incapacity, have been obliged to leave the institutions before finishing the course.
lead_paragraph: The selection of candidates for the West Point Military Academy and Annapolis Naval School devolves alternately upon members of Congress, so that all sections of the country may be represented in those valuable institutions. The result hitherto, however, has not been to secure an equal representation of all the States in the graduating classes as cadets, either from physical or mental incapacity, have been obliged to leave the institutions before finishing the course. This, heretofore, has been disadvantageous, not only to the boys thus disheartened but to the institutions, from a waste of time and the existence of many vacant scholarships. The classes were disorganized, and the energies of tutors to educate incompetent pupils have been literally wasted. The main cause of the misfortunes has been the loose manner in which cadets have been appointed -- through political influence, and not on account of any peculiar qualification for the places sought. Boys were catered as candidates for Army or Navy officers, without brain or muscle enough for a retail dry goods clerk, and were obliged to resign to their own disgrace and the great mortification of their parents. In order to obviate these evils, Hon. DANIEL E. SICKLES, member of Congress from the Third District, revived the plan adopted by Hon. HIRAM WALBRIDGE. Having the appointment of one cadet for each of the above-named institutions, he determined to choose them from the most fit and capable boys in the public schools. He accordingly addressed a letter to City Superintendent RANDALL, requesting him and his assistants to act as a Board of Examination of candidates to be presented by the schools of the District, the selection to be made "not only as to their fitness for preliminary examination, but as to their ability, intellectually and physically, to sustain themselves in the long and difficult training which every pupil must undergo before he can; graduate from either of those institutions."

abstract: The periodical attacks of irritation to which Democratic editors are subject are amusing in the extreme. The respective editors of the Memphis Avalanche and the Memphis Appeal have been carrying on a rather ardent correspondence, and though it has ended without resort to either pistols or broad-swords, one cannot but shudder to think of "what might have been." Col. GALLAWAY, of the Avalanche, feeling ag- ...
lead_paragraph: The periodical attacks of irritation to which Democratic editors are subject are amusing in the extreme. The respective editors of the Memphis Avalanche and the Memphis Appeal have been carrying on a rather ardent correspondence, and though it has ended without resort to either pistols or broad-swords, one cannot but shudder to think of "what might have been." Col. GALLAWAY, of the Avalanche, feeling agrieved at an article in the Appeal, wrote the editors of that journel a note, saying that he regarded the article as grossly offensive, and peremptorily demanding whether they intended any personal reflections, or to question the veracity of any of the Avalanche corps, closing his note with the customary courteous information: This will be handed you by my friend, Col. GEO. H. MONSARRAT; to which the Appeal men replied that they had previously felt aggrieved at something the Avalanche had said, and that any explanation from them was impossible until they were assured that so and so was neither the purpose nor motive of the article in the Avalanche. They too closed their note in the recognized fashion; This will be handed you by our mutual friend, Co H. MONSARRAT. To this the irate GALLAWAY made answer that the article referred to only sought to weaken the political influence of the Appeal, and by no means justified an attack upon his own personal honor, concluding by reiterating his demand and stating: This will be handed you by our mutual friend, Col. MONSARRAT. The Appeal men immediately replied that this explicit disclaimer left them free to say that in their article they spoke abstractly, and did not design to involve or impeach the personal honor and veracity of any of the Avalanche editors in the concrete. "This," they intimated, will be handed you by our mutual friend, Col. LEON TROUSDALE. This last note, like CHARLES LAMB's piece of oyster pie, "did the business." The impending Avalanche was averted, and an appeal to the field of honor on the part of the Appeal rendered perfectly unnecessary. Col. GALLAWAY instantly took his pen in hand to say that the note had been handed him by Mr. TRCUSDALE, and that it was perfectly satisfactory. That friendly relations were restored, and that this note, with intelligence to that effect, would be handed them by his friend, R.E. CHEW. The interesting correspondence was published in full, and each editor resumed his quill, feeling, no doubt, that he had done his duty to himself and to society. Poor Col. MONSARRAT was obliged to make temporary post-bags of his pockets, and carry and fetch like a well-broke retriever; but he seems to have been the only one that suffered. It is gratifying to know that the affair had so peaceable a termination, for it is much less sinful to shed ink than blood. "Soothing syrup ought to have a large sale in Genesee.

abstract: Order reigns at Occoquan. For some weeks Occoquan had been fearfully and wonderfully disturbed. Of course all our readers know where Occoquan is, but remembering MOLIERE's Bourgeois Gentil-homme, we shall pretend that they do not. It is a place, then, of great importance in the most enlightened part of Virginia, and will no doubt become a formidable rival of Philadelphia and Baltimore, as soon as the Great Eastern begins her regular trips between Norfolk and Milford Haven. The peace of this city was invaded early in June by sixty disaffected citizens, who insisted on hoisting a Republican banner bearing the names of LINCOLN and HAMLIN. The intelligent majority of the population remonstrated with these maniacs, but in vain. Inflamed, no doubt, with the spirit of JOHN BROWN, they persisted in asserting that they had a right to outrage the soil of the land of PATRICK HENRY, by expressing their own opinions, and so hoisted their intolerable flag. At every flap of that base bunting on the breeze, Occoquan shuddered. At last a few friends of human rights and public order announced their determination to abate the nuisance. A person of weak mind, the owner of the land on which the obnoxious flagstaff had been fixed, declared that although he did by no means agree with the Republicans in opinion, he would nevertheless insist on granting them the use of his property. He even went so far as to invoke the assistance of the Governor of the State to protect him in this extravagant position. The Governor sent him a troop of horse for that purpose. The troop of horse reached Occoquan, formed around the flagstaff, and sitting still on their horses, watched with great gravity the interesting process of its demolition by the friends of public decency. After this they turned their horses' heads and rode home again. The weak-minded owner of the land was then well beaten by a leading friend of public decency, and Occoquan once more drew a free breath, relieved of the hideous rag which had come between its brave citizens and the breath of heaven.

abstract: The great meteor of Friday evening, July 20, was probably seen far out at sea, by ships between the parallels of 35° and 40° N. All who observed it are requested to communicate the fact to Lieut. MAURY, National Observatory, Washington, stating as nearly as they can the position of the ship, the precise time of night, and describing the path of the meteor, its bearings from the observer, and its probable altitude.

abstract: The action of the Board of Councilmen on Friday night, in concurring with the Aldermen in the resolution which permits the junction of the Eighth and Ninth Avenue Railroads at Fifty-fourth-street, may be regarded as indicative of the triumph of the Gridiron Railroad project. Between the public and the consummation of the scheme nothing but the will of the Common Council interposes.
lead_paragraph: The action of the Board of Councilmen on Friday night, in concurring with the Aldermen in the resolution which permits the junction of the Eighth and Ninth Avenue Railroads at Fifty-fourth-street, may be regarded as indicative of the triumph of the Gridiron Railroad project. Between the public and the consummation of the scheme nothing but the will of the Common Council interposes. The bills were urged through the Legislature in spite of the Executive veto, and in the face of the unanimous outcry of the City Government, which filled Albany with its remonstrances against the avarice and arrogance of those men, who proposed to take possession of all our great thoroughfares, without tender of compensation to the unhappy tax-payers. Seldom have the debates of both Boards, even when discussing questions the interest or which has been intensified by the dependence thereupon of choice and not inconsiderable bits of pecuniary plunder, been marked with more fervor and more hearty indignation than when the acts finally passed the Legislature. The promptitude and bits of with which a message from the acting Mayor, denouncing the laws, was received, and the Counsel of the Corporation ordered to contest their constitutionality, is a memorable entry in the journals of the Council, contrasting singularly with the action on Friday, when only a minority of four was found to oppose the resolution. The significance of this change is unmistakable. The managers of this stupendous scheme have made no secret of their intentions to convert the City authorities to their views; and rumors, not in the least incredible, have circulated for some time past, that when all the prearranged removals of impracticable City officials should have been effected, and the only additional barrier to progress should be the Common Council, that there would be no difficulty in inducing that body to cause the withdrawal of legal opposition. A patient public need not be surprised at any moment to learn that this aim has been achieved.

abstract: On the 15th inst., ROBERT SLATTERY, an Irishman, 52 years of age, was admitted to the New-York Hospital, suffering from a broken jaw. He made various statements as to the manner in which he received his injury, at one time saying that he had been attacked by a gang of rowdies, one of whom struck him on the jaw with his fist, and at another asserting that a brick had been thrown at him, and his jaw had been fractured in that way. He was unable to state where the occurrence took place, and after lingering until Saturday, he died of inflammation of the brain. Yesterday Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest, but was unable to obtain evidence implicating any person, and a verdict of death from inflammation of the brain was rendered.
lead_paragraph: On the 15th inst., ROBERT SLATTERY, an Irishman, 52 years of age, was admitted to the New-York Hospital, suffering from a broken jaw. He was unable to state where the occurrence took place, and after lingering until Saturday, he died of inflammation of the brain. abstract: Bureau has just received ninety-four boxes and two barrels, containing a fine assortment of seeds and cuttings, from Beinet, Syria. These articles had been collected by desire of the late Commissioner of Patents Mr. HOLT, through the agency of his friend, Rev Dr. BARCLAY, who, by his position and knowledge of the Holy Land, was well qualified for the task. The assortment is composed of varieties of wheat, barley, grape cuttings, olives, scions of fruits and vegetable products. The cuttings, scions, &c., will be sent to the new propagating houses for experiment and increase, and no distribution will be made of the remainder until Fall. Among the interesting plants may be mentioned the Lessaban. It is believed by many that the crown of thorns was plaited of the branches of this tree. It makes an excellent article for hedges, and thus has a positive value, independent of any such tradition. As a tree it is very ornamental. There are also seeds of melon, squashes, &c., camel's food, dates, walnuts, equal to the English, and probably well adapted to' the middle and Southern States. The mais-tree is esteemed as medicinal, or rather prophylactic. The seeds sent were procured from the tree growing within the inclosure of the ancient temple of Sodom.

abstract: An indignant Briton takes the world and ourselves rather sharply to task for laughing at the British Volunteers and their grand review in Hyde Park. It is a curious feature in the progress of the age, that the traits which used to be considered most characteristically American are disappearing on this side of the water only to come out very strongly among our trans-atlantic cousins. ELIJAH POGRAM himself, that terrible fel- ...
lead_paragraph: An indignant Briton takes the world and ourselves rather sharply to task for laughing at the British Volunteers and their grand review in Hyde Park. It is a curious feature in the progress of the age, that the traits which used to be considered most characteristically American are disappearing on this side of the water only to come out very strongly among our trans-atlantic cousins. ELIJAH POGRAM himself, that terrible fellow who was always defying the despots of the earth and flinging back the insolent criticisms of an effete aristocracy into their own faces, seems to have crossed the seas and taken up his abode in the "inviolate isle." What with Mr. ROEBUCK, the "ban-dog of England," and Mr. KINGLAKE, who is just as familiar with the secret designs of Louis NAPOLEON, as Mr. POTT of the Eatanswill Gazette was with the machinations of the Czar NICHOLAS; and the incessant thunder of the London Times against the wiles and the wickedness of France, Russia and the United States, our excellent English friends are fast invading our ancient monopoly of fluent Buncombe and cutaneous susceptibility. We are sorry to see this, for we have a very sincere respect for our kinsmen, and we think it hardly fair that, after taking so much pains as they have throughout our whole early history, to point out to us, in the most benevolent manner in the world, our little failings and follies, they should now refuse us the privilege of discharging our debt in kind, and fall into a rage with us for quizzing them when they are quizzical. It is not the fault of America surely that the British people are afflicted with what the Russian journal, Le Nord, very happily calls an "intermittent fever of fear," or that being so afflicted, they are occasionally betrayed into ways and words which are too essentially absurd not to be ludicrous. If President BUCHANAN should review twenty thousand volunteers at Washington, and the American Press should thereupon announce that the United States were in a position to defy any foe, and begin to talk about regulating the affairs of mankind and improving the morals of monarchs, the American Press would do a very silly thing. Is the same thing any the less silly when it is done by the British Press on no better provocation? Our Britannic correspondent quite misses the real reason of the world's mirth over the Hyde Park demonstration. There is nothing contemptible in the attempt of England to put herself on a level with other powers in regard to her means of self-defence. On the contrary, it is highly creditable to the English people that they should frankly recognize the exposed and unprepared condition of their country, and energetically go to work to remedy it. But unless on Dr. JOHNSON's theory that "most foreigners are fools," Englishmen cannot possibly expect the "rest of mankind" to be awed by a parade of twenty thousand more or less blundering militia-men before a Queen in a close-carriage, or to accept the first crude result of a hastily organized popular enthusiasm as decisive proof that England has at last determined to become a great military nation. The present volunteer movement in Great Britain is respectable as a movement only. It has been engineered into existence by a combined effort of the leaders of English opinion, and is still, as every thoughtful Englishman must admit, in the condition rather of a fashionable emotion than of an established institution. It may certainly become in time a permanent feature in English life, and it will then be rational for Englishmen to count upon it as an element of the national strength. To compare it now, as our correspondent does, with the militia system of the United States is simply absurd. The militia system of the United States is a tradition of our colonial history. It is fixed in the habits, tastes and character of our people and although it is no doubt a very good joke that Colonels are as plentiful in Tennessee or Texas as Counts in Germany or Italy, or Knights in the City of London, still it is a great mistake to suppose that this joke has not its very serious side. The forms of a vast volunteer army are maintained by our militia, system through-out the Union; the spirit with which these forms are animated, is a part of the popular life, and although the temper of the public mind in regard to military matters, ebbs and flows as it does in regard to everything else under the sun, the permanent fact remains that every American adult in every generation is availably within the reach of his country whenever his services in the field may be needed. It is the aim of the Englishmen who are at the head of the volunteer movement in Great Britain to make this which is true of America true of England also. Our correspondent thinks they have attained their aim, at least as fully as it is attained in America. We do not agree with him, and he has certainly fallen into some sad mistakes in respect both to the organization of the militia forces of the United States and the condition of the Volunteer movement in his own country. On the authority of the Army Register for 1859, he quotes the enrolled Militia of the Union at 2,100,000. That authority puts down the total force at 2,727,486. He impugns the efficiency of our Militia on the strength of its general and staff organization, quoting the Army Register to prove that California in 1857 had 18 Generals for every 11,500 men. The Army Register, indeed, assigns eighteen Generals to California, but gives them 207,400 men to command. In his haste to "explode the American imposition," our correspondent has carried the 11,500 militia-men of Florida to the account of the Golden State. How he came by the still more extraordinary notion that the rifle is a weapon almost unknown to the United States, and that any man in New-York can "count on his fingers all his friends and acquaintances who ever draw a ramrod from January to December," we own ourselves unable to imagine. It is a pure flight of fancy, only paralleled by the assertion that, of the 124,000 uniformed British volunteers, every man is "carefully trained in company and battalion drill." So far is this from being the case, that the Saturday Review, the favorite organ of the volunteer movement, in commenting upon the display of the elite of these volunteers before the Queen at Wimbledon, finds it necessary to deplore "the fact that their movements generally showed some irregularity, and the spectacle -- painful to a military eye -- of some of them trailing, and others carrying, their arms as they moved in file in the actual presence of the Queen."
headline: {'main': 'Volunteers, English and American.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Volunteers, English and American.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Saturday night Capt. Dowling, of the Sixth Precinct, assisted by Officer Riordan, arrested Richard Bavendaun, a German, who keeps a drinking-place at No. 45 Baxter-street, on suspicion of having murdered on the night of the 30th of July, 1859, one Juan B. Gustarino, a native of Gibraltar, who was found dead in the alley-way of No. 37 1/2 Baxter-street. Bavendaun was apprehended at the instance of Mary O'Brien, a woman of very bad reputation, who made the following statement to the Police: At the time of the alleged murder she was a tenant of the accused, who rented the house No. 37 1/2 Baxter-street, and sublet appartments to a variety of disreputable people, the majority of whom, however, were women of her class. On the night in question the induced. Gustarino to visit her room, and it was not long before she ascertained that he had a considerable sum of money in a belt about his waist. This information she communicated to Bavendaun, and they agreed upon a plan to murder and rob him. Accordingly she returned to her room, and soon afterwards Bavendaun came up and struck Gustarino with a club as he lay asleep upon the bed, until he became unconscious. His money was then taken from him, and after his coat and hat were replaced, the still insensible man was removed by Bavendaun with the assistance of Margaret Welsh, another of the occupants of the house, to the alley-way, and placed in a a sitting posture. Next morning he was discovered by the police in the position in which he had been left, and it was supposed that his death was the result of intemperance. Coroner JACKMAN, however, held an inquest upon the body, and Dr. John Beach made a partial post-mortem examination, which demonstrated that death had been produced by a rupture of one of the small blood vessels, which was very much diseased. A verdict was therefore rendered in accordance with the physician's testimony. The woman, O'Brien, stated to Capt. Dowling, that she removed from the house immediately after the murder, and that until recently she had been on friendly terms with Bavendaun. A quarrel having occurred between them, however, she had been prompted to avenge herself by yielding him into the hands of the officers. The only corroborating circumstance in support of her singular story is the record at the Coroner's office of Gustarino's death, but Coroner JACKHAN and Dr. BEACH believe it to be a malicious fabrication. No external marks of the alleged violence were visible on the person of the deceased, and this fact the doctor considered sufficient, after ascertaing that the blood-vessel had been fractured, to warrant him in waiving a thorough examination. As the case now stands, it is the duty of the District-Attorney to have the remains exhumed, and order a new investigation, by which means the charge would probably be either verified or disproved. Bavendaun was yesterday taken before Justice WELSH, who committed him to the Tombs. The women O'Brien and Welsh are also in custody, and have been placed in the White-street House of Detention as witnesses.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night Capt. Dowling, of the Sixth Precinct, assisted by Officer Riordan, arrested Richard Bavendaun, a German, who keeps a drinking-place at No. 45 Baxter-street, on suspicion of having murdered on the night of the 30th of July, 1859, one Juan B. Gustarino, a native of Gibraltar, who was found dead in the alley-way of No. 37 1/2 Baxter-street. Bavendaun was apprehended at the instance of Mary O'Brien, a woman of very bad reputation, who made the following statement to the Police: At the time of the alleged murder she was a tenant of the accused, who rented the house No. 37 1/2 Baxter-street, and sublet appartments to a variety of disreputable people, the majority of whom, however, were women of her class. On the night in question the induced. Gustarino to visit her room, and it was not long before she ascertained that he had a considerable sum of money in a belt about his waist. This information she communicated to Bavendaun, and they agreed upon a plan to murder and rob him. Accordingly she returned to her room, and soon afterwards Bavendaun came up and struck Gustarino with a club as he lay asleep upon the bed, until he became unconscious. His money was then taken from him, and after his coat and hat were replaced, the still insensible man was removed by Bavendaun with the assistance of Margaret Welsh, another of the occupants of the house, to the alley-way, and placed in a a sitting posture. Next morning he was discovered by the police in the position in which he had been left, and it was supposed that his death was the result of intemperance. Coroner JACKMAN, however, held an inquest upon the body, and Dr. John Beach made a partial post-mortem examination, which demonstrated that death had been produced by a rupture of one of the small blood vessels, which was very much diseased. A verdict was therefore rendered in accordance with the physician's testimony. The woman, O'Brien, stated to Capt. Dowling, that she removed from the house immediately after the murder, and that until recently she had been on friendly terms with Bavendaun. A quarrel having occurred between them, however, she had been prompted to avenge herself by yielding him into the hands of the officers. The only corroborating circumstance in support of her singular story is the record at the Coroner's office of Gustarino's death, but Coroner JACKHAN and Dr. BEACH believe it to be a malicious fabrication. No external marks of the alleged violence were visible on the person of the deceased, and this fact the doctor considered sufficient, after ascertaing that the blood-vessel had been fractured, to warrant him in waiving a thorough examination. As the case now stands, it is the duty of the District-Attorney to have the remains exhumed, and order a new investigation, by which means the charge would probably be either verified or disproved. Bavendaun was yesterday taken before Justice WELSH, who committed him to the Tombs. The women O'Brien and Welsh are also in custody, and have been placed in the White-street House of Detention as witnesses.

abstract: The unfortunate Cass-Herran Treaty with New-Granada, after being shipwrecked twice, has at length reached Washington in charge of our Minister, Ex-Senator JONES of Iowa, who returned by the Ariel. It was first lost on its way to Bogota for ratification, on the Magdalena River, and subsequently, after ratification, on the passage from Carthagena. Even now, however, its benefits cannot be realized before the passage of a law by Congress providing for a commission for the settlement of claims under it, and making an appropriation to defray the necessary expenses. Gen. JONES, it is understood, is very popular at Bogota, and will soon return there.

abstract: The Danville (Va.) Appeal of the 25th says: "A duel was fought yesterday morning between Messrs. A.J. CLARK and EDMOND FITZGERALD, which resulted in the wounding of the latter. His injuries, however, are believed not to be serious, the ball having only penetrated his body to a limited extent. The weapons used were rifles, distance forty paces. The scene of the duel was a few miles from town in the neighboring County of Caswell, N.C.

abstract: (Mass.), Eagle, that Messrs. D. & H. STEARNS, of that place, found last week, in a bale of wool purchased in Boston, a stone weighing 83 pounds. The wool was imported from the Cape of Good Hope, where the stone was doubtless put in the bale. Sand in large quantities, and small stones up to the weight of one or two pounds, are often found in imported wool.

abstract: (N.Y.,) Banner says: The residence of RUDOLPH ROHR, in the town of New Bremen, was the scene of a most horrid tragedy, on Saturday and Sunday last. The following are the particulars as they were given at the Coroner's inquest: For several years past Mrs. LAURA ROHR, wife of RUDOLPH ROHR, was at times partly deranged, in consequence of religious excitement and dissatisfaction with her marriage relations. Early on Friday morning she came to the hay-field where her husband was at work, and informed him that the little boy (their only child, about four years old,) was missing. Mr. ROHR replied that he would go and look for him; she, however, insisted on his remaining at his work, saying she would find him. After a half hour might have elapsed, Mr. ROHR felt uneasy at the non-appearance of neither mother or child. He repaired to the house, found it deserted, and locking the doors, immediately commenced searching the neighborhood, without success. On returning to his house he found one of the doors open, and upon looking into the bedroom, his little boy lay upon the bed, dead, with a note in the hand-writing; of his wife across his forehead, saying: "The child died an easy death." The mother could not be found. Some time after she made her appearance, looking very wild, and denying having killed the child. She stated that while engaged in praying with the child, he suddenly died. Saturday night she with other persons watched over the corpse of the child, appearing rational. About 6 o'clock. Sunday morning, she left the house. Nothing was thought of it at first, until Mr. ROHR's razor case was discovered on the table, the razor was gone. Search was immediately made, and the unfortunate woman found in the bam, with her throat partly cut. She was alive, not having injured any of the main arteries. Her windpipe was about two thirds cut through.
lead_paragraph: (N.Y.,) Banner says: The residence of RUDOLPH ROHR, in the town of New Bremen, was the scene of a most horrid tragedy, on Saturday and Sunday last. The mother could not be found. Some time after she made her appearance, looking very wild, and denying having killed the child. abstract: We have received from Messrs. FRAZAR & CO., of this city, a copy of their Japanese Circular, which furnishes us with dates from Nagasaki to May 1. Business had improved considerably, and the exports of tea, wax, seaweed, &c., show a marked increase. There had been a fleet of about a dozen whaleships, principally American, in port during the month of April, which had received outfits and repairs, and left again for the Japan Seas to cruise. Horses are daily shipped to Shanghai for the use of the Allies in China. The American ship Kate Hooper chartered by the French Government, takes 260 horses to Shanghai, and the bark Maryland also takes a quantity on French Government account. The English are taking up several large ships in China to send to Nagasaki as transports for horses, which are now being collected in Japan. In regard to exports it is stated that the arrivals of produce at Nagasaki from the country have been more extensive than ever noted before, and there is great activity displayed at the present time in shipping to Shanghai and Hong-Kong. A brisk business this Summer is anticipated, as the Japanese are more and more disposed to enter into contracts with foreigners for supplies for the Chinese and home markets. Japanese tea[???] are much sought after for the English and American markets, and the exports of these have increased very materially. The Vesper, an American whaler, was in contact off Nagasaki with the Amoor, Russian whaler, and both returned for repairs. The captain of the Amoor jumped overboard and was drowned. No allusion is made in the circular to any political troubles. The wharf improvements at Nagasaki progress favorably.

abstract: The good people of Somerset County, Md., seem to be quite furious upon the oyster question. At a recent meeting of the citizens of Dame's Quarter and vicinity, much enthusiasm prevailed. The preamble and resolutions adopted on the occasion pronounce that "the Legislature, through covert means, and a willful negligence of our interests, have granted our oyster-rocks and shoals to an exclusive few, thereby depriving us of the means of gaining an honest livelihood; that in expressing indignation at such action, we particularize the delegates of our County (who voted for the bill referred to) in our censure of the acts of the Legislature, and that we will not support them or their co-members for any office hereafter in the gift of the people." The resolutions further set forth that any action of the monopolists will be resisted; that a Committee shall be appointed to warn off any and all vessels attempting to locate warrants; that, if they persist, a competent force shall be called out to drive the vessels away.
lead_paragraph: The good people of Somerset County, Md., seem to be quite furious upon the oyster question. abstract: Everybody expected that on Saturday, which was advertised as the last day of the exhibition of the Great Eastern, she would be crowded more than ever, but such was not the case. Partly, because everybody thought so, most people, fearful of the threatened squeeze, forebore to go, and partly the great vessel received far less than her usual number of visitors from the fact that Saturday is a very awkward day for country excursionists, and accordingly none came. Still, from eleven to welve thousand persons went onboard, moving about with comparative ease. The only event worthy of notice, was an attack on the first officer, Mr. MATCHIN, by one of the crew, who had just been relieved from a twelve day's confinement for drunkenness and insubordinate conduct. Mr. MATCHIN was pacing the deck, when the fellow attacked him with his fists, drawing blood and wounding him severely. Two or three others of the crew joined in the assault, whereupon the police arrested the whole of them, and conveyed them to the station-house, where, on an examination before the magistrate, they were committed for trial. In the evening, the ticket office was closed up, and the entrance and exit gangways removed.

abstract: SIR: The popular mind inclines to the sentiment that national self-respect should shield the position of President from any exposure of the delinquencies of the incumbent. The Constitution declares otherwise, and, in your case, it is most healthy for the public to advance to the constitutional limit. You have, besides, voluntarily entered the lists of partisan discussion, inviting all the consequences of the position.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK, Monday, July 30, 1860.

abstract: -- Says the Mobile Mercury of July 24: "Some negroes, who never learned to talk English, went up the railroad the other day. They don't get aboard at Mobile, but somewhere up in the piney woods country. It is not necessary to mention the particular place. There were twenty-five of them, apparently all of the pure, unadulterated African stock. Their destination is unknown. They may have been bound for Enterprise, to supply a demand which existed in that market some while ago for full-blooded African slaves, as per advertisement of sundry gentlemen up there, offering to buy such at a certain price. They were in charge of one who knows how to buy and sell negroes.
lead_paragraph: -- Says the Mobile Mercury of July 24: "Some negroes, who never learned to talk English, went up the railroad the other day. abstract: -- An attempt was made, on Saturday night last, to throw off the track, on the Worcester Railroad, the New-York Express train, coming east. The attempt was made about one mile south of the Framingham station, by placing several sleepers across the rails, which, in the darkness, were not seen by the engineer of the train until the locomotive was within a few feet of them, when it was too late to attempt to stop the train, then going at a high rate of speed. When the locomotive struck the obstructing sleepers all but one of them were thrown under the advancing train, without doing any damage. One of the sleepers, however, was caught between the side of the cow-catcher and the rail, where it was wedged so tight that it required nearly an hour to clear it from the engine. The most singular feature of the matter, and, indeed, it appears almost miraculous to the people in the train, was that not even the locomotive was thrown from the track, and not a person or car injured, although the passengers sustained quite a severe jar by the sudden stopping of the train. -- Boston Herald.
lead_paragraph: -- An attempt was made, on Saturday night last, to throw off the track, on the Worcester Railroad, the New-York Express train, coming east. The attempt was made about one mile south of the Framingham station, by placing several sleepers across the rails, which, in the darkness, were not seen by the engineer of the train until the locomotive was within a few feet of them, when it was too late to attempt to stop the train, then going at a high rate of speed. When the locomotive struck the obstructing sleepers all but one of them were thrown under the advancing train, without doing any damage. One of the sleepers, however, was caught between the side of the cow-catcher and the rail, where it was wedged so tight that it required nearly an hour to clear it from the engine. The most singular feature of the matter, and, indeed, it appears almost miraculous to the people in the train, was that not even the locomotive was thrown from the track, and not a person or car injured, although the passengers sustained quite a severe jar by the sudden stopping of the train. -- Boston Herald.

abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the body of a man was found floating in the water at the foot of York-street. The deceased was apparently a seaman, and was dressed in grey pants, black satin vest and brogans. His right hand grasped a three-quarter-inch rope, which he had apparently seized to save himself at the time of falling in the water. No marks of violence were found on him to indicate foul play. The following articles, which may lead to the identification of the body, were found in his pockets. A note to this effect:

abstract: On Saturday evening HENRY PAEBLA, a German, residing at No. 115 Third-street, was dangerously stabbed in the abdomen by another German named ADAM JAEGER, whom he met in a lager bier saloon in Third-street. At the time of the assault JAEGER was intoxicated, and it does not appear that any provocation was offered. PAEBLA was promptly removed by the police to Bellevue Hospital, where yesterday he was considered to be in so low a state that Coroner GAMBLE was summoned to take his ante-mortem deposition. He stated: "On Sunday night about ten o'clock I called at Mr. MYERS' lager-bier saloon in Third-street, between First-avenue and Avenue A, in order to get a glass of beer; I was about to leave the place and met a woman at the door, who asked me to bring her husband (JAEGER) from the saloon; I went back and told the man that she had pointed out that his wife was at the door and wanted to see him; he replied that he would go directly; we then drank together, and immediately afterwards he left in company with his wife and another man; ten minutes afterwards he returned to the saloon, and remarked that his wife had left him; I observed that he was intoxicated, and offered to see him home; he consented and we walked down Third-street towards Avenue A; another man joined us after we went into the street, and we all walked together; when we reached the corner of Avenue A I wished Jager good night, and was going home when he turned quickly around and stabbed me in the abdomen." JAGER, who had been apprehended immediately after the occurrence, was brought before the wounded man, who at once recognized him as his assailant. He was thereupon committed by the Coroner, pending the result of his victim's injuries. The accused states that he was intoxicated, and knows nothing of the transaction.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening HENRY PAEBLA, a German, residing at No. 115 Third-street, was dangerously stabbed in the abdomen by another German named ADAM JAEGER, whom he met in a lager bier saloon in Third-street. abstract: By the census of 1850, the aggregate number of slaves in the United States was 3,204,313. Of this number, 246,656 were of mixed blood, mulattoes,  The number of unmixed negro blood was, therefore, 2,487,455. The free black and mulatto population was 434,495, in the following proportions; blacks, 275,400; mulattoes, 159,095.

abstract: -- A burial lot purchased by the Franklin Typographical Society and Printers' Union, of Boston, at Mount Hope Cemetry, was dedicated on Saturday afternoon with appropriate ceremonies. An extra train over the Providence Railroad conveyed about 300 printers, with their wives and friends, to the ground, where a large number had already assembled. The services began by reading appropriate selections from Scripture, by Rev. A.A. MINER, who officiated as chaplain for the occasion, following the Scripture lesson with an impressive dedicatory prayer. Prof. E.H. FROST, assisted by a choir of sixteen young ladies then joined in singing a hymn, after which Mr. CHARLES H. WOODWELL, President of the Franklin Typographical Society, delivered an address.

abstract: While the procession was crossing Division-street bridge, over Fond du Lac River, it gave way under such an unwonted load of Democracy as had gathered upon it, and let the crowd into the water below. Fortunately the mud was much deeper than the water, and no other serious consequences ensued than the fright and the thick envelope of slough material brought up by those whom the bridge refused to transport in safety over this peril in the line of march. Several ladies took the unwelcome descent, and when rescued appeared in a much deeper shade of mourning than is a usual style of dress at a gala celebration. The light of torches changed to a scene of merriment among a crowd of fun-loving boys, what might otherwise have been a serious accident. -- Janasville (Wis.) Gazette.

abstract: The sixth annual regatta of the Empire City Regatta Club, which comes off the 10th of September next, promises to be a splendid affair. In addition to the usual prizes offered, which will amount this year to upwards of $400, a splendid silver pitcher is to be offered to amateurs throughout the United States. It is expected that the amateur oarsmen of Harvard and Yale Colleges and Brown University will join in the competition. The prize is confined to six-oared lapstreak boats.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, about 4 1/2 o'clock, the Great Eastern left her anchorage in the middle of the stream, in the North River, and proceeded on her Cape May excursion. She had between eleven and twelve hundred people on board, nearly all of whom had paid ten dollars each for their ticket. Among those who were invited, to do excellent service, were Sergeant DICKSON and four other officers attached to the Detective Police, who will prevent operations on the part of some noted thieves, who are known to have purchased tickets, expecting, undoubtedly, to realize the amount of them, twenty or fifty fold.

abstract: -- The number of vessels with cargoes clearing at the river ports of Virginia, for Northern cities, during the months of April, May and June, 1860, was 1,200, as follows: From Hampton Roads 696; York River, 109; Rappahannock, 88; Alexandria, 307. These were all sailing vessels. During the same time there have been 103 trips made by steamers from Norfolk to Philadelphia, New-York and Boston. The export of oysters to Northern cities alone amounted to 250 cargoes during the months of April and May, exceeding both in amount and value any other item of exports to the North made in the same time.

abstract: The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton on the 18th, arrived at this port yesterday, and the Bohemian, from Liverpool and Londonderry on the 19th, also arrived yesterday at Quebec. The intelligence by these arrivals is late and interesting. Particulars are received of the massacre of Christians at Damascus by the Druses. It is greatly feared that FUAD PACHA will not be able to arrest the tide of bloodshed, in which case France and England will interfere peremptorily. Russia, also, has expressed a desire to act in concert with the Western Powers. The Russian Cabinet reiterates its opinion that the events now transpiring in Syria hold in suspense the peace of the world, and that the very existence of Turkey is at stake. The Emperor NAPOLEON had received a letter from the Sultan, asseverating that he will use all the power at his command to restore order in Syria. All the accounts agree in saying that more massacres are contemplated, and will occur, if not prevented with a strong hand.

abstract: JENKINS and SHARKEY arrested, at Fifth and Market streets, a colored man, who was pointed out as a fugitive slave -- a warrant having been issued on the oath of JOSHUA BATEMEN, of Georgetown, D.C., for the arrest of BENJAMIN HARDEN, an alleged fugitive rom labor. The prisoner was on a dray when captured, and the neighborhood being thronged at the time, considerable excitement was the result. He was taken to the Marshal's office, where Mr. BATEMAN was in waiting. On the way he resisted the officers, but no more force was used than was necessary. Upon arriving at the office, Mr. BATEMAN said he was not the fugitive, and the officer at once released him. The name of the person taken into custody is BENJAMIN VALENTINE. He is about 50 years old, and it is said, came from Salem, N.J. He has a family residing in Whitehall-street, and it is said to have been driving dray in this city for twenty-six years. The officers did not act until they had the best reason for believing they were right. Mr. BATEMAN and his agent came on to the city a week or more ago, and, seeing VALENTINE, declared he was the man; they then want back, procured the necessary papers, and returned on Friday, bringing three others with them. Upon a second view of VALENTINE, Mr. BATEMAN reiterated his opinion, in which his neighbors joined. Their did not discover their mistake, so strong was the resamblance, until the prisoner began to talk. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 30.

abstract: Mr. J.B. GUTHRIE, of Washington, special agent of the Treasury office, upon whose report an officer of the Custom House in this City was removed from his post, takes serious exception to an editorial statement in the TIMES, which appears to him to imply that he was, or might have been, governed by unworthy motives in the discharge of his duty.
lead_paragraph: Mr. J.B. GUTHRIE, of Washington, special agent of the Treasury office, upon whose report an officer of the Custom House in this City was removed from his post, takes serious exception to an editorial statement in the TIMES, which appears to him to imply that he was, or might have been, governed by unworthy motives in the discharge of his duty. We have the authority of gentlemen of the highest position for believing Mr. GUTHRIE to be a man of character and capacity, and we own ourselves, therefore, a little surprised that he should require anything more than his own reflection in the matter to satisfy him that in commenting upon the transaction with which his name was in this instance connected, we neither had, nor could have had the slightest reason for doing him any injustice whatever. Mr. GUTHRIE appears in the matter simply as an official of the Government, commissioned to investigate charges preferred by other people against one of its subordinate functionaries. It is one of the disagreeable incidents of official station that the victims of any decision, however impartially and honorably it may have been rendered, are always swift to regard their judge as their enemy, and one of the unenviable privileges of the Press to be made the voice of all who are, or think themselves aggrieved. We certainly do not undertake to indorse all the complaints of the decapitated, knowing very well that a man is never less likely to talk either equity or common sense than when his head is off, and Mr. GUTHRIE should do us the justice to believe that if it is offensive to him to fancy that his character has been attacked, it is far from pleasant to us to be supposed guilty of attacking it.

abstract: Very few men live long enough to survive their habits. Mr. GEORGE SANDERS, known among his friends as at once the shrewdest of politicians and the gentlest of gentlemen, has fallen into the habit of vituperating the venerable and exalted Chief Magistrate of this great and glorious Union; and a glance at the latest effort of his rhetoric, reproduced in another column, will prove that each fresh assault is made with added fury and force of language. It would be unfair, we suspect, to acquit Mr. SANDERS of having "read up" in this particular field of rhetoric since he opened his epistolary warfare. There are traces in his style indicative of recent familiarity with all the great masters in all ages, of the art of oratorical scolding, from the philippics of the Athenian to the snarling and vindictive diatribes of "Junius." From such waters of Marah none but the bitterest draughts can be drawn. And in pressing the cup brimfull of them to the reluctant lips of the President, the better nature of our writer seems to have vanished, and he exults as he administers the wormwood with a certain unconcealed subhuman ferocity. Mr. BUCHANAN would hardly have experienced equal disgust and anger when that little bill for the famous Charleston dispatch of his advisory friend had to be footed to the tune of forty dollars, to that which he will experience when he comes to peruse this wrathful effort of invective.

Mr. GEORGE SANDERS, known among his friends as at once the shrewdest of politicians and the gentlest of gentlemen, has fallen into the habit of vituperating the venerable and exalted Chief Magistrate of this great and glorious Union; and a glance at the latest effort of his rhetoric, reproduced in another column, will prove that each fresh assault is made with added fury and force of language. It would be unfair, we suspect, to acquit Mr. SANDERS of having "read up" in this particular field of rhetoric since he opened his epistolary warfare. There are traces in his style indicative of recent familiarity with all the great masters in all ages, of the art of oratorical scolding, from the philippics of the Athenian to the snarling and vindictive diatribes of "Junius." From such waters of Marah none but the bitterest draughts can be drawn. And in pressing the cup brimfull of them to the reluctant lips of the President, the better nature of our writer seems to have vanished, and he exults as he administers the wormwood with a certain unconcealed subhuman ferocity. Mr. BUCHANAN would hardly have experienced equal disgust and anger when that little bill for the famous Charleston dispatch of his advisory friend had to be footed to the tune of forty dollars, to that which he will experience when he comes to peruse this wrathful effort of invective.

abstract: -- Messrs. TRACY and DANSE, messengers of the State Savings Institution of this city, were mysteriously deprived of a large sum of money while on their way hither on a steamboat, on Saturday night or yesterday morning. We give the details as furnished us by Capt. E.A. SHEBLE, of the Keokuk Packet Company's steamer City of Louisiana, which arrived in port yesterday morning, about 5 o'clock. Arriving at Hannibal, on her down trip, at 5 o'clock yesterday evening, the Louisiana was boarded by two messengers, who had just been to and returned from Independence, Missouri, having collected the sum of $33,000 specie for the paper of one of our branch banks located in that city. The messengers desired to have the money, $15,000, in one carpet sack, and $18,000 in another, placed in the boat's safe, but the clerks have a standing order to receive no large sums on deposit, as these packets always have a messenger of the United States Express on board. To that gentleman Messrs. T. & D. were referred, but after due deliberation they announced their intention of retaining the specie in their own charge, and accordingly they retired to their room, agreeing that one should watch while the other slept. The drowsy god, however, is no respecter of persons, and closed the eyes of both, the watcher being ensconced on a chair on the guard. At Cap-au-Gris, when the Die Vernon was met, the money was safe, but shortly after, about half-past one, Saturday night -- one of the messengers hurried along the cabin, found the porter, and had Capt. SHEBLE aroused from his berth, and informed him that the sack containing the $15,000 had disappeared, and another sack been put in its place. The sleeper had been aroused in the dar, suspected some person was in the room, and on quickly placing his hand on the shelf above him, where the sacks were placed, found that one was gone. Capt. SHEBLE instituted a search of all the passengers and every room and recess of the boat, but found not the smallest trace of the missing sack or money, and the messengers were in despair. On arriving here, information of the robbery was communicated to the police office, and officers were sent to prevent any person or thing from leaving the boat, while other officers proceeded anew to search the persons on board. The Detectives TUNNICLIFFE and RYAN were called, and they continued the search, extending it through the ladies' cabin. When things had been thus progressing fruitlessly for nearly an hour Officer EAGEN, of the City Police, came on board, and on learning the history of the case passed back through the gentlemen's cabin, in stateroom No. 25, between two mattresses, found two parcels of the money. Officer TUNNICLIFFE then found a third parcel in another berth of the same room -- the three parcels being the amount lost minus $100. The inference is that the thief or thieves adroitly transferred the packages from their persons to the berths while the search was proceeding, and after those berths had been searched, hoping that the money would remain undisturbed until the watch was relaxed when they could carry it ashore.

abstract: number of the Theatre-keepers received the polite attention of the Sheriff last week. Broadway and the Bowery both had scenes not set down in the bills. Various suits for offences against the Theatre-license Act and the recent Sunday Law, were commenced in the Supreme Court, some for penalties and some by injunctions. The Volks Garden people, who have so long trifled with the License Law, not liking the looks of matters a la EUSTACHI and HARMANN, under Judge BONNEY's decisions, are said by the Staats Zeitung to have applied for legal permission to give theatricals. The National Theatre people have done the same thing. The "Melodeon," and one or two other Broadway concerns are expected to follow suit. GUSTAV LINDENMULLER gave bail -- as he has done on various indictments -- and will probably keep on breaking the laws. Perhaps a process of injunction will be the only one he will regard.

abstract: FAREWELL TO A SWEDISH MISSIONARY. -- A meeting was held last evening at the Mariners' Church, No. 234 Cherry-street, for the purpose of bidding a formal farewell to Rev. Mr. O.F. NILSSON, a Swedish Baptist preacher about to return to his native country. Mr. NILSSON has been in this country about nine years, having been banished from Sweden on account of his religious opinions. He will leave this port on Wednesday, his expenses being borne by several churches in this City. Quite a large collection towards paying his passage was taken up last evening. He has also been promised support when he reaches his native land. He will probably now, however, suffer little persecution, as there are said to be 104 regular Baptist Churches there, sustained by about five thousand persons who have been baptized; and as he returns at the especial request of his friends in that country. The introductory remarks last evening were made by Rev. IRA R. STEWART, the pastor of the church, who was followed by Mr. LEAR, a member of the South Baptist Church Sunday School, which contributes towards defraying Mr. NILSSON's expenses. Mr. NILSSON made a few remarks, thanking his friends for their kindness, and expressing his happiness in returning to preach the Gospel to his people. After another short address by Rev. Mr. SARLES, of Brooklyn, and a prayer by Rev. Mr. DORRANCE, of the North Carolina Chapel, the meeting was dismissed.

abstract: Great curiosity exists among our peculiarly curious people as to the monetary result of the Great Eastern's speculating tour. She has been loosed from her Southampton moorings just forty-four days; during that period of time she has crossed the Atlantic successfully, has been received here enthusiastically, and visited constantly.
lead_paragraph: Great curiosity exists among our peculiarly curious people as to the monetary result of the Great Eastern's speculating tour. She has been loosed from her Southampton moorings just forty-four days; during that period of time she has crossed the Atlantic successfully, has been received here enthusiastically, and visited constantly. Her first experiment ended yesterday afternoon, when, with her load of sensationists, she departed hence for the stirring life of Cape May, and bound upon a second trip of commercial experiment. But to recur: has her first experiment been a financial success?

abstract: Early, yesterday morning George Leese, a middle-aged Englishman, residing at No. 221 Centre-street, was taken into custody on a charge of having attempted to shoot John Reed, of No. 524 Broomestreet, against whom he has long cherished feelings of animosity.
lead_paragraph: Early, yesterday morning George Leese, a middle-aged Englishman, residing at No. 221 Centre-street, was taken into custody on a charge of having attempted to shoot John Reed, of No. 524 Broomestreet, against whom he has long cherished feelings of animosity. Leese asserts that for a long time past an inexcusable intimacy has existed between Reed and his wife, and under these circumstances he had been forbidden to call at the house. Having gone home late on Sunday evening, Leese was astonished to find that the object of his hatred had braved his injunction, and was then enjoying the society of Mrs. Leese. Deeming the occurrence a matter that admitted of no explanation, he drew a pistol and pointed it at Reed's breast, but the cap failed to explode. Meantime the intended victim, in attempting to shield himself from the angry husband, stumbled on the stairs, and the misstep probably saved his life, for at that instant the ball from Leese's pistol whizzed above his head, and before Leese could commit further violence, he escaped. Leese was soon afterwards arrested, and yesterday he was brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH to answer a charge preferred by Reed of assault with intent to kill. In his examination he told his grievances, and added that the pistol was discharged accidentally. The circumstances, however, did not support his statement, and he was committed for trial in default of $1,000 bail. The prisoner is a picture frame maker by occupation, and it is said of somewhat dissolute habits. His wife made no attempt to afford him consolation in his trouble.

abstract: It is satisfactory to know that the Chinese authorities have at last resolved to discountenance the traffic in coolies. That the most horrible abuses have distinguished this trade is perfectly well known. In gross immorality and reckless disregard of life it is the rival of the Slave-trade. Hundreds of vessels annually leave certain notorious Chinese ports, laden with their living freight, and it is not even denied that a majority of the laborers are stolen from their homes, with the connivance and assistance of Government officials. The vessels, thus freighted, are under no legal obligations, and are bound by no contract. The masters or owners are at liberty to act as their own cruelty, or selfishness, or love of gain may dictate. In almost every case the ship is overcrowded, and the mortality on the passage frequently rises as high as fifty per cent. This immigration is chiefly carried on with the Chinchas and with Cuba. Peru, to her credit be it said, has, by judicious legislation, repressed the cruelty and avarice of her citizens engaged in the coolie trade; but Spain still offers every inducement to British and American vessels to prosecute a traffic which both British and American authorities have over and over again declared to be illegal. The immense demand for labor, and the hope of large gains, deaden the conscience of the Cuban proprietor to the voice of humanity. It is not to him that the world looks for the redress of this wrong; nor yet to Spain, who has evinced an utter disregard of public faith and of obligations that she solemnly bound herself to perform; but to the great Powers of Europe and America, who have not yet undertaken to arrest a practice so abhorrent to humanity, and so disgraceful to the civilization of the age in which we live.

abstract: On the arrival of the Republican Blues at Savannah, after their trip to New-York, they were received in their native city with a grand military display. The steamer was signaled at Tybee, and on her arrival opposite Broad-street a salute of 33 guns was fired by the Chatham Artillery, and salutes were also given by all the New-York steamers in port. There was a general display of colors from the other vessels. On arriving at the wharf, the Blues were received by their brother soldiers of the corps, who did not participate in the excursion, and escorted by them up the bluff, when they were received by a battalion, consisting of the Chatham Artillery, the Savannah Volunteer Guard, the Oglethorpe Light Infantry, and the Irish Jasper Greens. The line of march was then formed, and the Blues, with their escort, proceeded through the principal streets amid the cheers of the spectators and were dismissed. In the evening they dined with their military friends, at the Masonic Hall.
