abstract: It is strange and almost ominous to watch how one upon another the revered old things of England are passing away. Some short time since the old Beadle, at the Burlington Arcade, went the way of all beadlehood.
lead_paragraph: It is strange and almost ominous to watch how one upon another the revered old things of England are passing away. Some short time since the old Beadle, at the Burlington Arcade, went the way of all beadlehood. Part of Temple-bar, every cluster of moss upon whose aged column was revered as a part of the British Constitution, has lately given way. Sir ROBERT INGLIS and Col. SIBTHORP, are dead. SPOONER and NEWDEGATE -- of whom in kind old days gone by, the classic Sergeant MURPHY, (gone too by the last accounts to another land,) was wont to say there were three degrees of comparison -- SPOON, SPOONER, NEWDEGATE -- though still in the House, seem to be ever silent, or probably asleep, and TOM SAYERS has been whipped. Though we love rot the old things of England, it woke, we know not why, a strange sadness, to have to record their ruin. It seemed as if in sorrow for the departure of England's glory, and the surrender of that contempt for the Frenchman, which has been the earliest and strongest passion of the English heart, that these household gods had passed away. But amid this universal decay, one good old thing reared itself erect, defying every touch of time and innovation. That good old thing was the privilege of the House of Commons.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 17th inst., Mr. GLADSTONE made a statement of the financial position of the country, and the mode by which he proposed to provide for the expenses of the Chinese war. The total cost is at present estimated at £54,000,000, of which £21,000,000 are already provided, leaving a balance of £33,000,000. Presuming that under the action of the Lords, the House would continue the paper duty, this and other sums would reduce the amount to be provided to £2,336,000. To meet this he proposed to make an immediate addition to the duty on ardent spirits to the extent of 1s. 11d. per gallon, and a corresponding alteration in the tariff on wines, which was fixed to come into operation in January next. These measures would enable the Government to meet all demands. Resolutions sanctioning the proposed increase in the spirit duties were forthwith moved and agreed to.

abstract: -- A most mysterious murder has lately occupied public attention in England. A factory inspector, living near Frome in Somersetshire, one morning missed his youngest child, a boy of about four years of age, from the cot in the nurse's room, where he usually slept, and after a tedious search, found his body thrust down the vault of an outhouse, with the throat cut from ear to ear, and a large stab in the region of the heart, evidently inflicted after death. The mystery enveloping the whole affair baffles even the famous detectives of London. This may better be appreciated when it is known that in one of the bedrooms slept the nursemaid, and in the same room the deceased in a little cot, and in another part of the room another child in a second cot. At five o'clock the next morning the nurse awoke, and missed the deceased. The impression of the child's body still remained on the bed and pillow, but the under blanket was gone, and the coverlid carefully folded down. The father and mother were applied to by the nurse, to know if they had removed the child into their bed, but they had seen nothing of it since the previous night. Further search was made, and the drawing-room door, window, and shutter -- all of which had been fastened on the inside the previous night -- were found a little opened. After a time the body of the poor child was discovered in his night-clothes, as above stated. Every inmate of the house was searched, but not a spot of blood, or the slightest clue tending to criminate any one in the commission of the crime, could be found. How an individual could have taken the child from his cot, placed the bedclothes tidily, carried him through the drawing-room, across the lawn, through a shrubbery and stable-yard, where a watch-dog was loose roaming about, thence into the water-closet, deprived the child of life, and decamped without leaving behind them the smallest clue to their guilt, or disturbing the inmates, or awakening the child, or coming into collision with the dog -- is a mystery which time alone can unravel. A reward has been offered by the Government and a free pardon to any accessory, not being the actual murderer, who may give such information as may lead to the detection of the murderer.

abstract: These Clubs played an exciting match on Monday, at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, which ended in favor of the famed Atlantics. It might be supposed that in playing this match they were getting themselves in practice for their great contest with the Excelsiors, on the 2d proximo; but if the Mutuals had been fully represented by their regular pitchers, Burns and Powell, it might have been a tougher task for them to have come out evenly, instead of taking away the ball as easily as they have done. As a whole, the Mutuals have not lost any credit by losing this game, while leaving on the score-book so good a fifteen, against such fielding as the Atlantics. The batting of the Atlantics was of the usual heavy kind, and was well met by the out-fielders, no home runs being made; but the in-fielding, and misses of different catchers behind, (changed as usual, was) rather muffy. The pitching was also lacking in effectiveness, Beard not filling that post as well as that of catcher. Taking these important shortcomings, and the changes in positions of the fielders, into consideration, it is a wonder they came out so well. Gavagan put two men out on a fine catch from the bat and throw to a base, and Taylor at right field deserved all praise; a carriage prevented his making a clear home run. The Atlantics' batting was generally first-rate, but P. O'Brien was not as successful as usual in the field. Where is it possible to find perfection at all times? Although all fielded finely, Smith, Pierce and M. O'Brien seemed to excel most. A collation was given to the Atlantics by the Mutuals, at which much interchange of good-feeling took place, and the ball was presented by Mr. Wildey, with some appropriate remarks, to Mr. Tassey, President of the Atlantics, who made most friendly response, which was received by both parties with cheers. The Press was not forgotten amid the hilarity; and the Atlantics departed with another trophy to add to the many well-earned laurels they have won.

abstract: The wretched young King of Naples really seems to be working hard to save his throne. Thanks to the tremendous discipline which the success of GARIBALDI and the undisguised scorn of all Europe have administered to him; thanks, too, probably, to the counsels and the influence of his young and accomplished wife, a high-spirited Princess of Bavaria, who has evidently no wish to be the MARIE ANTOINETTE of Neapolitan history, FRANCIS II. is plainly bent on persuading his people, if possible, that they may trust his word, and that he really means to make them the arbiters of their own destiny. The steps which he has already taken are virtually irrevocable. By adjourning the summoning of the Neapolitan Parliament till September, the King has given time to the Liberal sentiment of Naples to look about itself, to take form and shape, to organize a party, and settle upon a policy. By September, Sicily will in all human probability have severed itself from the dominions of his crown, and have put itself under the protection of Sardinia. GARIBALDI will then have ceased to be a present power in behalf of the annexationists of the mainland, and a present peril to the Bourbon dynasty. If Neapolitan liberalism then decides on a violent political convulsion under his auspices, the ex-Dictator will have to begin again from the beginning, and land once more like CAESAR in a boat with his fortunes. It will then be a fair question for the Liberals of Naples whether they will accept the constitution of FRANCIS II., reduced as he now is to the same practical impotence for ill which has made a constitutional Queen of ISABELLA of Spain; or risk a general war in Europe by commencing at Naples a revolution which must inevitably spread to the Romagna and Venetia, or frankly vote the Bourbon dynasty from the throne and transfer their country bodily and peacefully to the crown of VICTOR EMANUEL. The probabilities with the balance of advantage are, we think with the third of these courses. Apathetic as the Neapolitan public has thus far shown itself at this great crisis of its fate, and hopelessly degraded as is the personal reputation for honor and good faith of the family to which FRANCIS II. belongs, it might yet be desirable for Naples to attempt a constitutional career of separate independence, were the condition of the rest of Italy satisfactory, or were her own resources equal to the emergencies which await every Italian State in the future. But while LAMORICIERE and ST. PATRICK keep watch over the Romans, and FRANCIS JOSEPH presses his bayonets to the heart of Venetia, no State of Italy can count on preserving her autonomy against the sweeping tide of Italian national war which must sooner or later break from its bounds, unless she is strong enough to sway that tide and to lead it. The loss of Sicily has made Naples too weak to dream of such a position, were she even as thoroughly united within her own borders and as well trained to political influence as Piedmont. When the great struggle comes, Naples must follow in the wake, not march by the side of Sardinia. Seeing this, the wisest friends of Neapolitan and Italian liberty must hope and believe that the coming Parliament of Naples will settle the problem before them by a quiet legislative annexation to that stronger State which has become in the Providential movement of history the head and heart at once of the Italian Peninsula.
